question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Movie: mystery, satire, crime, scientific, family
2. Music: ambient, d&b, hip-hop, rock, techno
3. Pet: rabbit, fish, hedgehog, lizard, rat
4. Sport: rugby, weightlifting, rowing, cricket, climbing
5. Job: security-guard, software-developer, dressmaker, engineer, fisherman

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who plays climbing and the person who likes rock music are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
2. the person who has fish as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who plays rugby
3. the person who likes hip-hop music is at the same position as or to the left of the person who has lizard as a pet
4. the person who plays rowing is a different person than the person who has rat as a pet or the person who likes satire movies is a different person than the person who plays rowing or both
5. the person who likes d&b music is a different person than the person who works as a engineer or the person who works as a engineer is a different person than the person who has rat as a pet or both
6. the person who likes crime movies is somewhere between the person who likes satire movies and the person who has rat as a pet (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
7. the person who works as a dressmaker and the person who likes crime movies are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
8. the person who plays weightlifting and the person who likes crime movies are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
9. the person who plays cricket is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes scientific movies
10. the person who plays rowing and the person who likes d&b music are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
11. the person who has rabbit as a pet is the same person as the person who likes techno music or the person who works as a engineer is the same person as the person who has rabbit as a pet, but not both
12. the person who plays rugby is the same person as the person who works as a security-guard or the person who works as a security-guard is the same person as the person who has fish as a pet or both
13. the person who plays cricket is a different person than the person who likes crime movies or the person who likes crime movies is a different person than the person who likes ambient music or both
14. the person who likes ambient music is at the same position as or to the left of the person who works as a security-guard
15. the person who likes mystery movies is a different person than at least one of the person who works as a software-developer or the person who has lizard as a pet
16. the person who has fish as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes mystery movies
17. the person who likes scientific movies is at the same position as or to the left of the person who works as a software-developer
18. the person who likes techno music is a different person than at least one of the person who has rat as a pet or the person who works as a dressmaker
19. the person who has fish as a pet and the person who likes rock music are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
20. the person who works as a software-developer is at the same position as or to the left of the person who works as a software-developer
21. the person who likes satire movies is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes ambient music
22. the person who works as a security-guard is at the same position as or to the left of the person who works as a software-developer
23. the person who likes ambient music is a different person than the person who likes family movies or the person who likes family movies is a different person than the person who has fish as a pet or both
24. the person who has lizard as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who has rat as a pet
25. the person who has rabbit as a pet is a different person than the person who likes ambient music or the person who works as a dressmaker is a different person than the person who has rabbit as a pet or both
26. the person who likes techno music and the person who likes mystery movies are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
27. the person who likes scientific movies is a different person than at least one of the person who plays cricket or the person who has rabbit as a pet
28. the person who works as a security-guard is at the same position as or to the left of the person who plays climbing
29. the person who likes d&b music and the person who has fish as a pet are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
30. the person who plays climbing is the same person as the person who likes d&b music or the person who likes d&b music is the same person as the person who works as a fisherman or both
31. the person who plays rowing is somewhere between the person who works as a engineer and the person who has hedgehog as a pet (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
32. the person who plays climbing is a different person than at least one of the person who likes crime movies or the person who has lizard as a pet
33. the person who likes ambient music and the person who has lizard as a pet are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
34. the person who works as a engineer is at the same position as or to the right of the person who plays cricket
35. the person who has fish as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who has lizard as a pet
36. the person who has fish as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who plays rugby
37. the person who likes satire movies is at the same position as or to the right of the person who has rat as a pet
38. the person who likes crime movies is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes crime movies
39. the person who likes rock music is the same person as the person who works as a software-developer or the person who likes mystery movies is the same person as the person who likes rock music or both
40. the person who has rabbit as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes techno music
41. the person who likes techno music is at the same position as or to the right of the person who works as a dressmaker
42. the person who likes satire movies and the person who likes rock music are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
43. the person who likes techno music and the person who works as a security-guard are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
44. the person who likes satire movies is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes satire movies
45. the person who works as a security-guard and the person who has fish as a pet are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
46. the person who plays climbing is the same person as exactly one of the person who likes techno music or the person who has hedgehog as a pet

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Job", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Movie", "Music", "Pet", "Sport", "Job"]
    items = {
        "Movie": ["mystery", "satire", "crime", "scientific", "family"],
        "Music": ["ambient", "d&b", "hip-hop", "rock", "techno"],
        "Pet": ["rabbit", "fish", "hedgehog", "lizard", "rat"],
        "Sport": ["rugby", "weightlifting", "rowing", "cricket", "climbing"],
        "Job": ["security-guard", "software-developer", "dressmaker", "engineer", "fisherman"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(),
            [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Helper function to get variable names
    def v(cat, it): return f"{cat}:{it}"

    # Clue 1
    problem.addConstraint(lambda climbing, rock: climbing % 2 == rock % 2,
        [v("Sport","climbing"), v("Music","rock")])

    # Clue 2
    problem.addConstraint(lambda fish, rugby: fish <= rugby,
        [v("Pet","fish"), v("Sport","rugby")])

    # Clue 3
    problem.addConstraint(lambda hiphop, lizard: hiphop <= lizard,
        [v("Music","hip-hop"), v("Pet","lizard")])

    # Clue 4
    def clue4(rowing, rat, satire):
        return rowing != rat or satire != rowing
    problem.addConstraint(clue4,
        [v("Sport","rowing"), v("Pet","rat"), v("Movie","satire")])

    # Clue 5
    def clue5(dnb, engineer, rat):
        return dnb != engineer or engineer != rat
    problem.addConstraint(clue5,
        [v("Music","d&b"), v("Job","engineer"), v("Pet","rat")])

    # Clue 6
    def clue6(satire, crime, rat):
        # crime between satire and rat means crime pos is strictly between satire and rat
        return (satire < crime < rat) or (rat < crime < satire)
    problem.addConstraint(clue6,
        [v("Movie","satire"), v("Movie","crime"), v("Pet","rat")])

    # Clue 7
    problem.addConstraint(lambda dressmaker, crime: dressmaker % 2 == crime % 2,
        [v("Job","dressmaker"), v("Movie","crime")])

    # Clue 8
    problem.addConstraint(lambda weightlifting, crime: (weightlifting % 2) != (crime % 2),
        [v("Sport","weightlifting"), v("Movie","crime")])

    # Clue 9
    problem.addConstraint(lambda cricket, scientific: cricket >= scientific,
        [v("Sport","cricket"), v("Movie","scientific")])

    # Clue 10
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rowing, dnb: (rowing % 2) != (dnb % 2),
        [v("Sport","rowing"), v("Music","d&b")])

    # Clue 11
    # XOR: (rabbit == techno) != (engineer == rabbit)
    def clue11(rabbit, techno, engineer):
        return (rabbit == techno) != (engineer == rabbit)
    problem.addConstraint(clue11,
        [v("Pet","rabbit"), v("Music","techno"), v("Job","engineer")])

    # Clue 12
    # (rugby == security-guard) or (security-guard == fish) or both
    def clue12(rugby, security_guard, fish):
        return (rugby == security_guard) or (security_guard == fish)
    problem.addConstraint(clue12,
        [v("Sport","rugby"), v("Job","security-guard"), v("Pet","fish")])

    # Clue 13
    # cricket != crime or crime != ambient or both
    def clue13(cricket, crime, ambient):
        return (cricket != crime) or (crime != ambient)
    problem.addConstraint(clue13,
        [v("Sport","cricket"), v("Movie","crime"), v("Music","ambient")])

    # Clue 14
    problem.addConstraint(lambda ambient, security_guard: ambient <= security_guard,
        [v("Music","ambient"), v("Job","security-guard")])

    # Clue 15
    # mystery != software-developer or mystery != lizard or both
    def clue15(mystery, software_dev, lizard):
        return (mystery != software_dev) or (mystery != lizard)
    problem.addConstraint(clue15,
        [v("Movie","mystery"), v("Job","software-developer"), v("Pet","lizard")])

    # Clue 16
    problem.addConstraint(lambda fish, mystery: fish <= mystery,
        [v("Pet","fish"), v("Movie","mystery")])

    # Clue 17
    problem.addConstraint(lambda scientific, software_dev: scientific <= software_dev,
        [v("Movie","scientific"), v("Job","software-developer")])

    # Clue 18
    # techno != rat or dressmaker != techno or both
    def clue18(techno, rat, dressmaker):
        return (techno != rat) or (dressmaker != techno)
    problem.addConstraint(clue18,
        [v("Music","techno"), v("Pet","rat"), v("Job","dressmaker")])

    # Clue 19
    problem.addConstraint(lambda fish, rock: (fish % 2) != (rock % 2),
        [v("Pet","fish"), v("Music","rock")])

    # Clue 20
    # The person who works as a software-developer is at the same position as or to the left of the person who works as a software-developer
    # This is always true, so no constraint needed.

    # Clue 21
    problem.addConstraint(lambda satire, ambient: satire <= ambient,
        [v("Movie","satire"), v("Music","ambient")])

    # Clue 22
    problem.addConstraint(lambda security_guard, software_dev: security_guard <= software_dev,
        [v("Job","security-guard"), v("Job","software-developer")])

    # Clue 23
    # ambient != family or family != fish or both
    def clue23(ambient, family, fish):
        return (ambient != family) or (family != fish)
    problem.addConstraint(clue23,
        [v("Music","ambient"), v("Movie","family"), v("Pet","fish")])

    # Clue 24
    problem.addConstraint(lambda lizard, rat: lizard >= rat,
        [v("Pet","lizard"), v("Pet","rat")])

    # Clue 25
    # rabbit != ambient or dressmaker != rabbit or both
    def clue25(rabbit, ambient, dressmaker):
        return (rabbit != ambient) or (dressmaker != rabbit)
    problem.addConstraint(clue25,
        [v("Pet","rabbit"), v("Music","ambient"), v("Job","dressmaker")])

    # Clue 26
    problem.addConstraint(lambda techno, mystery: (techno % 2) != (mystery % 2),
        [v("Music","techno"), v("Movie","mystery")])

    # Clue 27
    # scientific != cricket or scientific != rabbit or both
    def clue27(scientific, cricket, rabbit):
        return (scientific != cricket) or (scientific != rabbit)
    problem.addConstraint(clue27,
        [v("Movie","scientific"), v("Sport","cricket"), v("Pet","rabbit")])

    # Clue 28
    problem.addConstraint(lambda security_guard, climbing: security_guard <= climbing,
        [v("Job","security-guard"), v("Sport","climbing")])

    # Clue 29
    problem.addConstraint(lambda dnb, fish: (dnb % 2) == (fish % 2),
        [v("Music","d&b"), v("Pet","fish")])

    # Clue 30
    # climbing == d&b or d&b == fisherman or both
    def clue30(climbing, dnb, fisherman):
        return (climbing == dnb) or (dnb == fisherman)
    problem.addConstraint(clue30,
        [v("Sport","climbing"), v("Music","d&b"), v("Job","fisherman")])

    # Clue 31
    # rowing between engineer and hedgehog
    def clue31(engineer, rowing, hedgehog):
        return (engineer < rowing < hedgehog) or (hedgehog < rowing < engineer)
    problem.addConstraint(clue31,
        [v("Job","engineer"), v("Sport","rowing"), v("Pet","hedgehog")])

    # Clue 32
    # climbing != crime or climbing != lizard or both
    def clue32(climbing, crime, lizard):
        return (climbing != crime) or (climbing != lizard)
    problem.addConstraint(clue32,
        [v("Sport","climbing"), v("Movie","crime"), v("Pet","lizard")])

    # Clue 33
    problem.addConstraint(lambda ambient, lizard: (ambient % 2) == (lizard % 2),
        [v("Music","ambient"), v("Pet","lizard")])

    # Clue 34
    problem.addConstraint(lambda engineer, cricket: engineer >= cricket,
        [v("Job","engineer"), v("Sport","cricket")])

    # Clue 35
    problem.addConstraint(lambda fish, lizard: fish <= lizard,
        [v("Pet","fish"), v("Pet","lizard")])

    # Clue 36
    problem.addConstraint(lambda fish, rugby: fish >= rugby,
        [v("Pet","fish"), v("Sport","rugby")])

    # Clue 37
    problem.addConstraint(lambda satire, rat: satire >= rat,
        [v("Movie","satire"), v("Pet","rat")])

    # Clue 38
    # The person who likes crime movies is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes crime movies
    # Trivially true, no constraint needed.

    # Clue 39
    # rock == software-developer or mystery == rock or both
    def clue39(rock, software_dev, mystery):
        return (rock == software_dev) or (mystery == rock)
    problem.addConstraint(clue39,
        [v("Music","rock"), v("Job","software-developer"), v("Movie","mystery")])

    # Clue 40
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rabbit, techno: rabbit >= techno,
        [v("Pet","rabbit"), v("Music","techno")])

    # Clue 41
    problem.addConstraint(lambda techno, dressmaker: techno >= dressmaker,
        [v("Music","techno"), v("Job","dressmaker")])

    # Clue 42
    problem.addConstraint(lambda satire, rock: (satire % 2) != (rock % 2),
        [v("Movie","satire"), v("Music","rock")])

    # Clue 43
    problem.addConstraint(lambda techno, security_guard: (techno % 2) != (security_guard % 2),
        [v("Music","techno"), v("Job","security-guard")])

    # Clue 44
    # satire >= satire always true, no constraint needed.

    # Clue 45
    problem.addConstraint(lambda security_guard, fish: (security_guard % 2) == (fish % 2),
        [v("Job","security-guard"), v("Pet","fish")])

    # Clue 46
    # climbing is the same person as exactly one of techno or hedgehog
    def clue46(climbing, techno, hedgehog):
        return (climbing == techno) != (climbing == hedgehog)
    problem.addConstraint(clue46,
        [v("Sport","climbing"), v("Music","techno"), v("Pet","hedgehog")])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # If multiple solutions, pick the first
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Transport: trike, boat, motorbike, bike, snowmobile
2. Music: funk, trance, country, ambient, salsa
3. Nationality: french, russian, chinese, japanese, british

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the french person is immediately to the left of the person who likes ambient music
2. the japanese person is to the right of the person who uses boat for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
3. the russian person is to the right of the british person (not necessarily immediately)
4. the person who uses bike for transportation is the same person as the person who likes trance music
5. the person who uses snowmobile for transportation is immediately to the right of the person who likes salsa music
6. the person who likes country music is adjacent to the chinese person (either immediately left or right)
7. the person who uses bike for transportation is the same person as the french person
8. the person who uses boat for transportation is immediately to the right of the person who likes trance music
9. the person who likes trance music is immediately to the right of the person who uses snowmobile for transportation
10. the chinese person is adjacent to the person who uses motorbike for transportation (either immediately left or right)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Music", "Nationality").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Transport", "Music", "Nationality"]
    items = {
        "Transport": ["trike", "boat", "motorbike", "bike", "snowmobile"],
        "Music": ["funk", "trance", "country", "ambient", "salsa"],
        "Nationality": ["french", "russian", "chinese", "japanese", "british"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must occupy different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: the french person is immediately to the left of the person who likes ambient music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda french, ambient: french == ambient - 1,
        ["Nationality:french", "Music:ambient"]
    )

    # Clue 2: the japanese person is to the right of the person who uses boat for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda japanese, boat: japanese > boat,
        ["Nationality:japanese", "Transport:boat"]
    )

    # Clue 3: the russian person is to the right of the british person (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda russian, british: russian > british,
        ["Nationality:russian", "Nationality:british"]
    )

    # Clue 4: the person who uses bike for transportation is the same person as the person who likes trance music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bike, trance: bike == trance,
        ["Transport:bike", "Music:trance"]
    )

    # Clue 5: the person who uses snowmobile for transportation is immediately to the right of the person who likes salsa music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda snowmobile, salsa: snowmobile == salsa + 1,
        ["Transport:snowmobile", "Music:salsa"]
    )

    # Clue 6: the person who likes country music is adjacent to the chinese person (either immediately left or right)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda country, chinese: abs(country - chinese) == 1,
        ["Music:country", "Nationality:chinese"]
    )

    # Clue 7: the person who uses bike for transportation is the same person as the french person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bike, french: bike == french,
        ["Transport:bike", "Nationality:french"]
    )

    # Clue 8: the person who uses boat for transportation is immediately to the right of the person who likes trance music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda boat, trance: boat == trance + 1,
        ["Transport:boat", "Music:trance"]
    )

    # Clue 9: the person who likes trance music is immediately to the right of the person who uses snowmobile for transportation
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda trance, snowmobile: trance == snowmobile + 1,
        ["Music:trance", "Transport:snowmobile"]
    )

    # Clue 10: the chinese person is adjacent to the person who uses motorbike for transportation (either immediately left or right)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda chinese, motorbike: abs(chinese - motorbike) == 1,
        ["Nationality:chinese", "Transport:motorbike"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[var]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 3 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 3 unique items:

1. Transport: quad-bike, ship, scooter
2. Beverage: milk, juice, 7up
3. Nationality: japanese, thai, indonesian

Each category has exactly 3 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes juice is immediately to the right of the thai person
2. the japanese person is directly between the person who uses ship for transportation and the person who likes milk
3. 0 is at position 3

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Nationality").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 3

    categories = ["Transport", "Beverage", "Nationality"]
    items = {
        "Transport": ["quad-bike", "ship", "scooter"],
        "Beverage": ["milk", "juice", "7up"],
        "Nationality": ["japanese", "thai", "indonesian"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain being positions 0,1,2
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category must occupy different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_vars = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_vars)

    # Clue 1: the person who likes juice is immediately to the right of the thai person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda juice, thai: juice == thai + 1,
        ["Beverage:juice", "Nationality:thai"]
    )

    # Clue 2: the japanese person is directly between the person who uses ship for transportation and the person who likes milk
    # This means japanese is position between ship and milk,
    # so either japanese == ship + 1 and japanese == milk - 1 OR japanese == ship - 1 and japanese == milk + 1
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda japanese, ship, milk: (japanese == ship + 1 and japanese == milk - 1) or (japanese == ship - 1 and japanese == milk + 1),
        ["Nationality:japanese", "Transport:ship", "Beverage:milk"]
    )

    # Clue 3: "0 is at position 3"
    # The puzzle states 3 people, positions 1 to 3, 0-based indexing means position 2 is position 3
    # The clue "0 is at position 3" is ambiguous in the prompt, but presumably means "item 0" is at position 3.
    # Since 0 is not an item, this clue is unclear. Possibly a typo or means the person at position 3 is at index 2.
    # We interpret clue 3 as "the person at position 3 is position index 2", which is always true.
    # So this clue can be ignored or treated as no constraint.
    # Since no item named '0' exists, we skip this clue.

    # Solve
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # If multiple solutions, pick the first
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Prepare list of length num_positions
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions

            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Music: dubstep, ambient, salsa, reggae
2. Transport: bus, subway, train, quad-bike
3. Pet: bird, turtle, chinchilla, frog
4. Movie: disaster, superhero, documentary, musical
5. Job: engineer, dressmaker, software-developer, designer

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who has chinchilla as a pet is a different person than the person who uses quad-bike for transportation
2. the person who works as a software-developer is immediately to the left of the person who likes documentary movies
3. the person who has frog as a pet is the same person as the person who likes salsa music or the person who likes salsa music is the same person as the person who uses quad-bike for transportation, but not both
4. the person who has chinchilla as a pet is immediately to the left of the person who likes documentary movies
5. the person who likes dubstep music is immediately to the left of the person who likes disaster movies
6. the person who has bird as a pet is immediately to the left of the person who likes ambient music
7. the person who likes disaster movies is to the right of the person who likes superhero movies (not necessarily immediately)
8. the person who likes disaster movies is immediately to the right of the person who has frog as a pet
9. the person who works as a designer is adjacent to the person who uses quad-bike for transportation (either immediately left or right)
10. the person who uses quad-bike for transportation is at the same position as or to the left of the person who has chinchilla as a pet
11. the person who works as a designer is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses bus for transportation
12. the person who works as a engineer is to the right of the person who uses subway for transportation (not necessarily immediately)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Job", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Music", "Transport", "Pet", "Movie", "Job"]
    items = {
        "Music": ["dubstep", "ambient", "salsa", "reggae"],
        "Transport": ["bus", "subway", "train", "quad-bike"],
        "Pet": ["bird", "turtle", "chinchilla", "frog"],
        "Movie": ["disaster", "superhero", "documentary", "musical"],
        "Job": ["engineer", "dressmaker", "software-developer", "designer"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All different constraint within each category
    for category in categories:
        vars_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_cat)

    # Clue 1: chinchilla pet != quad-bike transport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda chinchilla, quad_bike: chinchilla != quad_bike,
        ["Pet:chinchilla", "Transport:quad-bike"]
    )

    # Clue 2: software-developer immediately left of documentary movie
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda software_dev, documentary: software_dev == documentary - 1,
        ["Job:software-developer", "Movie:documentary"]
    )

    # Clue 3: frog pet is xor of salsa music and quad-bike transport
    # (frog == salsa) xor (salsa == quad-bike)
    # We model as: (frog == salsa and salsa != quad-bike) or (frog != salsa and salsa == quad-bike)
    def xor_constraint(frog, salsa, quad_bike):
        return (frog == salsa and salsa != quad_bike) or (frog != salsa and salsa == quad_bike)
    problem.addConstraint(
        xor_constraint,
        ["Pet:frog", "Music:salsa", "Transport:quad-bike"]
    )

    # Clue 4: chinchilla pet immediately left of documentary movie
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda chinchilla, documentary: chinchilla == documentary - 1,
        ["Pet:chinchilla", "Movie:documentary"]
    )

    # Clue 5: dubstep music immediately left of disaster movie
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dubstep, disaster: dubstep == disaster - 1,
        ["Music:dubstep", "Movie:disaster"]
    )

    # Clue 6: bird pet immediately left of ambient music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bird, ambient: bird == ambient - 1,
        ["Pet:bird", "Music:ambient"]
    )

    # Clue 7: disaster movie to the right of superhero movie (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda disaster, superhero: disaster > superhero,
        ["Movie:disaster", "Movie:superhero"]
    )

    # Clue 8: disaster movie immediately right of frog pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda disaster, frog: disaster == frog + 1,
        ["Movie:disaster", "Pet:frog"]
    )

    # Clue 9: designer job adjacent to quad-bike transport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda designer, quad_bike: abs(designer - quad_bike) == 1,
        ["Job:designer", "Transport:quad-bike"]
    )

    # Clue 10: quad-bike transport same position as or left of chinchilla pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda quad_bike, chinchilla: quad_bike <= chinchilla,
        ["Transport:quad-bike", "Pet:chinchilla"]
    )

    # Clue 11: designer job same position as or right of bus transport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda designer, bus: designer >= bus,
        ["Job:designer", "Transport:bus"]
    )

    # Clue 12: engineer job to the right of subway transport (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda engineer, subway: engineer > subway,
        ["Job:engineer", "Transport:subway"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Job: lawyer, photographer, writer, manager, journalist
2. Sport: tennis, skiing, sailing, skateboarding, water-polo
3. Movie: comedy, sports, mystery, musical, spy
4. Pet: bird, dog, cat, pony, goldfish
5. Transport: car, trike, airplane, scooter, jet-ski

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who uses airplane for transportation and the person who likes sports movies are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
2. the person who uses trike for transportation is the same person as the person who plays skiing or the person who likes musical movies is the same person as the person who uses trike for transportation or both
3. the person who uses car for transportation is adjacent to the person who plays skiing (either immediately left or right)
4. the person who has dog as a pet is to the right of the person who works as a photographer (not necessarily immediately)
5. the person who has pony as a pet is to the left of the person who likes sports movies (not necessarily immediately)
6. the person who works as a journalist is at the same position as or to the right of the person who has goldfish as a pet
7. the person who has dog as a pet is adjacent to the person who plays skateboarding (either immediately left or right)
8. the person who has goldfish as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who works as a writer
9. the person who has bird as a pet is adjacent to the person who likes mystery movies (either immediately left or right)
10. the person who plays water-polo is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
11. the person who works as a manager is somewhere between the person who uses airplane for transportation and the person who uses car for transportation (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
12. the person who uses jet-ski for transportation is the same person as exactly one of the person who has cat as a pet or the person who likes mystery movies
13. the person who plays tennis is the same person as exactly one of the person who has goldfish as a pet or the person who likes spy movies
14. the person who works as a journalist is adjacent to the person who works as a photographer (either immediately left or right)
15. the person who uses scooter for transportation is the same person as at least one of the person who works as a manager or the person who plays skiing
16. the person who has cat as a pet is adjacent to the person who uses jet-ski for transportation (either immediately left or right)
17. the person who has cat as a pet is to the right of the person who has dog as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
18. the person who uses car for transportation is the same person as the person who has pony as a pet or the person who likes spy movies is the same person as the person who uses car for transportation or both
19. the person who has bird as a pet is the same person as the person who likes sports movies or the person who likes sports movies is the same person as the person who plays skiing, but not both

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Job", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Job", "Sport", "Movie", "Pet", "Transport"]
    items = {
        "Job": ["lawyer", "photographer", "writer", "manager", "journalist"],
        "Sport": ["tennis", "skiing", "sailing", "skateboarding", "water-polo"],
        "Movie": ["comedy", "sports", "mystery", "musical", "spy"],
        "Pet": ["bird", "dog", "cat", "pony", "goldfish"],
        "Transport": ["car", "trike", "airplane", "scooter", "jet-ski"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # All items in a category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_cat)

    # Clue 1: airplane and sports movie same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda airplane, sports: airplane % 2 == sports % 2,
        ["Transport:airplane", "Movie:sports"]
    )

    # Clue 2: trike is same person as skiing or musical or both
    # This means trike = skiing or trike = musical or both
    # So trike == skiing or trike == musical
    def clue2(trike, skiing, musical):
        return trike == skiing or trike == musical
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue2,
        ["Transport:trike", "Sport:skiing", "Movie:musical"]
    )

    # Clue 3: car adjacent to skiing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda car, skiing: abs(car - skiing) == 1,
        ["Transport:car", "Sport:skiing"]
    )

    # Clue 4: dog to right of photographer (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dog, photographer: dog > photographer,
        ["Pet:dog", "Job:photographer"]
    )

    # Clue 5: pony to left of sports movie (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pony, sports: pony < sports,
        ["Pet:pony", "Movie:sports"]
    )

    # Clue 6: journalist same position or right of goldfish
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda journalist, goldfish: journalist >= goldfish,
        ["Job:journalist", "Pet:goldfish"]
    )

    # Clue 7: dog adjacent to skateboarding
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dog, skateboarding: abs(dog - skateboarding) == 1,
        ["Pet:dog", "Sport:skateboarding"]
    )

    # Clue 8: goldfish same position or right of writer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda goldfish, writer: goldfish >= writer,
        ["Pet:goldfish", "Job:writer"]
    )

    # Clue 9: bird adjacent to mystery
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bird, mystery: abs(bird - mystery) == 1,
        ["Pet:bird", "Movie:mystery"]
    )

    # Clue 10: water-polo at an end position (0 or 4)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda waterpolo: waterpolo == 0 or waterpolo == 4,
        ["Sport:water-polo"]
    )

    # Clue 11: manager between airplane and car (not necessarily immediately)
    # i.e. manager position is between airplane and car positions
    # So manager > min(airplane, car) and manager < max(airplane, car)
    def clue11(manager, airplane, car):
        return (manager > min(airplane, car)) and (manager < max(airplane, car))
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue11,
        ["Job:manager", "Transport:airplane", "Transport:car"]
    )

    # Clue 12: jet-ski same person as exactly one of cat or mystery
    # Exactly one means XOR
    def clue12(jet_ski, cat, mystery):
        return (jet_ski == cat) != (jet_ski == mystery)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue12,
        ["Transport:jet-ski", "Pet:cat", "Movie:mystery"]
    )

    # Clue 13: tennis same person as exactly one of goldfish or spy
    def clue13(tennis, goldfish, spy):
        return (tennis == goldfish) != (tennis == spy)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue13,
        ["Sport:tennis", "Pet:goldfish", "Movie:spy"]
    )

    # Clue 14: journalist adjacent to photographer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda journalist, photographer: abs(journalist - photographer) == 1,
        ["Job:journalist", "Job:photographer"]
    )

    # Clue 15: scooter same person as at least one of manager or skiing
    # This means scooter == manager or scooter == skiing or both
    def clue15(scooter, manager, skiing):
        return scooter == manager or scooter == skiing
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue15,
        ["Transport:scooter", "Job:manager", "Sport:skiing"]
    )

    # Clue 16: cat adjacent to jet-ski
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cat, jet_ski: abs(cat - jet_ski) == 1,
        ["Pet:cat", "Transport:jet-ski"]
    )

    # Clue 17: cat to right of dog (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cat, dog: cat > dog,
        ["Pet:cat", "Pet:dog"]
    )

    # Clue 18: car same person as pony or spy or both
    # So car == pony or car == spy or both
    def clue18(car, pony, spy):
        return car == pony or car == spy
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue18,
        ["Transport:car", "Pet:pony", "Movie:spy"]
    )

    # Clue 19: bird same as sports or sports same as skiing, but not both
    # So (bird == sports) XOR (sports == skiing)
    def clue19(bird, sports, skiing):
        return (bird == sports) != (sports == skiing)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue19,
        ["Pet:bird", "Movie:sports", "Sport:skiing"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # Should be unique solution
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[var]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

1. the person who enjoys baking is directly between the person who works as a chef and the person who works as a photographer
2. 0 is at position 3
3. the person who works as a photographer is immediately to the right of the person who works as a journalist

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Hobby", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 3

    categories = ["Hobby", "Job"]
    items = {
        "Hobby": ["skydiving", "puzzles", "baking"],
        "Job": ["journalist", "photographer", "chef"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_items = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_items)

    # Clue 1: baking is directly between chef and photographer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda baking, chef, photographer: (baking == chef + 1 and baking == photographer - 1) or (baking == chef - 1 and baking == photographer + 1),
        ["Hobby:baking", "Job:chef", "Job:photographer"]
    )

    # Clue 2: 0 is at position 3 (position 3 means index 2)
    # This clue is ambiguous as "0" is not defined in the categories or items.
    # Assuming this means position 3 is occupied by an item named "0", but no such item exists.
    # Since no item "0" is given, we ignore this clue because it cannot be applied.
    # (If "0" is a typo or placeholder, ignoring it is the only option.)

    # Clue 3: photographer is immediately to the right of journalist
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda photographer, journalist: photographer == journalist + 1,
        ["Job:photographer", "Job:journalist"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    # There should be only one solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            position = solution[variable_name]
            result_dict[category][position] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():

    num_positions = 4
