from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint


def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Nationality", "Hobby", "Movie", "Music", "Pet"]
    items = {
        "Nationality": ["canadian", "polish", "russian", "pakistani", "german"],
        "Hobby": ["fishing", "camping", "hiking", "gardening", "reading"],
        "Movie": ["comedy", "adventure", "superhero", "scientific", "sports"],
        "Music": ["indie", "trance", "folk", "metal", "country"],
        "Pet": ["lizard", "bird", "hamster", "fish", "hedgehog"],
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Helper to get variable names
    def v(cat, item):
        return f"{cat}:{item}"

    # Clue 1
    problem.addConstraint(lambda hedgehog, gardening: hedgehog % 2 == gardening % 2,
                          [v("Pet", "hedgehog"), v("Hobby", "gardening")])

    # Clue 2
    problem.addConstraint(lambda comedy, metal: comedy >= metal,
                          [v("Movie", "comedy"), v("Music", "metal")])

    # Clue 3
    # The person who likes superhero movies is a different person than the person who likes trance music
    # or the canadian person is a different person than the person who likes superhero movies or both
    # This means not (superhero == trance and canadian == superhero)
    def clue3(superhero, trance, canadian):
        return not (superhero == trance and canadian == superhero)
    problem.addConstraint(clue3,
                          [v("Movie", "superhero"), v("Music", "trance"), v("Nationality", "canadian")])

    # Clue 4
    problem.addConstraint(lambda metal, adventure: metal % 2 == adventure % 2,
                          [v("Music", "metal"), v("Movie", "adventure")])

    # Clue 5
    problem.addConstraint(lambda hedgehog, superhero: (hedgehog % 2) != (superhero % 2),
                          [v("Pet", "hedgehog"), v("Movie", "superhero")])

    # Clue 6
    problem.addConstraint(lambda polish, comedy: polish >= comedy,
                          [v("Nationality", "polish"), v("Movie", "comedy")])

    # Clue 7
    problem.addConstraint(lambda comedy, pakistani: comedy >= pakistani,
                          [v("Movie", "comedy"), v("Nationality", "pakistani")])

    # Clue 8
    problem.addConstraint(lambda fishing, hamster: fishing >= hamster,
                          [v("Hobby", "fishing"), v("Pet", "hamster")])

    # Clue 9
    problem.addConstraint(lambda polish, fish: polish % 2 == fish % 2,
                          [v("Nationality", "polish"), v("Pet", "fish")])

    # Clue 10
    problem.addConstraint(lambda hamster, fish: hamster <= fish,
                          [v("Pet", "hamster"), v("Pet", "fish")])

    # Clue 11
    problem.addConstraint(lambda adventure, hamster: adventure >= hamster,
                          [v("Movie", "adventure"), v("Pet", "hamster")])

    # Clue 12
    problem.addConstraint(lambda fishing, scientific: fishing != scientific,
                          [v("Hobby", "fishing"), v("Movie", "scientific")])

    # Clue 13
    problem.addConstraint(lambda bird, folk: bird % 2 == folk % 2,
                          [v("Pet", "bird"), v("Music", "folk")])

    # Clue 14
    # polish != hedgehog or hedgehog != folk or both
    # means not (polish == hedgehog == folk)
    def clue14(polish, hedgehog, folk):
        return not (polish == hedgehog == folk)
    problem.addConstraint(clue14,
                          [v("Nationality", "polish"), v("Pet", "hedgehog"), v("Music", "folk")])

    # Clue 15
    problem.addConstraint(lambda polish, fishing: polish <= fishing,
                          [v("Nationality", "polish"), v("Hobby", "fishing")])

    # Clue 16
    # polish != fish or polish != comedy or both
    # not (polish == fish == comedy)
    def clue16(polish, fish, comedy):
        return not (polish == fish == comedy)
    problem.addConstraint(clue16,
                          [v("Nationality", "polish"), v("Pet", "fish"), v("Movie", "comedy")])

    # Clue 17
    # bird == exactly one of (adventure, polish)
    # means bird == adventure XOR bird == polish
    def clue17(bird, adventure, polish):
        return (bird == adventure) != (bird == polish)
    problem.addConstraint(clue17,
                          [v("Pet", "bird"), v("Movie", "adventure"), v("Nationality", "polish")])

    # Clue 18
    problem.addConstraint(lambda reading, hedgehog: (reading % 2) != (hedgehog % 2),
                          [v("Hobby", "reading"), v("Pet", "hedgehog")])

    # Clue 19
    problem.addConstraint(lambda pakistani, camping: pakistani != camping,
                          [v("Nationality", "pakistani"), v("Hobby", "camping")])

    # Clue 20
    # fishing == exactly one of (trance, russian)
    def clue20(fishing, trance, russian):
        return (fishing == trance) != (fishing == russian)
    problem.addConstraint(clue20,
                          [v("Hobby", "fishing"), v("Music", "trance"), v("Nationality", "russian")])

    # Clue 21
    problem.addConstraint(lambda pakistani, metal: pakistani <= metal,
                          [v("Nationality", "pakistani"), v("Music", "metal")])

    # Clue 22
    problem.addConstraint(lambda russian, reading: russian >= reading,
                          [v("Nationality", "russian"), v("Hobby", "reading")])

    # Clue 23
    # pakistani != folk or pakistani != lizard or both
    def clue23(pakistani, folk, lizard):
        return not (pakistani == folk == lizard)
    problem.addConstraint(clue23,
                          [v("Nationality", "pakistani"), v("Music", "folk"), v("Pet", "lizard")])

    # Clue 24
    problem.addConstraint(lambda polish, comedy: (polish % 2) != (comedy % 2),
                          [v("Nationality", "polish"), v("Movie", "comedy")])

    # Clue 25
    problem.addConstraint(lambda country, lizard: country <= lizard,
                          [v("Music", "country"), v("Pet", "lizard")])

    # Clue 26
    # bird != trance or bird != camping or both
    def clue26(bird, trance, camping):
        return not (bird == trance == camping)
    problem.addConstraint(clue26,
                          [v("Pet", "bird"), v("Music", "trance"), v("Hobby", "camping")])

    # Clue 27
    # adventure is between scientific and sports (not necessarily immediately)
    def clue27(adventure, scientific, sports):
        return (scientific < adventure < sports) or (sports < adventure < scientific)
    problem.addConstraint(clue27,
                          [v("Movie", "adventure"), v("Movie", "scientific"), v("Movie", "sports")])

    # Clue 28
    problem.addConstraint(lambda scientific, camping: scientific % 2 == camping % 2,
                          [v("Movie", "scientific"), v("Hobby", "camping")])

    # Clue 29
    problem.addConstraint(lambda fish, superhero: fish != superhero,
                          [v("Pet", "fish"), v("Movie", "superhero")])

    # Clue 30
    # russian is between hedgehog and fish (not necessarily immediately)
    def clue30(russian, hedgehog, fish):
        return (hedgehog < russian < fish) or (fish < russian < hedgehog)
    problem.addConstraint(clue30,
                          [v("Nationality", "russian"), v("Pet", "hedgehog"), v("Pet", "fish")])

    # Clue 31
    problem.addConstraint(lambda pakistani, adventure: pakistani <= adventure,
                          [v("Nationality", "pakistani"), v("Movie", "adventure")])

    # Clue 32
    problem.addConstraint(lambda hamster, adventure: hamster <= adventure,
                          [v("Pet", "hamster"), v("Movie", "adventure")])

    # Clue 33
    problem.addConstraint(lambda country, fishing: country >= fishing,
                          [v("Music", "country"), v("Hobby", "fishing")])

    # Clue 34
    problem.addConstraint(lambda country, scientific: country != scientific,
                          [v("Music", "country"), v("Movie", "scientific")])

    # Clue 35
    problem.addConstraint(lambda country, canadian: country <= canadian,
                          [v("Music", "country"), v("Nationality", "canadian")])

    # Clue 36
    problem.addConstraint(lambda fish, bird: fish <= bird,
                          [v("Pet", "fish"), v("Pet", "bird")])

    # Clue 37
    # fish == at least one of comedy or polish
    # means fish == comedy or fish == polish or both
    def clue37(fish, comedy, polish):
        return fish == comedy or fish == polish
    problem.addConstraint(clue37,
                          [v("Pet", "fish"), v("Movie", "comedy"), v("Nationality", "polish")])

    # Clue 38
    problem.addConstraint(lambda folk, hedgehog: folk <= hedgehog,
                          [v("Music", "folk"), v("Pet", "hedgehog")])

    # Clue 39
    problem.addConstraint(lambda fish, sports: fish <= sports,
                          [v("Pet", "fish"), v("Movie", "sports")])

    # Clue 40
    problem.addConstraint(lambda fishing, hiking: fishing >= hiking,
                          [v("Hobby", "fishing"), v("Hobby", "hiking")])

    # Clue 41
    problem.addConstraint(lambda adventure, russian: adventure % 2 == russian % 2,
                          [v("Movie", "adventure"), v("Nationality", "russian")])

    # Clue 42
    problem.addConstraint(lambda fishing, lizard: fishing != lizard,
                          [v("Hobby", "fishing"), v("Pet", "lizard")])

    # Clue 43
    problem.addConstraint(lambda lizard, german: lizard % 2 == german % 2,
                          [v("Pet", "lizard"), v("Nationality", "german")])

    # Clue 44
    # camping == exactly one of sports or trance
    def clue44(camping, sports, trance):
        return (camping == sports) != (camping == trance)
    problem.addConstraint(clue44,
                          [v("Hobby", "camping"), v("Movie", "sports"), v("Music", "trance")])

    # Clue 45
    # metal != at least one of reading or german
    # means not (metal == reading == german)
    def clue45(metal, reading, german):
        return not (metal == reading == german)
    problem.addConstraint(clue45,
                          [v("Music", "metal"), v("Hobby", "reading"), v("Nationality", "german")])

    # Clue 46
    problem.addConstraint(lambda polish, indie: polish <= indie,
                          [v("Nationality", "polish"), v("Music", "indie")])

    # Clue 47
    problem.addConstraint(lambda scientific, polish: scientific <= polish,
                          [v("Movie", "scientific"), v("Nationality", "polish")])

    # Clue 48
    problem.addConstraint(lambda gardening, polish: gardening >= polish,
                          [v("Hobby", "gardening"), v("Nationality", "polish")])

    # Clue 49
    # sports != at least one of camping or country
    # means not (sports == camping == country)
    def clue49(sports, camping, country):
        return not (sports == camping == country)
    problem.addConstraint(clue49,
                          [v("Movie", "sports"), v("Hobby", "camping"), v("Music", "country")])

    # Clue 50
    problem.addConstraint(lambda fishing, german: fishing <= german,
                          [v("Hobby", "fishing"), v("Nationality", "german")])

    # Clue 51
    # polish != reading or reading != country or both
    # not (polish == reading == country)
    def clue51(polish, reading, country):
        return not (polish == reading == country)
    problem.addConstraint(clue51,
                          [v("Nationality", "polish"), v("Hobby", "reading"), v("Music", "country")])

    # Clue 52
    problem.addConstraint(lambda lizard, polish: lizard != polish,
                          [v("Pet", "lizard"), v("Nationality", "polish")])

    # Clue 53
    problem.addConstraint(lambda sports, trance: sports >= trance,
                          [v("Movie", "sports"), v("Music", "trance")])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # Should not happen, but if it does, pick first
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    return format_solution_as_dict(solution, categories, items, num_positions)


def format_solution_as_dict(solution: dict, categories: list, items: dict, num_positions: int) -> dict:
    result_dict = {}

    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[var_name]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    return result_dict


print(solve_einstein_puzzle())

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Food: pomegranate, grapefruit, broccoli, radish
2. Sport: soccer, swimming, biathlon, handball
3. Hobby: traveling, card-games, woodworking, writing
4. Job: police-officer, fisherman, engineer, security-guard

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who works as a engineer is to the left of the person who works as a fisherman (not necessarily immediately)
2. the person who works as a engineer is to the right of the person who enjoys writing (not necessarily immediately)
3. the person who enjoys traveling is to the right of the person who works as a engineer (not necessarily immediately)
4. the person who enjoys card-games is at the same position as or to the left of the person who plays swimming
5. the person who plays biathlon is at the same position as or to the left of the person who enjoys writing
6. the person who enjoys woodworking is a different person than the person who works as a security-guard
7. the person who likes radish is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
8. the person who likes broccoli is a different person than the person who works as a engineer
9. the person who likes pomegranate is the same person as the person who works as a fisherman or the person who enjoys writing is the same person as the person who likes pomegranate or both
10. the person who enjoys traveling is adjacent to the person who works as a security-guard (either immediately left or right)
11. the person who likes pomegranate is the same person as the person who works as a fisherman or the person who plays soccer is the same person as the person who likes pomegranate, but not both
12. the person who enjoys card-games and the person who likes broccoli are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Hobby").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Food", "Sport", "Hobby", "Job"]
    items = {
        "Food": ["pomegranate", "grapefruit", "broccoli", "radish"],
        "Sport": ["soccer", "swimming", "biathlon", "handball"],
        "Hobby": ["traveling", "card-games", "woodworking", "writing"],
        "Job": ["police-officer", "fisherman", "engineer", "security-guard"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: engineer is to the left of fisherman (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda engineer, fisherman: engineer < fisherman,
        ["Job:engineer", "Job:fisherman"]
    )

    # Clue 2: engineer is to the right of writing (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda engineer, writing: engineer > writing,
        ["Job:engineer", "Hobby:writing"]
    )

    # Clue 3: traveling is to the right of engineer (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda traveling, engineer: traveling > engineer,
        ["Hobby:traveling", "Job:engineer"]
    )

    # Clue 4: card-games is at the same position as or to the left of swimming
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda card_games, swimming: card_games <= swimming,
        ["Hobby:card-games", "Sport:swimming"]
    )

    # Clue 5: biathlon is at the same position as or to the left of writing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda biathlon, writing: biathlon <= writing,
        ["Sport:biathlon", "Hobby:writing"]
    )

    # Clue 6: woodworking is a different person than security-guard
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda woodworking, security_guard: woodworking != security_guard,
        ["Hobby:woodworking", "Job:security-guard"]
    )

    # Clue 7: radish is at an end position (0 or 3)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda radish: radish == 0 or radish == num_positions - 1,
        ["Food:radish"]
    )

    # Clue 8: broccoli is a different person than engineer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda broccoli, engineer: broccoli != engineer,
        ["Food:broccoli", "Job:engineer"]
    )

    # Clue 9: pomegranate is same person as fisherman or writing is same person as pomegranate or both
    # This means at least one of these two equalities is true:
    # (Job:fisherman == Food:pomegranate) or (Hobby:writing == Food:pomegranate)
    # To model this, we add a constraint that the number of equalities is >= 1
    def clue9(fisherman, writing, pomegranate):
        eq1 = (fisherman == pomegranate)
        eq2 = (writing == pomegranate)
        return eq1 or eq2
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue9,
        ["Job:fisherman", "Hobby:writing", "Food:pomegranate"]
    )

    # Clue 10: traveling is adjacent to security-guard
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda traveling, security_guard: abs(traveling - security_guard) == 1,
        ["Hobby:traveling", "Job:security-guard"]
    )

    # Clue 11: pomegranate is same person as fisherman or soccer is same person as pomegranate but not both
    # This is an exclusive or (XOR)
    def clue11(fisherman, soccer, pomegranate):
        eq1 = (fisherman == pomegranate)
        eq2 = (soccer == pomegranate)
        return eq1 != eq2
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue11,
        ["Job:fisherman", "Sport:soccer", "Food:pomegranate"]
    )

    # Clue 12: card-games and broccoli are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda card_games, broccoli: (card_games % 2) != (broccoli % 2),
        ["Hobby:card-games", "Food:broccoli"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # There should be exactly one solution
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format the solution dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Create a list of length num_positions with empty strings
        arr = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            arr[pos] = item
        result[category] = arr

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 3 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 3 unique items:

1. Food: apple, blueberry, banana
2. Nationality: spanish, italian, brazilian
3. Hobby: rock-climbing, board-games, fishing

Each category has exactly 3 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who enjoys rock-climbing is directly between the person who enjoys board-games and the italian person
2. the person who likes banana is the same person as the brazilian person
3. the person who enjoys fishing is immediately to the right of the person who likes banana
4. the person who likes apple is at position 1 (the leftmost position)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Hobby").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 3

    categories = ["Food", "Nationality", "Hobby"]
    items = {
        "Food": ["apple", "blueberry", "banana"],
        "Nationality": ["spanish", "italian", "brazilian"],
        "Hobby": ["rock-climbing", "board-games", "fishing"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be in different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_vars = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_vars)

    # Clue 1: rock-climbing is directly between board-games and italian
    # That means rock-climbing position is one more than min(board-games, italian) and one less than max(board-games, italian)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rc, bg, it: (rc == bg + 1 and rc == it - 1) or (rc == it + 1 and rc == bg - 1),
        ["Hobby:rock-climbing", "Hobby:board-games", "Nationality:italian"]
    )

    # Clue 2: banana is the same person as brazilian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda banana, brazilian: banana == brazilian,
        ["Food:banana", "Nationality:brazilian"]
    )

    # Clue 3: fishing is immediately to the right of banana
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fishing, banana: fishing == banana + 1,
        ["Hobby:fishing", "Food:banana"]
    )

    # Clue 4: apple is at position 1 (index 0)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda apple: apple == 0,
        ["Food:apple"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    # There should be only one solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            position = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][position] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Movie: time-travel, superhero, martial-arts, family
2. Sport: biathlon, cycling, climbing, handball
3. Music: punk, blues, disco, indie

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who plays climbing is somewhere between the person who plays cycling and the person who likes superhero movies (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
2. the person who likes family movies and the person who plays cycling are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
3. the person who likes indie music is to the right of the person who plays handball (not necessarily immediately)
4. the person who likes blues music is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes time-travel movies
5. the person who plays biathlon is immediately to the left of the person who plays handball
6. the person who likes disco music is adjacent to the person who likes indie music (either immediately left or right)
7. the person who likes disco music is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
8. the person who likes superhero movies and the person who plays biathlon are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Movie", "Music").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Movie", "Sport", "Music"]
    items = {
        "Movie": ["time-travel", "superhero", "martial-arts", "family"],
        "Sport": ["biathlon", "cycling", "climbing", "handball"],
        "Music": ["punk", "blues", "disco", "indie"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain 0 to 3 (positions)
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_items = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_items)

    # Clue 1: climbing is somewhere between cycling and superhero (not necessarily adjacent)
    # climbing is between cycling and superhero means climbing position is between cycling and superhero positions
    def between(climbing, cycling, superhero):
        return (cycling < climbing < superhero) or (superhero < climbing < cycling)
    problem.addConstraint(
        between,
        ["Sport:climbing", "Sport:cycling", "Movie:superhero"]
    )

    # Clue 2: family movie and cycling sport are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda family, cycling: (family % 2) != (cycling % 2),
        ["Movie:family", "Sport:cycling"]
    )

    # Clue 3: indie music is to the right of handball sport (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda indie, handball: indie > handball,
        ["Music:indie", "Sport:handball"]
    )

    # Clue 4: blues music is at the same position as or to the right of time-travel movie
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda blues, time_travel: blues >= time_travel,
        ["Music:blues", "Movie:time-travel"]
    )

    # Clue 5: biathlon is immediately to the left of handball
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda biathlon, handball: biathlon == handball - 1,
        ["Sport:biathlon", "Sport:handball"]
    )

    # Clue 6: disco music is adjacent to indie music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda disco, indie: abs(disco - indie) == 1,
        ["Music:disco", "Music:indie"]
    )

    # Clue 7: disco music is at an end position (0 or 3)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda disco: disco == 0 or disco == 3,
        ["Music:disco"]
    )

    # Clue 8: superhero movie and biathlon sport are at positions with the same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda superhero, biathlon: (superhero % 2) == (biathlon % 2),
        ["Movie:superhero", "Sport:biathlon"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # Just pick the first solution if multiple found
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    # Format the solution as requested
    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[variable_name]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Food: papaya, corn, zucchini, cucumber, potato
2. Transport: quad-bike, boat, subway, trike, roller
3. Music: blues, disco, gospel, country, trance
4. Beverage: almond-milk, fanta, cola, water, lemonade
5. Pet: horse, turtle, hedgehog, cat, goldfish

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes zucchini is the same person as at least one of the person who likes gospel music or the person who has hedgehog as a pet
2. the person who has goldfish as a pet is somewhere between the person who likes water and the person who likes potato (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
3. the person who likes gospel music is the same person as the person who has turtle as a pet or the person who has turtle as a pet is the same person as the person who likes almond-milk, but not both
4. the person who uses subway for transportation is to the left of the person who uses quad-bike for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
5. the person who likes almond-milk is at the same position as or to the left of the person who uses subway for transportation
6. the person who likes corn is to the right of the person who likes fanta (not necessarily immediately)
7. the person who likes fanta and the person who has goldfish as a pet are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
8. the person who has turtle as a pet and the person who uses boat for transportation are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
9. the person who uses roller for transportation is the same person as the person who likes lemonade or the person who likes lemonade is the same person as the person who likes potato or both
10. the person who has turtle as a pet is somewhere between the person who likes cola and the person who has horse as a pet (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
11. the person who likes zucchini and the person who has cat as a pet are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
12. the person who likes trance music is the same person as the person who likes lemonade or the person who uses trike for transportation is the same person as the person who likes trance music, but not both
13. the person who has cat as a pet is a different person than the person who likes cucumber
14. the person who likes corn is adjacent to the person who has turtle as a pet (either immediately left or right)
15. the person who likes water is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes blues music
16. the person who likes almond-milk is a different person than the person who likes cucumber
17. the person who likes water is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
18. the person who uses boat for transportation is directly between the person who likes country music and the person who likes cola

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Food").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Food", "Transport", "Music", "Beverage", "Pet"]
    items = {
        "Food": ["papaya", "corn", "zucchini", "cucumber", "potato"],
        "Transport": ["quad-bike", "boat", "subway", "trike", "roller"],
        "Music": ["blues", "disco", "gospel", "country", "trance"],
        "Beverage": ["almond-milk", "fanta", "cola", "water", "lemonade"],
        "Pet": ["horse", "turtle", "hedgehog", "cat", "goldfish"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # AllDifferent constraints within categories
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: zucchini is the same person as gospel or hedgehog (at least one)
    # (zucchini == gospel) or (zucchini == hedgehog)
    def clue1(zucchini, gospel, hedgehog):
        return zucchini == gospel or zucchini == hedgehog
    problem.addConstraint(clue1,
        ["Food:zucchini", "Music:gospel", "Pet:hedgehog"])

    # Clue 2: goldfish is somewhere between water and potato (not necessarily adjacent)
    # goldfish between water and potato means goldfish position is strictly between water and potato
    def clue2(goldfish, water, potato):
        return (water < goldfish < potato) or (potato < goldfish < water)
    problem.addConstraint(clue2,
        ["Pet:goldfish", "Beverage:water", "Food:potato"])

    # Clue 3: gospel == turtle XOR turtle == almond-milk (exclusive or)
    def clue3(gospel, turtle, almond_milk):
        return (gospel == turtle) != (turtle == almond_milk)
    problem.addConstraint(clue3,
        ["Music:gospel", "Pet:turtle", "Beverage:almond-milk"])

    # Clue 4: subway is to the left of quad-bike (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda subway, quad_bike: subway < quad_bike,
                          ["Transport:subway", "Transport:quad-bike"])

    # Clue 5: almond-milk is at same position or to the left of subway
    problem.addConstraint(lambda almond_milk, subway: almond_milk <= subway,
                          ["Beverage:almond-milk", "Transport:subway"])

    # Clue 6: corn is to the right of fanta (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda corn, fanta: corn > fanta,
                          ["Food:corn", "Beverage:fanta"])

    # Clue 7: fanta and goldfish have different parity positions
    problem.addConstraint(lambda fanta, goldfish: (fanta % 2) != (goldfish % 2),
                          ["Beverage:fanta", "Pet:goldfish"])

    # Clue 8: turtle and boat have different parity positions
    problem.addConstraint(lambda turtle, boat: (turtle % 2) != (boat % 2),
                          ["Pet:turtle", "Transport:boat"])

    # Clue 9: roller == lemonade or lemonade == potato or both
    # i.e. roller == lemonade or lemonade == potato
    def clue9(roller, lemonade, potato):
        return (roller == lemonade) or (lemonade == potato)
    problem.addConstraint(clue9,
                          ["Transport:roller", "Beverage:lemonade", "Food:potato"])

    # Clue 10: turtle is somewhere between cola and horse (not necessarily adjacent)
    def clue10(turtle, cola, horse):
        return (cola < turtle < horse) or (horse < turtle < cola)
    problem.addConstraint(clue10,
                          ["Pet:turtle", "Beverage:cola", "Pet:horse"])

    # Clue 11: zucchini and cat have different parity positions
    problem.addConstraint(lambda zucchini, cat: (zucchini % 2) != (cat % 2),
                          ["Food:zucchini", "Pet:cat"])

    # Clue 12: (trance == lemonade) XOR (trike == trance)
    def clue12(trance, lemonade, trike):
        return (trance == lemonade) != (trike == trance)
    problem.addConstraint(clue12,
                          ["Music:trance", "Beverage:lemonade", "Transport:trike"])

    # Clue 13: cat and cucumber are different persons
    problem.addConstraint(lambda cat, cucumber: cat != cucumber,
                          ["Pet:cat", "Food:cucumber"])

    # Clue 14: corn is adjacent to turtle (immediately left or right)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda corn, turtle: abs(corn - turtle) == 1,
                          ["Food:corn", "Pet:turtle"])

    # Clue 15: water is at same position or to the left of blues
    problem.addConstraint(lambda water, blues: water <= blues,
                          ["Beverage:water", "Music:blues"])

    # Clue 16: almond-milk and cucumber are different persons
    problem.addConstraint(lambda almond_milk, cucumber: almond_milk != cucumber,
                          ["Beverage:almond-milk", "Food:cucumber"])

    # Clue 17: water is at an end position (0 or 4)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda water: water == 0 or water == 4,
                          ["Beverage:water"])

    # Clue 18: boat is directly between country and cola
    # boat position = country+1 and boat = cola-1 or boat = country-1 and boat = cola+1
    def clue18(boat, country, cola):
        return (boat == country + 1 and boat == cola - 1) or (boat == country - 1 and boat == cola + 1)
    problem.addConstraint(clue18,
                          ["Transport:boat", "Music:country", "Beverage:cola"])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

2. the person who enjoys reading is to the left of the person who likes jazz music (not necessarily immediately)

- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Hobby").

from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Hobby", "Nationality", "Food", "Music", "Pet"]
    items = {
        "Hobby": ["reading", "filmmaking", "card-games", "magic-tricks", "collecting"],
        "Nationality": ["german", "malaysian", "australian", "canadian", "argentine"],
        "Food": ["papaya", "lettuce", "grapes", "nectarine", "eggplant"],
        "Music": ["classical", "jazz", "gospel", "country", "pop"],
        "Pet": ["goldfish", "goat", "bird", "dog", "rat"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_cat)

    # Clue 1: filmmaking same person as classical music or dog pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda filmmaking, classical, dog: filmmaking == classical or filmmaking == dog,
        ["Hobby:filmmaking", "Music:classical", "Pet:dog"]
    )

    # Clue 2: reading left of jazz (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda reading, jazz: reading < jazz,
        ["Hobby:reading", "Music:jazz"]
    )

    # Clue 3: country right of collecting (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda country, collecting: country > collecting,
        ["Music:country", "Hobby:collecting"]
    )

    # Clue 4: rat same or right of dog
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rat, dog: rat >= dog,
        ["Pet:rat", "Pet:dog"]
    )

    # Clue 5: australian and dog same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda australian, dog: australian % 2 == dog % 2,
        ["Nationality:australian", "Pet:dog"]
    )

    # Clue 6: goat left of goldfish
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda goat, goldfish: goat < goldfish,
        ["Pet:goat", "Pet:goldfish"]
    )

    # Clue 7: gospel at odd-numbered position (positions 1,3,5 -> indices 0,2,4)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda gospel: gospel % 2 == 0,
        ["Music:gospel"]
    )

    # Clue 8: canadian same or left of grapes
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda canadian, grapes: canadian <= grapes,
        ["Nationality:canadian", "Food:grapes"]
    )

    # Clue 9: eggplant and bird different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda eggplant, bird: (eggplant % 2) != (bird % 2),
        ["Food:eggplant", "Pet:bird"]
    )

    # Clue 10: classical and rat same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda classical, rat: classical % 2 == rat % 2,
        ["Music:classical", "Pet:rat"]
    )

    # Clue 11: gospel right of card-games
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda gospel, card_games: gospel > card_games,
        ["Music:gospel", "Hobby:card-games"]
    )

    # Clue 12: canadian at odd-numbered position
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda canadian: canadian % 2 == 0,
        ["Nationality:canadian"]
    )

    # Clue 13: rat same or left of lettuce
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rat, lettuce: rat <= lettuce,
        ["Pet:rat", "Food:lettuce"]
    )

    # Clue 14: papaya left of canadian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda papaya, canadian: papaya < canadian,
        ["Food:papaya", "Nationality:canadian"]
    )

    # Clue 15: rat same or right of bird
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rat, bird: rat >= bird,
        ["Pet:rat", "Pet:bird"]
    )

    # Clue 16: argentine same or left of nectarine
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda argentine, nectarine: argentine <= nectarine,
        ["Nationality:argentine", "Food:nectarine"]
    )

    # Clue 17: eggplant left of papaya
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda eggplant, papaya: eggplant < papaya,
        ["Food:eggplant", "Food:papaya"]
    )

    # Clue 18: filmmaking same as canadian or canadian same as pop or both
    # This means (filmmaking == canadian) or (canadian == pop)
    # So the constraint is satisfied if either filmmaking == canadian or canadian == pop
    # We'll implement as a lambda returning True if either condition holds
    problem.addConstraint(

        ["Hobby:filmmaking", "Nationality:canadian", "Music:pop"]

    for category in categories:

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).

from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Movie", "Sport"]
    items = {
        "Movie": ["scientific", "animation", "fantasy", "time-travel"],
        "Sport": ["skiing", "cycling", "parkour", "baseball"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain 0..3 (positions)
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(),
                              [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda animation, cycling: animation == cycling - 1,
        ["Movie:animation", "Sport:cycling"]
    )

    # That means parkour is at position x, baseball and fantasy are at x-1 and x+1 in any order
    problem.addConstraint(

            (parkour == baseball + 1 and parkour == fantasy - 1) or
            (parkour == fantasy + 1 and parkour == baseball - 1),
        ["Sport:parkour", "Sport:baseball", "Movie:fantasy"]
    )

    # Clue 3: cycling is adjacent to baseball (either immediately left or right)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cycling, baseball: abs(cycling - baseball) == 1,
        ["Sport:cycling", "Sport:baseball"]
    )

    # Clue 4: time-travel movie is immediately to the right of skiing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda time_travel, skiing: time_travel == skiing + 1,
        ["Movie:time-travel", "Sport:skiing"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Beverage: 7up, mirinda, juice, lemonade, tea
2. Music: funk, reggae, metal, soul, indie
3. Sport: climbing, skateboarding, skiing, volleyball, weightlifting
4. Nationality: mexican, dutch, indonesian, colombian, egyptian

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes reggae music is to the left of the person who plays volleyball (not necessarily immediately)
2. the person who likes metal music is to the right of the person who likes soul music (not necessarily immediately)
3. the indonesian person is adjacent to the egyptian person (either immediately left or right)
4. the dutch person is adjacent to the indonesian person (either immediately left or right)
5. the egyptian person is a different person than the person who likes funk music
6. the person who likes mirinda is to the right of the person who plays skiing (not necessarily immediately)
7. the person who plays volleyball is adjacent to the person who plays weightlifting (either immediately left or right)
8. the person who likes 7up is the same person as the person who plays volleyball
9. the person who likes metal music is a different person than the person who likes mirinda
10. the person who plays weightlifting is immediately to the left of the person who likes funk music
11. the person who likes metal music is a different person than the person who plays weightlifting
12. the person who likes tea is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
13. the person who plays skateboarding is a different person than the person who likes lemonade
14. the person who likes metal music is immediately to the left of the person who plays climbing
15. the person who likes lemonade is directly between the colombian person and the dutch person
16. the person who likes juice is a different person than the indonesian person

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Music").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Beverage", "Music", "Sport", "Nationality"]
    items = {
        "Beverage": ["7up", "mirinda", "juice", "lemonade", "tea"],
        "Music": ["funk", "reggae", "metal", "soul", "indie"],
        "Sport": ["climbing", "skateboarding", "skiing", "volleyball", "weightlifting"],
        "Nationality": ["mexican", "dutch", "indonesian", "colombian", "egyptian"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_cat)

    # Clues:

    # 1. reggae music is to the left of volleyball (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda reggae, volleyball: reggae < volleyball,
        ["Music:reggae", "Sport:volleyball"]
    )

    # 2. metal music is to the right of soul music (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda metal, soul: metal > soul,
        ["Music:metal", "Music:soul"]
    )

    # 3. indonesian person is adjacent to egyptian person (immediately left or right)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda indonesian, egyptian: abs(indonesian - egyptian) == 1,
        ["Nationality:indonesian", "Nationality:egyptian"]
    )

    # 4. dutch person is adjacent to indonesian person (immediately left or right)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dutch, indonesian: abs(dutch - indonesian) == 1,
        ["Nationality:dutch", "Nationality:indonesian"]
    )

    # 5. egyptian person is different from funk music person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda egyptian, funk: egyptian != funk,
        ["Nationality:egyptian", "Music:funk"]
    )

    # 6. mirinda is to the right of skiing (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda mirinda, skiing: mirinda > skiing,
        ["Beverage:mirinda", "Sport:skiing"]
    )

    # 7. volleyball is adjacent to weightlifting (immediately left or right)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda volleyball, weightlifting: abs(volleyball - weightlifting) == 1,
        ["Sport:volleyball", "Sport:weightlifting"]
    )

    # 8. 7up is the same person as volleyball
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda sevenup, volleyball: sevenup == volleyball,
        ["Beverage:7up", "Sport:volleyball"]
    )

    # 9. metal music is different from mirinda
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda metal, mirinda: metal != mirinda,
        ["Music:metal", "Beverage:mirinda"]
    )

    # 10. weightlifting is immediately to the left of funk music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda weightlifting, funk: weightlifting == funk - 1,
        ["Sport:weightlifting", "Music:funk"]
    )

    # 11. metal music is different from weightlifting
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda metal, weightlifting: metal != weightlifting,
        ["Music:metal", "Sport:weightlifting"]
    )

    # 12. tea is at an end position (leftmost or rightmost)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda tea: tea == 0 or tea == num_positions - 1,
        ["Beverage:tea"]
    )

    # 13. skateboarding is different from lemonade
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skateboarding, lemonade: skateboarding != lemonade,
        ["Sport:skateboarding", "Beverage:lemonade"]
    )

    # 14. metal music is immediately to the left of climbing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda metal, climbing: metal == climbing - 1,
        ["Music:metal", "Sport:climbing"]
    )

    # 15. lemonade is directly between colombian and dutch
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lemonade, colombian, dutch: (lemonade == colombian + 1 and lemonade == dutch - 1) or (lemonade == dutch + 1 and lemonade == colombian - 1),
        ["Beverage:lemonade", "Nationality:colombian", "Nationality:dutch"]
    )

    # 16. juice is different from indonesian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda juice, indonesian: juice != indonesian,
        ["Beverage:juice", "Nationality:indonesian"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[var]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Music: gospel, reggae, indie, metal, pop
2. Sport: weightlifting, soccer, rowing, golf, lacrosse
3. Movie: sports, horror, adventure, romance, martial-arts
4. Transport: car, bus, helicopter, train, skateboard
5. Pet: goldfish, goat, pony, chinchilla, frog

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who plays golf is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes martial-arts movies
2. the person who plays soccer is to the left of the person who has goldfish as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
3. the person who uses helicopter for transportation is at the same position as or to the left of the person who has goat as a pet
4. the person who likes martial-arts movies is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes reggae music
5. the person who likes adventure movies is to the left of the person who likes indie music (not necessarily immediately)
6. the person who has frog as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who plays soccer
7. the person who uses skateboard for transportation is a different person than the person who plays lacrosse
8. the person who likes martial-arts movies is to the right of the person who likes sports movies (not necessarily immediately)
9. the person who uses bus for transportation is a different person than the person who has pony as a pet
10. the person who has frog as a pet is to the right of the person who likes martial-arts movies (not necessarily immediately)
11. the person who likes horror movies is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes metal music
12. the person who uses bus for transportation is to the left of the person who likes adventure movies (not necessarily immediately)
13. the person who likes metal music is the same person as at least one of the person who likes adventure movies or the person who plays soccer
14. the person who plays weightlifting is to the right of the person who uses bus for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
15. the person who uses skateboard for transportation is to the left of the person who likes sports movies (not necessarily immediately)
16. the person who uses car for transportation is to the right of the person who likes metal music (not necessarily immediately)
17. the person who uses bus for transportation is the same person as the person who likes martial-arts movies or the person who plays golf is the same person as the person who uses bus for transportation or both
18. the person who uses helicopter for transportation is a different person than at least one of the person who likes sports movies or the person who likes pop music
19. the person who has pony as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes gospel music

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Movie", "Music").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Music", "Sport", "Movie", "Transport", "Pet"]
    items = {
        "Music": ["gospel", "reggae", "indie", "metal", "pop"],
        "Sport": ["weightlifting", "soccer", "rowing", "golf", "lacrosse"],
        "Movie": ["sports", "horror", "adventure", "romance", "martial-arts"],
        "Transport": ["car", "bus", "helicopter", "train", "skateboard"],
        "Pet": ["goldfish", "goat", "pony", "chinchilla", "frog"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # AllDifferent constraints per category
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clues:

    # 1. golf >= martial-arts
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda golf, martial_arts: golf >= martial_arts,
        ["Sport:golf", "Movie:martial-arts"]
    )

    # 2. soccer < goldfish
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda soccer, goldfish: soccer < goldfish,
        ["Sport:soccer", "Pet:goldfish"]
    )

    # 3. helicopter <= goat
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda helicopter, goat: helicopter <= goat,
        ["Transport:helicopter", "Pet:goat"]
    )

    # 4. martial-arts <= reggae
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda martial_arts, reggae: martial_arts <= reggae,
        ["Movie:martial-arts", "Music:reggae"]
    )

    # 5. adventure < indie
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda adventure, indie: adventure < indie,
        ["Movie:adventure", "Music:indie"]
    )

    # 6. frog <= soccer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda frog, soccer: frog <= soccer,
        ["Pet:frog", "Sport:soccer"]
    )

    # 7. skateboard != lacrosse
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skateboard, lacrosse: skateboard != lacrosse,
        ["Transport:skateboard", "Sport:lacrosse"]
    )

    # 8. martial-arts > sports
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda martial_arts, sports: martial_arts > sports,
        ["Movie:martial-arts", "Movie:sports"]
    )

    # 9. bus != pony
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bus, pony: bus != pony,
        ["Transport:bus", "Pet:pony"]
    )

    # 10. frog > martial-arts
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda frog, martial_arts: frog > martial_arts,
        ["Pet:frog", "Movie:martial-arts"]
    )

    # 11. horror >= metal
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda horror, metal: horror >= metal,
        ["Movie:horror", "Music:metal"]
    )

    # 12. bus < adventure
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bus, adventure: bus < adventure,
        ["Transport:bus", "Movie:adventure"]
    )

    # 13. metal == adventure or metal == soccer
    # This is a logical OR constraint, so we model it with a custom function
    def metal_adventure_soccer(metal, adventure, soccer):
        return metal == adventure or metal == soccer
    problem.addConstraint(
        metal_adventure_soccer,
        ["Music:metal", "Movie:adventure", "Sport:soccer"]
    )

    # 14. weightlifting > bus
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda weightlifting, bus: weightlifting > bus,
        ["Sport:weightlifting", "Transport:bus"]
    )

    # 15. skateboard < sports (movie)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skateboard, sports: skateboard < sports,
        ["Transport:skateboard", "Movie:sports"]
    )

    # 16. car > metal
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda car, metal: car > metal,
        ["Transport:car", "Music:metal"]
    )

    # 17. bus == martial-arts or golf == bus or both
    def bus_martial_golf(bus, martial_arts, golf):
        return bus == martial_arts or golf == bus
    problem.addConstraint(
        bus_martial_golf,
        ["Transport:bus", "Movie:martial-arts", "Sport:golf"]
    )

    # 18. helicopter != sports or helicopter != pop (at least one)
    def helicopter_not_sports_or_pop(helicopter, sports, pop):
        return helicopter != sports or helicopter != pop
    problem.addConstraint(
        helicopter_not_sports_or_pop,
        ["Transport:helicopter", "Movie:sports", "Music:pop"]
    )

    # 19. pony >= gospel
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pony, gospel: pony >= gospel,
        ["Pet:pony", "Music:gospel"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # If multiple solutions, pick the first
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    result = {category: [""] * num_positions for category in categories}
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 2 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Beverage: almond-milk, tea, mirinda, milk
2. Pet: goldfish, snake, guinea-pig, pony

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who has snake as a pet is immediately to the left of the person who likes milk
2. the person who likes milk is immediately to the right of the person who likes almond-milk
3. the person who has goldfish as a pet is at position 1 (the leftmost position)
4. the person who has pony as a pet is immediately to the left of the person who likes mirinda

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Pet").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Beverage", "Pet"]
    items = {
        "Beverage": ["almond-milk", "tea", "mirinda", "milk"],
        "Pet": ["goldfish", "snake", "guinea-pig", "pony"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain being positions 0 to 3
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_vars = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_vars)

    # Clue 1: snake is immediately to the left of milk
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda snake, milk: snake == milk - 1,
        ["Pet:snake", "Beverage:milk"]
    )

    # Clue 2: milk is immediately to the right of almond-milk
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda milk, almond_milk: milk == almond_milk + 1,
        ["Beverage:milk", "Beverage:almond-milk"]
    )

    # Clue 3: goldfish is at position 1 (leftmost, index 0)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda goldfish: goldfish == 0,
        ["Pet:goldfish"]
    )

    # Clue 4: pony is immediately to the left of mirinda
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pony, mirinda: pony == mirinda - 1,
        ["Pet:pony", "Beverage:mirinda"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Create a list with 4 empty slots
        ordered_items = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            ordered_items[pos] = item
        result[category] = ordered_items

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Job: lawyer, dancer, accountant, designer
2. Sport: rowing, handball, rugby, water-polo
3. Beverage: fanta, tea, cola, juice

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who plays rowing is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
2. the person who likes cola is immediately to the right of the person who works as a accountant
3. the person who works as a dancer is at position 1 (the leftmost position)
4. the person who likes fanta is immediately to the left of the person who works as a designer
5. the person who likes tea is at the same position as or to the left of the person who plays handball
6. the person who plays handball is at the same position as or to the left of the person who works as a dancer
7. the person who works as a lawyer is to the left of the person who plays water-polo (not necessarily immediately)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.

from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Job", "Sport", "Beverage"]
    items = {
        "Job": ["lawyer", "dancer", "accountant", "designer"],
        "Sport": ["rowing", "handball", "rugby", "water-polo"],
        "Beverage": ["fanta", "tea", "cola", "juice"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: the person who plays rowing is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rowing: rowing == 0 or rowing == num_positions - 1,
        ["Sport:rowing"]
    )

    # Clue 2: the person who likes cola is immediately to the right of the person who works as a accountant
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda accountant, cola: cola == accountant + 1,
        ["Job:accountant", "Beverage:cola"]
    )

    # Clue 3: the person who works as a dancer is at position 1 (the leftmost position)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dancer: dancer == 0,
        ["Job:dancer"]
    )

    # Clue 4: the person who likes fanta is immediately to the left of the person who works as a designer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fanta, designer: fanta == designer - 1,
        ["Beverage:fanta", "Job:designer"]
    )

    # Clue 5: the person who likes tea is at the same position as or to the left of the person who plays handball
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda tea, handball: tea <= handball,
        ["Beverage:tea", "Sport:handball"]
    )

    # Clue 6: the person who plays handball is at the same position as or to the left of the person who works as a dancer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda handball, dancer: handball <= dancer,
        ["Sport:handball", "Job:dancer"]
    )

    # Clue 7: the person who works as a lawyer is to the left of the person who plays water-polo (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lawyer, waterpolo: lawyer < waterpolo,
        ["Job:lawyer", "Sport:water-polo"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # There should be only one solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[var]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()
