from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Hobby", "Movie", "Pet", "Music", "Transport"]
    items = {
        "Hobby": ["collecting", "camping", "cooking", "fishing", "woodworking"],
        "Movie": ["action", "drama", "fantasy", "sports", "animation"],
        "Pet": ["goat", "turtle", "guinea-pig", "fish", "ferret"],
        "Music": ["trance", "reggae", "house", "funk", "blues"],
        "Transport": ["roller", "car", "helicopter", "motorbike", "subway"]
    }

    # add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # all items in same category must be different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Helper to add AllDifferent for all categories
    # Constraints from clues:

    # 1. blues music and ferret pet different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda blues, ferret: (blues % 2) != (ferret % 2),
        ["Music:blues", "Pet:ferret"]
    )

    # 2. sports movie same or left of car transport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda sports, car: sports <= car,
        ["Movie:sports", "Transport:car"]
    )

    # 3. guinea-pig pet same or left of car transport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda guinea, car: guinea <= car,
        ["Pet:guinea-pig", "Transport:car"]
    )

    # 4. fish pet same or right of guinea-pig pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fish, guinea: fish >= guinea,
        ["Pet:fish", "Pet:guinea-pig"]
    )

    # 5. collecting hobby same or left of reggae music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda collecting, reggae: collecting <= reggae,
        ["Hobby:collecting", "Music:reggae"]
    )

    # 6. fantasy movie same or right of subway transport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fantasy, subway: fantasy >= subway,
        ["Movie:fantasy", "Transport:subway"]
    )

    # 7. guinea-pig pet and sports movie different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda guinea, sports: (guinea % 2) != (sports % 2),
        ["Pet:guinea-pig", "Movie:sports"]
    )

    # 8. blues music same or right of house music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda blues, house: blues >= house,
        ["Music:blues", "Music:house"]
    )

    # 9. woodworking hobby different person than blues music or blues music different person than goat pet or both
    # This is (woodworking != blues) OR (blues != goat)
    # So we add a constraint that forbids both equalities at once
    def woodworking_blues_goat_constraint(woodworking, blues, goat):
        return (woodworking != blues) or (blues != goat)
    problem.addConstraint(
        woodworking_blues_goat_constraint,
        ["Hobby:woodworking", "Music:blues", "Pet:goat"]
    )

    # 10. guinea-pig pet same or right of funk music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda guinea, funk: guinea >= funk,
        ["Pet:guinea-pig", "Music:funk"]
    )

    # 11. sports movie different person than ferret pet or house music different person than sports movie or both
    # (sports != ferret) OR (house != sports)
    def sports_ferret_house(sports, ferret, house):
        return (sports != ferret) or (house != sports)
    problem.addConstraint(
        sports_ferret_house,
        ["Movie:sports", "Pet:ferret", "Music:house"]
    )

    # 12. collecting hobby same person as guinea-pig pet or guinea-pig pet same person as roller transport, but not both
    # XOR: (collecting == guinea) XOR (guinea == roller)
    def collecting_guinea_roller(collecting, guinea, roller):
        return (collecting == guinea) != (guinea == roller)
    problem.addConstraint(
        collecting_guinea_roller,
        ["Hobby:collecting", "Pet:guinea-pig", "Transport:roller"]
    )

    # 13. car transport somewhere between woodworking hobby and fishing hobby (not necessarily adjacent)
    # i.e. (woodworking < car < fishing) OR (fishing < car < woodworking)
    def car_between_woodworking_fishing(car, woodworking, fishing):
        return (woodworking < car < fishing) or (fishing < car < woodworking)
    problem.addConstraint(
        car_between_woodworking_fishing,
        ["Transport:car", "Hobby:woodworking", "Hobby:fishing"]
    )

    # 14. drama movie same or right of motorbike transport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda drama, motorbike: drama >= motorbike,
        ["Movie:drama", "Transport:motorbike"]
    )

    # 15. reggae music somewhere between camping hobby and turtle pet (not necessarily adjacent)
    # (camping < reggae < turtle) OR (turtle < reggae < camping)
    def reggae_between_camping_turtle(reggae, camping, turtle):
        return (camping < reggae < turtle) or (turtle < reggae < camping)
    problem.addConstraint(
        reggae_between_camping_turtle,
        ["Music:reggae", "Hobby:camping", "Pet:turtle"]
    )

    # 16. fishing hobby somewhere between motorbike transport and woodworking hobby (not necessarily adjacent)
    # (motorbike < fishing < woodworking) OR (woodworking < fishing < motorbike)
    def fishing_between_motorbike_woodworking(fishing, motorbike, woodworking):
        return (motorbike < fishing < woodworking) or (woodworking < fishing < motorbike)
    problem.addConstraint(
        fishing_between_motorbike_woodworking,
        ["Hobby:fishing", "Transport:motorbike", "Hobby:woodworking"]
    )

    # 17. fishing hobby same or right of goat pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fishing, goat: fishing >= goat,
        ["Hobby:fishing", "Pet:goat"]
    )

    # 18. funk music different person than drama movie or drama movie different person than turtle pet or both
    # (funk != drama) OR (drama != turtle)
    def funk_drama_turtle(funk, drama, turtle):
        return (funk != drama) or (drama != turtle)
    problem.addConstraint(
        funk_drama_turtle,
        ["Music:funk", "Movie:drama", "Pet:turtle"]
    )

    # 19. drama movie and house music same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda drama, house: (drama % 2) == (house % 2),
        ["Movie:drama", "Music:house"]
    )

    # 20. turtle pet same or left of goat pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda turtle, goat: turtle <= goat,
        ["Pet:turtle", "Pet:goat"]
    )

    # 21. sports movie different person than at least one of roller transport or cooking hobby
    # i.e. sports != roller OR sports != cooking
    def sports_roller_cooking(sports, roller, cooking):
        return (sports != roller) or (sports != cooking)
    problem.addConstraint(
        sports_roller_cooking,
        ["Movie:sports", "Transport:roller", "Hobby:cooking"]
    )

    # 22. animation movie same or left of woodworking hobby
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda animation, woodworking: animation <= woodworking,
        ["Movie:animation", "Hobby:woodworking"]
    )

    # 23. trance music same person as camping hobby XOR camping hobby same person as action movie
    def trance_camping_action(trance, camping, action):
        return (trance == camping) != (camping == action)
    problem.addConstraint(
        trance_camping_action,
        ["Music:trance", "Hobby:camping", "Movie:action"]
    )

    # 24. reggae music same person as at least one of subway transport or camping hobby
    # i.e. reggae == subway OR reggae == camping
    def reggae_subway_camping(reggae, subway, camping):
        return (reggae == subway) or (reggae == camping)
    problem.addConstraint(
        reggae_subway_camping,
        ["Music:reggae", "Transport:subway", "Hobby:camping"]
    )

    # 25. blues music and roller transport same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda blues, roller: (blues % 2) == (roller % 2),
        ["Music:blues", "Transport:roller"]
    )

    # 26. guinea-pig pet same person as car transport or drama movie same person as guinea-pig pet or both
    # i.e. (guinea == car) OR (drama == guinea)
    def guinea_car_drama(guinea, car, drama):
        return (guinea == car) or (drama == guinea)
    problem.addConstraint(
        guinea_car_drama,
        ["Pet:guinea-pig", "Transport:car", "Movie:drama"]
    )

    # 27. drama movie same or left of turtle pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda drama, turtle: drama <= turtle,
        ["Movie:drama", "Pet:turtle"]
    )

    # 28. animation movie same or right of ferret pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda animation, ferret: animation >= ferret,
        ["Movie:animation", "Pet:ferret"]
    )

    # 29. turtle pet different person than at least one of funk music or fantasy movie
    # i.e. turtle != funk OR turtle != fantasy
    def turtle_funk_fantasy(turtle, funk, fantasy):
        return (turtle != funk) or (turtle != fantasy)
    problem.addConstraint(
        turtle_funk_fantasy,
        ["Pet:turtle", "Music:funk", "Movie:fantasy"]
    )

    # 30. sports movie somewhere between house music and action movie (not necessarily adjacent)
    # (house < sports < action) OR (action < sports < house)
    def sports_between_house_action(sports, house, action):
        return (house < sports < action) or (action < sports < house)
    problem.addConstraint(
        sports_between_house_action,
        ["Movie:sports", "Music:house", "Movie:action"]
    )

    # 31. ferret pet different person than at least one of cooking hobby or car transport
    # i.e. ferret != cooking OR ferret != car
    def ferret_cooking_car(ferret, cooking, car):
        return (ferret != cooking) or (ferret != car)
    problem.addConstraint(
        ferret_cooking_car,
        ["Pet:ferret", "Hobby:cooking", "Transport:car"]
    )

    # 32. action movie same or right of blues music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda action, blues: action >= blues,
        ["Movie:action", "Music:blues"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # We expect a unique solution
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        arr = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            arr[pos] = item
        result[category] = arr

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

1. Hobby: gardening, magic-tricks, camping
2. Transport: helicopter, car, motorbike
3. Nationality: egyptian, polish, dutch

Each category has exactly 3 items, and no item repeats within a category.

3. the person who uses helicopter for transportation is directly between the person who uses motorbike for transportation and the dutch person

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Hobby", "Nationality").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).

3. Job: project-manager, accountant, dancer, security-guard, nurse

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

2. the person who likes cranberry is immediately to the left of the person who plays ice-hockey
3. the person who plays skiing is to the right of the person who plays badminton (not necessarily immediately)
4. the person who likes cranberry is a different person than the person who works as a project-manager

6. the person who plays skiing is to the left of the person who likes plum (not necessarily immediately)
7. the person who works as a nurse is to the left of the person who likes cucumber (not necessarily immediately)
8. the person who likes nectarine is the same person as the person who works as a dancer
9. the person who works as a security-guard is immediately to the left of the person who works as a dancer
10. the person who plays basketball is to the right of the person who likes nectarine (not necessarily immediately)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.

from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Food", "Sport", "Job"]
    items = {
        "Food": ["plum", "nectarine", "onion", "cucumber", "cranberry"],
        "Sport": ["baseball", "badminton", "skiing", "ice-hockey", "basketball"],
        "Job": ["project-manager", "accountant", "dancer", "security-guard", "nurse"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: cranberry is to the right of basketball (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cranberry, basketball: cranberry > basketball,
        ["Food:cranberry", "Sport:basketball"]
    )

    # Clue 2: cranberry is immediately to the left of ice-hockey
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cranberry, ice_hockey: cranberry == ice_hockey - 1,
        ["Food:cranberry", "Sport:ice-hockey"]
    )

    # Clue 3: skiing is to the right of badminton (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skiing, badminton: skiing > badminton,
        ["Sport:skiing", "Sport:badminton"]
    )

    # Clue 4: cranberry is a different person than project-manager
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cranberry, project_manager: cranberry != project_manager,
        ["Food:cranberry", "Job:project-manager"]
    )

    # Clue 5: basketball is the same person as nurse
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda basketball, nurse: basketball == nurse,
        ["Sport:basketball", "Job:nurse"]
    )

    # Clue 6: skiing is to the left of plum (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skiing, plum: skiing < plum,
        ["Sport:skiing", "Food:plum"]
    )

    # Clue 7: nurse is to the left of cucumber (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda nurse, cucumber: nurse < cucumber,
        ["Job:nurse", "Food:cucumber"]
    )

    # Clue 8: nectarine is the same person as dancer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda nectarine, dancer: nectarine == dancer,
        ["Food:nectarine", "Job:dancer"]
    )

    # Clue 9: security-guard is immediately to the left of dancer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda security_guard, dancer: security_guard == dancer - 1,
        ["Job:security-guard", "Job:dancer"]
    )

    # Clue 10: basketball is to the right of nectarine (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda basketball, nectarine: basketball > nectarine,
        ["Sport:basketball", "Food:nectarine"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Food: radish, pomegranate, pepper, cranberry
2. Transport: tram, bike, train, skateboard
3. Nationality: brazilian, spanish, australian, german
4. Beverage: milk, fanta, mirinda, hot-chocolate

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes pepper is adjacent to the person who likes milk (either immediately left or right)
2. the person who uses skateboard for transportation is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
3. the spanish person is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes cranberry
4. the person who uses bike for transportation is to the left of the brazilian person (not necessarily immediately)
5. the person who likes radish is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses bike for transportation
6. the person who uses tram for transportation is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes fanta
7. the german person is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes radish
8. the brazilian person is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes mirinda
9. the person who likes fanta is to the left of the person who likes pomegranate (not necessarily immediately)
10. the australian person is to the left of the person who uses bike for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
11. the person who likes fanta and the person who likes pepper are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
12. the person who likes pepper is adjacent to the person who uses tram for transportation (either immediately left or right)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Food").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Food", "Transport", "Nationality", "Beverage"]
    items = {
        "Food": ["radish", "pomegranate", "pepper", "cranberry"],
        "Transport": ["tram", "bike", "train", "skateboard"],
        "Nationality": ["brazilian", "spanish", "australian", "german"],
        "Beverage": ["milk", "fanta", "mirinda", "hot-chocolate"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be in different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: pepper adjacent to milk
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pepper, milk: abs(pepper - milk) == 1,
        ["Food:pepper", "Beverage:milk"]
    )

    # Clue 2: skateboard at an end position (0 or 3)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skateboard: skateboard == 0 or skateboard == num_positions - 1,
        ["Transport:skateboard"]
    )

    # Clue 3: spanish same position or left of cranberry
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda spanish, cranberry: spanish <= cranberry,
        ["Nationality:spanish", "Food:cranberry"]
    )

    # Clue 4: bike to the left of brazilian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bike, brazilian: bike < brazilian,
        ["Transport:bike", "Nationality:brazilian"]
    )

    # Clue 5: radish same position or right of bike
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda radish, bike: radish >= bike,
        ["Food:radish", "Transport:bike"]
    )

    # Clue 6: tram same position or right of fanta
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda tram, fanta: tram >= fanta,
        ["Transport:tram", "Beverage:fanta"]
    )

    # Clue 7: german same position or right of radish
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda german, radish: german >= radish,
        ["Nationality:german", "Food:radish"]
    )

    # Clue 8: brazilian same position or left of mirinda
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda brazilian, mirinda: brazilian <= mirinda,
        ["Nationality:brazilian", "Beverage:mirinda"]
    )

    # Clue 9: fanta to the left of pomegranate
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fanta, pomegranate: fanta < pomegranate,
        ["Beverage:fanta", "Food:pomegranate"]
    )

    # Clue 10: australian to the left of bike
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda australian, bike: australian < bike,
        ["Nationality:australian", "Transport:bike"]
    )

    # Clue 11: fanta and pepper different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fanta, pepper: (fanta % 2) != (pepper % 2),
        ["Beverage:fanta", "Food:pepper"]
    )

    # Clue 12: pepper adjacent to tram
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pepper, tram: abs(pepper - tram) == 1,
        ["Food:pepper", "Transport:tram"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Music: country, pop, gospel, ambient
2. Nationality: mexican, egyptian, pakistani, thai
3. Hobby: traveling, singing, fishing, woodworking

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the thai person is directly between the person who enjoys traveling and the egyptian person
2. the person who likes pop music is the same person as the person who enjoys woodworking
3. the person who enjoys traveling is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
4. the person who likes ambient music is the same person as the person who enjoys singing
5. the person who likes pop music is immediately to the right of the person who enjoys fishing
6. the person who enjoys traveling is the same person as the pakistani person
7. the person who enjoys traveling is to the right of the person who enjoys singing (not necessarily immediately)
8. the person who likes country music is adjacent to the egyptian person (either immediately left or right)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Hobby", "Music").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Music", "Nationality", "Hobby"]
    items = {
        "Music": ["country", "pop", "gospel", "ambient"],
        "Nationality": ["mexican", "egyptian", "pakistani", "thai"],
        "Hobby": ["traveling", "singing", "fishing", "woodworking"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain being positions 0 to 3
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: the thai person is directly between the person who enjoys traveling and the egyptian person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda thai, traveling, egyptian:
            (thai == traveling + 1 and thai == egyptian - 1) or (thai == egyptian + 1 and thai == traveling - 1),
        ["Nationality:thai", "Hobby:traveling", "Nationality:egyptian"]
    )

    # Clue 2: the person who likes pop music is the same person as the person who enjoys woodworking
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pop, woodworking: pop == woodworking,
        ["Music:pop", "Hobby:woodworking"]
    )

    # Clue 3: the person who enjoys traveling is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda traveling: traveling == 0 or traveling == num_positions - 1,
        ["Hobby:traveling"]
    )

    # Clue 4: the person who likes ambient music is the same person as the person who enjoys singing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda ambient, singing: ambient == singing,
        ["Music:ambient", "Hobby:singing"]
    )

    # Clue 5: the person who likes pop music is immediately to the right of the person who enjoys fishing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pop, fishing: pop == fishing + 1,
        ["Music:pop", "Hobby:fishing"]
    )

    # Clue 6: the person who enjoys traveling is the same person as the pakistani person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda traveling, pakistani: traveling == pakistani,
        ["Hobby:traveling", "Nationality:pakistani"]
    )

    # Clue 7: the person who enjoys traveling is to the right of the person who enjoys singing (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda traveling, singing: traveling > singing,
        ["Hobby:traveling", "Hobby:singing"]
    )

    # Clue 8: the person who likes country music is adjacent to the egyptian person (either immediately left or right)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda country, egyptian: abs(country - egyptian) == 1,
        ["Music:country", "Nationality:egyptian"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # There should be exactly one solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format the solution as required
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Create a list of length num_positions
        ordered_items = [None] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            ordered_items[pos] = item
        result[category] = ordered_items

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Food", "Job", "Movie", "Beverage", "Music"]
    items = {
        "Food": ["spinach", "lettuce", "papaya", "asparagus", "watermelon"],
        "Job": ["librarian", "accountant", "videographer", "pilot", "analyst"],
        "Movie": ["superhero", "satire", "zombie", "martial-arts", "western"],
        "Beverage": ["mirinda", "almond-milk", "soy-milk", "lemonade", "cola"],
        "Music": ["electronic", "d&b", "reggae", "ambient", "disco"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: lemonade is somewhere between watermelon and western movies
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lemonade, watermelon, western:
        (watermelon < lemonade < western) or (western < lemonade < watermelon),
        ["Beverage:lemonade", "Food:watermelon", "Movie:western"]
    )

    # Clue 2: accountant and western have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda accountant, western: (accountant % 2) != (western % 2),
        ["Job:accountant", "Movie:western"]
    )

    # Clue 3: soy-milk same or left of videographer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda soy_milk, videographer: soy_milk <= videographer,
        ["Beverage:soy-milk", "Job:videographer"]
    )

    # Clue 4: western and cola different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda western, cola: (western % 2) != (cola % 2),
        ["Movie:western", "Beverage:cola"]
    )

    # Clue 5: satire and videographer different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda satire, videographer: (satire % 2) != (videographer % 2),
        ["Movie:satire", "Job:videographer"]
    )

    # Clue 6: satire somewhere between librarian and accountant
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda satire, librarian, accountant:
        (librarian < satire < accountant) or (accountant < satire < librarian),
        ["Movie:satire", "Job:librarian", "Job:accountant"]
    )

    # Clue 7: zombie same or right of analyst
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda zombie, analyst: zombie >= analyst,
        ["Movie:zombie", "Job:analyst"]
    )

    # Clue 8: martial-arts same person as lettuce or mirinda or both
    # This means martial-arts equals lettuce or martial-arts equals mirinda or both
    def martial_arts_lettuce_mirinda(ma, lt, mi):
        return ma == lt or ma == mi
    problem.addConstraint(
        martial_arts_lettuce_mirinda,
        ["Movie:martial-arts", "Food:lettuce", "Beverage:mirinda"]
    )

    # Clue 9: superhero same or left of papaya
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda superhero, papaya: superhero <= papaya,
        ["Movie:superhero", "Food:papaya"]
    )

    # Clue 10: reggae same or right of electronic
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda reggae, electronic: reggae >= electronic,
        ["Music:reggae", "Music:electronic"]
    )

    # Clue 11: reggae and satire different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda reggae, satire: (reggae % 2) != (satire % 2),
        ["Music:reggae", "Movie:satire"]
    )

    # Clue 12: almond-milk somewhere between zombie and lemonade
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda almond_milk, zombie, lemonade:
        (zombie < almond_milk < lemonade) or (lemonade < almond_milk < zombie),
        ["Beverage:almond-milk", "Movie:zombie", "Beverage:lemonade"]
    )

    # Clue 13: asparagus same or left of librarian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda asparagus, librarian: asparagus <= librarian,
        ["Food:asparagus", "Job:librarian"]
    )

    # Clue 14: analyst same person as papaya or zombie (at least one)
    def analyst_papaya_zombie(analyst, papaya, zombie):
        return analyst == papaya or analyst == zombie
    problem.addConstraint(
        analyst_papaya_zombie,
        ["Job:analyst", "Food:papaya", "Movie:zombie"]
    )

    # Clue 15: cola and asparagus same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cola, asparagus: (cola % 2) == (asparagus % 2),
        ["Beverage:cola", "Food:asparagus"]
    )

    # Clue 16: d&b and analyst different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dnb, analyst: (dnb % 2) != (analyst % 2),
        ["Music:d&b", "Job:analyst"]
    )

    # Clue 17: librarian same or left of martial-arts
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda librarian, martial_arts: librarian <= martial_arts,
        ["Job:librarian", "Movie:martial-arts"]
    )

    # Clue 18: watermelon and librarian different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda watermelon, librarian: (watermelon % 2) != (librarian % 2),
        ["Food:watermelon", "Job:librarian"]
    )

    # Clue 19: asparagus somewhere between spinach and papaya
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda asparagus, spinach, papaya:
        (spinach < asparagus < papaya) or (papaya < asparagus < spinach),
        ["Food:asparagus", "Food:spinach", "Food:papaya"]
    )

    # Clue 20: disco same or left of soy-milk
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda disco, soy_milk: disco <= soy_milk,
        ["Music:disco", "Beverage:soy-milk"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 2 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Nationality: turkish, american, pakistani, nigerian
2. Music: blues, gospel, classical, techno

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the american person is adjacent to the pakistani person (either immediately left or right)
2. the nigerian person is directly between the person who likes techno music and the person who likes gospel music
3. the person who likes classical music is directly between the pakistani person and the person who likes techno music
4. the person who likes gospel music is immediately to the left of the person who likes blues music

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Music", "Nationality").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Nationality", "Music"]
    items = {
        "Nationality": ["turkish", "american", "pakistani", "nigerian"],
        "Music": ["blues", "gospel", "classical", "techno"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain 0 to 3 representing positions
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be in different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_category = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_category)

    # Clue 1: The american person is adjacent to the pakistani person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda american, pakistani: abs(american - pakistani) == 1,
        ["Nationality:american", "Nationality:pakistani"]
    )

    # Clue 2: The nigerian person is directly between the person who likes techno music and the person who likes gospel music
    # means nigerian is at position x, techno and gospel at positions x-1 and x+1 in any order
    def nigerian_between_techno_gospel(nigerian, techno, gospel):
        return (nigerian == techno + 1 and nigerian == gospel - 1) or (nigerian == gospel + 1 and nigerian == techno - 1)
    problem.addConstraint(
        nigerian_between_techno_gospel,
        ["Nationality:nigerian", "Music:techno", "Music:gospel"]
    )

    # Clue 3: The person who likes classical music is directly between the pakistani person and the person who likes techno music
    def classical_between_pakistani_techno(classical, pakistani, techno):
        return (classical == pakistani + 1 and classical == techno - 1) or (classical == techno + 1 and classical == pakistani - 1)
    problem.addConstraint(
        classical_between_pakistani_techno,
        ["Music:classical", "Nationality:pakistani", "Music:techno"]
    )

    # Clue 4: The person who likes gospel music is immediately to the left of the person who likes blues music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda gospel, blues: gospel == blues - 1,
        ["Music:gospel", "Music:blues"]
    )

    # Solve the problem
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # There should be exactly one solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Create a list of length num_positions
        ordered_items = [None] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            ordered_items[pos] = item
        result[category] = ordered_items

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Transport: train, roller, boat, scooter
2. Sport: basketball, lacrosse, baseball, rowing
3. Beverage: sprite, water, soy-milk, tea
4. Food: watermelon, pumpkin, peach, cherry

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes cherry is at position 1 (the leftmost position)
2. the person who plays basketball is adjacent to the person who likes soy-milk (either immediately left or right)
3. the person who likes watermelon is to the right of the person who likes sprite (not necessarily immediately)
4. the person who uses train for transportation is adjacent to the person who likes cherry (either immediately left or right)
5. the person who uses scooter for transportation is immediately to the left of the person who uses boat for transportation
6. the person who likes tea is at position 1 (the leftmost position)
7. the person who uses roller for transportation is to the left of the person who plays lacrosse (not necessarily immediately)
8. the person who plays baseball is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes sprite
9. the person who likes water is the same person as the person who uses train for transportation
10. the person who uses train for transportation and the person who likes pumpkin are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Food").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4  # positions 0 to 3 representing positions 1 to 4

    categories = ["Transport", "Sport", "Beverage", "Food"]
    items = {
        "Transport": ["train", "roller", "boat", "scooter"],
        "Sport": ["basketball", "lacrosse", "baseball", "rowing"],
        "Beverage": ["sprite", "water", "soy-milk", "tea"],
        "Food": ["watermelon", "pumpkin", "peach", "cherry"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clues:
    # 1. the person who likes cherry is at position 1 (leftmost)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda cherry: cherry == 0, ["Food:cherry"])

    # 2. basketball adjacent to soy-milk
    problem.addConstraint(lambda basketball, soy_milk: abs(basketball - soy_milk) == 1,
                          ["Sport:basketball", "Beverage:soy-milk"])

    # 3. watermelon is to the right of sprite (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda watermelon, sprite: watermelon > sprite,
                          ["Food:watermelon", "Beverage:sprite"])

    # 4. train adjacent to cherry
    problem.addConstraint(lambda train, cherry: abs(train - cherry) == 1,
                          ["Transport:train", "Food:cherry"])

    # 5. scooter immediately to the left of boat
    problem.addConstraint(lambda scooter, boat: scooter == boat - 1,
                          ["Transport:scooter", "Transport:boat"])

    # 6. tea at position 1 (leftmost)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda tea: tea == 0, ["Beverage:tea"])

    # 7. roller to the left of lacrosse (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda roller, lacrosse: roller < lacrosse,
                          ["Transport:roller", "Sport:lacrosse"])

    # 8. baseball at same position or to the right of sprite
    problem.addConstraint(lambda baseball, sprite: baseball >= sprite,
                          ["Sport:baseball", "Beverage:sprite"])

    # 9. water same person as train
    problem.addConstraint(lambda water, train: water == train,
                          ["Beverage:water", "Transport:train"])

    # 10. train and pumpkin positions have same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda train, pumpkin: (train % 2) == (pumpkin % 2),
                          ["Transport:train", "Food:pumpkin"])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # There should be exactly one solution
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {category: [""] * num_positions for category in categories}
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Beverage: milk, water, juice, sprite, 7up
2. Nationality: malaysian, colombian, brazilian, italian, egyptian
3. Music: gospel, house, dubstep, jazz, electronic
4. Pet: rat, horse, lizard, bird, snake
5. Movie: mystery, comedy, fantasy, zombie, family

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes family movies and the person who likes 7up are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
2. the italian person is the same person as the person who likes jazz music or the person who likes 7up is the same person as the italian person or both
3. the malaysian person is at the same position as or to the left of the egyptian person
4. the person who has snake as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes water
5. the person who likes electronic music is somewhere between the egyptian person and the person who has horse as a pet (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
6. the italian person is to the right of the person who has rat as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
7. the person who likes electronic music is to the right of the person who likes house music (not necessarily immediately)
8. the person who likes milk is to the left of the person who has snake as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
9. the colombian person and the person who likes 7up are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
10. the person who likes 7up and the person who likes zombie movies are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
11. the person who likes family movies is to the left of the person who likes zombie movies (not necessarily immediately)
12. the person who likes 7up is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes juice
13. the person who likes zombie movies is a different person than the person who has snake as a pet
14. the malaysian person is the same person as the person who likes 7up or the person who likes electronic music is the same person as the malaysian person or both
15. the person who likes zombie movies is to the left of the person who likes mystery movies (not necessarily immediately)
16. the person who likes electronic music is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes water
17. the person who likes zombie movies is at the same position as or to the right of the person who has bird as a pet
18. the person who likes water is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes comedy movies
19. the person who likes mystery movies is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes 7up
20. the person who likes gospel music is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes milk

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Beverage", "Nationality", "Music", "Pet", "Movie"]
    items = {
        "Beverage": ["milk", "water", "juice", "sprite", "7up"],
        "Nationality": ["malaysian", "colombian", "brazilian", "italian", "egyptian"],
        "Music": ["gospel", "house", "dubstep", "jazz", "electronic"],
        "Pet": ["rat", "horse", "lizard", "bird", "snake"],
        "Movie": ["mystery", "comedy", "fantasy", "zombie", "family"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: family movies and 7up different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda family, sevenup: (family % 2) != (sevenup % 2),
        ["Movie:family", "Beverage:7up"]
    )

    # Clue 2: italian == jazz or italian == 7up or both
    # This means italian == jazz or italian == 7up or both.
    # So italian == jazz or italian == 7up
    # We model this as: italian == jazz or italian == 7up
    # Which is: (italian == jazz) or (italian == 7up)
    def italian_jazz_7up(italian, jazz, sevenup):
        return italian == jazz or italian == sevenup
    problem.addConstraint(
        italian_jazz_7up,
        ["Nationality:italian", "Music:jazz", "Beverage:7up"]
    )

    # Clue 3: malaysian same or left of egyptian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda malaysian, egyptian: malaysian <= egyptian,
        ["Nationality:malaysian", "Nationality:egyptian"]
    )

    # Clue 4: snake same or left of water
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda snake, water: snake <= water,
        ["Pet:snake", "Beverage:water"]
    )

    # Clue 5: electronic between egyptian and horse (not necessarily immediately)
    # Means electronic is strictly between egyptian and horse
    def electronic_between(electronic, egyptian, horse):
        return (egyptian < electronic < horse) or (horse < electronic < egyptian)
    problem.addConstraint(
        electronic_between,
        ["Music:electronic", "Nationality:egyptian", "Pet:horse"]
    )

    # Clue 6: italian to the right of rat
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda italian, rat: italian > rat,
        ["Nationality:italian", "Pet:rat"]
    )

    # Clue 7: electronic to the right of house
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda electronic, house: electronic > house,
        ["Music:electronic", "Music:house"]
    )

    # Clue 8: milk to the left of snake
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda milk, snake: milk < snake,
        ["Beverage:milk", "Pet:snake"]
    )

    # Clue 9: colombian and 7up same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda colombian, sevenup: (colombian % 2) == (sevenup % 2),
        ["Nationality:colombian", "Beverage:7up"]
    )

    # Clue 10: 7up and zombie different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda sevenup, zombie: (sevenup % 2) != (zombie % 2),
        ["Beverage:7up", "Movie:zombie"]
    )

    # Clue 11: family to the left of zombie
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda family, zombie: family < zombie,
        ["Movie:family", "Movie:zombie"]
    )

    # Clue 12: 7up same or left of juice
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda sevenup, juice: sevenup <= juice,
        ["Beverage:7up", "Beverage:juice"]
    )

    # Clue 13: zombie different person than snake
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda zombie, snake: zombie != snake,
        ["Movie:zombie", "Pet:snake"]
    )

    # Clue 14: malaysian == 7up or electronic == malaysian or both
    # So malaysian == 7up or electronic == malaysian
    def malaysian_7up_electronic(malaysian, sevenup, electronic):
        return malaysian == sevenup or electronic == malaysian
    problem.addConstraint(
        malaysian_7up_electronic,
        ["Nationality:malaysian", "Beverage:7up", "Music:electronic"]
    )

    # Clue 15: zombie to the left of mystery
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda zombie, mystery: zombie < mystery,
        ["Movie:zombie", "Movie:mystery"]
    )

    # Clue 16: electronic same or left of water
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda electronic, water: electronic <= water,
        ["Music:electronic", "Beverage:water"]
    )

    # Clue 17: zombie same or right of bird
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda zombie, bird: zombie >= bird,
        ["Movie:zombie", "Pet:bird"]
    )

    # Clue 18: water same or left of comedy
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda water, comedy: water <= comedy,
        ["Beverage:water", "Movie:comedy"]
    )

    # Clue 19: mystery same or left of 7up
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda mystery, sevenup: mystery <= sevenup,
        ["Movie:mystery", "Beverage:7up"]
    )

    # Clue 20: gospel same or left of milk
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda gospel, milk: gospel <= milk,
        ["Music:gospel", "Beverage:milk"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # There might be multiple solutions but we only print one
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Create list of length num_positions
        ordered_items = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            ordered_items[pos] = item
        result[category] = ordered_items

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Music: soul, electronic, reggae, gospel
2. Food: lime, potato, apricot, cherry
3. Hobby: board-games, traveling, photography, magic-tricks
4. Pet: guinea-pig, goat, pony, cat
5. Job: freelancer, project-manager, journalist, police-officer

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes electronic music is directly between the person who works as a journalist and the person who works as a project-manager
2. the person who enjoys photography is at the same position as or to the left of the person who has goat as a pet
3. the person who likes apricot is the same person as at least one of the person who works as a journalist or the person who likes reggae music
4. the person who likes electronic music is immediately to the right of the person who likes reggae music
5. the person who likes apricot is immediately to the left of the person who has guinea-pig as a pet
6. the person who likes cherry is the same person as the person who works as a project-manager
7. the person who works as a freelancer is somewhere between the person who likes soul music and the person who enjoys magic-tricks (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
8. the person who enjoys traveling is to the left of the person who has guinea-pig as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
9. the person who has guinea-pig as a pet is immediately to the right of the person who has pony as a pet
10. the person who enjoys magic-tricks is the same person as the person who has cat as a pet
11. the person who enjoys magic-tricks is immediately to the right of the person who likes lime

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Hobby").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Music", "Food", "Hobby", "Pet", "Job"]
    items = {
        "Music": ["soul", "electronic", "reggae", "gospel"],
        "Food": ["lime", "potato", "apricot", "cherry"],
        "Hobby": ["board-games", "traveling", "photography", "magic-tricks"],
        "Pet": ["guinea-pig", "goat", "pony", "cat"],
        "Job": ["freelancer", "project-manager", "journalist", "police-officer"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be in different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(),
                              [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: electronic music is directly between journalist and project-manager
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda electronic, journalist, project_manager:
            (electronic == journalist + 1 and electronic == project_manager - 1) or
            (electronic == project_manager + 1 and electronic == journalist - 1),
        ["Music:electronic", "Job:journalist", "Job:project-manager"]
    )

    # Clue 2: photography is at the same position as or to the left of goat
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda photography, goat: photography <= goat,
        ["Hobby:photography", "Pet:goat"]
    )

    # Clue 3: apricot is the same person as journalist or reggae (at least one)
    # This means apricot == journalist or apricot == reggae
    # We model as a disjunction: apricot == journalist OR apricot == reggae
    # python-constraint does not support OR directly, so we add two constraints and get solutions that satisfy either
    # We'll add a custom constraint that enforces this OR condition
    def apricot_constraint(apricot, journalist, reggae):
        return apricot == journalist or apricot == reggae
    problem.addConstraint(
        apricot_constraint,
        ["Food:apricot", "Job:journalist", "Music:reggae"]
    )

    # Clue 4: electronic music immediately to the right of reggae music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda electronic, reggae: electronic == reggae + 1,
        ["Music:electronic", "Music:reggae"]
    )

    # Clue 5: apricot immediately to the left of guinea-pig
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda apricot, guinea_pig: apricot == guinea_pig - 1,
        ["Food:apricot", "Pet:guinea-pig"]
    )

    # Clue 6: cherry is the same person as project-manager
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cherry, project_manager: cherry == project_manager,
        ["Food:cherry", "Job:project-manager"]
    )

    # Clue 7: freelancer is somewhere between soul music and magic-tricks (not necessarily immediately)
    # That means freelancer is strictly between soul and magic-tricks or magic-tricks is strictly between soul and freelancer or soul is strictly between freelancer and magic-tricks
    # But the clue says freelancer is somewhere between soul and magic-tricks, so freelancer is between soul and magic-tricks
    # That means either (soul < freelancer < magic-tricks) or (magic-tricks < freelancer < soul)
    def freelancer_between(soul, freelancer, magic_tricks):
        return (soul < freelancer < magic_tricks) or (magic_tricks < freelancer < soul)
    problem.addConstraint(
        freelancer_between,
        ["Music:soul", "Job:freelancer", "Hobby:magic-tricks"]
    )

    # Clue 8: traveling is to the left of guinea-pig (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda traveling, guinea_pig: traveling < guinea_pig,
        ["Hobby:traveling", "Pet:guinea-pig"]
    )

    # Clue 9: guinea-pig immediately to the right of pony
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda guinea_pig, pony: guinea_pig == pony + 1,
        ["Pet:guinea-pig", "Pet:pony"]
    )

    # Clue 10: magic-tricks is the same person as cat
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda magic_tricks, cat: magic_tricks == cat,
        ["Hobby:magic-tricks", "Pet:cat"]
    )

    # Clue 11: magic-tricks immediately to the right of lime
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda magic_tricks, lime: magic_tricks == lime + 1,
        ["Hobby:magic-tricks", "Food:lime"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    # There should be only one solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format the solution as dictionary
    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Movie: romance, horror, documentary, crime, superhero
2. Transport: ship, scooter, car, subway, tram
3. Food: peach, carrot, nectarine, tomato, pepper
4. Pet: goldfish, cat, mouse, goat, turtle
5. Nationality: pakistani, japanese, british, egyptian, russian

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes crime movies is somewhere between the person who uses subway for transportation and the japanese person (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
2. the person who likes carrot is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes superhero movies
3. the person who likes peach is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes documentary movies
4. the russian person is at the same position as or to the right of the person who has goldfish as a pet
5. the japanese person is to the left of the british person (not necessarily immediately)
6. the person who uses subway for transportation is to the right of the person who uses car for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
7. the person who has turtle as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the british person
8. the person who likes documentary movies is somewhere between the person who uses tram for transportation and the person who likes tomato (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
9. the egyptian person and the person who has goldfish as a pet are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
10. the person who has goat as a pet and the person who likes documentary movies are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
11. the japanese person is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes nectarine
12. the person who likes nectarine and the person who uses tram for transportation are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
13. the egyptian person is to the left of the pakistani person (not necessarily immediately)
14. the person who has goat as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes crime movies
15. the person who likes horror movies is a different person than at least one of the person who likes nectarine or the person who uses car for transportation
16. the person who has mouse as a pet and the egyptian person are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
17. the person who has goldfish as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses car for transportation
18. the egyptian person is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes superhero movies
19. the egyptian person is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes horror movies
20. the person who has cat as a pet is the same person as the person who uses car for transportation or the person who likes documentary movies is the same person as the person who has cat as a pet or both
21. the person who uses scooter for transportation is to the right of the person who has goldfish as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
22. the person who has mouse as a pet is to the right of the person who uses subway for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
23. the british person is the same person as exactly one of the person who likes peach or the person who has goat as a pet
24. the person who uses scooter for transportation and the russian person are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Movie", "Transport", "Food", "Pet", "Nationality"]
    items = {
        "Movie": ["romance", "horror", "documentary", "crime", "superhero"],
        "Transport": ["ship", "scooter", "car", "subway", "tram"],
        "Food": ["peach", "carrot", "nectarine", "tomato", "pepper"],
        "Pet": ["goldfish", "cat", "mouse", "goat", "turtle"],
        "Nationality": ["pakistani", "japanese", "british", "egyptian", "russian"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain 0..4 (positions)
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(),
                              [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: crime movie is somewhere between subway and japanese (not necessarily adjacent)
    # That means crime is strictly between subway and japanese in position
    # So either subway < crime < japanese or japanese < crime < subway
    def clue1(subway, crime, japanese):
        return (subway < crime < japanese) or (japanese < crime < subway)
    problem.addConstraint(clue1,
                          ["Transport:subway", "Movie:crime", "Nationality:japanese"])

    # Clue 2: carrot is at same position or to right of superhero
    problem.addConstraint(lambda carrot, superhero: carrot >= superhero,
                          ["Food:carrot", "Movie:superhero"])

    # Clue 3: peach is at same position or to left of documentary
    problem.addConstraint(lambda peach, documentary: peach <= documentary,
                          ["Food:peach", "Movie:documentary"])

    # Clue 4: russian is at same position or to right of goldfish
    problem.addConstraint(lambda russian, goldfish: russian >= goldfish,
                          ["Nationality:russian", "Pet:goldfish"])

    # Clue 5: japanese is to left of british
    problem.addConstraint(lambda japanese, british: japanese < british,
                          ["Nationality:japanese", "Nationality:british"])

    # Clue 6: subway is to right of car
    problem.addConstraint(lambda subway, car: subway > car,
                          ["Transport:subway", "Transport:car"])

    # Clue 7: turtle is at same position or to left of british
    problem.addConstraint(lambda turtle, british: turtle <= british,
                          ["Pet:turtle", "Nationality:british"])

    # Clue 8: documentary is somewhere between tram and tomato (not necessarily adjacent)
    # documentary strictly between tram and tomato
    def clue8(tram, documentary, tomato):
        return (tram < documentary < tomato) or (tomato < documentary < tram)
    problem.addConstraint(clue8,
                          ["Transport:tram", "Movie:documentary", "Food:tomato"])

    # Clue 9: egyptian and goldfish at positions with same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda egyptian, goldfish: egyptian % 2 == goldfish % 2,
                          ["Nationality:egyptian", "Pet:goldfish"])

    # Clue 10: goat and documentary at positions with same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda goat, documentary: goat % 2 == documentary % 2,
                          ["Pet:goat", "Movie:documentary"])

    # Clue 11: japanese is at same position or to right of nectarine
    problem.addConstraint(lambda japanese, nectarine: japanese >= nectarine,
                          ["Nationality:japanese", "Food:nectarine"])

    # Clue 12: nectarine and tram at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda nectarine, tram: (nectarine % 2) != (tram % 2),
                          ["Food:nectarine", "Transport:tram"])

    # Clue 13: egyptian is to left of pakistani
    problem.addConstraint(lambda egyptian, pakistani: egyptian < pakistani,
                          ["Nationality:egyptian", "Nationality:pakistani"])

    # Clue 14: goat is at same position or to right of crime
    problem.addConstraint(lambda goat, crime: goat >= crime,
                          ["Pet:goat", "Movie:crime"])

    # Clue 15: horror is a different person than at least one of nectarine or car
    # That means horror != nectarine or horror != car (or both)
    def clue15(horror, nectarine, car):
        return horror != nectarine or horror != car
    problem.addConstraint(clue15,
                          ["Movie:horror", "Food:nectarine", "Transport:car"])

    # Clue 16: mouse and egyptian at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda mouse, egyptian: (mouse % 2) != (egyptian % 2),
                          ["Pet:mouse", "Nationality:egyptian"])

    # Clue 17: goldfish is at same position or to right of car
    problem.addConstraint(lambda goldfish, car: goldfish >= car,
                          ["Pet:goldfish", "Transport:car"])

    # Clue 18: egyptian is at same position or to left of superhero
    problem.addConstraint(lambda egyptian, superhero: egyptian <= superhero,
                          ["Nationality:egyptian", "Movie:superhero"])

    # Clue 19: egyptian is at same position or to right of horror
    problem.addConstraint(lambda egyptian, horror: egyptian >= horror,
                          ["Nationality:egyptian", "Movie:horror"])

    # Clue 20: cat is same person as car or documentary or both
    # cat == car or cat == documentary
    def clue20(cat, car, documentary):
        return cat == car or cat == documentary
    problem.addConstraint(clue20,
                          ["Pet:cat", "Transport:car", "Movie:documentary"])

    # Clue 21: scooter is to right of goldfish
    problem.addConstraint(lambda scooter, goldfish: scooter > goldfish,
                          ["Transport:scooter", "Pet:goldfish"])

    # Clue 22: mouse is to right of subway
    problem.addConstraint(lambda mouse, subway: mouse > subway,
                          ["Pet:mouse", "Transport:subway"])

    # Clue 23: british is same person as exactly one of peach or goat
    # That means (british == peach and british != goat) or (british != peach and british == goat)
    def clue23(british, peach, goat):
        return (british == peach and british != goat) or (british != peach and british == goat)
    problem.addConstraint(clue23,
                          ["Nationality:british", "Food:peach", "Pet:goat"])

    # Clue 24: scooter and russian at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda scooter, russian: (scooter % 2) != (russian % 2),
                          ["Transport:scooter", "Nationality:russian"])

    # Solve
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # Multiple solutions found; raise error
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Create a list of 5 empty strings
        pos_list = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            pos_list[pos] = item
        result[category] = pos_list

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 2 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Hobby: rock-climbing, baking, board-games, photography
2. Transport: tram, jet-ski, car, trike

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who uses tram for transportation is adjacent to the person who enjoys rock-climbing (either immediately left or right)
2. the person who uses tram for transportation is to the right of the person who uses car for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
3. the person who uses jet-ski for transportation is to the right of the person who uses tram for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
4. the person who uses jet-ski for transportation is the same person as the person who enjoys baking
5. the person who enjoys photography is to the right of the person who uses jet-ski for transportation (not necessarily immediately)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Hobby", "Transport").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Hobby", "Transport"]
    items = {
        "Hobby": ["rock-climbing", "baking", "board-games", "photography"],
        "Transport": ["tram", "jet-ski", "car", "trike"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(),
                              [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: tram adjacent to rock-climbing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda tram, rock_climbing: abs(tram - rock_climbing) == 1,
        ["Transport:tram", "Hobby:rock-climbing"]
    )

    # Clue 2: tram to the right of car (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda tram, car: tram > car,
        ["Transport:tram", "Transport:car"]
    )

    # Clue 3: jet-ski to the right of tram (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda jet_ski, tram: jet_ski > tram,
        ["Transport:jet-ski", "Transport:tram"]
    )

    # Clue 4: jet-ski same as baking
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda jet_ski, baking: jet_ski == baking,
        ["Transport:jet-ski", "Hobby:baking"]
    )

    # Clue 5: photography to the right of jet-ski (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda photography, jet_ski: photography > jet_ski,
        ["Hobby:photography", "Transport:jet-ski"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # There should be exactly one solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output
    result = {category: [""]*num_positions for category in categories}
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

4. Beverage: 7up, tea, cola, coffee, milk

1. the person who likes animation movies is to the right of the person who likes milk (not necessarily immediately)

3. the american person and the person who plays swimming are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
4. the person who likes cola is a different person than the person who plays climbing
5. the japanese person is to the left of the argentine person (not necessarily immediately)
6. the person who plays surfing and the person who likes animation movies are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)

8. the person who likes romance movies and the person who has ferret as a pet are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)

13. the mexican person is to the left of the person who has rat as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
14. the person who likes milk and the person who has ferret as a pet are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
15. the person who likes romance movies and the person who has hedgehog as a pet are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
16. the person who plays swimming is at the same position as or to the right of the person who plays surfing
17. the person who likes tea is to the left of the person who plays volleyball (not necessarily immediately)
18. the person who likes horror movies is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes animation movies
19. the person who likes 7up is the same person as exactly one of the american person or the person who has dog as a pet
20. the person who likes horror movies is to the right of the person who likes cola (not necessarily immediately)
21. the mexican person is the same person as at least one of the person who likes spy movies or the person who has rat as a pet
22. the mexican person is at the same position as or to the left of the person who plays climbing
23. the person who likes romance movies is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes mystery movies

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
