rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Hobby", "Job", "Movie", "Sport", "Transport"]
    items = {
        "Hobby": ["card-games", "board-games", "cooking", "puzzles", "chess"],
        "Job": ["police-officer", "firefighter", "fisherman", "manager", "doctor"],
        "Movie": ["scientific", "action", "mystery", "sports", "spy"],
        "Sport": ["climbing", "skiing", "rowing", "ice-hockey", "baseball"],
        "Transport": ["roller", "bike", "bus", "train", "jet-ski"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_cat)

    # Clue 1: bike and scientific same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bike, scientific: bike % 2 == scientific % 2,
        ["Transport:bike", "Movie:scientific"]
    )

    # Clue 2: board-games and spy same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda board_games, spy: board_games % 2 == spy % 2,
        ["Hobby:board-games", "Movie:spy"]
    )

    # Clue 3: chess to the left of puzzles
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda chess, puzzles: chess < puzzles,
        ["Hobby:chess", "Hobby:puzzles"]
    )

    # Clue 4: scientific same or right of firefighter
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda scientific, firefighter: scientific >= firefighter,
        ["Movie:scientific", "Job:firefighter"]
    )

    # Clue 5: bus to the right of fisherman
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bus, fisherman: bus > fisherman,
        ["Transport:bus", "Job:fisherman"]
    )

    # Clue 6: skiing and train same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skiing, train: skiing % 2 == train % 2,
        ["Sport:skiing", "Transport:train"]
    )

    # Clue 7: mystery is different from at least one of train or manager
    # Implemented as mystery != train OR mystery != manager
    def clue7(mystery, train, manager):
        return mystery != train or mystery != manager
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue7,
        ["Movie:mystery", "Transport:train", "Job:manager"]
    )

    # Clue 8: mystery and jet-ski same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda mystery, jetski: mystery % 2 == jetski % 2,
        ["Movie:mystery", "Transport:jet-ski"]
    )

    # Clue 9: spy to the right of mystery
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda spy, mystery: spy > mystery,
        ["Movie:spy", "Movie:mystery"]
    )

    # Clue 10: action at odd-numbered position (1-based odd means 0-based even)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda action: action % 2 == 0,
        ["Movie:action"]
    )

    # Clue 11: climbing and mystery same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda climbing, mystery: climbing % 2 == mystery % 2,
        ["Sport:climbing", "Movie:mystery"]
    )

    # Clue 12: rowing to the right of bus
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rowing, bus: rowing > bus,
        ["Sport:rowing", "Transport:bus"]
    )

    # Clue 13: doctor same person as exactly one of train or chess
    # Exactly one means XOR
    def clue13(doctor, train, chess):
        return (doctor == train) != (doctor == chess)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue13,
        ["Job:doctor", "Transport:train", "Hobby:chess"]
    )

    # Clue 14: police-officer and spy same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda police, spy: police % 2 == spy % 2,
        ["Job:police-officer", "Movie:spy"]
    )

    # Clue 15: sports same or left of chess
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda sports, chess: sports <= chess,
        ["Movie:sports", "Hobby:chess"]
    )

    # Clue 16: action same or right of jet-ski
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda action, jetski: action >= jetski,
        ["Movie:action", "Transport:jet-ski"]
    )

    # Clue 17: rowing to right of baseball
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rowing, baseball: rowing > baseball,
        ["Sport:rowing", "Sport:baseball"]
    )

    # Clue 18: skiing same person as at least one of jet-ski or doctor
    def clue18(skiing, jetski, doctor):
        return skiing == jetski or skiing == doctor
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue18,
        ["Sport:skiing", "Transport:jet-ski", "Job:doctor"]
    )

    # Clue 19: rowing different person than bus
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rowing, bus: rowing != bus,
        ["Sport:rowing", "Transport:bus"]
    )

    # Clue 20: police-officer same or right of manager
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda police, manager: police >= manager,
        ["Job:police-officer", "Job:manager"]
    )

    # Clue 21: roller same person as sports OR sports same person as fisherman, but not both
    # XOR between (roller==sports) and (sports==fisherman)
    def clue21(roller, sports, fisherman):
        return (roller == sports) != (sports == fisherman)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue21,
        ["Transport:roller", "Movie:sports", "Job:fisherman"]
    )

    # Clue 22: fisherman and jet-ski same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fisherman, jetski: fisherman % 2 == jetski % 2,
        ["Job:fisherman", "Transport:jet-ski"]
    )

    # Clue 23: bike same or right of jet-ski
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bike, jetski: bike >= jetski,
        ["Transport:bike", "Transport:jet-ski"]
    )

    # Clue 24: baseball to left of card-games
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda baseball, card_games: baseball < card_games,
        ["Sport:baseball", "Hobby:card-games"]
    )

    # Clue 25: board-games same person as jet-ski OR doctor same person as board-games, but not both
    # XOR between (board-games == jet-ski) and (doctor == board-games)
    def clue25(board_games, jetski, doctor):
        return (board_games == jetski) != (doctor == board_games)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue25,
        ["Hobby:board-games", "Transport:jet-ski", "Job:doctor"]
    )

    # Clue 26: train to left of puzzles
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda train, puzzles: train < puzzles,
        ["Transport:train", "Hobby:puzzles"]
    )

    # Clue 27: action different person than card-games
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda action, card_games: action != card_games,
        ["Movie:action", "Hobby:card-games"]
    )

    # Clue 28: (action != puzzles) OR (jet-ski != action) OR both
    # This is: NOT((action == puzzles) AND (jet-ski == action))
    def clue28(action, puzzles, jetski):
        return not (action == puzzles and jetski == action)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue28,
        ["Movie:action", "Hobby:puzzles", "Transport:jet-ski"]
    )

    # Clue 29: ice-hockey same person as at least one of scientific or train
    def clue29(ice_hockey, scientific, train):
        return ice_hockey == scientific or ice_hockey == train
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue29,
        ["Sport:ice-hockey", "Movie:scientific", "Transport:train"]
    )

    # Clue 30: ice-hockey to right of climbing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda ice_hockey, climbing: ice_hockey > climbing,
        ["Sport:ice-hockey", "Sport:climbing"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # Just pick first solution if multiple found
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    # Format solution dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Create list of items ordered by position
        positions = [None] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            positions[pos] = item
        result[category] = positions

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 2 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Beverage: fanta, water, cola, coffee
2. Nationality: thai, mexican, canadian, malaysian

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the canadian person is at position 1 (the leftmost position)
2. the person who likes water is immediately to the left of the mexican person
3. 0 is at position 4
4. the mexican person is immediately to the right of the malaysian person
5. the person who likes water is immediately to the right of the person who likes coffee
6. the canadian person is the same person as the person who likes coffee

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Nationality").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Beverage", "Nationality"]
    items = {
        "Beverage": ["fanta", "water", "cola", "coffee"],
        "Nationality": ["thai", "mexican", "canadian", "malaysian"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All different constraints within each category
    for category in categories:
        category_items = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_items)

    # Clue 1: the canadian person is at position 1 (0-indexed position 0)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda canadian: canadian == 0, ["Nationality:canadian"])

    # Clue 2: the person who likes water is immediately to the left of the mexican person
    problem.addConstraint(lambda water, mexican: water == mexican - 1, ["Beverage:water", "Nationality:mexican"])

    # Clue 3: the item "0" is at position 4 (position 3)
    # This clue is ambiguous as "0" is not defined, so we ignore it.

    # Clue 4: the mexican person is immediately to the right of the malaysian person
    problem.addConstraint(lambda mexican, malaysian: mexican == malaysian + 1, ["Nationality:mexican", "Nationality:malaysian"])

    # Clue 5: the person who likes water is immediately to the right of the person who likes coffee
    problem.addConstraint(lambda water, coffee: water == coffee + 1, ["Beverage:water", "Beverage:coffee"])

    # Clue 6: the canadian person is the same person as the person who likes coffee
    problem.addConstraint(lambda canadian, coffee: canadian == coffee, ["Nationality:canadian", "Beverage:coffee"])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # Take the first solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            position = solution[variable_name]
            result_dict[category][position] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: superhero movie is to the right of water-polo (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda superhero, water_polo: superhero > water_polo,
        ["Movie:superhero", "Sport:water-polo"]
    )

    # Clue 2: golf is at an even-numbered position (positions 0-based, so even means 1 or 3)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda golf: golf in [1,3],
        ["Sport:golf"]
    )

    # Clue 3: drama movie is immediately to the right of hedgehog pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda drama, hedgehog: drama == hedgehog + 1,
        ["Movie:drama", "Pet:hedgehog"]
    )

    # Clue 4: peach food is same person as goldfish pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda peach, goldfish: peach == goldfish,
        ["Food:peach", "Pet:goldfish"]
    )

    # Clue 5: tomato food is directly between pomegranate food and skateboarding sport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda tomato, pomegranate, skateboarding: 
            (tomato == pomegranate + 1 and tomato == skateboarding - 1) or 
            (tomato == skateboarding + 1 and tomato == pomegranate - 1),
        ["Food:tomato", "Food:pomegranate", "Sport:skateboarding"]
    )

    # Clue 6: hedgehog pet is immediately to the left of lemon food
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda hedgehog, lemon: hedgehog == lemon - 1,
        ["Pet:hedgehog", "Food:lemon"]
    )

    # Clue 7: climbing sport is at same position or to the left of snake pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda climbing, snake: climbing <= snake,
        ["Sport:climbing", "Pet:snake"]
    )

    # Clue 8: pony pet is directly between skateboarding sport and climbing sport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pony, skateboarding, climbing: 
            (pony == skateboarding + 1 and pony == climbing - 1) or 
            (pony == climbing + 1 and pony == skateboarding - 1),
        ["Pet:pony", "Sport:skateboarding", "Sport:climbing"]
    )

    # Clue 9: snake pet is somewhere between crime movie and golf sport (not necessarily adjacent)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda crime, snake, golf: (crime < snake < golf) or (golf < snake < crime),
        ["Movie:crime", "Pet:snake", "Sport:golf"]
    )

    # Clue 10: rabbit pet is at same position or to the right of sailing sport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rabbit, sailing: rabbit >= sailing,
        ["Pet:rabbit", "Sport:sailing"]
    )

    # Clue 11: zombie movie is at same position or to the left of sailing sport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda zombie, sailing: zombie <= sailing,
        ["Movie:zombie", "Sport:sailing"]
    )

    # Clue 12: lemon food is at same position or to the left of peach food
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lemon, peach: lemon <= peach,
        ["Food:lemon", "Food:peach"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[var]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Nationality: american, indonesian, japanese, british
2. Transport: helicopter, roller, taxi, tram
3. Sport: cycling, volleyball, water-polo, baseball
4. Movie: drama, documentary, family, disaster
5. Job: police-officer, coach, photographer, pilot

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who plays cycling is to the left of the person who uses helicopter for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
2. the person who works as a photographer is directly between the person who uses tram for transportation and the person who works as a coach
3. the person who plays baseball is to the right of the person who likes documentary movies (not necessarily immediately)
4. the person who plays cycling is the same person as at least one of the person who likes disaster movies or the american person
5. the british person is somewhere between the indonesian person and the person who likes family movies (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
6. the person who uses helicopter for transportation is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
7. the person who plays volleyball and the person who likes documentary movies are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
8. the american person and the person who likes disaster movies are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
9. the person who works as a coach is to the left of the person who likes family movies (not necessarily immediately)
10. the person who likes documentary movies is to the right of the person who works as a pilot (not necessarily immediately)
11. the indonesian person is immediately to the right of the person who likes drama movies
12. the person who uses roller for transportation is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes disaster movies
13. the person who uses tram for transportation is adjacent to the person who plays volleyball (either immediately left or right)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Job", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Nationality", "Transport", "Sport", "Movie", "Job"]
    items = {
        "Nationality": ["american", "indonesian", "japanese", "british"],
        "Transport": ["helicopter", "roller", "taxi", "tram"],
        "Sport": ["cycling", "volleyball", "water-polo", "baseball"],
        "Movie": ["drama", "documentary", "family", "disaster"],
        "Job": ["police-officer", "coach", "photographer", "pilot"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # AllDifferent constraints per category
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: cycling is to the left of helicopter (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cycling, helicopter: cycling < helicopter,
        ["Sport:cycling", "Transport:helicopter"]
    )

    # Clue 2: photographer is directly between tram and coach
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda photographer, tram, coach: (photographer == tram + 1 and photographer == coach - 1) or (photographer == tram - 1 and photographer == coach + 1),
        ["Job:photographer", "Transport:tram", "Job:coach"]
    )

    # Clue 3: baseball is to the right of documentary (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda baseball, documentary: baseball > documentary,
        ["Sport:baseball", "Movie:documentary"]
    )

    # Clue 4: cycling is the same person as at least one of disaster or american
    # i.e. cycling == disaster or cycling == american
    # We model this as cycling == disaster or cycling == american
    def clue4(cycling, disaster, american):
        return cycling == disaster or cycling == american
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue4,
        ["Sport:cycling", "Movie:disaster", "Nationality:american"]
    )

    # Clue 5: british is somewhere between indonesian and family (not necessarily adjacent)
    # means british is between indonesian and family: either (indonesian < british < family) or (family < british < indonesian)
    def clue5(british, indonesian, family):
        return (indonesian < british < family) or (family < british < indonesian)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue5,
        ["Nationality:british", "Nationality:indonesian", "Movie:family"]
    )

    # Clue 6: helicopter is at an end position (0 or 3)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda helicopter: helicopter == 0 or helicopter == num_positions - 1,
        ["Transport:helicopter"]
    )

    # Clue 7: volleyball and documentary have same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda volleyball, documentary: volleyball % 2 == documentary % 2,
        ["Sport:volleyball", "Movie:documentary"]
    )

    # Clue 8: american and disaster have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda american, disaster: (american % 2) != (disaster % 2),
        ["Nationality:american", "Movie:disaster"]
    )

    # Clue 9: coach is to the left of family (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda coach, family: coach < family,
        ["Job:coach", "Movie:family"]
    )

    # Clue 10: documentary is to the right of pilot (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda documentary, pilot: documentary > pilot,
        ["Movie:documentary", "Job:pilot"]
    )

    # Clue 11: indonesian is immediately to the right of drama
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda indonesian, drama: indonesian == drama + 1,
        ["Nationality:indonesian", "Movie:drama"]
    )

    # Clue 12: roller is at the same position as or to the right of disaster
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda roller, disaster: roller >= disaster,
        ["Transport:roller", "Movie:disaster"]
    )

    # Clue 13: tram is adjacent to volleyball (either immediately left or right)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda tram, volleyball: abs(tram - volleyball) == 1,
        ["Transport:tram", "Sport:volleyball"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format the solution dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Hobby", "Sport", "Transport", "Pet", "Food"]
    items = {
        "Hobby": ["woodworking", "traveling", "chess", "sudoku", "gardening"],
        "Sport": ["ice-hockey", "climbing", "golf", "lacrosse", "badminton"],
        "Transport": ["bike", "trike", "skateboard", "car", "snowmobile"],
        "Pet": ["goldfish", "frog", "pony", "bird", "rabbit"],
        "Food": ["apple", "lettuce", "onion", "pear", "papaya"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain 0..4 (positions)
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: ice-hockey >= bike
    problem.addConstraint(lambda ih, b: ih >= b, ["Sport:ice-hockey", "Transport:bike"])

    # Clue 2: papaya <= trike
    problem.addConstraint(lambda p, t: p <= t, ["Food:papaya", "Transport:trike"])

    # Clue 3: bird >= lacrosse
    problem.addConstraint(lambda b, l: b >= l, ["Pet:bird", "Sport:lacrosse"])

    # Clue 4: skateboard != frog or lettuce != skateboard or both
    # This is equivalent to: not (skateboard == frog and lettuce == skateboard)
    def clue4(skateboard, frog, lettuce):
        return not (skateboard == frog and lettuce == skateboard)
    problem.addConstraint(clue4, ["Transport:skateboard", "Pet:frog", "Food:lettuce"])

    # Clue 5: sudoku and goldfish same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda s, g: s % 2 == g % 2, ["Hobby:sudoku", "Pet:goldfish"])

    # Clue 6: apple <= trike
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, t: a <= t, ["Food:apple", "Transport:trike"])

    # Clue 7: bike is between pony and bird (not necessarily adjacent)
    # So bike > min(pony,bird) and bike < max(pony,bird)
    def clue7(bike, pony, bird):
        return (bike > min(pony, bird)) and (bike < max(pony, bird))
    problem.addConstraint(clue7, ["Transport:bike", "Pet:pony", "Pet:bird"])

    # Clue 8: onion <= skateboard
    problem.addConstraint(lambda o, s: o <= s, ["Food:onion", "Transport:skateboard"])

    # Clue 9: bike != sudoku or bike != lacrosse or both
    # Equivalent to: not (bike == sudoku and bike == lacrosse)
    def clue9(bike, sudoku, lacrosse):
        return not (bike == sudoku == lacrosse)
    problem.addConstraint(clue9, ["Transport:bike", "Hobby:sudoku", "Sport:lacrosse"])

    # Clue 10: traveling is between climbing and lettuce (not necessarily adjacent)
    def clue10(traveling, climbing, lettuce):
        return (traveling > min(climbing, lettuce)) and (traveling < max(climbing, lettuce))
    problem.addConstraint(clue10, ["Hobby:traveling", "Sport:climbing", "Food:lettuce"])

    # Clue 11: bird != woodworking
    problem.addConstraint(lambda b, w: b != w, ["Pet:bird", "Hobby:woodworking"])

    # Clue 12: apple == climbing or skateboard == apple or both
    # So at least one of (apple==climbing), (skateboard==apple)
    def clue12(apple, climbing, skateboard):
        return (apple == climbing) or (skateboard == apple)
    problem.addConstraint(clue12, ["Food:apple", "Sport:climbing", "Transport:skateboard"])

    # Clue 13: woodworking same as exactly one of trike or frog
    # So woodworking == trike xor woodworking == frog
    def clue13(woodworking, trike, frog):
        return (woodworking == trike) != (woodworking == frog)
    problem.addConstraint(clue13, ["Hobby:woodworking", "Transport:trike", "Pet:frog"])

    # Clue 14: goldfish <= pony
    problem.addConstraint(lambda g, p: g <= p, ["Pet:goldfish", "Pet:pony"])

    # Clue 15: skateboard != pear or skateboard != woodworking or both
    # not (skateboard == pear and skateboard == woodworking)
    def clue15(skateboard, pear, woodworking):
        return not (skateboard == pear and skateboard == woodworking)
    problem.addConstraint(clue15, ["Transport:skateboard", "Food:pear", "Hobby:woodworking"])

    # Clue 16: pear != rabbit
    problem.addConstraint(lambda pear, rabbit: pear != rabbit, ["Food:pear", "Pet:rabbit"])

    # Clue 17: papaya <= climbing
    problem.addConstraint(lambda papaya, climbing: papaya <= climbing, ["Food:papaya", "Sport:climbing"])

    # Clue 18: snowmobile == pony or climbing == snowmobile or both
    # So at least one of (snowmobile==pony), (climbing==snowmobile)
    def clue18(snowmobile, pony, climbing):
        return (snowmobile == pony) or (climbing == snowmobile)
    problem.addConstraint(clue18, ["Transport:snowmobile", "Pet:pony", "Sport:climbing"])

    # Clue 19: badminton and apple same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda badminton, apple: badminton % 2 == apple % 2, ["Sport:badminton", "Food:apple"])

    # Clue 20: pony != lettuce
    problem.addConstraint(lambda pony, lettuce: pony != lettuce, ["Pet:pony", "Food:lettuce"])

    # Clue 21: traveling <= rabbit
    problem.addConstraint(lambda traveling, rabbit: traveling <= rabbit, ["Hobby:traveling", "Pet:rabbit"])

    # Clue 22: lacrosse <= lacrosse (always true, redundant)
    # No constraint needed.

    # Clue 23: goldfish and woodworking different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda g, w: (g % 2) != (w % 2), ["Pet:goldfish", "Hobby:woodworking"])

    # Clue 24: pony == golf xor pony == bike
    def clue24(pony, golf, bike):
        return (pony == golf) != (pony == bike)
    problem.addConstraint(clue24, ["Pet:pony", "Sport:golf", "Transport:bike"])

    # Clue 25: pony and apple different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda pony, apple: (pony % 2) != (apple % 2), ["Pet:pony", "Food:apple"])

    # Clue 26: lettuce is between pear and traveling (not necessarily adjacent)
    def clue26(lettuce, pear, traveling):
        return (lettuce > min(pear, traveling)) and (lettuce < max(pear, traveling))
    problem.addConstraint(clue26, ["Food:lettuce", "Food:pear", "Hobby:traveling"])

    # Clue 27: bird == sudoku or bird == onion or both
    def clue27(bird, sudoku, onion):
        return (bird == sudoku) or (bird == onion)
    problem.addConstraint(clue27, ["Pet:bird", "Hobby:sudoku", "Food:onion"])

    # Clue 28: goldfish != papaya
    problem.addConstraint(lambda g, p: g != p, ["Pet:goldfish", "Food:papaya"])

    # Clue 29: pear <= frog
    problem.addConstraint(lambda pear, frog: pear <= frog, ["Food:pear", "Pet:frog"])

    # Clue 30: chess != golf
    problem.addConstraint(lambda chess, golf: chess != golf, ["Hobby:chess", "Sport:golf"])

    # Clue 31: pony and trike different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda pony, trike: (pony % 2) != (trike % 2), ["Pet:pony", "Transport:trike"])

    # Clue 32: gardening and skateboard different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda gardening, skateboard: (gardening % 2) != (skateboard % 2), ["Hobby:gardening", "Transport:skateboard"])

    # Clue 33: gardening and apple different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda gardening, apple: (gardening % 2) != (apple % 2), ["Hobby:gardening", "Food:apple"])

    # Solve
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dict
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

        "Sport": ["skateboarding", "rowing", "weightlifting", "soccer", "biathlon"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: plum immediately to the left of pilot
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda plum, pilot: plum == pilot - 1,
        ["Food:plum", "Job:pilot"]
    )

    # Clue 2: architect directly between soccer and skateboarding
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda architect, soccer, skateboarding: (architect == soccer + 1 and architect == skateboarding - 1) or (architect == skateboarding + 1 and architect == soccer - 1),
        ["Job:architect", "Sport:soccer", "Sport:skateboarding"]
    )

    # Clue 3: kale to the left of security-guard (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda kale, security_guard: kale < security_guard,
        ["Food:kale", "Job:security-guard"]
    )

    # Clue 4: pineapple directly between traveling and soccer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pineapple, traveling, soccer: (pineapple == traveling + 1 and pineapple == soccer - 1) or (pineapple == soccer + 1 and pineapple == traveling - 1),
        ["Food:pineapple", "Hobby:traveling", "Sport:soccer"]
    )

    # Clue 5: skydiving same person as architect
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skydiving, architect: skydiving == architect,
        ["Hobby:skydiving", "Job:architect"]
    )

    # Clue 6: weightlifting same person as filmmaking
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda weightlifting, filmmaking: weightlifting == filmmaking,
        ["Sport:weightlifting", "Hobby:filmmaking"]
    )

    # Clue 7: rowing adjacent to chef
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rowing, chef: abs(rowing - chef) == 1,
        ["Sport:rowing", "Job:chef"]
    )

    # Clue 8: singing to the right of rowing (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda singing, rowing: singing > rowing,
        ["Hobby:singing", "Sport:rowing"]
    )

    # Clue 9: pilot to the left of rowing (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pilot, rowing: pilot < rowing,
        ["Job:pilot", "Sport:rowing"]
    )

    # Clue 10: grapefruit same person as rowing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda grapefruit, rowing: grapefruit == rowing,
        ["Food:grapefruit", "Sport:rowing"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Hobby: sudoku, gardening, video-games, board-games, filmmaking
2. Sport: ice-hockey, golf, cricket, rugby, biathlon
3. Job: doctor, designer, analyst, lawyer, pilot
4. Transport: scooter, subway, bike, quad-bike, trike

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who works as a doctor is the same person as the person who plays cricket
2. the person who uses trike for transportation is the same person as the person who works as a analyst
3. the person who uses scooter for transportation is immediately to the right of the person who uses bike for transportation
4. the person who enjoys sudoku is the same person as the person who works as a doctor or the person who uses scooter for transportation is the same person as the person who enjoys sudoku, but not both
5. the person who enjoys board-games is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses quad-bike for transportation
6. the person who plays ice-hockey is immediately to the right of the person who works as a pilot
7. the person who enjoys gardening and the person who works as a doctor are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
8. the person who plays rugby is at the same position as or to the left of the person who plays biathlon
9. the person who plays rugby and the person who uses bike for transportation are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
10. the person who uses quad-bike for transportation is somewhere between the person who enjoys sudoku and the person who enjoys video-games (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
11. the person who works as a designer is at the same position as or to the right of the person who plays biathlon
12. the person who enjoys filmmaking is at the same position as or to the right of the person who plays biathlon
13. the person who works as a pilot is the same person as the person who uses subway for transportation
14. the person who works as a analyst is the same person as the person who plays rugby or the person who enjoys board-games is the same person as the person who works as a analyst or both

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Hobby", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Hobby", "Sport", "Job", "Transport"]
    items = {
        "Hobby": ["sudoku", "gardening", "video-games", "board-games", "filmmaking"],
        "Sport": ["ice-hockey", "golf", "cricket", "rugby", "biathlon"],
        "Job": ["doctor", "designer", "analyst", "lawyer", "pilot"],
        "Transport": ["scooter", "subway", "bike", "quad-bike", "trike"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All different constraints in each category
    for category in categories:
        vars_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_cat)

    # Clue 1: doctor == cricket
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda doctor, cricket: doctor == cricket,
        ["Job:doctor", "Sport:cricket"]
    )

    # Clue 2: trike == analyst
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda trike, analyst: trike == analyst,
        ["Transport:trike", "Job:analyst"]
    )

    # Clue 3: scooter immediately right of bike
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda scooter, bike: scooter == bike + 1,
        ["Transport:scooter", "Transport:bike"]
    )

    # Clue 4: sudoku == doctor XOR scooter == sudoku (exclusive or)
    def clue4(sudoku, doctor, scooter):
        return (sudoku == doctor) != (scooter == sudoku)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue4,
        ["Hobby:sudoku", "Job:doctor", "Transport:scooter"]
    )

    # Clue 5: board-games >= quad-bike
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda board_games, quad_bike: board_games >= quad_bike,
        ["Hobby:board-games", "Transport:quad-bike"]
    )

    # Clue 6: ice-hockey immediately right of pilot
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda ice_hockey, pilot: ice_hockey == pilot + 1,
        ["Sport:ice-hockey", "Job:pilot"]
    )

    # Clue 7: gardening and doctor positions have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda gardening, doctor: (gardening % 2) != (doctor % 2),
        ["Hobby:gardening", "Job:doctor"]
    )

    # Clue 8: rugby <= biathlon
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rugby, biathlon: rugby <= biathlon,
        ["Sport:rugby", "Sport:biathlon"]
    )

    # Clue 9: rugby and bike have same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rugby, bike: (rugby % 2) == (bike % 2),
        ["Sport:rugby", "Transport:bike"]
    )

    # Clue 10: quad-bike is somewhere between sudoku and video-games
    def clue10(quad_bike, sudoku, video_games):
        # quad-bike is strictly between sudoku and video-games
        return (sudoku < quad_bike < video_games) or (video_games < quad_bike < sudoku)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue10,
        ["Transport:quad-bike", "Hobby:sudoku", "Hobby:video-games"]
    )

    # Clue 11: designer >= biathlon
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda designer, biathlon: designer >= biathlon,
        ["Job:designer", "Sport:biathlon"]
    )

    # Clue 12: filmmaking >= biathlon
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda filmmaking, biathlon: filmmaking >= biathlon,
        ["Hobby:filmmaking", "Sport:biathlon"]
    )

    # Clue 13: pilot == subway
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pilot, subway: pilot == subway,
        ["Job:pilot", "Transport:subway"]
    )

    # Clue 14: analyst == rugby or board-games == analyst or both
    def clue14(analyst, rugby, board_games):
        return (analyst == rugby) or (board_games == analyst)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue14,
        ["Job:analyst", "Sport:rugby", "Hobby:board-games"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # In case multiple solutions, pick first
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {category: [""] * num_positions for category in categories}
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Pet: turtle, pony, snake, hamster, chinchilla
2. Nationality: russian, dutch, french, malaysian, australian
3. Transport: bus, van, jet-ski, airplane, snowmobile
4. Job: coach, nurse, musician, doctor, paramedic
5. Beverage: mirinda, soy-milk, hot-chocolate, coffee, 7up

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes soy-milk is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes hot-chocolate
2. the russian person is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes mirinda
3. the malaysian person is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes hot-chocolate
4. the person who uses snowmobile for transportation is somewhere between the person who works as a doctor and the person who works as a coach (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
5. the person who likes mirinda is the same person as at least one of the russian person or the person who uses airplane for transportation
6. the dutch person is at the same position as or to the right of the malaysian person
7. the person who works as a musician is at the same position as or to the left of the russian person
8. the malaysian person is somewhere between the french person and the dutch person (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
9. the french person is the same person as the person who has pony as a pet or the person who has pony as a pet is the same person as the person who uses van for transportation or both
10. the person who works as a doctor is at the same position as or to the right of the person who has chinchilla as a pet
11. the person who works as a musician is at the same position as or to the right of the person who has turtle as a pet
12. the person who uses van for transportation is at the same position as or to the left of the malaysian person
13. the dutch person is at the same position as or to the left of the person who has snake as a pet
14. the person who has snake as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who has turtle as a pet
15. the person who works as a coach is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses airplane for transportation
16. the person who likes soy-milk is the same person as the dutch person or the person who uses bus for transportation is the same person as the person who likes soy-milk or both
17. the person who works as a nurse is at the same position as or to the left of the malaysian person
18. the person who likes soy-milk is a different person than the person who has snake as a pet or the person who uses snowmobile for transportation is a different person than the person who likes soy-milk or both
19. the russian person is somewhere between the person who likes coffee and the person who works as a nurse (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
20. the person who uses airplane for transportation is the same person as at least one of the person who works as a musician or the russian person

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.

from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Pet", "Nationality", "Transport", "Job", "Beverage"]
    items = {
        "Pet": ["turtle", "pony", "snake", "hamster", "chinchilla"],
        "Nationality": ["russian", "dutch", "french", "malaysian", "australian"],
        "Transport": ["bus", "van", "jet-ski", "airplane", "snowmobile"],
        "Job": ["coach", "nurse", "musician", "doctor", "paramedic"],
        "Beverage": ["mirinda", "soy-milk", "hot-chocolate", "coffee", "7up"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be in different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Helper function for "somewhere between" (not necessarily immediately)
    def somewhere_between(x, y, z):
        return (y < x < z) or (z < x < y)

    # Clue 1: soy-milk is same position or to the right of hot-chocolate
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda soy_milk, hot_chocolate: soy_milk >= hot_chocolate,
        ["Beverage:soy-milk", "Beverage:hot-chocolate"]
    )

    # Clue 2: russian is same position or to the left of mirinda
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda russian, mirinda: russian <= mirinda,
        ["Nationality:russian", "Beverage:mirinda"]
    )

    # Clue 3: malaysian is same position or to the right of hot-chocolate
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda malaysian, hot_chocolate: malaysian >= hot_chocolate,
        ["Nationality:malaysian", "Beverage:hot-chocolate"]
    )

    # Clue 4: snowmobile is somewhere between doctor and coach (not necessarily adjacent)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda snowmobile, doctor, coach: somewhere_between(snowmobile, doctor, coach),
        ["Transport:snowmobile", "Job:doctor", "Job:coach"]
    )

    # Clue 5: mirinda is same person as at least one of russian or airplane
    def mirinda_constraint(mirinda, russian, airplane):
        return mirinda == russian or mirinda == airplane
    problem.addConstraint(
        mirinda_constraint,
        ["Beverage:mirinda", "Nationality:russian", "Transport:airplane"]
    )

    # Clue 6: dutch is same position or to the right of malaysian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dutch, malaysian: dutch >= malaysian,
        ["Nationality:dutch", "Nationality:malaysian"]
    )

    # Clue 7: musician is same position or to the left of russian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda musician, russian: musician <= russian,
        ["Job:musician", "Nationality:russian"]
    )

    # Clue 8: malaysian is somewhere between french and dutch
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda malaysian, french, dutch: somewhere_between(malaysian, french, dutch),
        ["Nationality:malaysian", "Nationality:french", "Nationality:dutch"]
    )

    # Clue 9: french is same person as pony or pony is same person as van or both
    # So french == pony or pony == van or (french == pony and pony == van)
    # Which means: french == pony or pony == van
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda french, pony, van: french == pony or pony == van,
        ["Nationality:french", "Pet:pony", "Transport:van"]
    )

    # Clue 10: doctor is same position or to the right of chinchilla
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda doctor, chinchilla: doctor >= chinchilla,
        ["Job:doctor", "Pet:chinchilla"]
    )

    # Clue 11: musician is same position or to the right of turtle
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda musician, turtle: musician >= turtle,
        ["Job:musician", "Pet:turtle"]
    )

    # Clue 12: van is same position or to the left of malaysian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda van, malaysian: van <= malaysian,
        ["Transport:van", "Nationality:malaysian"]
    )

    # Clue 13: dutch is same position or to the left of snake
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dutch, snake: dutch <= snake,
        ["Nationality:dutch", "Pet:snake"]
    )

    # Clue 14: snake is same position or to the left of turtle
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda snake, turtle: snake <= turtle,
        ["Pet:snake", "Pet:turtle"]
    )

    # Clue 15: coach is same position or to the right of airplane
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda coach, airplane: coach >= airplane,
        ["Job:coach", "Transport:airplane"]
    )

    # Clue 16: soy-milk is same person as dutch or bus is same person as soy-milk or both
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda soy_milk, dutch, bus: soy_milk == dutch or bus == soy_milk,
        ["Beverage:soy-milk", "Nationality:dutch", "Transport:bus"]
    )

    # Clue 17: nurse is same position or to the left of malaysian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda nurse, malaysian: nurse <= malaysian,
        ["Job:nurse", "Nationality:malaysian"]
    )

    # Clue 18: soy-milk different person than snake or snowmobile different person than soy-milk or both
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda soy_milk, snake, snowmobile: soy_milk != snake or snowmobile != soy_milk,
        ["Beverage:soy-milk", "Pet:snake", "Transport:snowmobile"]
    )

    # Clue 19: russian is somewhere between coffee and nurse
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda russian, coffee, nurse: somewhere_between(russian, coffee, nurse),
        ["Nationality:russian", "Beverage:coffee", "Job:nurse"]
    )

    # Clue 20: airplane is same person as musician or russian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda airplane, musician, russian: airplane == musician or airplane == russian,
        ["Transport:airplane", "Job:musician", "Nationality:russian"]
    )

    # Solve
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # There might be multiple solutions, but puzzle assumed unique
        # Pick first anyway
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [None] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 3 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 2 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 3 unique items:

1. Transport: roller, bus, subway
2. Movie: mystery, horror, documentary

Each category has exactly 3 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. 0 is at the center position (position 2)
2. the person who likes horror movies is immediately to the right of the person who likes mystery movies
3. the person who likes mystery movies is directly between the person who uses subway for transportation and the person who likes horror movies

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Movie", "Transport").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 3  # positions 0,1,2

    categories = ["Transport", "Movie"]
    items = {
        "Transport": ["roller", "bus", "subway"],
        "Movie": ["mystery", "horror", "documentary"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain 0..2
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_category = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_category)

    # Clue 1: 0 is at the center position (position 2)
    # The person at position 2 is the center (0-based index 1)
    # The puzzle says "0 is at center position (position 2)" 
    # We interpret position 2 as 1-based indexing, so position 2 means index 1 in 0-based
    # So the person at index 1 is the center
    # But clue says "0 is at center position (position 2)", meaning the person at position 2 (index 1) is person 0
    # Since the puzzle only has items, no explicit person variable, we interpret that the person at position 1 is the center
    # So position 1 is center, so we can say the person at position 1 is the center
    # Since we have no person variable, this clue means that the center position is position 1 (0-based)
    # So we fix that the center position is position 1. But the clue is somewhat ambiguous.
    # Assuming it means the center position is position 1 (0-based), so the middle position is position 1.
    # So we can set that the middle position is position 1 (which is natural), so no variable constraint needed.
    # So no constraint needed here, as we already use 0-based indexing and positions 0,1,2.

    # Clue 2: the person who likes horror movies is immediately to the right of the person who likes mystery movies
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda horror, mystery: horror == mystery + 1,
        ["Movie:horror", "Movie:mystery"]
    )

    # Clue 3: the person who likes mystery movies is directly between the person who uses subway for transportation and the person who likes horror movies
    # "directly between" means mystery position is one more than subway and one less than horror OR vice versa
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda mystery, subway, horror: (mystery == subway + 1 and mystery == horror -1) or (mystery == horror +1 and mystery == subway -1),
        ["Movie:mystery", "Transport:subway", "Movie:horror"]
    )

    # Solve
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # There should be exactly one solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {category: [""] * num_positions for category in categories}
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()
