    items = {
        "Hobby": ["writing", "fishing", "chess", "magic-tricks", "singing"],
        "Food": ["asparagus", "apricot", "lettuce", "papaya", "garlic"],
        "Transport": ["roller", "bus", "tram", "scooter", "taxi"],
        "Sport": ["surfing", "ice-hockey", "lacrosse", "rugby", "tennis"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must occupy different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_vars = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_vars)

    # Clue 1: singing and roller have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda singing, roller: (singing % 2) != (roller % 2),
                          ["Hobby:singing", "Transport:roller"])

    # Clue 2: asparagus and magic-tricks have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda asparagus, magic: (asparagus % 2) != (magic % 2),
                          ["Food:asparagus", "Hobby:magic-tricks"])

    # Clue 3: papaya is at the same position or to the right of magic-tricks
    problem.addConstraint(lambda papaya, magic: papaya >= magic,
                          ["Food:papaya", "Hobby:magic-tricks"])

    # Clue 4: rugby is to the right of ice-hockey (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rugby, ice_hockey: rugby > ice_hockey,
                          ["Sport:rugby", "Sport:ice-hockey"])

    # Clue 5: tram is at the same position or to the left of singing
    problem.addConstraint(lambda tram, singing: tram <= singing,
                          ["Transport:tram", "Hobby:singing"])

    # Clue 6: writing and lettuce are the same person
    problem.addConstraint(lambda writing, lettuce: writing == lettuce,
                          ["Hobby:writing", "Food:lettuce"])

    # Clue 7: roller is to the right of taxi
    problem.addConstraint(lambda roller, taxi: roller > taxi,
                          ["Transport:roller", "Transport:taxi"])

    # Clue 8: singing is immediately to the right of magic-tricks
    problem.addConstraint(lambda singing, magic: singing == magic + 1,
                          ["Hobby:singing", "Hobby:magic-tricks"])

    # Clue 9: taxi is to the right of bus
    problem.addConstraint(lambda taxi, bus: taxi > bus,
                          ["Transport:taxi", "Transport:bus"])

    # Clue 10: rugby is to the left of tram
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rugby, tram: rugby < tram,
                          ["Sport:rugby", "Transport:tram"])

    # Clue 11: lacrosse and apricot are the same person
    problem.addConstraint(lambda lacrosse, apricot: lacrosse == apricot,
                          ["Sport:lacrosse", "Food:apricot"])

    # Clue 12: roller is adjacent to apricot
    problem.addConstraint(lambda roller, apricot: abs(roller - apricot) == 1,
                          ["Transport:roller", "Food:apricot"])

    # Clue 13: singing is at the same position or to the left of tennis
    problem.addConstraint(lambda singing, tennis: singing <= tennis,
                          ["Hobby:singing", "Sport:tennis"])

    # Clue 14: scooter is adjacent to roller
    problem.addConstraint(lambda scooter, roller: abs(scooter - roller) == 1,
                          ["Transport:scooter", "Transport:roller"])

    # Clue 15: asparagus is somewhere between fishing and tram (not necessarily immediately)
    # That means asparagus is strictly between fishing and tram
    # So either fishing < asparagus < tram or tram < asparagus < fishing
    def between(asparagus, fishing, tram):
        return (fishing < asparagus < tram) or (tram < asparagus < fishing)
    problem.addConstraint(between,
                          ["Food:asparagus", "Hobby:fishing", "Transport:tram"])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # According to instructions, only one solution expected
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[variable_name]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Music: house, indie, d&b, folk, punk
2. Sport: ice-hockey, swimming, parkour, cycling, water-polo
3. Food: asparagus, spinach, nectarine, pumpkin, pear
4. Movie: horror, adventure, thriller, time-travel, superhero
5. Beverage: juice, almond-milk, mirinda, hot-chocolate, sprite

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes punk music is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes folk music
2. the person who likes house music is at the same position as or to the right of the person who plays ice-hockey
3. the person who likes hot-chocolate and the person who likes pear are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
4. the person who likes house music and the person who plays cycling are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
5. the person who likes folk music is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes indie music
6. the person who plays cycling is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes time-travel movies
7. the person who likes pear is a different person than the person who plays ice-hockey
8. the person who likes time-travel movies is somewhere between the person who likes juice and the person who likes d&b music (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
9. the person who plays swimming is at the same position as or to the left of the person who plays water-polo
10. the person who plays swimming is at the same position as or to the right of the person who plays ice-hockey
11. the person who likes spinach is a different person than the person who plays swimming or the person who likes house music is a different person than the person who likes spinach or both
12. the person who likes adventure movies is a different person than the person who likes pumpkin
13. the person who plays water-polo is the same person as at least one of the person who likes mirinda or the person who likes pumpkin
14. the person who likes juice is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes adventure movies
15. the person who likes asparagus is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes spinach
16. the person who likes thriller movies is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes pear
17. the person who likes spinach is the same person as the person who likes juice or the person who likes time-travel movies is the same person as the person who likes spinach, but not both
18. the person who plays swimming and the person who likes spinach are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
19. the person who likes folk music is a different person than the person who likes nectarine
20. the person who likes horror movies is the same person as at least one of the person who likes hot-chocolate or the person who likes house music
21. the person who plays water-polo is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes almond-milk
22. the person who likes folk music is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes hot-chocolate
23. the person who likes almond-milk is a different person than the person who likes pear
24. the person who likes sprite is a different person than at least one of the person who likes d&b music or the person who plays ice-hockey
25. the person who likes punk music is a different person than at least one of the person who likes pumpkin or the person who likes adventure movies
26. the person who likes indie music is at the same position as or to the right of the person who plays cycling
27. the person who likes d&b music is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes house music
28. the person who likes sprite and the person who plays swimming are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
29. the person who likes indie music is the same person as exactly one of the person who likes juice or the person who likes thriller movies
30. the person who likes thriller movies is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes pear
31. the person who plays swimming is a different person than the person who likes horror movies
32. the person who plays cycling is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes horror movies
33. the person who plays parkour is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes juice
34. the person who plays swimming is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes sprite

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Food").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Music", "Sport", "Food", "Movie", "Beverage"]
    items = {
        "Music": ["house", "indie", "d&b", "folk", "punk"],
        "Sport": ["ice-hockey", "swimming", "parkour", "cycling", "water-polo"],
        "Food": ["asparagus", "spinach", "nectarine", "pumpkin", "pear"],
        "Movie": ["horror", "adventure", "thriller", "time-travel", "superhero"],
        "Beverage": ["juice", "almond-milk", "mirinda", "hot-chocolate", "sprite"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items within a category must be in different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(),
                              [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: punk music <= folk music
    problem.addConstraint(lambda punk, folk: punk <= folk,
                          ["Music:punk", "Music:folk"])

    # Clue 2: house music >= ice-hockey
    problem.addConstraint(lambda house, ice_hockey: house >= ice_hockey,
                          ["Music:house", "Sport:ice-hockey"])

    # Clue 3: hot-chocolate and pear different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda hc, pear: (hc % 2) != (pear % 2),
                          ["Beverage:hot-chocolate", "Food:pear"])

    # Clue 4: house music and cycling different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda house, cycling: (house % 2) != (cycling % 2),
                          ["Music:house", "Sport:cycling"])

    # Clue 5: folk music <= indie music
    problem.addConstraint(lambda folk, indie: folk <= indie,
                          ["Music:folk", "Music:indie"])

    # Clue 6: cycling <= time-travel
    problem.addConstraint(lambda cycling, tt: cycling <= tt,
                          ["Sport:cycling", "Movie:time-travel"])

    # Clue 7: pear != ice-hockey
    problem.addConstraint(lambda pear, ice_hockey: pear != ice_hockey,
                          ["Food:pear", "Sport:ice-hockey"])

    # Clue 8: time-travel between juice and d&b (not necessarily adjacent)
    # That means time-travel position is strictly between juice and d&b positions
    # So either juice < time-travel < d&b or d&b < time-travel < juice
    def between(tt, juice, dnb):
        return (juice < tt < dnb) or (dnb < tt < juice)
    problem.addConstraint(between,
                          ["Movie:time-travel", "Beverage:juice", "Music:d&b"])

    # Clue 9: swimming <= water-polo
    problem.addConstraint(lambda swim, wp: swim <= wp,
                          ["Sport:swimming", "Sport:water-polo"])

    # Clue 10: swimming >= ice-hockey
    problem.addConstraint(lambda swim, ice_hockey: swim >= ice_hockey,
                          ["Sport:swimming", "Sport:ice-hockey"])

    # Clue 11: (spinach != swimming) or (house != spinach) or both
    # This is equivalent to: not (spinach == swimming and house == spinach)
    def clue11(spinach, swimming, house):
        return not (spinach == swimming and house == spinach)
    problem.addConstraint(clue11,
                          ["Food:spinach", "Sport:swimming", "Music:house"])

    # Clue 12: adventure != pumpkin
    problem.addConstraint(lambda adventure, pumpkin: adventure != pumpkin,
                          ["Movie:adventure", "Food:pumpkin"])

    # Clue 13: water-polo == mirinda or water-polo == pumpkin (at least one)
    def clue13(wp, mirinda, pumpkin):
        return wp == mirinda or wp == pumpkin
    problem.addConstraint(clue13,
                          ["Sport:water-polo", "Beverage:mirinda", "Food:pumpkin"])

    # Clue 14: juice <= adventure
    problem.addConstraint(lambda juice, adventure: juice <= adventure,
                          ["Beverage:juice", "Movie:adventure"])

    # Clue 15: asparagus >= spinach
    problem.addConstraint(lambda asparagus, spinach: asparagus >= spinach,
                          ["Food:asparagus", "Food:spinach"])

    # Clue 16: thriller <= pear
    problem.addConstraint(lambda thriller, pear: thriller <= pear,
                          ["Movie:thriller", "Food:pear"])

    # Clue 17: (spinach == juice) xor (time-travel == spinach)
    # Exactly one of these is true
    def clue17(spinach, juice, time_travel):
        return (spinach == juice) ^ (time_travel == spinach)
    problem.addConstraint(clue17,
                          ["Food:spinach", "Beverage:juice", "Movie:time-travel"])

    # Clue 18: swimming and spinach different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda swim, spinach: (swim % 2) != (spinach % 2),
                          ["Sport:swimming", "Food:spinach"])

    # Clue 19: folk != nectarine
    problem.addConstraint(lambda folk, nectarine: folk != nectarine,
                          ["Music:folk", "Food:nectarine"])

    # Clue 20: horror == hot-chocolate or horror == house
    def clue20(horror, hot_choc, house):
        return horror == hot_choc or horror == house
    problem.addConstraint(clue20,
                          ["Movie:horror", "Beverage:hot-chocolate", "Music:house"])

    # Clue 21: water-polo <= almond-milk
    problem.addConstraint(lambda wp, almond: wp <= almond,
                          ["Sport:water-polo", "Beverage:almond-milk"])

    # Clue 22: folk <= hot-chocolate
    problem.addConstraint(lambda folk, hot_choc: folk <= hot_choc,
                          ["Music:folk", "Beverage:hot-chocolate"])

    # Clue 23: almond-milk != pear
    problem.addConstraint(lambda almond, pear: almond != pear,
                          ["Beverage:almond-milk", "Food:pear"])

    # Clue 24: sprite != d&b or sprite != ice-hockey (at least one)
    def clue24(sprite, dnb, ice_hockey):
        return sprite != dnb or sprite != ice_hockey
    problem.addConstraint(clue24,
                          ["Beverage:sprite", "Music:d&b", "Sport:ice-hockey"])

    # Clue 25: punk != pumpkin or punk != adventure (at least one)
    def clue25(punk, pumpkin, adventure):
        return punk != pumpkin or punk != adventure
    problem.addConstraint(clue25,
                          ["Music:punk", "Food:pumpkin", "Movie:adventure"])

    # Clue 26: indie >= cycling
    problem.addConstraint(lambda indie, cycling: indie >= cycling,
                          ["Music:indie", "Sport:cycling"])

    # Clue 27: d&b >= house
    problem.addConstraint(lambda dnb, house: dnb >= house,
                          ["Music:d&b", "Music:house"])

    # Clue 28: sprite and swimming same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda sprite, swim: (sprite % 2) == (swim % 2),
                          ["Beverage:sprite", "Sport:swimming"])

    # Clue 29: indie == exactly one of juice or thriller
    def clue29(indie, juice, thriller):
        return ((indie == juice) + (indie == thriller)) == 1
    problem.addConstraint(clue29,
                          ["Music:indie", "Beverage:juice", "Movie:thriller"])

    # Clue 30: thriller >= pear
    problem.addConstraint(lambda thriller, pear: thriller >= pear,
                          ["Movie:thriller", "Food:pear"])

    # Clue 31: swimming != horror
    problem.addConstraint(lambda swim, horror: swim != horror,
                          ["Sport:swimming", "Movie:horror"])

    # Clue 32: cycling <= horror
    problem.addConstraint(lambda cycling, horror: cycling <= horror,
                          ["Sport:cycling", "Movie:horror"])

    # Clue 33: parkour <= juice
    problem.addConstraint(lambda parkour, juice: parkour <= juice,
                          ["Sport:parkour", "Beverage:juice"])

    # Clue 34: swimming <= sprite
    problem.addConstraint(lambda swim, sprite: swim <= sprite,
                          ["Sport:swimming", "Beverage:sprite"])

    # Solve
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # Could happen, but puzzle expects unique solution
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 3 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 2 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 3 unique items:

1. Food: grapefruit, pumpkin, banana
2. Beverage: milk, juice, soy-milk

Each category has exactly 3 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes pumpkin is immediately to the left of the person who likes banana
2. the person who likes banana is immediately to the right of the person who likes soy-milk
3. the person who likes milk is immediately to the right of the person who likes banana

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Food").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 3

    categories = ["Food", "Beverage"]
    items = {
        "Food": ["grapefruit", "pumpkin", "banana"],
        "Beverage": ["milk", "juice", "soy-milk"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must occupy different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_items = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_items)

    # Clue 1: pumpkin is immediately to the left of banana
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pumpkin, banana: pumpkin == banana - 1,
        ["Food:pumpkin", "Food:banana"]
    )

    # Clue 2: banana is immediately to the right of soy-milk
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda banana, soy_milk: banana == soy_milk + 1,
        ["Food:banana", "Beverage:soy-milk"]
    )

    # Clue 3: milk is immediately to the right of banana
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda milk, banana: milk == banana + 1,
        ["Beverage:milk", "Food:banana"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {category: [""] * num_positions for category in categories}

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            position = solution[variable_name]
            result_dict[category][position] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Transport: motorbike, roller, trike, taxi
2. Music: punk, techno, funk, salsa
3. Pet: goldfish, hamster, dog, rat

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who has hamster as a pet is directly between the person who has rat as a pet and the person who uses trike for transportation
2. the person who likes salsa music is the same person as the person who uses motorbike for transportation
3. the person who has rat as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who has goldfish as a pet
4. the person who uses motorbike for transportation is to the left of the person who likes funk music (not necessarily immediately)
5. the person who uses trike for transportation is somewhere between the person who uses roller for transportation and the person who has hamster as a pet (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
6. the person who has dog as a pet is immediately to the right of the person who likes punk music

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Music", "Pet").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Transport", "Music", "Pet"]
    items = {
        "Transport": ["motorbike", "roller", "trike", "taxi"],
        "Music": ["punk", "techno", "funk", "salsa"],
        "Pet": ["goldfish", "hamster", "dog", "rat"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in each category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: hamster is directly between rat and trike
    # That means hamster is at position x, rat and trike at x-1 and x+1 in any order
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda hamster, rat, trike: (hamster == rat + 1 and hamster == trike - 1) or (hamster == trike + 1 and hamster == rat - 1),
        ["Pet:hamster", "Pet:rat", "Transport:trike"]
    )

    # Clue 2: salsa music same person as motorbike
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda salsa, motorbike: salsa == motorbike,
        ["Music:salsa", "Transport:motorbike"]
    )

    # Clue 3: rat is at same position or to the right of goldfish
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rat, goldfish: rat >= goldfish,
        ["Pet:rat", "Pet:goldfish"]
    )

    # Clue 4: motorbike is to the left of funk music (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda motorbike, funk: motorbike < funk,
        ["Transport:motorbike", "Music:funk"]
    )

    # Clue 5: trike is somewhere between roller and hamster (not necessarily adjacent)
    # So trike position is strictly between roller and hamster positions
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda trike, roller, hamster: (roller < trike < hamster) or (hamster < trike < roller),
        ["Transport:trike", "Transport:roller", "Pet:hamster"]
    )

    # Clue 6: dog is immediately to the right of punk music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dog, punk: dog == punk + 1,
        ["Pet:dog", "Music:punk"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format the solution dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

2. Transport: ship, roller, boat, jet-ski, snowmobile
3. Food: plum, grapefruit, peach, potato, tomato
4. Music: pop, electronic, blues, salsa, house

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

2. the person who likes blues music is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses snowmobile for transportation
3. the person who plays skateboarding is a different person than the person who uses roller for transportation

15. the person who plays baseball is somewhere between the canadian person and the person who uses boat for transportation (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
16. the person who likes grapefruit and the person who uses jet-ski for transportation are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
17. the person who uses snowmobile for transportation is at the same position as or to the left of the person who plays weightlifting
18. the person who plays baseball is to the left of the person who plays climbing (not necessarily immediately)
19. the person who plays snowboarding is the same person as exactly one of the person who uses roller for transportation or the canadian person
20. the person who plays weightlifting is to the right of the person who likes electronic music (not necessarily immediately)
21. the person who plays baseball and the person who likes peach are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Music").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Nationality", "Transport", "Food", "Music", "Sport"]
    items = {
        "Nationality": ["malaysian", "spanish", "american", "indian", "canadian"],
        "Transport": ["ship", "roller", "boat", "jet-ski", "snowmobile"],
        "Food": ["plum", "grapefruit", "peach", "potato", "tomato"],
        "Music": ["pop", "electronic", "blues", "salsa", "house"],
        "Sport": ["climbing", "skateboarding", "baseball", "snowboarding", "weightlifting"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be in different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Helper functions for "somewhere between" constraint
    def between(x, a, b):
        return (a < x < b) or (b < x < a)

    # Clue 1: XOR between climbing=house or grapefruit=climbing but not both
    def clue1(climbing, house, grapefruit):
        cond1 = climbing == house
        cond2 = grapefruit == climbing
        return (cond1 != cond2)  # XOR
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue1,
        ["Sport:climbing", "Music:house", "Food:grapefruit"]
    )

    # Clue 2: blues same position as or right of snowmobile
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda blues, snowmobile: blues >= snowmobile,
        ["Music:blues", "Transport:snowmobile"]
    )

    # Clue 3: skateboarding != roller
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skateboarding, roller: skateboarding != roller,
        ["Sport:skateboarding", "Transport:roller"]
    )

    # Clue 4: boat != grapefruit
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda boat, grapefruit: boat != grapefruit,
        ["Transport:boat", "Food:grapefruit"]
    )

    # Clue 5: spanish <= peach
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda spanish, peach: spanish <= peach,
        ["Nationality:spanish", "Food:peach"]
    )

    # Clue 6: potato <= baseball
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda potato, baseball: potato <= baseball,
        ["Food:potato", "Sport:baseball"]
    )

    # Clue 7: electronic and grapefruit same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda electronic, grapefruit: electronic % 2 == grapefruit % 2,
        ["Music:electronic", "Food:grapefruit"]
    )

    # Clue 8: blues=climbing or climbing=indian or both
    # This means blues==climbing or climbing==indian (at least one true)
    def clue8(blues, climbing, indian):
        return (blues == climbing) or (climbing == indian)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue8,
        ["Music:blues", "Sport:climbing", "Nationality:indian"]
    )

    # Clue 9: skateboarding <= weightlifting
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skateboarding, weightlifting: skateboarding <= weightlifting,
        ["Sport:skateboarding", "Sport:weightlifting"]
    )

    # Clue 10: american is somewhere between weightlifting and indian
    def clue10(american, weightlifting, indian):
        return between(american, weightlifting, indian)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue10,
        ["Nationality:american", "Sport:weightlifting", "Nationality:indian"]
    )

    # Clue 11: canadian is somewhere between tomato and baseball
    def clue11(canadian, tomato, baseball):
        return between(canadian, tomato, baseball)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue11,
        ["Nationality:canadian", "Food:tomato", "Sport:baseball"]
    )

    # Clue 12: salsa > roller
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda salsa, roller: salsa > roller,
        ["Music:salsa", "Transport:roller"]
    )

    # Clue 13: ship != canadian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda ship, canadian: ship != canadian,
        ["Transport:ship", "Nationality:canadian"]
    )

    # Clue 14: ship somewhere between peach and blues
    def clue14(ship, peach, blues):
        return between(ship, peach, blues)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue14,
        ["Transport:ship", "Food:peach", "Music:blues"]
    )

    # Clue 15: baseball somewhere between canadian and boat
    def clue15(baseball, canadian, boat):
        return between(baseball, canadian, boat)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue15,
        ["Sport:baseball", "Nationality:canadian", "Transport:boat"]
    )

    # Clue 16: grapefruit and jet-ski same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda grapefruit, jetski: grapefruit % 2 == jetski % 2,
        ["Food:grapefruit", "Transport:jet-ski"]
    )

    # Clue 17: snowmobile <= weightlifting
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda snowmobile, weightlifting: snowmobile <= weightlifting,
        ["Transport:snowmobile", "Sport:weightlifting"]
    )

    # Clue 18: baseball < climbing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda baseball, climbing: baseball < climbing,
        ["Sport:baseball", "Sport:climbing"]
    )

    # Clue 19: snowboarding same person as exactly one of roller or canadian
    # XOR between snowboarding==roller and snowboarding==canadian
    def clue19(snowboarding, roller, canadian):
        cond1 = snowboarding == roller
        cond2 = snowboarding == canadian
        return cond1 != cond2
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue19,
        ["Sport:snowboarding", "Transport:roller", "Nationality:canadian"]
    )

    # Clue 20: weightlifting > electronic
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda weightlifting, electronic: weightlifting > electronic,
        ["Sport:weightlifting", "Music:electronic"]
    )

    # Clue 21: baseball and peach same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda baseball, peach: baseball % 2 == peach % 2,
        ["Sport:baseball", "Food:peach"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    # Only one solution expected
    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [None]*num_positions
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 3 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 3 unique items:

1. Job: scientist, videographer, designer
2. Music: indie, punk, r&b
3. Movie: musical, time-travel, action

Each category has exactly 3 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes action movies is immediately to the left of the person who likes r&b music
2. the person who likes musical movies is immediately to the left of the person who works as a scientist
3. the person who likes punk music is immediately to the left of the person who likes indie music
4. the person who works as a scientist is immediately to the right of the person who works as a designer

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Job", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 3

    categories = ["Job", "Music", "Movie"]
    items = {
        "Job": ["scientist", "videographer", "designer"],
        "Music": ["indie", "punk", "r&b"],
        "Movie": ["musical", "time-travel", "action"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain 0..2 (positions)
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_items = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_items)

    # Clue 1: action movie is immediately to the left of r&b music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda action, rnb: action == rnb - 1,
        ["Movie:action", "Music:r&b"]
    )

    # Clue 2: musical movie is immediately to the left of scientist job
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda musical, scientist: musical == scientist - 1,
        ["Movie:musical", "Job:scientist"]
    )

    # Clue 3: punk music is immediately to the left of indie music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda punk, indie: punk == indie - 1,
        ["Music:punk", "Music:indie"]
    )

    # Clue 4: scientist job is immediately to the right of designer job
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda scientist, designer: scientist == designer + 1,
        ["Job:scientist", "Job:designer"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Prepare a list of length num_positions
        ordered_items = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            ordered_items[pos] = item
        result_dict[category] = ordered_items

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Transport: jet-ski, subway, boat, taxi, quad-bike
2. Sport: ice-hockey, golf, snowboarding, handball, biathlon
3. Movie: spy, documentary, adventure, zombie, western
4. Pet: guinea-pig, lizard, hamster, goldfish, turtle

2. the person who has turtle as a pet is to the right of the person who uses jet-ski for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
3. the person who has guinea-pig as a pet is to the right of the person who uses taxi for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
4. the person who has hamster as a pet is directly between the person who plays ice-hockey and the person who likes documentary movies
5. the person who uses boat for transportation is adjacent to the person who plays golf (either immediately left or right)
6. the person who likes western movies is somewhere between the person who likes adventure movies and the person who likes spy movies (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
7. the person who plays ice-hockey is to the left of the person who likes zombie movies (not necessarily immediately)

9. the person who plays ice-hockey is adjacent to the person who plays snowboarding (either immediately left or right)
10. the person who uses subway for transportation is to the right of the person who has turtle as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
11. the person who likes spy movies is to the right of the person who plays biathlon (not necessarily immediately)
12. the person who likes adventure movies is adjacent to the person who uses quad-bike for transportation (either immediately left or right)

- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Movie", "Pet").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Transport", "Sport", "Movie", "Pet"]
    items = {
        "Transport": ["jet-ski", "subway", "boat", "taxi", "quad-bike"],
        "Sport": ["ice-hockey", "golf", "snowboarding", "handball", "biathlon"],
        "Movie": ["spy", "documentary", "adventure", "zombie", "western"],
        "Pet": ["guinea-pig", "lizard", "hamster", "goldfish", "turtle"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be in different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_vars = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_vars)

    # Clue 1: hamster immediately to the right of subway
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda hamster, subway: hamster == subway + 1,
        ["Pet:hamster", "Transport:subway"]
    )

    # Clue 2: turtle to the right of jet-ski (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda turtle, jetski: turtle > jetski,
        ["Pet:turtle", "Transport:jet-ski"]
    )

    # Clue 3: guinea-pig to the right of taxi (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda guinea_pig, taxi: guinea_pig > taxi,
        ["Pet:guinea-pig", "Transport:taxi"]
    )

    # Clue 4: hamster directly between ice-hockey and documentary
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda hamster, ice_hockey, documentary:
            (hamster == ice_hockey + 1 and hamster == documentary - 1) or
            (hamster == documentary + 1 and hamster == ice_hockey - 1),
        ["Pet:hamster", "Sport:ice-hockey", "Movie:documentary"]
    )

    # Clue 5: boat adjacent to golf
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda boat, golf: abs(boat - golf) == 1,
        ["Transport:boat", "Sport:golf"]
    )

    # Clue 6: western somewhere between adventure and spy (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda western, adventure, spy:
            (adventure < western < spy) or (spy < western < adventure),
        ["Movie:western", "Movie:adventure", "Movie:spy"]
    )

    # Clue 7: ice-hockey to the left of zombie (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda ice_hockey, zombie: ice_hockey < zombie,
        ["Sport:ice-hockey", "Movie:zombie"]
    )

    # Clue 8: adventure to the left of lizard (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda adventure, lizard: adventure < lizard,
        ["Movie:adventure", "Pet:lizard"]
    )

    # Clue 9: ice-hockey adjacent to snowboarding
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda ice_hockey, snowboarding: abs(ice_hockey - snowboarding) == 1,
        ["Sport:ice-hockey", "Sport:snowboarding"]
    )

    # Clue 10: subway to the right of turtle (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda subway, turtle: subway > turtle,
        ["Transport:subway", "Pet:turtle"]
    )

    # Clue 11: spy to the right of biathlon (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda spy, biathlon: spy > biathlon,
        ["Movie:spy", "Sport:biathlon"]
    )

    # Clue 12: adventure adjacent to quad-bike
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda adventure, quad_bike: abs(adventure - quad_bike) == 1,
        ["Movie:adventure", "Transport:quad-bike"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Clues:

2. the person who enjoys puzzles is to the right of the argentine person (not necessarily immediately)

4. the french person is a different person than the person who likes spy movies

6. the french person is adjacent to the person who enjoys reading (either immediately left or right)

14. the person who likes crime movies is the same person as the person who has guinea-pig as a pet or the person who has guinea-pig as a pet is the same person as the person who enjoys puzzles, but not both
15. the argentine person is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes ambient music
16. the russian person and the person who likes romance movies are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)

18. the person who enjoys filmmaking is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes zombie movies
19. the person who enjoys filmmaking is adjacent to the person who likes romance movies (either immediately left or right)
20. the french person is a different person than the person who likes satire movies
21. the person who likes indie music is to the left of the person who likes ambient music (not necessarily immediately)
22. the person who has rabbit as a pet is adjacent to the argentine person (either immediately left or right)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Hobby", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Hobby", "Nationality", "Pet", "Music", "Movie"]
    items = {
        "Hobby": ["reading", "baking", "filmmaking", "puzzles", "cooking"],
        "Nationality": ["canadian", "french", "egyptian", "russian", "argentine"],
        "Pet": ["mouse", "bird", "rabbit", "guinea-pig", "turtle"],
        "Music": ["reggae", "house", "indie", "funk", "ambient"],
        "Movie": ["spy", "zombie", "romance", "crime", "satire"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain being the possible positions
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_items = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_items)

    # Clue 1: baking <= crime
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda baking, crime: baking <= crime,
        ["Hobby:baking", "Movie:crime"]
    )

    # Clue 2: puzzles > argentine
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda puzzles, argentine: puzzles > argentine,
        ["Hobby:puzzles", "Nationality:argentine"]
    )

    # Clue 3: turtle adjacent to canadian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda turtle, canadian: abs(turtle - canadian) == 1,
        ["Pet:turtle", "Nationality:canadian"]
    )

    # Clue 4: french != spy
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda french, spy: french != spy,
        ["Nationality:french", "Movie:spy"]
    )

    # Clue 5: turtle adjacent to mouse
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda turtle, mouse: abs(turtle - mouse) == 1,
        ["Pet:turtle", "Pet:mouse"]
    )

    # Clue 6: french adjacent to reading
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda french, reading: abs(french - reading) == 1,
        ["Nationality:french", "Hobby:reading"]
    )

    # Clue 7: baking >= reggae
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda baking, reggae: baking >= reggae,
        ["Hobby:baking", "Music:reggae"]
    )

    # Clue 8: spy != baking
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda spy, baking: spy != baking,
        ["Movie:spy", "Hobby:baking"]
    )

    # Clue 9: reading > funk
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda reading, funk: reading > funk,
        ["Hobby:reading", "Music:funk"]
    )

    # Clue 10: rabbit adjacent to reggae
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rabbit, reggae: abs(rabbit - reggae) == 1,
        ["Pet:rabbit", "Music:reggae"]
    )

    # Clue 11: indie and baking same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda indie, baking: (indie % 2) == (baking % 2),
        ["Music:indie", "Hobby:baking"]
    )

    # Clue 12: romance > cooking
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda romance, cooking: romance > cooking,
        ["Movie:romance", "Hobby:cooking"]
    )

    # Clue 13: egyptian == satire or satire == puzzles or both
    # This means egyptian == satire or satire == puzzles or egyptian == satire == puzzles
    # So at least one of these is true:
    # egyptian == satire
    # satire == puzzles
    # So we impose: (egyptian == satire) or (satire == puzzles)
    def clue_13(egyptian, satire, puzzles):
        return (egyptian == satire) or (satire == puzzles)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue_13,
        ["Nationality:egyptian", "Movie:satire", "Hobby:puzzles"]
    )

    # Clue 14: (crime == guinea-pig) xor (guinea-pig == puzzles)
    # Exactly one of these is true
    def clue_14(crime, guinea_pig, puzzles):
        first = (crime == guinea_pig)
        second = (guinea_pig == puzzles)
        return first != second
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue_14,
        ["Movie:crime", "Pet:guinea-pig", "Hobby:puzzles"]
    )

    # Clue 15: argentine >= ambient
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda argentine, ambient: argentine >= ambient,
        ["Nationality:argentine", "Music:ambient"]
    )

    # Clue 16: russian and romance same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda russian, romance: (russian % 2) == (romance % 2),
        ["Nationality:russian", "Movie:romance"]
    )

    # Clue 17: crime <= mouse
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda crime, mouse: crime <= mouse,
        ["Movie:crime", "Pet:mouse"]
    )

    # Clue 18: filmmaking <= zombie
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda filmmaking, zombie: filmmaking <= zombie,
        ["Hobby:filmmaking", "Movie:zombie"]
    )

    # Clue 19: filmmaking adjacent to romance
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda filmmaking, romance: abs(filmmaking - romance) == 1,
        ["Hobby:filmmaking", "Movie:romance"]
    )

    # Clue 20: french != satire
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda french, satire: french != satire,
        ["Nationality:french", "Movie:satire"]
    )

    # Clue 21: indie < ambient
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda indie, ambient: indie < ambient,
        ["Music:indie", "Music:ambient"]
    )

    # Clue 22: rabbit adjacent to argentine
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rabbit, argentine: abs(rabbit - argentine) == 1,
        ["Pet:rabbit", "Nationality:argentine"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = format_solution_as_dict(solution, categories, items, num_positions)

    print(result_dict)

def format_solution_as_dict(solution: dict, categories: list, items: dict, num_positions: int) -> dict:
    result_dict = {}

    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            position = solution[variable_name]
            result_dict[category][position] = item

    return result_dict

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 3 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 2 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 3 unique items:

1. Music: funk, dubstep, salsa
2. Pet: hamster, goldfish, cat

Each category has exactly 3 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes dubstep music is the same person as the person who has hamster as a pet
2. the person who likes dubstep music is to the right of the person who has goldfish as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
3. the person who likes salsa music is directly between the person who has cat as a pet and the person who has hamster as a pet

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Music", "Pet").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 3

    categories = ["Music", "Pet"]
    items = {
        "Music": ["funk", "dubstep", "salsa"],
        "Pet": ["hamster", "goldfish", "cat"]
    }

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    for category in categories:
        category_items = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_items)

    # Clue 1: the person who likes dubstep music is the same person as the person who has hamster as a pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dubstep, hamster: dubstep == hamster,
        ["Music:dubstep", "Pet:hamster"]
    )

    # Clue 2: the person who likes dubstep music is to the right of the person who has goldfish as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dubstep, goldfish: dubstep > goldfish,
        ["Music:dubstep", "Pet:goldfish"]
    )

    # Clue 3: the person who likes salsa music is directly between the person who has cat as a pet and the person who has hamster as a pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda salsa, cat, hamster: (salsa == cat + 1 and salsa == hamster - 1) or (salsa == hamster + 1 and salsa == cat - 1),
        ["Music:salsa", "Pet:cat", "Pet:hamster"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # We expect only one solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {category: [""] * num_positions for category in categories}
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            position = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][position] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Pet: hedgehog, dog, snake, turtle, lizard
2. Hobby: puzzles, fishing, dancing, card-games, rock-climbing
3. Food: pumpkin, tomato, pineapple, peach, cabbage
4. Job: engineer, software-developer, mechanic, architect, fisherman
5. Sport: swimming, cycling, handball, biathlon, skateboarding

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who has hedgehog as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who plays skateboarding
2. the person who works as a architect is at the same position as or to the right of the person who plays skateboarding
3. the person who likes tomato is at the same position as or to the right of the person who has snake as a pet
4. the person who plays cycling is somewhere between the person who enjoys dancing and the person who enjoys fishing (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
5. the person who works as a software-developer is at the same position as or to the right of the person who plays handball
6. the person who plays cycling is at the same position as or to the left of the person who plays handball
7. the person who enjoys dancing and the person who plays handball are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
8. the person who plays handball and the person who has hedgehog as a pet are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
9. the person who enjoys fishing is the same person as at least one of the person who has snake as a pet or the person who plays swimming
10. the person who likes pineapple is at the same position as or to the right of the person who works as a software-developer
11. the person who enjoys rock-climbing is at the same position as or to the right of the person who enjoys dancing
12. the person who likes cabbage and the person who has snake as a pet are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
13. the person who likes pumpkin is somewhere between the person who plays skateboarding and the person who plays handball (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
14. the person who likes peach is somewhere between the person who works as a mechanic and the person who has dog as a pet (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
15. the person who has lizard as a pet and the person who enjoys fishing are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
16. the person who likes cabbage is at the same position as or to the right of the person who has lizard as a pet
17. the person who likes peach is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes tomato
18. the person who works as a software-developer is the same person as the person who enjoys card-games or the person who has dog as a pet is the same person as the person who works as a software-developer or both
19. the person who has turtle as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who works as a engineer

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Hobby").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Pet", "Hobby", "Food", "Job", "Sport"]
    items = {
        "Pet": ["hedgehog", "dog", "snake", "turtle", "lizard"],
        "Hobby": ["puzzles", "fishing", "dancing", "card-games", "rock-climbing"],
        "Food": ["pumpkin", "tomato", "pineapple", "peach", "cabbage"],
        "Job": ["engineer", "software-developer", "mechanic", "architect", "fisherman"],
        "Sport": ["swimming", "cycling", "handball", "biathlon", "skateboarding"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in a category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: hedgehog pet same position or left of skateboarding sport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda hedgehog, skateboarding: hedgehog <= skateboarding,
        ["Pet:hedgehog", "Sport:skateboarding"]
    )

    # Clue 2: architect job same position or right of skateboarding sport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda architect, skateboarding: architect >= skateboarding,
        ["Job:architect", "Sport:skateboarding"]
    )

    # Clue 3: tomato food same position or right of snake pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda tomato, snake: tomato >= snake,
        ["Food:tomato", "Pet:snake"]
    )

    # Clue 4: cycling sport is somewhere between dancing hobby and fishing hobby (not necessarily immediately)
    # So cycling is > min(dancing,fishing) and < max(dancing,fishing)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cycling, dancing, fishing: (cycling > min(dancing, fishing)) and (cycling < max(dancing, fishing)),
        ["Sport:cycling", "Hobby:dancing", "Hobby:fishing"]
    )

    # Clue 5: software-developer job same position or right of handball sport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda software_dev, handball: software_dev >= handball,
        ["Job:software-developer", "Sport:handball"]
    )

    # Clue 6: cycling sport same position or left of handball sport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cycling, handball: cycling <= handball,
        ["Sport:cycling", "Sport:handball"]
    )

    # Clue 7: dancing hobby and handball sport are at positions with same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dancing, handball: (dancing % 2) == (handball % 2),
        ["Hobby:dancing", "Sport:handball"]
    )

    # Clue 8: handball sport and hedgehog pet are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda handball, hedgehog: (handball % 2) != (hedgehog % 2),
        ["Sport:handball", "Pet:hedgehog"]
    )

    # Clue 9: fishing hobby is same person as snake pet or swimming sport or both
    # So fishing == snake OR fishing == swimming
    # Model as: fishing == snake OR fishing == swimming
    # This requires a custom constraint that accepts three variables
    def fishing_snake_swimming(fishing, snake, swimming):
        return fishing == snake or fishing == swimming
    problem.addConstraint(
        fishing_snake_swimming,
        ["Hobby:fishing", "Pet:snake", "Sport:swimming"]
    )

    # Clue 10: pineapple food same position or right of software-developer job
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pineapple, software_dev: pineapple >= software_dev,
        ["Food:pineapple", "Job:software-developer"]
    )

    # Clue 11: rock-climbing hobby same position or right of dancing hobby
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rock_climbing, dancing: rock_climbing >= dancing,
        ["Hobby:rock-climbing", "Hobby:dancing"]
    )

    # Clue 12: cabbage food and snake pet at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cabbage, snake: (cabbage % 2) != (snake % 2),
        ["Food:cabbage", "Pet:snake"]
    )

    # Clue 13: pumpkin food somewhere between skateboarding sport and handball sport (not necessarily immediately)
    # pumpkin > min(skateboarding, handball) and pumpkin < max(skateboarding, handball)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pumpkin, skateboarding, handball: (pumpkin > min(skateboarding, handball)) and (pumpkin < max(skateboarding, handball)),
        ["Food:pumpkin", "Sport:skateboarding", "Sport:handball"]
    )

    # Clue 14: peach food somewhere between mechanic job and dog pet (not necessarily immediately)
    # peach > min(mechanic, dog) and peach < max(mechanic, dog)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda peach, mechanic, dog: (peach > min(mechanic, dog)) and (peach < max(mechanic, dog)),
        ["Food:peach", "Job:mechanic", "Pet:dog"]
    )

    # Clue 15: lizard pet and fishing hobby at positions with same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lizard, fishing: (lizard % 2) == (fishing % 2),
        ["Pet:lizard", "Hobby:fishing"]
    )

    # Clue 16: cabbage food same position or right of lizard pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cabbage, lizard: cabbage >= lizard,
        ["Food:cabbage", "Pet:lizard"]
    )

    # Clue 17: peach food same position or left of tomato food
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda peach, tomato: peach <= tomato,
        ["Food:peach", "Food:tomato"]
    )

    # Clue 18: software-developer job same person as card-games hobby or dog pet same person as software-developer job or both
    # So software-developer == card-games OR dog == software-developer OR both
    # So (software-dev == card-games) or (dog == software-dev)
    def software_dev_card_games_dog(software_dev, card_games, dog):
        return (software_dev == card_games) or (dog == software_dev)
    problem.addConstraint(
        software_dev_card_games_dog,
        ["Job:software-developer", "Hobby:card-games", "Pet:dog"]
    )

    # Clue 19: turtle pet same position or left of engineer job
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda turtle, engineer: turtle <= engineer,
        ["Pet:turtle", "Job:engineer"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # If multiple solutions, pick first (the puzzle should have unique solution)
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    # Format solution dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        pos_to_item = [None]*num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            pos_to_item[pos] = item
        result[category] = pos_to_item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

2. the person who likes peach is directly between the person who uses van for transportation and the person who uses quad-bike for transportation
3. the person who uses van for transportation is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes zucchini
4. the person who likes lettuce is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses quad-bike for transportation
5. the person who works as a journalist is directly between the person who uses ship for transportation and the person who likes pumpkin
6. the person who works as a nurse is to the left of the person who uses scooter for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
7. the person who likes lettuce is immediately to the left of the person who uses ship for transportation
8. the person who uses quad-bike for transportation is to the right of the person who works as a accountant (not necessarily immediately)
9. the person who works as a librarian is immediately to the left of the person who uses van for transportation

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Transport", "Job", "Food"]
    items = {
        "Transport": ["scooter", "ship", "quad-bike", "van", "helicopter"],
        "Job": ["musician", "librarian", "nurse", "journalist", "accountant"],
        "Food": ["peach", "pomegranate", "lettuce", "pumpkin", "zucchini"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: van and musician same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda van, musician: van % 2 == musician % 2,
        ["Transport:van", "Job:musician"]
    )

    # Clue 2: peach is directly between van and quad-bike
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda peach, van, quad: (peach == van + 1 and peach == quad - 1) or (peach == quad + 1 and peach == van - 1),
        ["Food:peach", "Transport:van", "Transport:quad-bike"]
    )

    # Clue 3: van same position or left of zucchini
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda van, zucchini: van <= zucchini,
        ["Transport:van", "Food:zucchini"]
    )

    # Clue 4: lettuce same position or right of quad-bike
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lettuce, quad: lettuce >= quad,
        ["Food:lettuce", "Transport:quad-bike"]
    )

    # Clue 5: journalist directly between ship and pumpkin
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda journalist, ship, pumpkin: (journalist == ship + 1 and journalist == pumpkin - 1) or (journalist == pumpkin + 1 and journalist == ship - 1),
        ["Job:journalist", "Transport:ship", "Food:pumpkin"]
    )

    # Clue 6: nurse to the left of scooter (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda nurse, scooter: nurse < scooter,
        ["Job:nurse", "Transport:scooter"]
    )

    # Clue 7: lettuce immediately to the left of ship
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lettuce, ship: lettuce == ship - 1,
        ["Food:lettuce", "Transport:ship"]
    )

    # Clue 8: quad-bike to the right of accountant (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda quad, accountant: quad > accountant,
        ["Transport:quad-bike", "Job:accountant"]
    )

    # Clue 9: librarian immediately to the left of van
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda librarian, van: librarian == van - 1,
        ["Job:librarian", "Transport:van"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        pos_list = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            pos_list[pos] = item
        result[category] = pos_list

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Job", "Beverage", "Sport", "Pet", "Music"]
    items = {
        "Job": ["nurse", "software-developer", "engineer", "dressmaker", "doctor"],
        "Beverage": ["water", "juice", "iced-tea", "sprite", "milk"],
        "Sport": ["rugby", "skateboarding", "surfing", "badminton", "climbing"],
        "Pet": ["ferret", "guinea-pig", "snake", "frog", "lizard"],
        "Music": ["disco", "classical", "r&b", "jazz", "electronic"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: electronic music immediately to the right of r&b music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda electronic, rnb: electronic == rnb + 1,
        ["Music:electronic", "Music:r&b"]
    )

    # Clue 2: dressmaker at an end position (0 or 4)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dressmaker: dressmaker == 0 or dressmaker == 4,
        ["Job:dressmaker"]
    )

    # Clue 3: surfing same person as nurse
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda surfing, nurse: surfing == nurse,
        ["Sport:surfing", "Job:nurse"]
    )

    # Clue 4: surfing to the right of badminton (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda surfing, badminton: surfing > badminton,
        ["Sport:surfing", "Sport:badminton"]
    )

    # Clue 5: juice and guinea-pig have same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda juice, guinea_pig: juice % 2 == guinea_pig % 2,
        ["Beverage:juice", "Pet:guinea-pig"]
    )

    # Clue 6: dressmaker and electronic music have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dressmaker, electronic: (dressmaker % 2) != (electronic % 2),
        ["Job:dressmaker", "Music:electronic"]
    )

    # Clue 7: disco at position 0 (leftmost)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda disco: disco == 0,
        ["Music:disco"]
    )

    # Clue 8: juice and lizard are different persons
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda juice, lizard: juice != lizard,
        ["Beverage:juice", "Pet:lizard"]
    )

    # Clue 9: sprite to the left of milk (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda sprite, milk: sprite < milk,
        ["Beverage:sprite", "Beverage:milk"]
    )

    # Clue 10: climbing immediately to the right of dressmaker
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda climbing, dressmaker: climbing == dressmaker + 1,
        ["Sport:climbing", "Job:dressmaker"]
    )

    # Clue 11: software-developer adjacent to iced-tea
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda software_dev, iced_tea: abs(software_dev - iced_tea) == 1,
        ["Job:software-developer", "Beverage:iced-tea"]
    )

    # Clue 12: milk same position or to the right of juice
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda milk, juice: milk >= juice,
        ["Beverage:milk", "Beverage:juice"]
    )

    # Clue 13: skateboarding immediately to the right of jazz
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skateboarding, jazz: skateboarding == jazz + 1,
        ["Sport:skateboarding", "Music:jazz"]
    )

    # Clue 14: milk same person as jazz or software-developer (milk == jazz or milk == software-dev)
    def milk_jazz_or_software(milk, jazz, software_dev):
        return milk == jazz or milk == software_dev
    problem.addConstraint(
        milk_jazz_or_software,
        ["Beverage:milk", "Music:jazz", "Job:software-developer"]
    )

    # Clue 15: dressmaker and milk same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dressmaker, milk: (dressmaker % 2) == (milk % 2),
        ["Job:dressmaker", "Beverage:milk"]
    )

    # Clue 16: engineer to the left of r&b (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda engineer, rnb: engineer < rnb,
        ["Job:engineer", "Music:r&b"]
    )

    # Clue 17: snake is between electronic music and frog (not necessarily adjacent)
    # That means snake is strictly between electronic and frog positions
    def snake_between(electronic, snake, frog):
        return (electronic < snake < frog) or (frog < snake < electronic)
    problem.addConstraint(
        snake_between,
        ["Music:electronic", "Pet:snake", "Pet:frog"]

    # Clue 18: guinea-pig adjacent to badminton

        lambda guinea_pig, badminton: abs(guinea_pig - badminton) == 1,
