from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Job", "Movie", "Pet", "Beverage", "Nationality"]
    items = {
        "Job": ["lawyer", "bartender", "scientist", "engineer", "police-officer"],
        "Movie": ["sports", "crime", "action", "family", "superhero"],
        "Pet": ["mouse", "hamster", "guinea-pig", "pony", "chinchilla"],
        "Beverage": ["lemonade", "soy-milk", "tea", "fanta", "iced-tea"],
        "Nationality": ["russian", "egyptian", "chinese", "brazilian", "canadian"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # AllDifferent constraints per category
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(),
                              [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Helper functions for constraints
    def same_position_or_left(x, y):
        return x <= y

    def same_position_or_right(x, y):
        return x >= y

    def different_person(x, y):
        return x != y

    def same_parity(x, y):
        return x % 2 == y % 2

    def different_parity(x, y):
        return x % 2 != y % 2

    def exactly_one(x, y, z):
        # exactly one of y or z equals x
        return (x == y) != (x == z)

    def at_least_one(x, y, z):
        # x equals at least one of y or z
        return x == y or x == z

    def at_least_one_different(x, y, z):
        # x differs from at least one of y or z
        return x != y or x != z

    def between(x, y, z):
        # x is between y and z (not necessarily adjacent)
        return (y < x < z) or (z < x < y)

    def between_or_equal(x, y, z):
        # x is between or equal to y and z
        return (y <= x <= z) or (z <= x <= y)

    def or_constraint(x, y, z):
        # x differs from y or x differs from z or both
        return x != y or x != z

    # Clue 1
    problem.addConstraint(lambda family, chinese: family <= chinese,
                          ["Movie:family", "Nationality:chinese"])

    # Clue 2: mouse pet is same person as exactly one of chinese or action movie
    def clue2(mouse, chinese, action):
        return (mouse == chinese) != (mouse == action)
    problem.addConstraint(clue2, ["Pet:mouse", "Nationality:chinese", "Movie:action"])

    # Clue 3: police-officer != iced-tea
    problem.addConstraint(different_person, ["Job:police-officer", "Beverage:iced-tea"])

    # Clue 4: family movie same position as or to right of superhero movie
    problem.addConstraint(lambda family, superhero: family >= superhero,
                          ["Movie:family", "Movie:superhero"])

    # Clue 5: iced-tea same person as at least one of scientist or crime movie
    problem.addConstraint(at_least_one, ["Beverage:iced-tea", "Job:scientist", "Movie:crime"])

    # Clue 6: iced-tea same position or left of egyptian
    problem.addConstraint(lambda iced_tea, egyptian: iced_tea <= egyptian,
                          ["Beverage:iced-tea", "Nationality:egyptian"])

    # Clue 7: chinese same position or right of guinea-pig pet
    problem.addConstraint(lambda chinese, guinea_pig: chinese >= guinea_pig,
                          ["Nationality:chinese", "Pet:guinea-pig"])

    # Clue 8: guinea-pig pet same position or left of soy-milk
    problem.addConstraint(lambda guinea_pig, soy_milk: guinea_pig <= soy_milk,
                          ["Pet:guinea-pig", "Beverage:soy-milk"])

    # Clue 9: mouse pet != iced-tea
    problem.addConstraint(different_person, ["Pet:mouse", "Beverage:iced-tea"])

    # Clue 10: iced-tea and lawyer different parity
    problem.addConstraint(different_parity, ["Beverage:iced-tea", "Job:lawyer"])

    # Clue 11: superhero movie != soy-milk
    problem.addConstraint(different_person, ["Movie:superhero", "Beverage:soy-milk"])

    # Clue 12: brazilian same position or left of soy-milk
    problem.addConstraint(lambda brazilian, soy_milk: brazilian <= soy_milk,
                          ["Nationality:brazilian", "Beverage:soy-milk"])

    # Clue 13: fanta != action movie
    problem.addConstraint(different_person, ["Beverage:fanta", "Movie:action"])

    # Clue 14: lawyer different person than at least one of chinese or crime movie
    problem.addConstraint(at_least_one_different, ["Job:lawyer", "Nationality:chinese", "Movie:crime"])

    # Clue 15: brazilian same position or left of guinea-pig pet
    problem.addConstraint(lambda brazilian, guinea_pig: brazilian <= guinea_pig,
                          ["Nationality:brazilian", "Pet:guinea-pig"])

    # Clue 16: guinea-pig pet same position or left of russian
    problem.addConstraint(lambda guinea_pig, russian: guinea_pig <= russian,
                          ["Pet:guinea-pig", "Nationality:russian"])

    # Clue 17: superhero movie same person as exactly one of scientist or egyptian
    def clue17(superhero, scientist, egyptian):
        return (superhero == scientist) != (superhero == egyptian)
    problem.addConstraint(clue17, ["Movie:superhero", "Job:scientist", "Nationality:egyptian"])

    # Clue 18: tea is somewhere between sports movie and police-officer
    problem.addConstraint(between, ["Beverage:tea", "Movie:sports", "Job:police-officer"])

    # Clue 19: mouse pet is somewhere between hamster pet and crime movie
    problem.addConstraint(between, ["Pet:mouse", "Pet:hamster", "Movie:crime"])

    # Clue 20: police-officer and sports movie same parity
    problem.addConstraint(same_parity, ["Job:police-officer", "Movie:sports"])

    # Clue 21: police-officer same position or left of bartender
    problem.addConstraint(lambda police, bartender: police <= bartender,
                          ["Job:police-officer", "Job:bartender"])

    # Clue 22: iced-tea different person than at least one of lawyer or guinea-pig pet
    problem.addConstraint(at_least_one_different, ["Beverage:iced-tea", "Job:lawyer", "Pet:guinea-pig"])

    # Clue 23: guinea-pig pet different person than soy-milk or scientist or both
    def clue23(guinea_pig, soy_milk, scientist):
        return guinea_pig != soy_milk or guinea_pig != scientist
    problem.addConstraint(clue23, ["Pet:guinea-pig", "Beverage:soy-milk", "Job:scientist"])

    # Clue 24: guinea-pig pet different person than at least one of superhero movie or lawyer
    problem.addConstraint(at_least_one_different, ["Pet:guinea-pig", "Movie:superhero", "Job:lawyer"])

    # Clue 25: sports movie and fanta same parity
    problem.addConstraint(same_parity, ["Movie:sports", "Beverage:fanta"])

    # Clue 26: bartender and family movie same parity
    problem.addConstraint(same_parity, ["Job:bartender", "Movie:family"])

    # Clue 27: hamster pet different person than chinese or chinese different person than lemonade or both
    def clue27(hamster, chinese, lemonade):
        return hamster != chinese or chinese != lemonade
    problem.addConstraint(clue27, ["Pet:hamster", "Nationality:chinese", "Beverage:lemonade"])

    # Clue 28: lawyer different person than brazilian or action movie different person than lawyer or both
    def clue28(lawyer, brazilian, action):
        return lawyer != brazilian or action != lawyer
    problem.addConstraint(clue28, ["Job:lawyer", "Nationality:brazilian", "Movie:action"])

    # Clue 29: action movie same person as exactly one of canadian or lemonade
    def clue29(action, canadian, lemonade):
        return (action == canadian) != (action == lemonade)
    problem.addConstraint(clue29, ["Movie:action", "Nationality:canadian", "Beverage:lemonade"])

    # Clue 30: brazilian same position or right of egyptian
    problem.addConstraint(lambda brazilian, egyptian: brazilian >= egyptian,
                          ["Nationality:brazilian", "Nationality:egyptian"])

    # Clue 31: bartender same position or right of sports movie
    problem.addConstraint(lambda bartender, sports: bartender >= sports,
                          ["Job:bartender", "Movie:sports"])

    # Clue 32: iced-tea same position or left of scientist
    problem.addConstraint(lambda iced_tea, scientist: iced_tea <= scientist,
                          ["Beverage:iced-tea", "Job:scientist"])

    # Clue 33: fanta same person as exactly one of russian or lawyer
    def clue33(fanta, russian, lawyer):
        return (fanta == russian) != (fanta == lawyer)
    problem.addConstraint(clue33, ["Beverage:fanta", "Nationality:russian", "Job:lawyer"])

    # Clue 34: hamster pet and action movie different parity
    problem.addConstraint(different_parity, ["Pet:hamster", "Movie:action"])

    # Clue 35: family movie different person than at least one of brazilian or police-officer
    problem.addConstraint(at_least_one_different, ["Movie:family", "Nationality:brazilian", "Job:police-officer"])

    # Clue 36: guinea-pig pet same person as at least one of chinese or engineer
    problem.addConstraint(at_least_one, ["Pet:guinea-pig", "Nationality:chinese", "Job:engineer"])

    # Clue 37: scientist different person than soy-milk
    problem.addConstraint(different_person, ["Job:scientist", "Beverage:soy-milk"])

    # Clue 38: action movie and hamster pet different parity (same as 34)
    problem.addConstraint(different_parity, ["Movie:action", "Pet:hamster"])

    # Clue 39: action movie different person than at least one of police-officer or russian
    problem.addConstraint(at_least_one_different, ["Movie:action", "Job:police-officer", "Nationality:russian"])

    # Clue 40: mouse pet different person than crime movie or crime movie different person than scientist or both
    def clue40(mouse, crime, scientist):
        return mouse != crime or crime != scientist
    problem.addConstraint(clue40, ["Pet:mouse", "Movie:crime", "Job:scientist"])

    # Clue 41: superhero movie same person as exactly one of brazilian or engineer
    def clue41(superhero, brazilian, engineer):
        return (superhero == brazilian) != (superhero == engineer)
    problem.addConstraint(clue41, ["Movie:superhero", "Nationality:brazilian", "Job:engineer"])

    # Clue 42: engineer same position or left of lemonade
    problem.addConstraint(lambda engineer, lemonade: engineer <= lemonade,
                          ["Job:engineer", "Beverage:lemonade"])

    # Clue 43: soy-milk same position or right of lemonade
    problem.addConstraint(lambda soy_milk, lemonade: soy_milk >= lemonade,
                          ["Beverage:soy-milk", "Beverage:lemonade"])

    # Clue 44: pony pet and engineer same parity
    problem.addConstraint(same_parity, ["Pet:pony", "Job:engineer"])

    # Clue 45: family movie same position or right of guinea-pig pet
    problem.addConstraint(lambda family, guinea_pig: family >= guinea_pig,
                          ["Movie:family", "Pet:guinea-pig"])

    # Clue 46: action movie and canadian same parity
    problem.addConstraint(same_parity, ["Movie:action", "Nationality:canadian"])

    # Clue 47: guinea-pig pet same position or right of superhero movie
    problem.addConstraint(lambda guinea_pig, superhero: guinea_pig >= superhero,
                          ["Pet:guinea-pig", "Movie:superhero"])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    def format_solution_as_dict(solution, categories, items, num_positions):
        result_dict = {}
        for category in categories:
            result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for category in categories:
            for item in items[category]:
                var = f"{category}:{item}"
                pos = solution[var]
                result_dict[category][pos] = item
        return result_dict

    result = format_solution_as_dict(solution, categories, items, num_positions)
    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

    problem.addConstraint(

    # Clue 3: 0 is at the center position (position 2)
    # The clue is ambiguous but likely means the item '0' is at position 2.
    # Since no item named '0', interpret that the item '0' is position index 1 (center)
    # But positions are 0-indexed, so center is position 1.
    # Since the puzzle says "0 is at the center position (position 2)" and positions are 1-indexed in the clue,
    # position 2 means index 1 in code.
    # So we must assign one of the items named '0' to position 1. But no '0' item.
    # So likely the clue means the item '0' is at position 2 (index 1).
    # Possibly '0' is a typo or means the person at position 2 (index 1).
    # Since no other info, we interpret clue 3 as: the person at position 2 (index 1) is the middle person.
    # So no variable to assign, the clue is positional.
    # So no constraint needed here.

    # However, since the puzzle says "0 is at the center position (position 2)", possibly the attribute '0' is at position 2.
    # Since no attribute named '0', assume the clue means position 2 is index 1 (center).
    # So no variable constraint.

    # Actually, likely a misinterpretation.
    # Let's assume the clue means that the person at position 2 (index 1) is the middle person.
    # So no variable constraint.

    # Now solve
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # Pick the first solution
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}

Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Beverage: iced-tea, almond-milk, cola, fanta
2. Pet: rabbit, fish, turtle, dog
3. Job: chef, writer, firefighter, mechanic
4. Nationality: indian, italian, thai, french

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who has dog as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who works as a chef
2. the person who likes almond-milk is to the left of the person who has rabbit as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
3. the person who works as a mechanic is immediately to the left of the person who has rabbit as a pet
4. the person who has rabbit as a pet and the person who works as a writer are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
5. the person who has fish as a pet is the same person as the french person
6. the person who has dog as a pet is to the right of the italian person (not necessarily immediately)
7. the person who works as a chef is at the same position as or to the left of the person who has turtle as a pet
8. the person who works as a chef is the same person as exactly one of the person who has rabbit as a pet or the indian person
9. the person who likes fanta is immediately to the right of the person who likes iced-tea
10. the person who works as a chef is the same person as the person who likes cola

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Beverage", "Pet", "Job", "Nationality"]
    items = {
        "Beverage": ["iced-tea", "almond-milk", "cola", "fanta"],
        "Pet": ["rabbit", "fish", "turtle", "dog"],
        "Job": ["chef", "writer", "firefighter", "mechanic"],
        "Nationality": ["indian", "italian", "thai", "french"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: dog is same or to the left of chef
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dog, chef: dog <= chef,
        ["Pet:dog", "Job:chef"]
    )

    # Clue 2: almond-milk is to the left of rabbit (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda almond_milk, rabbit: almond_milk < rabbit,
        ["Beverage:almond-milk", "Pet:rabbit"]
    )

    # Clue 3: mechanic is immediately to the left of rabbit
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda mechanic, rabbit: mechanic == rabbit - 1,
        ["Job:mechanic", "Pet:rabbit"]
    )

    # Clue 4: rabbit and writer have different parity positions
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rabbit, writer: (rabbit % 2) != (writer % 2),
        ["Pet:rabbit", "Job:writer"]
    )

    # Clue 5: fish and french are same person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fish, french: fish == french,
        ["Pet:fish", "Nationality:french"]
    )

    # Clue 6: dog is to the right of italian (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dog, italian: dog > italian,
        ["Pet:dog", "Nationality:italian"]
    )

    # Clue 7: chef is same or to the left of turtle
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda chef, turtle: chef <= turtle,
        ["Job:chef", "Pet:turtle"]
    )

    # Clue 8: chef is same person as exactly one of rabbit or indian
    # That means (chef == rabbit) XOR (chef == indian)
    def chef_xor(chef, rabbit, indian):
        return (chef == rabbit) != (chef == indian)
    problem.addConstraint(
        chef_xor,
        ["Job:chef", "Pet:rabbit", "Nationality:indian"]
    )

    # Clue 9: fanta is immediately to the right of iced-tea
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fanta, iced_tea: fanta == iced_tea + 1,
        ["Beverage:fanta", "Beverage:iced-tea"]
    )

    # Clue 10: chef is same person as cola
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda chef, cola: chef == cola,
        ["Job:chef", "Beverage:cola"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Job", "Sport", "Movie", "Pet", "Beverage"]
    items = {
        "Job": ["manager", "electrician", "coach", "police-officer", "lawyer"],
        "Sport": ["sailing", "cricket", "cycling", "rugby", "ice-hockey"],
        "Movie": ["spy", "comedy", "time-travel", "action", "disaster"],
        "Pet": ["rat", "chinchilla", "guinea-pig", "hamster", "mouse"],
        "Beverage": ["7up", "milk", "fanta", "soy-milk", "water"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain 0-4 (positions)
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in each category must be in different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(),
                              [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1
    problem.addConstraint(lambda coach, milk: (coach % 2) != (milk % 2),
                          ["Job:coach", "Beverage:milk"])

    # Clue 2
    # mouse is same person as spy or milk (at least one)
    # This means mouse == spy or mouse == milk or both
    def clue2(mouse, spy, milk):
        return mouse == spy or mouse == milk
    problem.addConstraint(clue2,
                          ["Pet:mouse", "Movie:spy", "Beverage:milk"])

    # Clue 3
    # rat is at same position or to the left of chinchilla
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rat, chinchilla: rat <= chinchilla,
                          ["Pet:rat", "Pet:chinchilla"])

    # Clue 4
    # (action == water) XOR (lawyer == action)
    def clue4(action, water, lawyer):
        a = (action == water)
        b = (lawyer == action)
        return (a != b)
    problem.addConstraint(clue4,
                          ["Movie:action", "Beverage:water", "Job:lawyer"])

    # Clue 5
    # coach is somewhere between police-officer and mouse (not necessarily adjacent)
    # So coach is between police-officer and mouse: (police < coach < mouse) or (mouse < coach < police)
    def clue5(coach, police, mouse):
        return (police < coach < mouse) or (mouse < coach < police)
    problem.addConstraint(clue5,
                          ["Job:coach", "Job:police-officer", "Pet:mouse"])

    # Clue 6
    # rugby != coach or action != rugby or both
    # So not (rugby == coach and action == rugby)
    def clue6(rugby, coach, action):
        if rugby == coach and action == rugby:
            return False
        return True
    problem.addConstraint(clue6,
                          ["Sport:rugby", "Job:coach", "Movie:action"])

    # Clue 7
    # cycling and guinea-pig have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda cycling, guinea_pig: (cycling % 2) != (guinea_pig % 2),
                          ["Sport:cycling", "Pet:guinea-pig"])

    # Clue 8
    # coach != time-travel or time-travel != guinea-pig or both
    # Not (coach == time-travel == guinea-pig)
    def clue8(coach, time_travel, guinea_pig):
        if coach == time_travel == guinea_pig:
            return False
        return True
    problem.addConstraint(clue8,
                          ["Job:coach", "Movie:time-travel", "Pet:guinea-pig"])

    # Clue 9
    # rugby == fanta or rugby == disaster or both
    def clue9(rugby, fanta, disaster):
        return rugby == fanta or rugby == disaster
    problem.addConstraint(clue9,
                          ["Sport:rugby", "Beverage:fanta", "Movie:disaster"])

    # Clue 10
    # cricket is same person as exactly one of hamster or milk
    def clue10(cricket, hamster, milk):
        return (cricket == hamster) != (cricket == milk)
    problem.addConstraint(clue10,
                          ["Sport:cricket", "Pet:hamster", "Beverage:milk"])

    # Clue 11
    # 7up == disaster or disaster == electrician or both
    def clue11(sevenup, disaster, electrician):
        return (sevenup == disaster) or (disaster == electrician)
    problem.addConstraint(clue11,
                          ["Beverage:7up", "Movie:disaster", "Job:electrician"])

    # Clue 12
    # milk and police-officer have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda milk, police: (milk % 2) != (police % 2),
                          ["Beverage:milk", "Job:police-officer"])

    # Clue 13
    # sailing and manager different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda sailing, manager: (sailing % 2) != (manager % 2),
                          ["Sport:sailing", "Job:manager"])

    # Clue 14
    # time-travel and 7up same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda time_travel, sevenup: (time_travel % 2) == (sevenup % 2),
                          ["Movie:time-travel", "Beverage:7up"])

    # Clue 15
    # fanta != police-officer or police-officer != time-travel or both
    def clue15(fanta, police, time_travel):
        if fanta == police and police == time_travel:
            return False
        return True
    problem.addConstraint(clue15,
                          ["Beverage:fanta", "Job:police-officer", "Movie:time-travel"])

    # Clue 16
    # lawyer != spy or spy != ice-hockey or both
    def clue16(lawyer, spy, ice_hockey):
        if lawyer == spy and spy == ice_hockey:
            return False
        return True
    problem.addConstraint(clue16,
                          ["Job:lawyer", "Movie:spy", "Sport:ice-hockey"])

    # Clue 17
    # water and cycling same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda water, cycling: (water % 2) == (cycling % 2),
                          ["Beverage:water", "Sport:cycling"])

    # Clue 18
    # rat somewhere between cycling and cricket (not necessarily adjacent)
    # (cycling < rat < cricket) or (cricket < rat < cycling)
    def clue18(rat, cycling, cricket):
        return (cycling < rat < cricket) or (cricket < rat < cycling)
    problem.addConstraint(clue18,
                          ["Pet:rat", "Sport:cycling", "Sport:cricket"])

    # Clue 19
    # coach same or left of comedy
    problem.addConstraint(lambda coach, comedy: coach <= comedy,
                          ["Job:coach", "Movie:comedy"])

    # Clue 20
    # ice-hockey same or right of rat
    problem.addConstraint(lambda ice_hockey, rat: ice_hockey >= rat,
                          ["Sport:ice-hockey", "Pet:rat"])

    # Clue 21
    # guinea-pig same or right of chinchilla
    problem.addConstraint(lambda guinea_pig, chinchilla: guinea_pig >= chinchilla,
                          ["Pet:guinea-pig", "Pet:chinchilla"])

    # Clue 22
    # time-travel same or right of soy-milk
    problem.addConstraint(lambda time_travel, soy_milk: time_travel >= soy_milk,
                          ["Movie:time-travel", "Beverage:soy-milk"])

    # Clue 23
    # electrician and time-travel same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda electrician, time_travel: (electrician % 2) == (time_travel % 2),
                          ["Job:electrician", "Movie:time-travel"])

    # Clue 24
    # soy-milk same or right of spy
    problem.addConstraint(lambda soy_milk, spy: soy_milk >= spy,
                          ["Beverage:soy-milk", "Movie:spy"])

    # Clue 25 (same as 1, repeated)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda coach, milk: (coach % 2) != (milk % 2),
                          ["Job:coach", "Beverage:milk"])

    # Clue 26
    # action same or left of electrician
    problem.addConstraint(lambda action, electrician: action <= electrician,
                          ["Movie:action", "Job:electrician"])

    # Clue 27
    # spy same or left of chinchilla
    problem.addConstraint(lambda spy, chinchilla: spy <= chinchilla,
                          ["Movie:spy", "Pet:chinchilla"])

    # Clue 28
    # disaster same or right of action
    problem.addConstraint(lambda disaster, action: disaster >= action,
                          ["Movie:disaster", "Movie:action"])

    # Clue 29
    # rugby same or left of water
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rugby, water: rugby <= water,
                          ["Sport:rugby", "Beverage:water"])

    # Clue 30
    # police-officer same or left of ice-hockey
    problem.addConstraint(lambda police, ice_hockey: police <= ice_hockey,
                          ["Job:police-officer", "Sport:ice-hockey"])

    # Clue 31
    # time-travel different from at least one of manager or hamster
    def clue31(time_travel, manager, hamster):
        return time_travel != manager or time_travel != hamster
    problem.addConstraint(clue31,
                          ["Movie:time-travel", "Job:manager", "Pet:hamster"])

    # Clue 32
    # rugby somewhere between disaster and lawyer (not necessarily adjacent)
    # (disaster < rugby < lawyer) or (lawyer < rugby < disaster)
    def clue32(rugby, disaster, lawyer):
        return (disaster < rugby < lawyer) or (lawyer < rugby < disaster)
    problem.addConstraint(clue32,
                          ["Sport:rugby", "Movie:disaster", "Job:lawyer"])

    # Clue 33
    # disaster same or right of cycling
    problem.addConstraint(lambda disaster, cycling: disaster >= cycling,
                          ["Movie:disaster", "Sport:cycling"])

    # Clue 34
    # guinea-pig same or left of comedy
    problem.addConstraint(lambda guinea_pig, comedy: guinea_pig <= comedy,
                          ["Pet:guinea-pig", "Movie:comedy"])

    # Clue 35
    # 7up same or right of coach
    problem.addConstraint(lambda sevenup, coach: sevenup >= coach,
                          ["Beverage:7up", "Job:coach"])

    # Clue 36
    # rat != soy-milk or soy-milk != manager or both
    def clue36(rat, soy_milk, manager):
        return rat != soy_milk or soy_milk != manager
    problem.addConstraint(clue36,
                          ["Pet:rat", "Beverage:soy-milk", "Job:manager"])

    # Clue 37
    # fanta same or left of water
    problem.addConstraint(lambda fanta, water: fanta <= water,
                          ["Beverage:fanta", "Beverage:water"])

    # Clue 38
    # comedy same or right of spy
    problem.addConstraint(lambda comedy, spy: comedy >= spy,
                          ["Movie:comedy", "Movie:spy"])

    # Clue 39
    # fanta == comedy or manager == fanta or both
    def clue39(fanta, comedy, manager):
        return fanta == comedy or manager == fanta
    problem.addConstraint(clue39,
                          ["Beverage:fanta", "Movie:comedy", "Job:manager"])

    # Clue 40
    # (7up == chinchilla) XOR (chinchilla == rugby)
    def clue40(sevenup, chinchilla, rugby):
        a = (sevenup == chinchilla)
        b = (chinchilla == rugby)
        return a != b
    problem.addConstraint(clue40,
                          ["Beverage:7up", "Pet:chinchilla", "Sport:rugby"])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # If multiple solutions, raise error
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 3 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 2 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 3 unique items:

1. Pet: turtle, rat, rabbit
2. Music: funk, reggae, disco

Each category has exactly 3 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes disco music is directly between the person who likes funk music and the person who has rabbit as a pet
2. the person who has turtle as a pet is directly between the person who likes funk music and the person who likes reggae music
3. the person who likes reggae music is to the left of the person who likes disco music (not necessarily immediately)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Music", "Pet").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 3

    categories = ["Pet", "Music"]
    items = {
        "Pet": ["turtle", "rat", "rabbit"],
        "Music": ["funk", "reggae", "disco"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain being the possible positions (0,1,2)
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_items = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_items)

    # Clue 1: disco is directly between funk and rabbit
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda disco, funk, rabbit: (disco == funk + 1 and disco == rabbit - 1) or (disco == funk - 1 and disco == rabbit + 1),
        ["Music:disco", "Music:funk", "Pet:rabbit"]
    )

    # Clue 2: turtle is directly between funk and reggae
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda turtle, funk, reggae: (turtle == funk + 1 and turtle == reggae - 1) or (turtle == funk - 1 and turtle == reggae + 1),
        ["Pet:turtle", "Music:funk", "Music:reggae"]
    )

    # Clue 3: reggae is to the left of disco (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda reggae, disco: reggae < disco,
        ["Music:reggae", "Music:disco"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {category: [""] * num_positions for category in categories}

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[var]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Music: ambient, gospel, disco, soul, r&b
2. Food: garlic, onion, radish, tomato, orange
3. Job: security-guard, social-worker, librarian, bartender, manager
4. Movie: martial-arts, documentary, time-travel, drama, superhero

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes superhero movies is at the same position as or to the right of the person who works as a security-guard
2. the person who likes onion and the person who likes soul music are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
3. the person who likes time-travel movies is immediately to the left of the person who works as a social-worker
4. the person who likes ambient music is immediately to the right of the person who likes r&b music
5. the person who likes gospel music is a different person than the person who likes garlic
6. the person who works as a librarian is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes ambient music
7. the person who works as a social-worker is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes r&b music
8. the person who likes drama movies is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes garlic
9. the person who likes superhero movies is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes ambient music
10. the person who likes orange is to the right of the person who works as a bartender (not necessarily immediately)
11. the person who likes tomato is the same person as the person who works as a security-guard
12. the person who likes superhero movies is a different person than the person who likes tomato
13. the person who likes drama movies is directly between the person who likes time-travel movies and the person who likes documentary movies
14. the person who likes onion is a different person than the person who works as a social-worker
15. the person who likes gospel music is to the right of the person who likes orange (not necessarily immediately)
16. the person who works as a bartender is a different person than the person who likes ambient music
17. the person who likes orange is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes radish
18. the person who works as a librarian is a different person than the person who likes onion

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Music", "Food", "Job", "Movie"]
    items = {
        "Music": ["ambient", "gospel", "disco", "soul", "r&b"],
        "Food": ["garlic", "onion", "radish", "tomato", "orange"],
        "Job": ["security-guard", "social-worker", "librarian", "bartender", "manager"],
        "Movie": ["martial-arts", "documentary", "time-travel", "drama", "superhero"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # AllDifferent constraints within each category
    for category in categories:
        category_vars = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_vars)

    # Clues:

    # 1. superhero movies >= security-guard
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda superhero, security_guard: superhero >= security_guard,
        ["Movie:superhero", "Job:security-guard"]
    )

    # 2. onion and soul music different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda onion, soul: (onion % 2) != (soul % 2),
        ["Food:onion", "Music:soul"]
    )

    # 3. time-travel immediately left of social-worker
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda time_travel, social_worker: time_travel == social_worker - 1,
        ["Movie:time-travel", "Job:social-worker"]
    )

    # 4. ambient immediately right of r&b
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda ambient, rnb: ambient == rnb + 1,
        ["Music:ambient", "Music:r&b"]
    )

    # 5. gospel and garlic different person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda gospel, garlic: gospel != garlic,
        ["Music:gospel", "Food:garlic"]
    )

    # 6. librarian >= ambient
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda librarian, ambient: librarian >= ambient,
        ["Job:librarian", "Music:ambient"]
    )

    # 7. social-worker >= r&b
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda social_worker, rnb: social_worker >= rnb,
        ["Job:social-worker", "Music:r&b"]
    )

    # 8. drama <= garlic
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda drama, garlic: drama <= garlic,
        ["Movie:drama", "Food:garlic"]
    )

    # 9. superhero <= ambient
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda superhero, ambient: superhero <= ambient,
        ["Movie:superhero", "Music:ambient"]
    )

    # 10. orange > bartender
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda orange, bartender: orange > bartender,
        ["Food:orange", "Job:bartender"]
    )

    # 11. tomato == security-guard
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda tomato, security_guard: tomato == security_guard,
        ["Food:tomato", "Job:security-guard"]
    )

    # 12. superhero != tomato
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda superhero, tomato: superhero != tomato,
        ["Movie:superhero", "Food:tomato"]
    )

    # 13. drama directly between time-travel and documentary
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda drama, time_travel, documentary: (drama == time_travel + 1 and drama == documentary - 1) or (drama == documentary + 1 and drama == time_travel - 1),
        ["Movie:drama", "Movie:time-travel", "Movie:documentary"]
    )

    # 14. onion != social-worker
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda onion, social_worker: onion != social_worker,
        ["Food:onion", "Job:social-worker"]
    )

    # 15. gospel > orange
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda gospel, orange: gospel > orange,
        ["Music:gospel", "Food:orange"]
    )

    # 16. bartender != ambient
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bartender, ambient: bartender != ambient,
        ["Job:bartender", "Music:ambient"]
    )

    # 17. orange >= radish
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda orange, radish: orange >= radish,
        ["Food:orange", "Food:radish"]
    )

    # 18. librarian != onion
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda librarian, onion: librarian != onion,
        ["Job:librarian", "Food:onion"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[var_name]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Sport: skateboarding, golf, cycling, climbing
2. Job: architect, engineer, manager, lawyer
3. Movie: zombie, thriller, satire, scientific

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes zombie movies is the same person as the person who plays cycling
2. the person who works as a lawyer is adjacent to the person who works as a architect (either immediately left or right)
3. the person who likes scientific movies is to the right of the person who works as a architect (not necessarily immediately)
4. the person who likes thriller movies is the same person as the person who plays skateboarding
5. the person who plays cycling is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
6. the person who works as a manager is immediately to the left of the person who works as a engineer
7. the person who likes thriller movies is adjacent to the person who works as a manager (either immediately left or right)
8. the person who plays golf is adjacent to the person who likes thriller movies (either immediately left or right)
9. the person who likes thriller movies is to the left of the person who works as a lawyer (not necessarily immediately)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Job", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Sport", "Job", "Movie"]
    items = {
        "Sport": ["skateboarding", "golf", "cycling", "climbing"],
        "Job": ["architect", "engineer", "manager", "lawyer"],
        "Movie": ["zombie", "thriller", "satire", "scientific"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(),
                              [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: the person who likes zombie movies is the same person as the person who plays cycling
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda zombie, cycling: zombie == cycling,
        ["Movie:zombie", "Sport:cycling"]
    )

    # Clue 2: the person who works as a lawyer is adjacent to the person who works as an architect
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lawyer, architect: abs(lawyer - architect) == 1,
        ["Job:lawyer", "Job:architect"]
    )

    # Clue 3: the person who likes scientific movies is to the right of the person who works as an architect
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda scientific, architect: scientific > architect,
        ["Movie:scientific", "Job:architect"]
    )

    # Clue 4: the person who likes thriller movies is the same person as the person who plays skateboarding
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda thriller, skateboarding: thriller == skateboarding,
        ["Movie:thriller", "Sport:skateboarding"]
    )

    # Clue 5: the person who plays cycling is at an end position (0 or 3)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cycling: cycling == 0 or cycling == num_positions - 1,
        ["Sport:cycling"]
    )

    # Clue 6: the person who works as a manager is immediately to the left of the person who works as an engineer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda manager, engineer: manager == engineer - 1,
        ["Job:manager", "Job:engineer"]
    )

    # Clue 7: the person who likes thriller movies is adjacent to the person who works as a manager
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda thriller, manager: abs(thriller - manager) == 1,
        ["Movie:thriller", "Job:manager"]
    )

    # Clue 8: the person who plays golf is adjacent to the person who likes thriller movies
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda golf, thriller: abs(golf - thriller) == 1,
        ["Sport:golf", "Movie:thriller"]
    )

    # Clue 9: the person who likes thriller movies is to the left of the person who works as a lawyer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda thriller, lawyer: thriller < lawyer,
        ["Movie:thriller", "Job:lawyer"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # If multiple solutions found, raise error
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format the solution dictionary
    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Music: classical, folk, funk, blues
2. Sport: tennis, cricket, handball, rugby
3. Food: onion, plum, lettuce, artichoke
4. Pet: cat, snake, ferret, guinea-pig

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who has cat as a pet is the same person as the person who plays cricket
2. the person who likes classical music and the person who plays cricket are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
3. the person who likes funk music is the same person as the person who plays handball
4. the person who likes lettuce is immediately to the left of the person who likes plum
5. the person who plays cricket is to the left of the person who has ferret as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
6. the person who plays tennis is the same person as at least one of the person who likes artichoke or the person who has snake as a pet
7. the person who likes lettuce is to the right of the person who has ferret as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
8. the person who likes plum is immediately to the right of the person who likes folk music
9. the person who likes funk music is the same person as the person who has snake as a pet

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Music").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Music", "Sport", "Food", "Pet"]
    items = {
        "Music": ["classical", "folk", "funk", "blues"],
        "Sport": ["tennis", "cricket", "handball", "rugby"],
        "Food": ["onion", "plum", "lettuce", "artichoke"],
        "Pet": ["cat", "snake", "ferret", "guinea-pig"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be in different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: the person who has cat as a pet is the same person as the person who plays cricket
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cat, cricket: cat == cricket,
        ["Pet:cat", "Sport:cricket"]
    )

    # Clue 2: the person who likes classical music and the person who plays cricket are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda classical, cricket: classical % 2 != cricket % 2,
        ["Music:classical", "Sport:cricket"]
    )

    # Clue 3: the person who likes funk music is the same person as the person who plays handball
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda funk, handball: funk == handball,
        ["Music:funk", "Sport:handball"]
    )

    # Clue 4: the person who likes lettuce is immediately to the left of the person who likes plum
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lettuce, plum: lettuce == plum - 1,
        ["Food:lettuce", "Food:plum"]
    )

    # Clue 5: the person who plays cricket is to the left of the person who has ferret as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cricket, ferret: cricket < ferret,
        ["Sport:cricket", "Pet:ferret"]
    )

    # Clue 6: the person who plays tennis is the same person as at least one of the person who likes artichoke or the person who has snake as a pet
    # This means tennis == artichoke OR tennis == snake
    # We implement this by a custom constraint over tennis, artichoke, snake
    def tennis_artichoke_snake(tennis, artichoke, snake):
        return tennis == artichoke or tennis == snake
    problem.addConstraint(
        tennis_artichoke_snake,
        ["Sport:tennis", "Food:artichoke", "Pet:snake"]
    )

    # Clue 7: the person who likes lettuce is to the right of the person who has ferret as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lettuce, ferret: lettuce > ferret,
        ["Food:lettuce", "Pet:ferret"]
    )

    # Clue 8: the person who likes plum is immediately to the right of the person who likes folk music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda plum, folk: plum == folk + 1,
        ["Food:plum", "Music:folk"]
    )

    # Clue 9: the person who likes funk music is the same person as the person who has snake as a pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda funk, snake: funk == snake,
        ["Music:funk", "Pet:snake"]
    )

    # Solve
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # Just take first solution if multiple
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Create a list of length num_positions
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Pet: rabbit, lizard, rat, fish, frog
2. Beverage: fanta, tea, iced-tea, almond-milk, mirinda
3. Job: manager, bartender, project-manager, software-developer, designer
4. Transport: bike, scooter, airplane, jet-ski, car
5. Sport: volleyball, golf, cricket, climbing, baseball

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who works as a project-manager is the same person as the person who uses jet-ski for transportation or the person who plays golf is the same person as the person who works as a project-manager, but not both
2. the person who has lizard as a pet is to the right of the person who works as a designer (not necessarily immediately)
3. the person who works as a bartender is at the same position as or to the left of the person who works as a designer
4. the person who uses car for transportation is the same person as at least one of the person who has rabbit as a pet or the person who works as a bartender
5. the person who plays cricket is to the right of the person who uses car for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
6. the person who plays baseball is a different person than the person who has fish as a pet
7. the person who has frog as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who works as a manager
8. the person who works as a software-developer is at the same position as or to the left of the person who uses scooter for transportation
9. the person who likes tea is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes almond-milk
10. the person who uses car for transportation is a different person than at least one of the person who plays climbing or the person who likes fanta
11. the person who uses car for transportation is to the right of the person who uses scooter for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
12. the person who uses bike for transportation is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes tea
13. the person who has frog as a pet is to the left of the person who has rat as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
14. the person who plays climbing and the person who likes fanta are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
15. the person who likes mirinda is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses car for transportation
16. the person who uses jet-ski for transportation is at the same position as or to the left of the person who works as a designer
17. the person who likes mirinda and the person who uses bike for transportation are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
18. the person who likes almond-milk and the person who uses jet-ski for transportation are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
19. the person who works as a project-manager and the person who plays climbing are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
20. the person who plays cricket is at the same position as or to the left of the person who works as a bartender

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Pet", "Beverage", "Job", "Transport", "Sport"]
    items = {
        "Pet": ["rabbit", "lizard", "rat", "fish", "frog"],
        "Beverage": ["fanta", "tea", "iced-tea", "almond-milk", "mirinda"],
        "Job": ["manager", "bartender", "project-manager", "software-developer", "designer"],
        "Transport": ["bike", "scooter", "airplane", "jet-ski", "car"],
        "Sport": ["volleyball", "golf", "cricket", "climbing", "baseball"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain 0..4 (positions)
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: XOR between "project-manager" == "jet-ski" or "golf" == "project-manager"
    def clue1(pm, js, golf):
        return (pm == js) != (golf == pm)
    problem.addConstraint(clue1,
                          ["Job:project-manager", "Transport:jet-ski", "Sport:golf"])

    # Clue 2: lizard is to the right of designer (lizard > designer)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda lizard, designer: lizard > designer,
                          ["Pet:lizard", "Job:designer"])

    # Clue 3: bartender same or to left of designer (bartender <= designer)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda bartender, designer: bartender <= designer,
                          ["Job:bartender", "Job:designer"])

    # Clue 4: car same as at least one of rabbit or bartender
    # (car == rabbit) or (car == bartender)
    def clue4(car, rabbit, bartender):
        return car == rabbit or car == bartender
    problem.addConstraint(clue4,
                          ["Transport:car", "Pet:rabbit", "Job:bartender"])

    # Clue 5: cricket is to the right of car (cricket > car)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda cricket, car: cricket > car,
                          ["Sport:cricket", "Transport:car"])

    # Clue 6: baseball different from fish
    problem.addConstraint(lambda baseball, fish: baseball != fish,
                          ["Sport:baseball", "Pet:fish"])

    # Clue 7: frog same or to right of manager (frog >= manager)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda frog, manager: frog >= manager,
                          ["Pet:frog", "Job:manager"])

    # Clue 8: software-developer same or to left of scooter (software-developer <= scooter)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda sd, scooter: sd <= scooter,
                          ["Job:software-developer", "Transport:scooter"])

    # Clue 9: tea same or to left of almond-milk (tea <= almond-milk)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda tea, almond: tea <= almond,
                          ["Beverage:tea", "Beverage:almond-milk"])

    # Clue 10: car different from at least one of climbing or fanta
    # i.e. car != climbing or car != fanta
    def clue10(car, climbing, fanta):
        return car != climbing or car != fanta
    problem.addConstraint(clue10,
                          ["Transport:car", "Sport:climbing", "Beverage:fanta"])

    # Clue 11: car to the right of scooter (car > scooter)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda car, scooter: car > scooter,
                          ["Transport:car", "Transport:scooter"])

    # Clue 12: bike same or to left of tea (bike <= tea)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda bike, tea: bike <= tea,
                          ["Transport:bike", "Beverage:tea"])

    # Clue 13: frog to the left of rat (frog < rat)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda frog, rat: frog < rat,
                          ["Pet:frog", "Pet:rat"])

    # Clue 14: climbing and fanta same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda climbing, fanta: climbing % 2 == fanta % 2,
                          ["Sport:climbing", "Beverage:fanta"])

    # Clue 15: mirinda same or to right of car (mirinda >= car)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda mirinda, car: mirinda >= car,
                          ["Beverage:mirinda", "Transport:car"])

    # Clue 16: jet-ski same or to left of designer (jet-ski <= designer)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda js, designer: js <= designer,
                          ["Transport:jet-ski", "Job:designer"])

    # Clue 17: mirinda and bike same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda mirinda, bike: mirinda % 2 == bike % 2,
                          ["Beverage:mirinda", "Transport:bike"])

    # Clue 18: almond-milk and jet-ski different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda almond, js: (almond % 2) != (js % 2),
                          ["Beverage:almond-milk", "Transport:jet-ski"])

    # Clue 19: project-manager and climbing different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda pm, climbing: (pm % 2) != (climbing % 2),
                          ["Job:project-manager", "Sport:climbing"])

    # Clue 20: cricket same or to left of bartender (cricket <= bartender)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda cricket, bartender: cricket <= bartender,
                          ["Sport:cricket", "Job:bartender"])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Create a list of 5 empty strings
        ordered_items = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            ordered_items[pos] = item
        result[category] = ordered_items

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

3. the person who plays badminton is immediately to the left of the person who works as a project-manager
4. the person who plays skateboarding is immediately to the right of the french person

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Job", "Nationality").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 3

    categories = ["Nationality", "Job", "Sport"]
    items = {
        "Nationality": ["malaysian", "french", "nigerian"],
        "Job": ["project-manager", "electrician", "scientist"],
        "Sport": ["badminton", "skateboarding", "golf"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: badminton is immediately to the right of malaysian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda badminton, malaysian: badminton == malaysian + 1,
        ["Sport:badminton", "Nationality:malaysian"]
    )

    # Clue 2: scientist immediately to the left of electrician
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda scientist, electrician: scientist == electrician - 1,
        ["Job:scientist", "Job:electrician"]
    )

    # Clue 3: badminton immediately to the left of project-manager
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda badminton, project_manager: badminton == project_manager - 1,
        ["Sport:badminton", "Job:project-manager"]
    )

    # Clue 4: skateboarding immediately to the right of french
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skateboarding, french: skateboarding == french + 1,
        ["Sport:skateboarding", "Nationality:french"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Create a list of length num_positions to hold items in order
        ordered_items = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[var]
            ordered_items[pos] = item
        result_dict[category] = ordered_items

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Music: salsa, dubstep, disco, blues
2. Job: librarian, accountant, teacher, photographer
3. Transport: car, taxi, boat, roller
4. Pet: lizard, mouse, hedgehog, horse

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who has mouse as a pet is immediately to the right of the person who uses roller for transportation
2. the person who uses roller for transportation is adjacent to the person who works as a librarian (either immediately left or right)
3. the person who uses car for transportation is immediately to the right of the person who likes dubstep music
4. the person who uses taxi for transportation is directly between the person who works as a accountant and the person who works as a photographer
5. the person who likes disco music is at the same position as or to the right of the person who works as a teacher
6. the person who has hedgehog as a pet and the person who works as a teacher are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
7. the person who likes salsa music and the person who works as a accountant are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
8. the person who works as a photographer is at the same position as or to the right of the person who has horse as a pet
9. the person who uses roller for transportation is a different person than the person who has hedgehog as a pet
10. the person who uses taxi for transportation is a different person than the person who works as a librarian
11. the person who has horse as a pet is immediately to the left of the person who likes blues music

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Job", "Music").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Music", "Job", "Transport", "Pet"]
    items = {
        "Music": ["salsa", "dubstep", "disco", "blues"],
        "Job": ["librarian", "accountant", "teacher", "photographer"],
        "Transport": ["car", "taxi", "boat", "roller"],
        "Pet": ["lizard", "mouse", "hedgehog", "horse"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: mouse is immediately to the right of roller
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda mouse, roller: mouse == roller + 1,
        ["Pet:mouse", "Transport:roller"]
    )

    # Clue 2: roller is adjacent to librarian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda roller, librarian: abs(roller - librarian) == 1,
        ["Transport:roller", "Job:librarian"]
    )

    # Clue 3: car is immediately to the right of dubstep
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda car, dubstep: car == dubstep + 1,
        ["Transport:car", "Music:dubstep"]
    )

    # Clue 4: taxi is directly between accountant and photographer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda taxi, accountant, photographer: (taxi == accountant + 1 and taxi == photographer - 1) or (taxi == photographer + 1 and taxi == accountant - 1),
        ["Transport:taxi", "Job:accountant", "Job:photographer"]
    )

    # Clue 5: disco is at same position or to the right of teacher
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda disco, teacher: disco >= teacher,
        ["Music:disco", "Job:teacher"]
    )

    # Clue 6: hedgehog and teacher are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda hedgehog, teacher: (hedgehog % 2) != (teacher % 2),
        ["Pet:hedgehog", "Job:teacher"]
    )

    # Clue 7: salsa and accountant are at positions with same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda salsa, accountant: (salsa % 2) == (accountant % 2),
        ["Music:salsa", "Job:accountant"]
    )

    # Clue 8: photographer is at same position or to the right of horse
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda photographer, horse: photographer >= horse,
        ["Job:photographer", "Pet:horse"]
    )

    # Clue 9: roller and hedgehog are different persons
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda roller, hedgehog: roller != hedgehog,
        ["Transport:roller", "Pet:hedgehog"]
    )

    # Clue 10: taxi and librarian are different persons
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda taxi, librarian: taxi != librarian,
        ["Transport:taxi", "Job:librarian"]
    )

    # Clue 11: horse is immediately to the left of blues
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda horse, blues: horse == blues - 1,
        ["Pet:horse", "Music:blues"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Food: onion, potato, cabbage, apple
2. Transport: roller, boat, airplane, helicopter
3. Hobby: traveling, writing, camping, board-games
4. Beverage: fanta, lemonade, hot-chocolate, cola
5. Movie: scientific, thriller, documentary, spy

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who uses airplane for transportation is directly between the person who uses helicopter for transportation and the person who enjoys traveling
2. the person who likes potato is to the right of the person who likes cabbage (not necessarily immediately)
3. the person who likes cabbage is to the left of the person who likes cola (not necessarily immediately)
4. the person who enjoys writing is at the same position as or to the right of the person who enjoys board-games
5. the person who enjoys writing is the same person as at least one of the person who likes thriller movies or the person who uses boat for transportation
6. the person who likes cabbage is to the right of the person who enjoys traveling (not necessarily immediately)
7. the person who likes lemonade is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes onion
8. the person who likes fanta is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes onion
9. the person who likes hot-chocolate is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes spy movies
10. the person who likes cola is directly between the person who likes fanta and the person who likes scientific movies
11. the person who uses roller for transportation is a different person than the person who likes spy movies or the person who likes hot-chocolate is a different person than the person who uses roller for transportation or both
12. the person who likes onion is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Food").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint


def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Food", "Transport", "Hobby", "Beverage", "Movie"]
    items = {
        "Food": ["onion", "potato", "cabbage", "apple"],
        "Transport": ["roller", "boat", "airplane", "helicopter"],
        "Hobby": ["traveling", "writing", "camping", "board-games"],
        "Beverage": ["fanta", "lemonade", "hot-chocolate", "cola"],
        "Movie": ["scientific", "thriller", "documentary", "spy"],
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain 0..3 (positions)
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be in different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: airplane is directly between helicopter and traveling
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda airplane, helicopter, traveling: (airplane == helicopter + 1 and airplane == traveling - 1)
        or (airplane == traveling + 1 and airplane == helicopter - 1),
        ["Transport:airplane", "Transport:helicopter", "Hobby:traveling"],
    )

    # Clue 2: potato is to the right of cabbage (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda potato, cabbage: potato > cabbage,
        ["Food:potato", "Food:cabbage"],
    )

    # Clue 3: cabbage is to the left of cola (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cabbage, cola: cabbage < cola,
        ["Food:cabbage", "Beverage:cola"],
    )

    # Clue 4: writing is at the same position as or to the right of board-games
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda writing, board_games: writing >= board_games,
        ["Hobby:writing", "Hobby:board-games"],
    )

    # Clue 5: writing is the same person as at least one of thriller or boat
    # So writing == thriller OR writing == boat
    # We implement this as: writing == thriller OR writing == boat
    # We can add a custom constraint that takes writing, thriller, boat and returns True if writing==thriller or writing==boat
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda writing, thriller, boat: writing == thriller or writing == boat,
        ["Hobby:writing", "Movie:thriller", "Transport:boat"],
    )

    # Clue 6: cabbage is to the right of traveling (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cabbage, traveling: cabbage > traveling,
        ["Food:cabbage", "Hobby:traveling"],
    )

    # Clue 7: lemonade is at the same position as or to the right of onion
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lemonade, onion: lemonade >= onion,
        ["Beverage:lemonade", "Food:onion"],
    )

    # Clue 8: fanta is at the same position as or to the left of onion
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fanta, onion: fanta <= onion,
        ["Beverage:fanta", "Food:onion"],
    )

    # Clue 9: hot-chocolate is at the same position as or to the right of spy
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda hot_chocolate, spy: hot_chocolate >= spy,
        ["Beverage:hot-chocolate", "Movie:spy"],
    )

    # Clue 10: cola is directly between fanta and scientific
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cola, fanta, scientific: (cola == fanta + 1 and cola == scientific - 1)
        or (cola == scientific + 1 and cola == fanta - 1),
        ["Beverage:cola", "Beverage:fanta", "Movie:scientific"],
    )

    # Clue 11: roller is a different person than spy or hot-chocolate is different than roller or both
    # So not (roller == spy and hot-chocolate == roller)
    # This is equivalent to: (roller != spy) OR (hot-chocolate != roller)
    # Implement as: if roller == spy then hot-chocolate != roller
    # or roller != spy
    def clue11(roller, spy, hot_chocolate):
        if roller == spy:
            return hot_chocolate != roller
        else:
            return True

    problem.addConstraint(
        clue11,
        ["Transport:roller", "Movie:spy", "Beverage:hot-chocolate"],
    )

    # Clue 12: onion is at an end position (0 or 3)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda onion: onion == 0 or onion == num_positions - 1,
        ["Food:onion"],
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format solution dictionary
    result = {category: [""] * num_positions for category in categories}
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)


solve_einstein_puzzle()
