from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Nationality", "Sport", "Hobby", "Food", "Beverage"]
    items = {
        "Nationality": ["japanese", "american", "pakistani", "chinese", "brazilian"],
        "Sport": ["golf", "skateboarding", "badminton", "parkour", "biathlon"],
        "Hobby": ["collecting", "sudoku", "video-games", "cooking", "baking"],
        "Food": ["cauliflower", "lettuce", "eggplant", "kale", "peas"],
        "Beverage": ["sprite", "hot-chocolate", "fanta", "water", "cola"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # AllDifferent constraints within categories
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Helper lambdas
    same_parity = lambda x, y: x % 2 == y % 2
    different_parity = lambda x, y: x % 2 != y % 2
    left_or_same = lambda x, y: x <= y
    right_or_same = lambda x, y: x >= y
    left = lambda x, y: x < y
    right = lambda x, y: x > y
    adjacent = lambda x, y: abs(x - y) == 1
    between = lambda x, a, b: (a < x < b) or (b < x < a)
    exactly_one_same = lambda x, y, z: (x == y) != (x == z)  # xor
    xor = lambda a, b: a != b

    # Clues:

    # 1. parkour and collecting same parity
    problem.addConstraint(same_parity, ["Sport:parkour", "Hobby:collecting"])

    # 2. american at same or right of sprite
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Beverage:sprite", "Nationality:american"])

    # 3. cooking and peas same parity
    problem.addConstraint(same_parity, ["Hobby:cooking", "Food:peas"])

    # 4. badminton at same or right of biathlon
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Sport:biathlon", "Sport:badminton"])

    # 5. american != sudoku or sudoku != water or both
    # (american != sudoku) or (sudoku != water)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda american, sudoku, water: (american != sudoku) or (sudoku != water),
        ["Nationality:american", "Hobby:sudoku", "Beverage:water"]
    )

    # 6. pakistani != golf or video-games != pakistani or both
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pakistani, golf, video_games: (pakistani != golf) or (video_games != pakistani),
        ["Nationality:pakistani", "Sport:golf", "Hobby:video-games"]
    )

    # 7. lettuce and collecting same parity
    problem.addConstraint(same_parity, ["Food:lettuce", "Hobby:collecting"])

    # 8. water != biathlon
    problem.addConstraint(lambda water, biathlon: water != biathlon, ["Beverage:water", "Sport:biathlon"])

    # 9. parkour same or right of badminton
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Sport:badminton", "Sport:parkour"])

    # 10. lettuce same person as exactly one of pakistani or cola
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lettuce, pakistani, cola: exactly_one_same(lettuce, pakistani, cola),
        ["Food:lettuce", "Nationality:pakistani", "Beverage:cola"]
    )

    # 11. parkour same or right of video-games
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Hobby:video-games", "Sport:parkour"])

    # 12. (video-games == eggplant) xor (brazilian == video-games)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda video_games, eggplant, brazilian: xor(video_games == eggplant, brazilian == video_games),
        ["Hobby:video-games", "Food:eggplant", "Nationality:brazilian"]
    )

    # 13. (cola == lettuce) or (japanese == cola) or both
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cola, lettuce, japanese: (cola == lettuce) or (japanese == cola),
        ["Beverage:cola", "Food:lettuce", "Nationality:japanese"]
    )

    # 14. (cola != skateboarding) or (sudoku != cola) or both
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cola, skateboarding, sudoku: (cola != skateboarding) or (sudoku != cola),
        ["Beverage:cola", "Sport:skateboarding", "Hobby:sudoku"]
    )

    # 15. water and japanese same parity
    problem.addConstraint(same_parity, ["Beverage:water", "Nationality:japanese"])

    # 16. pakistani != badminton
    problem.addConstraint(lambda pakistani, badminton: pakistani != badminton, ["Nationality:pakistani", "Sport:badminton"])

    # 17. eggplant same or right of collecting
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Hobby:collecting", "Food:eggplant"])

    # 18. japanese same or left of lettuce
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Nationality:japanese", "Food:lettuce"])

    # 19. sudoku and american different parity
    problem.addConstraint(different_parity, ["Hobby:sudoku", "Nationality:american"])

    # 20. lettuce between sudoku and cauliflower (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lettuce, sudoku, cauliflower: between(lettuce, sudoku, cauliflower),
        ["Food:lettuce", "Hobby:sudoku", "Food:cauliflower"]
    )

    # 21. eggplant and collecting different parity
    problem.addConstraint(different_parity, ["Food:eggplant", "Hobby:collecting"])

    # 22. golf same or left of baking
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Sport:golf", "Hobby:baking"])

    # 23. fanta != chinese or parkour != fanta or both
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fanta, chinese, parkour: (fanta != chinese) or (parkour != fanta),
        ["Beverage:fanta", "Nationality:chinese", "Sport:parkour"]
    )

    # 24. pakistani same or right of biathlon
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Sport:biathlon", "Nationality:pakistani"])

    # 25. sprite same or left of japanese
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Beverage:sprite", "Nationality:japanese"])

    # 26. sudoku != eggplant
    problem.addConstraint(lambda sudoku, eggplant: sudoku != eggplant, ["Hobby:sudoku", "Food:eggplant"])

    # 27. eggplant same or right of skateboarding
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Sport:skateboarding", "Food:eggplant"])

    # 28. sudoku same or left of collecting
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Hobby:sudoku", "Hobby:collecting"])

    # 29. water between parkour and japanese (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda water, parkour, japanese: between(water, parkour, japanese),
        ["Beverage:water", "Sport:parkour", "Nationality:japanese"]
    )

    # 30. sudoku same or left of biathlon
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Hobby:sudoku", "Sport:biathlon"])

    # 31. hot-chocolate same or left of fanta
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Beverage:hot-chocolate", "Beverage:fanta"])

    # 32. pakistani and video-games different parity
    problem.addConstraint(different_parity, ["Nationality:pakistani", "Hobby:video-games"])

    # 33. video-games same or left of brazilian
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Hobby:video-games", "Nationality:brazilian"])

    # 34. fanta same or right of chinese
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Nationality:chinese", "Beverage:fanta"])

    # 35. (chinese == peas) xor (water == chinese)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda chinese, peas, water: xor(chinese == peas, water == chinese),
        ["Nationality:chinese", "Food:peas", "Beverage:water"]
    )

    # 36. japanese != water
    problem.addConstraint(lambda japanese, water: japanese != water, ["Nationality:japanese", "Beverage:water"])

    # 37. golf same or right of water
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Beverage:water", "Sport:golf"])

    # 38. cola same or left of lettuce
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Beverage:cola", "Food:lettuce"])

    # 39. biathlon same or left of parkour
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Sport:biathlon", "Sport:parkour"])

    # 40. eggplant same or right of water
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Beverage:water", "Food:eggplant"])

    # 41. golf same or left of pakistani
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Sport:golf", "Nationality:pakistani"])

    # 42. japanese same or left of pakistani
    problem.addConstraint(left_or_same, ["Nationality:japanese", "Nationality:pakistani"])

    # 43. hot-chocolate and cooking same parity
    problem.addConstraint(same_parity, ["Beverage:hot-chocolate", "Hobby:cooking"])

    # Solve
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Sport: baseball, surfing, weightlifting, rowing
2. Job: musician, manager, software-developer, engineer
3. Food: pineapple, cauliflower, corn, tomato

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes pineapple is immediately to the right of the person who plays surfing
2. the person who plays surfing is the same person as the person who likes corn
3. the person who works as a engineer is immediately to the left of the person who plays baseball
4. the person who plays surfing is immediately to the left of the person who works as a software-developer
5. the person who plays rowing is immediately to the left of the person who works as a engineer
6. the person who works as a engineer is immediately to the left of the person who works as a musician
7. the person who works as a engineer is immediately to the left of the person who likes cauliflower

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Sport", "Job", "Food"]
    items = {
        "Sport": ["baseball", "surfing", "weightlifting", "rowing"],
        "Job": ["musician", "manager", "software-developer", "engineer"],
        "Food": ["pineapple", "cauliflower", "corn", "tomato"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All different constraints within categories
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: pineapple is immediately to the right of surfing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pineapple, surfing: pineapple == surfing + 1,
        ["Food:pineapple", "Sport:surfing"]
    )

    # Clue 2: surfing is the same person as corn
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda surfing, corn: surfing == corn,
        ["Sport:surfing", "Food:corn"]
    )

    # Clue 3: engineer is immediately to the left of baseball
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda engineer, baseball: engineer == baseball - 1,
        ["Job:engineer", "Sport:baseball"]
    )

    # Clue 4: surfing is immediately to the left of software-developer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda surfing, software_developer: surfing == software_developer - 1,
        ["Sport:surfing", "Job:software-developer"]
    )

    # Clue 5: rowing is immediately to the left of engineer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rowing, engineer: rowing == engineer - 1,
        ["Sport:rowing", "Job:engineer"]
    )

    # Clue 6: engineer is immediately to the left of musician
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda engineer, musician: engineer == musician - 1,
        ["Job:engineer", "Job:musician"]
    )

    # Clue 7: engineer is immediately to the left of cauliflower
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda engineer, cauliflower: engineer == cauliflower - 1,
        ["Job:engineer", "Food:cauliflower"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Food: radish, plum, onion, broccoli
2. Movie: martial-arts, adventure, sports, horror
3. Job: social-worker, writer, chef, musician
4. Pet: bird, chinchilla, lizard, mouse

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes horror movies is at an odd-numbered position
2. the person who likes sports movies is immediately to the right of the person who works as a chef
3. the person who works as a writer is immediately to the left of the person who has chinchilla as a pet
4. the person who has lizard as a pet is to the left of the person who likes radish (not necessarily immediately)
5. the person who likes martial-arts movies is at an odd-numbered position
6. the person who likes broccoli is immediately to the left of the person who likes horror movies
7. the person who has lizard as a pet is to the right of the person who has bird as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
8. the person who has mouse as a pet is somewhere between the person who works as a musician and the person who likes adventure movies (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
9. the person who likes plum is adjacent to the person who works as a social-worker (either immediately left or right)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Food", "Movie", "Job", "Pet"]
    items = {
        "Food": ["radish", "plum", "onion", "broccoli"],
        "Movie": ["martial-arts", "adventure", "sports", "horror"],
        "Job": ["social-worker", "writer", "chef", "musician"],
        "Pet": ["bird", "chinchilla", "lizard", "mouse"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_category = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_category)

    # Clue 1: the person who likes horror movies is at an odd-numbered position
    problem.addConstraint(lambda horror: horror % 2 == 0, ["Movie:horror"])  # positions 0,2 are odd-numbered 1,3

    # Clue 2: the person who likes sports movies is immediately to the right of the person who works as a chef
    problem.addConstraint(lambda chef, sports: sports == chef + 1, ["Job:chef", "Movie:sports"])

    # Clue 3: the person who works as a writer is immediately to the left of the person who has chinchilla as a pet
    problem.addConstraint(lambda writer, chinchilla: writer == chinchilla - 1, ["Job:writer", "Pet:chinchilla"])

    # Clue 4: the person who has lizard as a pet is to the left of the person who likes radish (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda lizard, radish: lizard < radish, ["Pet:lizard", "Food:radish"])

    # Clue 5: the person who likes martial-arts movies is at an odd-numbered position
    problem.addConstraint(lambda martial_arts: martial_arts % 2 == 0, ["Movie:martial-arts"])

    # Clue 6: the person who likes broccoli is immediately to the left of the person who likes horror movies
    problem.addConstraint(lambda broccoli, horror: broccoli == horror - 1, ["Food:broccoli", "Movie:horror"])

    # Clue 7: the person who has lizard as a pet is to the right of the person who has bird as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda bird, lizard: bird < lizard, ["Pet:bird", "Pet:lizard"])

    # Clue 8: the person who has mouse as a pet is somewhere between the person who works as a musician and the person who likes adventure movies (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
    def mouse_between(musician, mouse, adventure):
        # mouse position is strictly between musician and adventure positions
        return (musician < mouse < adventure) or (adventure < mouse < musician)
    problem.addConstraint(mouse_between, ["Job:musician", "Pet:mouse", "Movie:adventure"])

    # Clue 9: the person who likes plum is adjacent to the person who works as a social-worker (either immediately left or right)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda plum, social_worker: abs(plum - social_worker) == 1, ["Food:plum", "Job:social-worker"])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    # Should be unique solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Food", "Transport", "Hobby", "Movie", "Pet"]
    items = {
        "Food": ["asparagus", "pumpkin", "radish", "strawberry", "garlic"],
        "Transport": ["bike", "subway", "scooter", "skateboard", "ship"],
        "Hobby": ["camping", "reading", "collecting", "gardening", "hiking"],
        "Movie": ["horror", "superhero", "spy", "animation", "scientific"],
        "Pet": ["bird", "dog", "pony", "hedgehog", "snake"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in a category must be assigned to different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: pumpkin <= scooter
    problem.addConstraint(lambda pumpkin, scooter: pumpkin <= scooter,
                          ["Food:pumpkin", "Transport:scooter"])

    # Clue 2: spy >= dog
    problem.addConstraint(lambda spy, dog: spy >= dog,
                          ["Movie:spy", "Pet:dog"])

    # Clue 3: strawberry != reading or hedgehog != strawberry or both
    # This means strawberry != reading OR hedgehog != strawberry
    # We model as: NOT (strawberry == reading AND hedgehog == strawberry)
    def clue3(strawberry, reading, hedgehog):
        return not (strawberry == reading == hedgehog)
    problem.addConstraint(clue3, ["Food:strawberry", "Hobby:reading", "Pet:hedgehog"])

    # Clue 4: strawberry > garlic
    problem.addConstraint(lambda strawberry, garlic: strawberry > garlic,
                          ["Food:strawberry", "Food:garlic"])

    # Clue 5: spy and dog different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda spy, dog: (spy % 2) != (dog % 2),
                          ["Movie:spy", "Pet:dog"])

    # Clue 6: camping and dog different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda camping, dog: (camping % 2) != (dog % 2),
                          ["Hobby:camping", "Pet:dog"])

    # Clue 7: animation < camping
    problem.addConstraint(lambda animation, camping: animation < camping,
                          ["Movie:animation", "Hobby:camping"])

    # Clue 8: radish < bird
    problem.addConstraint(lambda radish, bird: radish < bird,
                          ["Food:radish", "Pet:bird"])

    # Clue 9: hiking between camping and hedgehog
    # Means hiking > min(camping, hedgehog) and hiking < max(camping, hedgehog)
    def clue9(hiking, camping, hedgehog):
        return (min(camping, hedgehog) < hiking < max(camping, hedgehog))
    problem.addConstraint(clue9, ["Hobby:hiking", "Hobby:camping", "Pet:hedgehog"])

    # Clue 10: bike == snake or bike == collecting
    def clue10(bike, snake, collecting):
        return bike == snake or bike == collecting
    problem.addConstraint(clue10, ["Transport:bike", "Pet:snake", "Hobby:collecting"])

    # Clue 11: ship >= horror
    problem.addConstraint(lambda ship, horror: ship >= horror,
                          ["Transport:ship", "Movie:horror"])

    # Clue 12: subway == superhero XOR camping == subway
    def clue12(subway, superhero, camping):
        return (subway == superhero) != (camping == subway)
    problem.addConstraint(clue12, ["Transport:subway", "Movie:superhero", "Hobby:camping"])

    # Clue 13: scooter >= strawberry
    problem.addConstraint(lambda scooter, strawberry: scooter >= strawberry,
                          ["Transport:scooter", "Food:strawberry"])

    # Clue 14: horror <= scientific
    problem.addConstraint(lambda horror, scientific: horror <= scientific,
                          ["Movie:horror", "Movie:scientific"])

    # Clue 15: collecting <= hiking
    problem.addConstraint(lambda collecting, hiking: collecting <= hiking,
                          ["Hobby:collecting", "Hobby:hiking"])

    # Clue 16: snake <= horror
    problem.addConstraint(lambda snake, horror: snake <= horror,
                          ["Pet:snake", "Movie:horror"])

    # Clue 17: garlic and scooter different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda garlic, scooter: (garlic % 2) != (scooter % 2),
                          ["Food:garlic", "Transport:scooter"])

    # Clue 18: dog and subway same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda dog, subway: (dog % 2) == (subway % 2),
                          ["Pet:dog", "Transport:subway"])

    # Clue 19: radish >= pony
    problem.addConstraint(lambda radish, pony: radish >= pony,
                          ["Food:radish", "Pet:pony"])

    # Clue 20: asparagus same person as exactly one of pony or collecting
    # Means asparagus == pony XOR asparagus == collecting
    def clue20(asparagus, pony, collecting):
        return (asparagus == pony) != (asparagus == collecting)
    problem.addConstraint(clue20, ["Food:asparagus", "Pet:pony", "Hobby:collecting"])

    # Clue 21: bike >= bird
    problem.addConstraint(lambda bike, bird: bike >= bird,
                          ["Transport:bike", "Pet:bird"])

    # Solve
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # There should be exactly one solution
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        arr = [None]*num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            arr[pos] = item
        result[category] = arr

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Food: lettuce, orange, zucchini, cauliflower
2. Job: videographer, doctor, engineer, project-manager
3. Transport: helicopter, skateboard, tram, boat
4. Pet: snake, fish, pony, bird

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who has snake as a pet is to the left of the person who likes orange (not necessarily immediately)
2. the person who uses helicopter for transportation is at the same position as or to the left of the person who uses skateboard for transportation
3. the person who uses helicopter for transportation is to the right of the person who likes orange (not necessarily immediately)
4. the person who likes orange is a different person than the person who works as a doctor
5. the person who likes lettuce is to the right of the person who works as a engineer (not necessarily immediately)
6. the person who has fish as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses helicopter for transportation
7. the person who uses helicopter for transportation is directly between the person who uses boat for transportation and the person who works as a project-manager
8. the person who works as a videographer is the same person as the person who has pony as a pet or the person who uses boat for transportation is the same person as the person who works as a videographer or both
9. the person who has bird as a pet and the person who works as a doctor are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
10. the person who likes zucchini and the person who has snake as a pet are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Food", "Job", "Transport", "Pet"]
    items = {
        "Food": ["lettuce", "orange", "zucchini", "cauliflower"],
        "Job": ["videographer", "doctor", "engineer", "project-manager"],
        "Transport": ["helicopter", "skateboard", "tram", "boat"],
        "Pet": ["snake", "fish", "pony", "bird"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category have different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: snake pet is to the left of orange food (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda snake, orange: snake < orange,
        ["Pet:snake", "Food:orange"]
    )

    # Clue 2: helicopter transport is at same position or to the left of skateboard transport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda helicopter, skateboard: helicopter <= skateboard,
        ["Transport:helicopter", "Transport:skateboard"]
    )

    # Clue 3: helicopter transport is to the right of orange food (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda helicopter, orange: helicopter > orange,
        ["Transport:helicopter", "Food:orange"]
    )

    # Clue 4: orange food is a different person than doctor job
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda orange, doctor: orange != doctor,
        ["Food:orange", "Job:doctor"]
    )

    # Clue 5: lettuce food is to the right of engineer job (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lettuce, engineer: lettuce > engineer,
        ["Food:lettuce", "Job:engineer"]
    )

    # Clue 6: fish pet is at same position or to the right of helicopter transport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fish, helicopter: fish >= helicopter,
        ["Pet:fish", "Transport:helicopter"]
    )

    # Clue 7: helicopter transport is directly between boat transport and project-manager job
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda helicopter, boat, project_manager:
            (helicopter == boat + 1 and helicopter == project_manager - 1) or
            (helicopter == project_manager + 1 and helicopter == boat - 1),
        ["Transport:helicopter", "Transport:boat", "Job:project-manager"]
    )

    # Clue 8: videographer job is same person as pony pet or boat transport or both
    # This means videographer == pony OR videographer == boat
    # We model this as a custom constraint that returns True if either condition is met
    def clue8(videographer, pony, boat):
        return videographer == pony or videographer == boat

    problem.addConstraint(
        clue8,
        ["Job:videographer", "Pet:pony", "Transport:boat"]
    )

    # Clue 9: bird pet and doctor job are at positions with same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bird, doctor: bird % 2 == doctor % 2,
        ["Pet:bird", "Job:doctor"]
    )

    # Clue 10: zucchini food and snake pet are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda zucchini, snake: (zucchini % 2) != (snake % 2),
        ["Food:zucchini", "Pet:snake"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Pet: pony, horse, ferret, bird, turtle
2. Music: country, folk, dubstep, rock, pop
3. Movie: fantasy, family, western, spy, animation
4. Food: mango, cranberry, raspberry, grapes, pineapple
5. Hobby: traveling, dancing, board-games, photography, writing

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who enjoys dancing is somewhere between the person who likes raspberry and the person who likes dubstep music (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
2. the person who enjoys dancing is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes western movies
3. the person who likes country music and the person who enjoys photography are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
4. the person who likes pop music and the person who has bird as a pet are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
5. the person who enjoys writing is somewhere between the person who has turtle as a pet and the person who has horse as a pet (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
6. the person who likes mango is the same person as the person who has ferret as a pet or the person who likes pop music is the same person as the person who likes mango or both
7. the person who likes spy movies is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes animation movies
8. the person who has horse as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who has turtle as a pet
9. the person who likes dubstep music is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes pop music
10. the person who likes country music is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes rock music
11. the person who likes western movies is the same person as the person who has bird as a pet or the person who has bird as a pet is the same person as the person who likes pop music or both
12. the person who enjoys writing is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes rock music
13. the person who has bird as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who has ferret as a pet
14. the person who likes pop music is somewhere between the person who likes western movies and the person who likes grapes (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
15. the person who likes family movies and the person who likes folk music are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
16. the person who likes folk music is the same person as exactly one of the person who enjoys board-games or the person who likes cranberry
17. the person who likes animation movies is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes western movies
18. the person who likes dubstep music is the same person as the person who likes family movies or the person who enjoys board-games is the same person as the person who likes dubstep music or both

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Hobby").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Pet", "Music", "Movie", "Food", "Hobby"]
    items = {
        "Pet": ["pony", "horse", "ferret", "bird", "turtle"],
        "Music": ["country", "folk", "dubstep", "rock", "pop"],
        "Movie": ["fantasy", "family", "western", "spy", "animation"],
        "Food": ["mango", "cranberry", "raspberry", "grapes", "pineapple"],
        "Hobby": ["traveling", "dancing", "board-games", "photography", "writing"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category have different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: dancing is somewhere between raspberry and dubstep (not necessarily adjacent)
    # dancing is between raspberry and dubstep means dancing position is strictly between raspberry and dubstep positions
    # i.e. (raspberry < dancing < dubstep) or (dubstep < dancing < raspberry)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dancing, raspberry, dubstep:
            (raspberry < dancing < dubstep) or (dubstep < dancing < raspberry),
        ["Hobby:dancing", "Food:raspberry", "Music:dubstep"]
    )

    # Clue 2: dancing is at same position or to the left of western
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dancing, western: dancing <= western,
        ["Hobby:dancing", "Movie:western"]
    )

    # Clue 3: country music and photography have same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda country, photography: country % 2 == photography % 2,
        ["Music:country", "Hobby:photography"]
    )

    # Clue 4: pop music and bird pet have same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pop, bird: pop % 2 == bird % 2,
        ["Music:pop", "Pet:bird"]
    )

    # Clue 5: writing is somewhere between turtle and horse (not necessarily adjacent)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda writing, turtle, horse:
            (turtle < writing < horse) or (horse < writing < turtle),
        ["Hobby:writing", "Pet:turtle", "Pet:horse"]
    )

    # Clue 6: mango is same person as ferret or pop is same person as mango or both
    # So mango == ferret or pop == mango or both
    def clue6(mango, ferret, pop):
        return mango == ferret or pop == mango
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue6,
        ["Food:mango", "Pet:ferret", "Music:pop"]
    )

    # Clue 7: spy is at same position or to right of animation
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda spy, animation: spy >= animation,
        ["Movie:spy", "Movie:animation"]
    )

    # Clue 8: horse is at same position or to left of turtle
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda horse, turtle: horse <= turtle,
        ["Pet:horse", "Pet:turtle"]
    )

    # Clue 9: dubstep is at same position or to right of pop
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dubstep, pop: dubstep >= pop,
        ["Music:dubstep", "Music:pop"]
    )

    # Clue 10: country is at same position or to right of rock
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda country, rock: country >= rock,
        ["Music:country", "Music:rock"]
    )

    # Clue 11: western == bird or bird == pop or both
    def clue11(western, bird, pop):
        return western == bird or bird == pop
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue11,
        ["Movie:western", "Pet:bird", "Music:pop"]
    )

    # Clue 12: writing is at same position or to left of rock
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda writing, rock: writing <= rock,
        ["Hobby:writing", "Music:rock"]
    )

    # Clue 13: bird is at same position or to left of ferret
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bird, ferret: bird <= ferret,
        ["Pet:bird", "Pet:ferret"]
    )

    # Clue 14: pop is somewhere between western and grapes (not necessarily adjacent)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pop, western, grapes:
            (western < pop < grapes) or (grapes < pop < western),
        ["Music:pop", "Movie:western", "Food:grapes"]
    )

    # Clue 15: family and folk have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda family, folk: (family % 2) != (folk % 2),
        ["Movie:family", "Music:folk"]
    )

    # Clue 16: folk is same person as exactly one of board-games or cranberry
    # Exactly one means XOR
    def clue16(folk, board_games, cranberry):
        return (folk == board_games) != (folk == cranberry)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue16,
        ["Music:folk", "Hobby:board-games", "Food:cranberry"]
    )

    # Clue 17: animation is at same position or to right of western
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda animation, western: animation >= western,
        ["Movie:animation", "Movie:western"]
    )

    # Clue 18: dubstep is same as family or board-games same as dubstep or both
    def clue18(dubstep, family, board_games):
        return dubstep == family or board_games == dubstep
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue18,
        ["Music:dubstep", "Movie:family", "Hobby:board-games"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # Just take first solution if multiple
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [None] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 3 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 2 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 3 unique items:

1. Pet: bird, ferret, rat
2. Nationality: spanish, canadian, indian

Each category has exactly 3 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the spanish person is immediately to the right of the person who has bird as a pet
2. the indian person is at position 1 (the leftmost position)
3. the person who has rat as a pet is at position 1 (the leftmost position)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Nationality", "Pet").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 3

    categories = ["Pet", "Nationality"]
    items = {
        "Pet": ["bird", "ferret", "rat"],
        "Nationality": ["spanish", "canadian", "indian"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain 0..2 (positions)
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_items = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_items)

    # Clue 1: the spanish person is immediately to the right of the person who has bird as a pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda spanish, bird: spanish == bird + 1,
        ["Nationality:spanish", "Pet:bird"]
    )

    # Clue 2: the indian person is at position 1 (leftmost position, index 0)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda indian: indian == 0,
        ["Nationality:indian"]
    )

    # Clue 3: the person who has rat as a pet is at position 1 (leftmost position, index 0)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rat: rat == 0,
        ["Pet:rat"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # There should be exactly one solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format the solution dictionary
    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()

    categories = ["Sport", "Music", "Nationality"]
    items = {
        "Sport": ["soccer", "weightlifting", "rugby", "baseball"],

    problem.addConstraint(

        ["Music:salsa", "Sport:rugby"]

    # Clue 5: the person who plays soccer is adjacent to the person who plays weightlifting (either immediately left or right)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda soccer, weightlifting: abs(soccer - weightlifting) == 1,
        ["Sport:soccer", "Sport:weightlifting"]

    # Clue 6: the person who plays baseball is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes reggae music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda baseball, reggae: baseball >= reggae,

    # Clue 7: the japanese person and the person who likes trance music are at positions with the same parity (both even or both odd)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda japanese, trance: japanese % 2 == trance % 2,
        ["Nationality:japanese", "Music:trance"]
    )

    # Clue 8: the person who likes reggae music is the same person as the pakistani person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda reggae, pakistani: reggae == pakistani,
        ["Music:reggae", "Nationality:pakistani"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

2. Food: plum, onion, potato, carrot, blueberry
3. Transport: trike, helicopter, snowmobile, skateboard, airplane
4. Music: indie, house, rock, metal, classical
5. Beverage: water, cola, sprite, lemonade, milk

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes carrot is a different person than the person who likes sprite or the person who uses helicopter for transportation is a different person than the person who likes carrot or both
2. the person who likes metal music is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes classical music
3. the person who likes classical music is a different person than the person who uses helicopter for transportation
4. the person who uses helicopter for transportation is a different person than the person who likes potato
5. the person who likes cola and the person who uses snowmobile for transportation are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
6. the person who likes carrot is to the right of the person who likes potato (not necessarily immediately)
7. the person who likes animation movies and the person who likes plum are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
8. the person who uses trike for transportation is to the right of the person who likes lemonade (not necessarily immediately)
9. the person who likes western movies is to the left of the person who likes milk (not necessarily immediately)
10. the person who likes carrot is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses airplane for transportation
11. the person who uses helicopter for transportation is to the right of the person who likes mystery movies (not necessarily immediately)
12. the person who likes water is the same person as at least one of the person who likes house music or the person who likes western movies
13. the person who likes action movies is to the left of the person who likes lemonade (not necessarily immediately)
14. the person who likes plum is to the right of the person who likes indie music (not necessarily immediately)
15. the person who likes metal music is to the right of the person who likes house music (not necessarily immediately)
16. the person who likes onion is the same person as exactly one of the person who likes classical music or the person who likes mystery movies
17. the person who likes blueberry is the same person as at least one of the person who likes classical music or the person who likes lemonade
18. the person who likes classical music is to the left of the person who likes western movies (not necessarily immediately)
19. the person who uses helicopter for transportation is somewhere between the person who uses airplane for transportation and the person who uses skateboard for transportation (not necessarily immediately adjacent)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Food").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Movie", "Food", "Transport", "Music", "Beverage"]
    items = {
        "Movie": ["animation", "western", "action", "romance", "mystery"],
        "Food": ["plum", "onion", "potato", "carrot", "blueberry"],
        "Transport": ["trike", "helicopter", "snowmobile", "skateboard", "airplane"],
        "Music": ["indie", "house", "rock", "metal", "classical"],
        "Beverage": ["water", "cola", "sprite", "lemonade", "milk"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1:
    # the person who likes carrot is a different person than the person who likes sprite or the person who uses helicopter for transportation is a different person than the person who likes carrot or both
    # This means carrot != sprite OR helicopter != carrot
    # This is equivalent to: not (carrot == sprite and helicopter == carrot)
    # So we add a constraint that forbids carrot == sprite == helicopter
    def clue1(carrot, sprite, helicopter):
        return not (carrot == sprite == helicopter)
    problem.addConstraint(clue1, ["Food:carrot", "Beverage:sprite", "Transport:helicopter"])

    # Clue 2:
    # metal music is at same position or to the left of classical music
    problem.addConstraint(lambda metal, classical: metal <= classical, ["Music:metal", "Music:classical"])

    # Clue 3:
    # classical music is different person than helicopter
    problem.addConstraint(lambda classical, helicopter: classical != helicopter, ["Music:classical", "Transport:helicopter"])

    # Clue 4:
    # helicopter different person than potato
    problem.addConstraint(lambda helicopter, potato: helicopter != potato, ["Transport:helicopter", "Food:potato"])

    # Clue 5:
    # cola and snowmobile are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda cola, snowmobile: (cola % 2) != (snowmobile % 2), ["Beverage:cola", "Transport:snowmobile"])

    # Clue 6:
    # carrot is to the right of potato
    problem.addConstraint(lambda carrot, potato: carrot > potato, ["Food:carrot", "Food:potato"])

    # Clue 7:
    # animation movies and plum are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda animation, plum: (animation % 2) != (plum % 2), ["Movie:animation", "Food:plum"])

    # Clue 8:
    # trike is to the right of lemonade
    problem.addConstraint(lambda trike, lemonade: trike > lemonade, ["Transport:trike", "Beverage:lemonade"])

    # Clue 9:
    # western movies is to the left of milk
    problem.addConstraint(lambda western, milk: western < milk, ["Movie:western", "Beverage:milk"])

    # Clue 10:
    # carrot is at same position or to the right of airplane
    problem.addConstraint(lambda carrot, airplane: carrot >= airplane, ["Food:carrot", "Transport:airplane"])

    # Clue 11:
    # helicopter is to the right of mystery movies
    problem.addConstraint(lambda helicopter, mystery: helicopter > mystery, ["Transport:helicopter", "Movie:mystery"])

    # Clue 12:
    # water is same person as at least one of house music or western movies
    # So water == house OR water == western
    def clue12(water, house, western):
        return water == house or water == western
    problem.addConstraint(clue12, ["Beverage:water", "Music:house", "Movie:western"])

    # Clue 13:
    # action movies is to the left of lemonade
    problem.addConstraint(lambda action, lemonade: action < lemonade, ["Movie:action", "Beverage:lemonade"])

    # Clue 14:
    # plum is to the right of indie music
    problem.addConstraint(lambda plum, indie: plum > indie, ["Food:plum", "Music:indie"])

    # Clue 15:
    # metal music is to the right of house music
    problem.addConstraint(lambda metal, house: metal > house, ["Music:metal", "Music:house"])

    # Clue 16:
    # onion is same person as exactly one of classical music or mystery movies
    # That means onion == classical xor onion == mystery
    def clue16(onion, classical, mystery):
        return (onion == classical) != (onion == mystery)
    problem.addConstraint(clue16, ["Food:onion", "Music:classical", "Movie:mystery"])

    # Clue 17:
    # blueberry is same person as at least one of classical music or lemonade
    def clue17(blueberry, classical, lemonade):
        return blueberry == classical or blueberry == lemonade
    problem.addConstraint(clue17, ["Food:blueberry", "Music:classical", "Beverage:lemonade"])

    # Clue 18:
    # classical music is to the left of western movies
    problem.addConstraint(lambda classical, western: classical < western, ["Music:classical", "Movie:western"])

    # Clue 19:
    # helicopter is somewhere between airplane and skateboard (not necessarily adjacent)
    # That means helicopter is strictly between airplane and skateboard
    # So helicopter position is between the other two positions
    def clue19(helicopter, airplane, skateboard):
        return (airplane < helicopter < skateboard) or (skateboard < helicopter < airplane)
    problem.addConstraint(clue19, ["Transport:helicopter", "Transport:airplane", "Transport:skateboard"])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # If multiple solutions, raise error
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Initialize list of length num_positions
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 3 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 3 unique items:

1. Beverage: tea, mirinda, sprite
2. Music: jazz, pop, indie
3. Transport: ship, tram, snowmobile

Each category has exactly 3 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes indie music is the same person as the person who uses snowmobile for transportation
2. the person who likes tea is directly between the person who likes pop music and the person who likes indie music
3. the person who likes sprite is the same person as the person who uses snowmobile for transportation
4. the person who likes tea is immediately to the right of the person who uses tram for transportation

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Music").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 3

    categories = ["Beverage", "Music", "Transport"]
    items = {
        "Beverage": ["tea", "mirinda", "sprite"],
        "Music": ["jazz", "pop", "indie"],
        "Transport": ["ship", "tram", "snowmobile"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: indie music same person as snowmobile
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda indie, snowmobile: indie == snowmobile,
        ["Music:indie", "Transport:snowmobile"]
    )

    # Clue 2: tea is directly between pop and indie
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda tea, pop, indie: (tea == pop + 1 and tea == indie - 1) or (tea == indie + 1 and tea == pop - 1),
        ["Beverage:tea", "Music:pop", "Music:indie"]
    )

    # Clue 3: sprite same person as snowmobile
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda sprite, snowmobile: sprite == snowmobile,
        ["Beverage:sprite", "Transport:snowmobile"]
    )

    # Clue 4: tea immediately to the right of tram
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda tea, tram: tea == tram + 1,
        ["Beverage:tea", "Transport:tram"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Nationality: colombian, indian, pakistani, polish
2. Hobby: puzzles, photography, camping, fishing
3. Movie: fantasy, martial-arts, spy, drama
4. Job: writer, dressmaker, software-developer, freelancer

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who enjoys camping is to the right of the person who likes spy movies (not necessarily immediately)
2. the person who likes martial-arts movies is the same person as the person who works as a writer
3. the indian person is immediately to the left of the person who enjoys fishing
4. the pakistani person is adjacent to the polish person (either immediately left or right)
5. the pakistani person is at an even-numbered position
6. the person who enjoys puzzles is the same person as the person who works as a freelancer
7. the person who works as a software-developer is adjacent to the person who enjoys fishing (either immediately left or right)
8. the person who likes drama movies is to the left of the person who enjoys photography (not necessarily immediately)
9. the person who works as a writer is to the left of the person who likes spy movies (not necessarily immediately)
10. the pakistani person is a different person than the person who enjoys camping

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Hobby", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Nationality", "Hobby", "Movie", "Job"]
    items = {
        "Nationality": ["colombian", "indian", "pakistani", "polish"],
        "Hobby": ["puzzles", "photography", "camping", "fishing"],
        "Movie": ["fantasy", "martial-arts", "spy", "drama"],
        "Job": ["writer", "dressmaker", "software-developer", "freelancer"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_vars = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_vars)

    # Clue 1: camping is to the right of spy (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda camping, spy: camping > spy,
        ["Hobby:camping", "Movie:spy"]
    )

    # Clue 2: martial-arts movie = writer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda martial_arts, writer: martial_arts == writer,
        ["Movie:martial-arts", "Job:writer"]
    )

    # Clue 3: indian immediately to the left of fishing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda indian, fishing: indian == fishing - 1,
        ["Nationality:indian", "Hobby:fishing"]
    )

    # Clue 4: pakistani adjacent to polish
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pakistani, polish: abs(pakistani - polish) == 1,
        ["Nationality:pakistani", "Nationality:polish"]
    )

    # Clue 5: pakistani at even-numbered position (positions 1-based: 2 or 4; zero-based: 1 or 3)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pakistani: pakistani in [1,3],
        ["Nationality:pakistani"]
    )

    # Clue 6: puzzles = freelancer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda puzzles, freelancer: puzzles == freelancer,
        ["Hobby:puzzles", "Job:freelancer"]
    )

    # Clue 7: software-developer adjacent to fishing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda software_dev, fishing: abs(software_dev - fishing) == 1,
        ["Job:software-developer", "Hobby:fishing"]
    )

    # Clue 8: drama to the left of photography (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda drama, photography: drama < photography,
        ["Movie:drama", "Hobby:photography"]
    )

    # Clue 9: writer to the left of spy (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda writer, spy: writer < spy,
        ["Job:writer", "Movie:spy"]
    )

    # Clue 10: pakistani different from camping
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pakistani, camping: pakistani != camping,
        ["Nationality:pakistani", "Hobby:camping"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Hobby").
