rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Movie", "Beverage", "Hobby", "Music", "Pet"]
    items = {
        "Movie": ["fantasy", "zombie", "thriller", "martial-arts", "horror"],
        "Beverage": ["lemonade", "tea", "water", "7up", "coffee"],
        "Hobby": ["filmmaking", "camping", "collecting", "dancing", "rock-climbing"],
        "Music": ["classical", "soul", "ambient", "house", "rock"],
        "Pet": ["ferret", "lizard", "turtle", "mouse", "cat"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All different constraints within each category
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: filmmaking is the same person as at least one of mouse or classical
    # means filmmaking == mouse or filmmaking == classical
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda filmmaking, mouse, classical: filmmaking == mouse or filmmaking == classical,
        ["Hobby:filmmaking", "Pet:mouse", "Music:classical"]
    )

    # Clue 2: rock-climbing != lemonade
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rock_climbing, lemonade: rock_climbing != lemonade,
        ["Hobby:rock-climbing", "Beverage:lemonade"]
    )

    # Clue 3: zombie and dancing have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda zombie, dancing: (zombie % 2) != (dancing % 2),
        ["Movie:zombie", "Hobby:dancing"]
    )

    # Clue 4: filmmaking is at same position or to the left of rock music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda filmmaking, rock: filmmaking <= rock,
        ["Hobby:filmmaking", "Music:rock"]
    )

    # Clue 5: rock-climbing is somewhere between camping and collecting (not necessarily adjacent)
    # So rock-climbing is strictly between camping and collecting or vice versa
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda camping, rock_climbing, collecting:
            (camping < rock_climbing < collecting) or (collecting < rock_climbing < camping),
        ["Hobby:camping", "Hobby:rock-climbing", "Hobby:collecting"]
    )

    # Clue 6: horror is same person as exactly one of lizard or rock-climbing
    # meaning (horror == lizard and horror != rock-climbing) or (horror != lizard and horror == rock-climbing)
    def exactly_one(horror, lizard, rock_climbing):
        return (horror == lizard and horror != rock_climbing) or (horror != lizard and horror == rock_climbing)
    problem.addConstraint(
        exactly_one,
        ["Movie:horror", "Pet:lizard", "Hobby:rock-climbing"]
    )

    # Clue 7: soul != fantasy
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda soul, fantasy: soul != fantasy,
        ["Music:soul", "Movie:fantasy"]
    )

    # Clue 8: house and zombie same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda house, zombie: (house % 2) == (zombie % 2),
        ["Music:house", "Movie:zombie"]
    )

    # Clue 9: horror and ambient same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda horror, ambient: (horror % 2) == (ambient % 2),
        ["Movie:horror", "Music:ambient"]
    )

    # Clue 10: fantasy != dancing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fantasy, dancing: fantasy != dancing,
        ["Movie:fantasy", "Hobby:dancing"]
    )

    # Clue 11: horror same position or to the left of coffee
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda horror, coffee: horror <= coffee,
        ["Movie:horror", "Beverage:coffee"]
    )

    # Clue 12: classical and water different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda classical, water: (classical % 2) != (water % 2),
        ["Music:classical", "Beverage:water"]
    )

    # Clue 13: lemonade somewhere between lizard and cat (not necessarily adjacent)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lizard, lemonade, cat:
            (lizard < lemonade < cat) or (cat < lemonade < lizard),
        ["Pet:lizard", "Beverage:lemonade", "Pet:cat"]
    )

    # Clue 14: thriller and classical different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda thriller, classical: (thriller % 2) != (classical % 2),
        ["Movie:thriller", "Music:classical"]
    )

    # Clue 15: tea same position or to the right of rock music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda tea, rock: tea >= rock,
        ["Beverage:tea", "Music:rock"]
    )

    # Clue 16: zombie != 7up
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda zombie, _7up: zombie != _7up,
        ["Movie:zombie", "Beverage:7up"]
    )

    # Clue 17: rock-climbing same position or to the left of martial-arts
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rock_climbing, martial_arts: rock_climbing <= martial_arts,
        ["Hobby:rock-climbing", "Movie:martial-arts"]
    )

    # Clue 18: zombie same position or to the left of ferret
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda zombie, ferret: zombie <= ferret,
        ["Movie:zombie", "Pet:ferret"]
    )

    # Clue 19: lemonade and rock-climbing same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lemonade, rock_climbing: (lemonade % 2) == (rock_climbing % 2),
        ["Beverage:lemonade", "Hobby:rock-climbing"]
    )

    # Clue 20: camping same position or to the right of rock-climbing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda camping, rock_climbing: camping >= rock_climbing,
        ["Hobby:camping", "Hobby:rock-climbing"]
    )

    # Clue 21: ambient != ferret
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda ambient, ferret: ambient != ferret,
        ["Music:ambient", "Pet:ferret"]
    )

    # Clue 22: ferret same position or to the left of lizard
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda ferret, lizard: ferret <= lizard,
        ["Pet:ferret", "Pet:lizard"]
    )

    # Clue 23: coffee != turtle or ambient != coffee or both
    # So at least one of these is true:
    # coffee != turtle OR ambient != coffee
    # which is equivalent to NOT(coffee == turtle AND ambient == coffee)
    def coffee_turtle_ambient_coffee(coffee, turtle, ambient):
        return not (coffee == turtle and ambient == coffee)
    problem.addConstraint(
        coffee_turtle_ambient_coffee,
        ["Beverage:coffee", "Pet:turtle", "Music:ambient"]
    )

    # Clue 24: water and ferret different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda water, ferret: (water % 2) != (ferret % 2),
        ["Beverage:water", "Pet:ferret"]
    )

    # Clue 25: thriller and lemonade same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda thriller, lemonade: (thriller % 2) == (lemonade % 2),
        ["Movie:thriller", "Beverage:lemonade"]
    )

    # Clue 26: turtle same position or to the right of martial-arts
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda turtle, martial_arts: turtle >= martial_arts,
        ["Pet:turtle", "Movie:martial-arts"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # If multiple solutions, raise error
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[var]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 2 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Movie: satire, comedy, disaster, crime
2. Hobby: collecting, chess, singing, baking

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes crime movies is immediately to the left of the person who likes disaster movies
2. the person who likes crime movies is immediately to the right of the person who enjoys baking
3. the person who enjoys singing is at an even-numbered position
4. the person who likes satire movies is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
5. the person who enjoys chess is immediately to the right of the person who likes satire movies

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Hobby", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Movie", "Hobby"]
    items = {
        "Movie": ["satire", "comedy", "disaster", "crime"],
        "Hobby": ["collecting", "chess", "singing", "baking"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category must be in different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: crime immediately to the left of disaster
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda crime, disaster: crime == disaster - 1,
        ["Movie:crime", "Movie:disaster"]
    )

    # Clue 2: crime immediately to the right of baking
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda crime, baking: crime == baking + 1,
        ["Movie:crime", "Hobby:baking"]
    )

    # Clue 3: singing at even-numbered position (0-based even positions: 1 and 3)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda singing: singing % 2 == 1,
        ["Hobby:singing"]
    )

    # Clue 4: satire at an end position (0 or 3)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda satire: satire == 0 or satire == 3,
        ["Movie:satire"]
    )

    # Clue 5: chess immediately to the right of satire
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda chess, satire: chess == satire + 1,
        ["Hobby:chess", "Movie:satire"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # There should be exactly one solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format the solution dictionary
    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Sport: swimming, surfing, badminton, rowing, handball
2. Music: soul, techno, gospel, trance, classical
3. Movie: martial-arts, epic, adventure, fantasy, sports
4. Food: pear, broccoli, kiwi, grapes, tomato

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes sports movies is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
2. the person who likes epic movies is somewhere between the person who likes techno music and the person who plays rowing (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
3. the person who likes techno music is somewhere between the person who plays badminton and the person who likes sports movies (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
4. the person who likes adventure movies is immediately to the right of the person who likes pear
5. the person who likes pear and the person who likes gospel music are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
6. the person who likes classical music is to the right of the person who likes gospel music (not necessarily immediately)
7. the person who plays surfing is somewhere between the person who plays handball and the person who likes tomato (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
8. the person who plays badminton is the same person as the person who likes adventure movies
9. the person who plays handball is to the left of the person who likes broccoli (not necessarily immediately)
10. the person who plays swimming is to the left of the person who plays surfing (not necessarily immediately)
11. the person who likes grapes is somewhere between the person who likes kiwi and the person who likes martial-arts movies (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
12. the person who likes pear is immediately to the right of the person who likes classical music
13. the person who likes soul music is adjacent to the person who likes broccoli (either immediately left or right)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Sport", "Music", "Movie", "Food"]
    items = {
        "Sport": ["swimming", "surfing", "badminton", "rowing", "handball"],
        "Music": ["soul", "techno", "gospel", "trance", "classical"],
        "Movie": ["martial-arts", "epic", "adventure", "fantasy", "sports"],
        "Food": ["pear", "broccoli", "kiwi", "grapes", "tomato"]
    }

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    for category in categories:
        category_items = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_items)

    # Clue 1: the person who likes sports movies is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda sports: sports == 0 or sports == num_positions - 1,
                          ["Movie:sports"])

    # Clue 2: the person who likes epic movies is somewhere between the person who likes techno music and the person who plays rowing (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
    # i.e. (techno < epic < rowing) or (rowing < epic < techno)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda epic, techno, rowing: (techno < epic < rowing) or (rowing < epic < techno),
        ["Movie:epic", "Music:techno", "Sport:rowing"]
    )

    # Clue 3: the person who likes techno music is somewhere between the person who plays badminton and the person who likes sports movies (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
    # i.e. (badminton < techno < sports) or (sports < techno < badminton)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda techno, badminton, sports: (badminton < techno < sports) or (sports < techno < badminton),
        ["Music:techno", "Sport:badminton", "Movie:sports"]
    )

    # Clue 4: the person who likes adventure movies is immediately to the right of the person who likes pear
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda adventure, pear: adventure == pear + 1,
        ["Movie:adventure", "Food:pear"]
    )

    # Clue 5: the person who likes pear and the person who likes gospel music are at positions with the same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pear, gospel: pear % 2 == gospel % 2,
        ["Food:pear", "Music:gospel"]
    )

    # Clue 6: the person who likes classical music is to the right of the person who likes gospel music (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda classical, gospel: classical > gospel,
        ["Music:classical", "Music:gospel"]
    )

    # Clue 7: the person who plays surfing is somewhere between the person who plays handball and the person who likes tomato (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
    # (handball < surfing < tomato) or (tomato < surfing < handball)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda surfing, handball, tomato: (handball < surfing < tomato) or (tomato < surfing < handball),
        ["Sport:surfing", "Sport:handball", "Food:tomato"]
    )

    # Clue 8: the person who plays badminton is the same person as the person who likes adventure movies
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda badminton, adventure: badminton == adventure,
        ["Sport:badminton", "Movie:adventure"]
    )

    # Clue 9: the person who plays handball is to the left of the person who likes broccoli (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda handball, broccoli: handball < broccoli,
        ["Sport:handball", "Food:broccoli"]
    )

    # Clue 10: the person who plays swimming is to the left of the person who plays surfing (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda swimming, surfing: swimming < surfing,
        ["Sport:swimming", "Sport:surfing"]
    )

    # Clue 11: the person who likes grapes is somewhere between the person who likes kiwi and the person who likes martial-arts movies (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
    # (kiwi < grapes < martial-arts) or (martial-arts < grapes < kiwi)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda grapes, kiwi, martial_arts: (kiwi < grapes < martial_arts) or (martial_arts < grapes < kiwi),
        ["Food:grapes", "Food:kiwi", "Movie:martial-arts"]
    )

    # Clue 12: the person who likes pear is immediately to the right of the person who likes classical music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pear, classical: pear == classical + 1,
        ["Food:pear", "Music:classical"]
    )

    # Clue 13: the person who likes soul music is adjacent to the person who likes broccoli (either immediately left or right)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda soul, broccoli: abs(soul - broccoli) == 1,
        ["Music:soul", "Food:broccoli"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[variable_name]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Job: architect, doctor, journalist, engineer
2. Transport: helicopter, jet-ski, bike, airplane
3. Nationality: turkish, nigerian, egyptian, italian
4. Movie: scientific, horror, satire, martial-arts
5. Music: salsa, ambient, indie, hip-hop

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who works as a engineer is directly between the person who works as a doctor and the person who likes ambient music
2. the egyptian person is the same person as at least one of the person who likes horror movies or the person who likes salsa music
3. the person who uses jet-ski for transportation and the egyptian person are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
4. the person who uses helicopter for transportation is to the right of the person who works as a engineer (not necessarily immediately)
5. the italian person is somewhere between the person who uses bike for transportation and the person who likes martial-arts movies (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
6. the person who likes salsa music is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses helicopter for transportation
7. the person who uses bike for transportation is adjacent to the person who works as a architect (either immediately left or right)
8. the person who uses bike for transportation is to the left of the turkish person (not necessarily immediately)
9. the person who likes scientific movies is to the left of the person who likes hip-hop music (not necessarily immediately)
10. the person who works as a doctor is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes horror movies
11. the person who likes salsa music is the same person as the person who uses jet-ski for transportation or the egyptian person is the same person as the person who likes salsa music, but not both
12. the italian person is the same person as at least one of the person who uses jet-ski for transportation or the person who likes satire movies

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Job", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Job", "Transport", "Nationality", "Movie", "Music"]
    items = {
        "Job": ["architect", "doctor", "journalist", "engineer"],
        "Transport": ["helicopter", "jet-ski", "bike", "airplane"],
        "Nationality": ["turkish", "nigerian", "egyptian", "italian"],
        "Movie": ["scientific", "horror", "satire", "martial-arts"],
        "Music": ["salsa", "ambient", "indie", "hip-hop"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: engineer is directly between doctor and ambient music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda engineer, doctor, ambient:
        (engineer == doctor + 1 and engineer == ambient - 1) or (engineer == doctor - 1 and engineer == ambient + 1),
        ["Job:engineer", "Job:doctor", "Music:ambient"]
    )

    # Clue 2: egyptian is same person as at least one of horror or salsa
    # Means egyptian == horror or egyptian == salsa or both
    # So: egyptian == horror or egyptian == salsa
    def clue2(egyptian, horror, salsa):
        return egyptian == horror or egyptian == salsa
    problem.addConstraint(clue2, ["Nationality:egyptian", "Movie:horror", "Music:salsa"])

    # Clue 3: jet-ski and egyptian have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda jet_ski, egyptian: (jet_ski % 2) != (egyptian % 2),
        ["Transport:jet-ski", "Nationality:egyptian"]
    )

    # Clue 4: helicopter is to the right of engineer (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda helicopter, engineer: helicopter > engineer,
        ["Transport:helicopter", "Job:engineer"]
    )

    # Clue 5: italian is somewhere between bike and martial-arts (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
    # means italian position is strictly between bike and martial-arts
    def clue5(italian, bike, martial_arts):
        return (bike < italian < martial_arts) or (martial_arts < italian < bike)
    problem.addConstraint(clue5, ["Nationality:italian", "Transport:bike", "Movie:martial-arts"])

    # Clue 6: salsa is at same position as or to right of helicopter
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda salsa, helicopter: salsa >= helicopter,
        ["Music:salsa", "Transport:helicopter"]
    )

    # Clue 7: bike is adjacent to architect (immediately left or right)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bike, architect: abs(bike - architect) == 1,
        ["Transport:bike", "Job:architect"]
    )

    # Clue 8: bike is to the left of turkish (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bike, turkish: bike < turkish,
        ["Transport:bike", "Nationality:turkish"]
    )

    # Clue 9: scientific is to the left of hip-hop (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda scientific, hip_hop: scientific < hip_hop,
        ["Movie:scientific", "Music:hip-hop"]
    )

    # Clue 10: doctor is at same position or to the left of horror
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda doctor, horror: doctor <= horror,
        ["Job:doctor", "Movie:horror"]
    )

    # Clue 11: salsa is same person as jet-ski or egyptian is same person as salsa, but not both
    # XOR condition: (salsa == jet-ski) != (egyptian == salsa)
    def clue11(salsa, jet_ski, egyptian):
        return (salsa == jet_ski) != (egyptian == salsa)
    problem.addConstraint(clue11, ["Music:salsa", "Transport:jet-ski", "Nationality:egyptian"])

    # Clue 12: italian is same person as at least one of jet-ski or satire
    # italian == jet-ski or italian == satire or both
    def clue12(italian, jet_ski, satire):
        return italian == jet_ski or italian == satire
    problem.addConstraint(clue12, ["Nationality:italian", "Transport:jet-ski", "Movie:satire"])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # In case multiple solutions, take first
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Create list with 4 empty slots
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

def solve_einstein_puzzle():

    items = {

        "Food": ["pumpkin", "peas", "nectarine", "cauliflower", "lettuce"],
        "Sport": ["skiing", "water-polo", "swimming", "weightlifting", "rowing"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: nectarine and swimming different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda nectarine, swimming: (nectarine % 2) != (swimming % 2),
        ["Food:nectarine", "Sport:swimming"]

        lambda lettuce, japanese: lettuce > japanese,

    problem.addConstraint(

    )

    # Clue 10: electronic to the right of french
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda electronic, french: electronic > french,
        ["Music:electronic", "Nationality:french"]
    )

    # Clue 11: (cola == japanese) xor (japanese == lettuce)
    def clue11(cola, japanese, lettuce):
        cond1 = (cola == japanese)
        cond2 = (japanese == lettuce)
        return (cond1 != cond2)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue11,
        ["Beverage:cola", "Nationality:japanese", "Food:lettuce"]
    )

    # Clue 12: nigerian same or to the right of house
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda nigerian, house: nigerian >= house,
        ["Nationality:nigerian", "Music:house"]
    )

    # Clue 13: peas between cauliflower and rowing (not necessarily adjacent)
    # means peas > min(cauliflower, rowing) and peas < max(cauliflower, rowing)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda peas, cauliflower, rowing: (min(cauliflower, rowing) < peas < max(cauliflower, rowing)),
        ["Food:peas", "Food:cauliflower", "Sport:rowing"]
    )

    # Clue 14: skiing same or to the left of swimming
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skiing, swimming: skiing <= swimming,
        ["Sport:skiing", "Sport:swimming"]
    )

    # Clue 15: italian == hot-chocolate or techno == italian or both
    # means italian == hot-chocolate or techno == italian or both
    # So: (italian == hot-chocolate) OR (techno == italian)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda italian, hot_chocolate, techno: (italian == hot_chocolate) or (techno == italian),
        ["Nationality:italian", "Beverage:hot-chocolate", "Music:techno"]
    )

    # Clue 16: lemonade between swimming and pumpkin (not necessarily adjacent)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lemonade, swimming, pumpkin: (min(swimming, pumpkin) < lemonade < max(swimming, pumpkin)),
        ["Beverage:lemonade", "Sport:swimming", "Food:pumpkin"]
    )

    # Clue 17: salsa to the left of lettuce
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda salsa, lettuce: salsa < lettuce,
        ["Music:salsa", "Food:lettuce"]
    )

    # Clue 18: nigerian same or to the right of lemonade
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda nigerian, lemonade: nigerian >= lemonade,
        ["Nationality:nigerian", "Beverage:lemonade"]
    )

    # Clue 19: cauliflower same or to the right of techno
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cauliflower, techno: cauliflower >= techno,
        ["Food:cauliflower", "Music:techno"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # If multiple solutions found, raise error as puzzle should have unique solution
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format solution dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Sport: handball, volleyball, sailing, swimming, weightlifting
2. Nationality: russian, american, colombian, british, dutch
3. Food: cherry, lime, tomato, artichoke, kale

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who plays volleyball is the same person as the person who likes tomato
2. the person who plays weightlifting is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
3. the person who plays swimming is at the same position as or to the right of the british person
4. the person who plays sailing and the person who likes kale are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
5. the person who plays handball is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes lime
6. the colombian person is adjacent to the british person (either immediately left or right)
7. the person who plays volleyball is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes artichoke
8. the person who plays sailing is adjacent to the person who plays handball (either immediately left or right)
9. the russian person is immediately to the left of the person who likes kale
10. the dutch person is the same person as the person who plays sailing
11. the russian person is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes cherry
12. the british person and the person who likes tomato are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Nationality").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Sport", "Nationality", "Food"]
    items = {
        "Sport": ["handball", "volleyball", "sailing", "swimming", "weightlifting"],
        "Nationality": ["russian", "american", "colombian", "british", "dutch"],
        "Food": ["cherry", "lime", "tomato", "artichoke", "kale"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: volleyball == tomato
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda volleyball, tomato: volleyball == tomato,
        ["Sport:volleyball", "Food:tomato"]
    )

    # Clue 2: weightlifting at an end position (0 or 4)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda weightlifting: weightlifting == 0 or weightlifting == 4,
        ["Sport:weightlifting"]
    )

    # Clue 3: swimming >= british
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda swimming, british: swimming >= british,
        ["Sport:swimming", "Nationality:british"]
    )

    # Clue 4: sailing and kale have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda sailing, kale: (sailing % 2) != (kale % 2),
        ["Sport:sailing", "Food:kale"]
    )

    # Clue 5: handball <= lime
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda handball, lime: handball <= lime,
        ["Sport:handball", "Food:lime"]
    )

    # Clue 6: colombian adjacent to british
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda colombian, british: abs(colombian - british) == 1,
        ["Nationality:colombian", "Nationality:british"]
    )

    # Clue 7: volleyball <= artichoke
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda volleyball, artichoke: volleyball <= artichoke,
        ["Sport:volleyball", "Food:artichoke"]
    )

    # Clue 8: sailing adjacent to handball
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda sailing, handball: abs(sailing - handball) == 1,
        ["Sport:sailing", "Sport:handball"]
    )

    # Clue 9: russian immediately to the left of kale
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda russian, kale: russian == kale - 1,
        ["Nationality:russian", "Food:kale"]
    )

    # Clue 10: dutch == sailing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dutch, sailing: dutch == sailing,
        ["Nationality:dutch", "Sport:sailing"]
    )

    # Clue 11: russian <= cherry
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda russian, cherry: russian <= cherry,
        ["Nationality:russian", "Food:cherry"]
    )

    # Clue 12: british and tomato have same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda british, tomato: (british % 2) == (tomato % 2),
        ["Nationality:british", "Food:tomato"]
    )

    # Solve
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 3 unique items:

1. Movie: musical, martial-arts, horror
2. Transport: tram, boat, trike
3. Sport: baseball, climbing, ice-hockey

Each category has exactly 3 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes musical movies is immediately to the left of the person who uses tram for transportation
2. the person who likes martial-arts movies is the same person as the person who plays climbing
3. the person who uses boat for transportation is immediately to the left of the person who uses trike for transportation
4. 0 is at position 3
5. the person who plays baseball is to the right of the person who plays ice-hockey (not necessarily immediately)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Movie", "Sport").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 3

    categories = ["Movie", "Transport", "Sport"]
    items = {
        "Movie": ["musical", "martial-arts", "horror"],
        "Transport": ["tram", "boat", "trike"],
        "Sport": ["baseball", "climbing", "ice-hockey"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: musical movie is immediately to the left of tram
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda musical, tram: musical == tram - 1,
        ["Movie:musical", "Transport:tram"]
    )

    # Clue 2: martial-arts movie same person as climbing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda martial_arts, climbing: martial_arts == climbing,
        ["Movie:martial-arts", "Sport:climbing"]
    )

    # Clue 3: boat is immediately to the left of trike
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda boat, trike: boat == trike - 1,
        ["Transport:boat", "Transport:trike"]
    )

    # Clue 4: 0 is at position 3
    # This clue is ambiguous in wording, but likely means "person 0 is at position 3"
    # Since we have no person category, interpret as "the item '0' is at position 3"
    # But no '0' item exists. Possibly a typo or means position index 2 (3rd position)
    # Possibly means something else, ignore or interpret as "position 2" (index 2)
    # Since no '0' item, skip this clue as no variable matches '0'.
    # Alternatively, ignore clue 4 as it is ambiguous.

    # Clue 5: baseball is to the right of ice-hockey (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda baseball, ice_hockey: baseball > ice_hockey,
        ["Sport:baseball", "Sport:ice-hockey"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()
    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # If multiple solutions, pick the first
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

3. Movie: crime, mystery, disaster, thriller, superhero

22. the egyptian person is the same person as at least one of the person who plays snowboarding or the person who likes disco music

from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint


def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Nationality", "Music", "Movie", "Sport", "Job"]
    items = {
        "Nationality": ["chinese", "indonesian", "italian", "argentine", "egyptian"],
        "Music": ["trance", "folk", "indie", "blues", "disco"],
        "Movie": ["crime", "mystery", "disaster", "thriller", "superhero"],
        "Sport": ["surfing", "handball", "snowboarding", "skiing", "golf"],
        "Job": ["dressmaker", "engineer", "analyst", "security-guard", "police-officer"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # AllDifferent constraints within each category
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clues

    # 1. security-guard != handball
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda sg, hb: sg != hb,
        ["Job:security-guard", "Sport:handball"]
    )

    # 2. (trance == argentine) XOR (dressmaker == trance)
    def clue2(trance, argentine, dressmaker):
        return (trance == argentine) != (dressmaker == trance)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue2,
        ["Music:trance", "Nationality:argentine", "Job:dressmaker"]
    )

    # 3. trance adjacent to surfing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda trance, surfing: abs(trance - surfing) == 1,
        ["Music:trance", "Sport:surfing"]
    )

    # 4. golf is somewhere between thriller and analyst
    # i.e. golf position is strictly between thriller and analyst positions
    def clue4(golf, thriller, analyst):
        return (thriller < golf < analyst) or (analyst < golf < thriller)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue4,
        ["Sport:golf", "Movie:thriller", "Job:analyst"]
    )

    # 5. dressmaker and folk have same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dressmaker, folk: dressmaker % 2 == folk % 2,
        ["Job:dressmaker", "Music:folk"]
    )

    # 6. indonesian adjacent to mystery
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda indo, mystery: abs(indo - mystery) == 1,
        ["Nationality:indonesian", "Movie:mystery"]
    )

    # 7. golf adjacent to engineer
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda golf, engineer: abs(golf - engineer) == 1,
        ["Sport:golf", "Job:engineer"]
    )

    # 8. dressmaker != surfing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dressmaker, surfing: dressmaker != surfing,
        ["Job:dressmaker", "Sport:surfing"]
    )

    # 9. indonesian is at same position or to the left of disaster
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda indo, disaster: indo <= disaster,
        ["Nationality:indonesian", "Movie:disaster"]
    )

    # 10. indonesian adjacent to superhero
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda indo, superhero: abs(indo - superhero) == 1,
        ["Nationality:indonesian", "Movie:superhero"]
    )

    # 11. disco != handball
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda disco, handball: disco != handball,
        ["Music:disco", "Sport:handball"]
    )

    # 12. surfing and mystery have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda surfing, mystery: (surfing % 2) != (mystery % 2),
        ["Sport:surfing", "Movie:mystery"]
    )

    # 13. handball adjacent to indie
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda handball, indie: abs(handball - indie) == 1,
        ["Sport:handball", "Music:indie"]
    )

    # 14. police-officer at same position or to the left of superhero
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda police, superhero: police <= superhero,
        ["Job:police-officer", "Movie:superhero"]
    )

    # 15. crime adjacent to italian
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda crime, italian: abs(crime - italian) == 1,
        ["Movie:crime", "Nationality:italian"]
    )

    # 16. crime at an end position (0 or 4)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda crime: crime == 0 or crime == 4,
        ["Movie:crime"]
    )

    # 17. surfing != at least one of disaster or disco
    # i.e. surfing != disaster OR surfing != disco (at least one)
    def clue17(surfing, disaster, disco):
        return (surfing != disaster) or (surfing != disco)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue17,
        ["Sport:surfing", "Movie:disaster", "Music:disco"]
    )

    # 18. blues adjacent to skiing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda blues, skiing: abs(blues - skiing) == 1,
        ["Music:blues", "Sport:skiing"]
    )

    # 19. engineer to the right of superhero

        lambda engineer, superhero: engineer > superhero,
        ["Job:engineer", "Movie:superhero"]
    )

    # 20. handball at same position or to the right of blues
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda handball, blues: handball >= blues,
        ["Sport:handball", "Music:blues"]
    )

    # 21. (italian == golf) XOR (golf == crime)
    def clue21(italian, golf, crime):
        return (italian == golf) != (golf == crime)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue21,
        ["Nationality:italian", "Sport:golf", "Movie:crime"]
    )

    # 22. egyptian == at least one of snowboarding or disco
    # i.e. egyptian == snowboarding OR egyptian == disco (at least one)
    def clue22(egyptian, snowboarding, disco):
        return (egyptian == snowboarding) or (egyptian == disco)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue22,
        ["Nationality:egyptian", "Sport:snowboarding", "Music:disco"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:

    if len(solutions) > 1:

        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:

    print(result)

        lambda chess, librarian: chess == librarian + 1,
        ["Hobby:chess", "Job:librarian"]
    )

    # 9. chess and trike different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda chess, trike: chess % 2 != trike % 2,
        ["Hobby:chess", "Transport:trike"]
    )

    # 10. subway immediately right of dressmaker
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda subway, dressmaker: subway == dressmaker + 1,
        ["Transport:subway", "Job:dressmaker"]
    )

    # 11. dancing and teacher same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dancing, teacher: dancing % 2 == teacher % 2,
        ["Hobby:dancing", "Job:teacher"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Sport: cricket, baseball, rowing, golf
2. Food: carrot, spinach, papaya, apricot
3. Music: jazz, folk, metal, disco
4. Movie: sports, mystery, spy, time-travel

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes apricot is to the right of the person who likes folk music (not necessarily immediately)
2. the person who plays rowing is immediately to the left of the person who plays cricket
3. the person who likes jazz music is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes metal music
4. the person who likes folk music is the same person as the person who plays baseball or the person who plays baseball is the same person as the person who likes spinach or both
5. the person who likes spy movies is directly between the person who likes papaya and the person who likes mystery movies
6. the person who likes metal music is immediately to the left of the person who plays cricket
7. the person who likes carrot is the same person as the person who plays baseball or the person who likes spy movies is the same person as the person who likes carrot or both
8. the person who plays cricket is the same person as exactly one of the person who likes carrot or the person who likes sports movies
9. the person who likes mystery movies is immediately to the right of the person who likes spinach
10. the person who likes jazz music is somewhere between the person who likes time-travel movies and the person who likes metal music (not necessarily immediately adjacent)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Sport", "Food", "Music", "Movie"]
    items = {
        "Sport": ["cricket", "baseball", "rowing", "golf"],
        "Food": ["carrot", "spinach", "papaya", "apricot"],
        "Music": ["jazz", "folk", "metal", "disco"],
        "Movie": ["sports", "mystery", "spy", "time-travel"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be in different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: apricot is to the right of folk (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda apricot, folk: apricot > folk,
        ["Food:apricot", "Music:folk"]
    )

    # Clue 2: rowing is immediately to the left of cricket
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rowing, cricket: rowing == cricket - 1,
        ["Sport:rowing", "Sport:cricket"]
    )

    # Clue 3: jazz is at the same position as or to the left of metal
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda jazz, metal: jazz <= metal,
        ["Music:jazz", "Music:metal"]
    )

    # Clue 4: folk is the same person as baseball or baseball is the same person as spinach or both
    # This means at least one of these equalities hold: folk==baseball or baseball==spinach
    # We model this as a constraint that enforces at least one equality
    def folk_baseball_spinach(folk, baseball, spinach):
        return folk == baseball or baseball == spinach
    problem.addConstraint(
        folk_baseball_spinach,
        ["Music:folk", "Sport:baseball", "Food:spinach"]
    )

    # Clue 5: spy movie is directly between papaya and mystery movie
    # spy is at position x, papaya and mystery at positions y,z such that spy is between them
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda spy, papaya, mystery:
            (spy == papaya + 1 and spy == mystery -1) or (spy == mystery + 1 and spy == papaya -1),
        ["Movie:spy", "Food:papaya", "Movie:mystery"]
    )

    # Clue 6: metal is immediately to the left of cricket
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda metal, cricket: metal == cricket -1,
        ["Music:metal", "Sport:cricket"]
    )

    # Clue 7: carrot is the same person as baseball or spy is the same person as carrot or both
    # At least one of: carrot==baseball or spy==carrot
    def carrot_baseball_spy(carrot, baseball, spy):
        return carrot == baseball or spy == carrot
    problem.addConstraint(
        carrot_baseball_spy,
        ["Food:carrot", "Sport:baseball", "Movie:spy"]
    )

    # Clue 8: cricket is the same person as exactly one of carrot or sports movies
    # Exactly one means (cricket == carrot) xor (cricket == sports)
    def cricket_carrot_sports(cricket, carrot, sports):
        return (cricket == carrot) != (cricket == sports)
    problem.addConstraint(
        cricket_carrot_sports,
        ["Sport:cricket", "Food:carrot", "Movie:sports"]
    )

    # Clue 9: mystery is immediately to the right of spinach
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda mystery, spinach: mystery == spinach + 1,
        ["Movie:mystery", "Food:spinach"]
    )

    # Clue 10: jazz is somewhere between time-travel and metal (not necessarily immediately)
    # i.e. jazz is strictly between time-travel and metal
    def jazz_between_time_travel_metal(jazz, time_travel, metal):
        return (time_travel < jazz < metal) or (metal < jazz < time_travel)
    problem.addConstraint(
        jazz_between_time_travel_metal,
        ["Music:jazz", "Movie:time-travel", "Music:metal"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format the solution dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

3. Pet: rabbit, frog, rat, bird, horse
4. Job: bartender, mechanic, doctor, architect, pilot
5. Beverage: almond-milk, coffee, water, soy-milk, lemonade

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who plays water-polo is the same person as at least one of the person who has rat as a pet or the person who uses airplane for transportation
2. the person who has rabbit as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes water
3. the person who works as a architect is the same person as the person who likes coffee or the person who likes coffee is the same person as the person who plays surfing or both
4. the person who works as a architect is the same person as the person who has frog as a pet or the person who has frog as a pet is the same person as the person who uses van for transportation or both
5. the person who likes soy-milk is at the same position as or to the right of the person who works as a architect
6. the person who has rabbit as a pet is at an odd-numbered position
7. the person who uses bike for transportation is to the left of the person who likes water (not necessarily immediately)
8. the person who uses quad-bike for transportation is to the right of the person who likes water (not necessarily immediately)
9. the person who has rabbit as a pet is the same person as exactly one of the person who plays surfing or the person who uses van for transportation
10. the person who plays weightlifting is to the right of the person who has bird as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
11. the person who works as a doctor is somewhere between the person who works as a mechanic and the person who likes coffee (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
12. the person who has rat as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who plays surfing
13. the person who works as a architect is the same person as the person who plays badminton or the person who plays badminton is the same person as the person who has rabbit as a pet, but not both
14. the person who uses bike for transportation and the person who likes almond-milk are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
15. the person who likes almond-milk and the person who has bird as a pet are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
16. the person who works as a pilot is to the right of the person who uses van for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
17. the person who has frog as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who uses van for transportation
18. the person who plays weightlifting is to the left of the person who works as a architect (not necessarily immediately)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Sport", "Transport", "Pet", "Job", "Beverage"]
    items = {
        "Sport": ["water-polo", "weightlifting", "surfing", "skiing", "badminton"],
        "Transport": ["van", "quad-bike", "bike", "train", "airplane"],
        "Pet": ["rabbit", "frog", "rat", "bird", "horse"],
        "Job": ["bartender", "mechanic", "doctor", "architect", "pilot"],
        "Beverage": ["almond-milk", "coffee", "water", "soy-milk", "lemonade"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: water-polo is the same person as at least one of rat or airplane
    # (water-polo == rat) or (water-polo == airplane) or both
    def clue1(water_polo, rat, airplane):
        return water_polo == rat or water_polo == airplane
    problem.addConstraint(clue1, ["Sport:water-polo", "Pet:rat", "Transport:airplane"])

    # Clue 2: rabbit is at same position as or to the left of water
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rabbit, water: rabbit <= water, ["Pet:rabbit", "Beverage:water"])

    # Clue 3: architect == coffee or coffee == surfing or both
    def clue3(architect, coffee, surfing):
        return architect == coffee or coffee == surfing
    problem.addConstraint(clue3, ["Job:architect", "Beverage:coffee", "Sport:surfing"])

    # Clue 4: architect == frog or frog == van or both
    def clue4(architect, frog, van):
        return architect == frog or frog == van
    problem.addConstraint(clue4, ["Job:architect", "Pet:frog", "Transport:van"])

    # Clue 5: soy-milk is at same position as or to the right of architect
    problem.addConstraint(lambda soy_milk, architect: soy_milk >= architect, ["Beverage:soy-milk", "Job:architect"])

    # Clue 6: rabbit is at an odd-numbered position (positions 1,3,5 => indices 0,2,4)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rabbit: rabbit % 2 == 0, ["Pet:rabbit"])

    # Clue 7: bike is to the left of water (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda bike, water: bike < water, ["Transport:bike", "Beverage:water"])

    # Clue 8: quad-bike is to the right of water (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda quad_bike, water: quad_bike > water, ["Transport:quad-bike", "Beverage:water"])

    # Clue 9: rabbit is the same person as exactly one of surfing or van
    # i.e. (rabbit == surfing) != (rabbit == van)
    def clue9(rabbit, surfing, van):
        return (rabbit == surfing) != (rabbit == van)
    problem.addConstraint(clue9, ["Pet:rabbit", "Sport:surfing", "Transport:van"])

    # Clue 10: weightlifting is to the right of bird (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda weightlifting, bird: weightlifting > bird, ["Sport:weightlifting", "Pet:bird"])

    # Clue 11: doctor is somewhere between mechanic and coffee (not necessarily adjacent)
    # i.e. mechanic < doctor < coffee or coffee < doctor < mechanic
    def clue11(mechanic, doctor, coffee):
        return (mechanic < doctor < coffee) or (coffee < doctor < mechanic)
    problem.addConstraint(clue11, ["Job:mechanic", "Job:doctor", "Beverage:coffee"])

    # Clue 12: rat is at same position as or to the left of surfing
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rat, surfing: rat <= surfing, ["Pet:rat", "Sport:surfing"])

    # Clue 13: architect == badminton or badminton == rabbit but not both
    # i.e. (architect == badminton) != (badminton == rabbit)
    def clue13(architect, badminton, rabbit):
        return (architect == badminton) != (badminton == rabbit)
    problem.addConstraint(clue13, ["Job:architect", "Sport:badminton", "Pet:rabbit"])

    # Clue 14: bike and almond-milk at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda bike, almond_milk: (bike % 2) != (almond_milk % 2), ["Transport:bike", "Beverage:almond-milk"])

    # Clue 15: almond-milk and bird at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda almond_milk, bird: (almond_milk % 2) != (bird % 2), ["Beverage:almond-milk", "Pet:bird"])

    # Clue 16: pilot is to the right of van (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda pilot, van: pilot > van, ["Job:pilot", "Transport:van"])

    # Clue 17: frog is at same position as or to the left of van
    problem.addConstraint(lambda frog, van: frog <= van, ["Pet:frog", "Transport:van"])

    # Clue 18: weightlifting is to the left of architect (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda weightlifting, architect: weightlifting < architect, ["Sport:weightlifting", "Job:architect"])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # To ensure only one solution, raise error if multiple
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 2 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 3 unique items:

1. Food: onion, zucchini, garlic

Each category has exactly 3 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who plays golf is immediately to the left of the person who plays handball
2. the person who likes onion is immediately to the left of the person who likes garlic
3. the person who plays handball is the same person as the person who likes onion

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Sport").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 3

    categories = ["Food", "Sport"]
    items = {
        "Food": ["onion", "zucchini", "garlic"],
        "Sport": ["badminton", "handball", "golf"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # AllDifferent constraints within each category
    for category in categories:
        category_items = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_items)

    # Clue 1: golf immediately to the left of handball
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda golf, handball: golf == handball - 1,
        ["Sport:golf", "Sport:handball"]
    )

    # Clue 2: onion immediately to the left of garlic
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda onion, garlic: onion == garlic - 1,
        ["Food:onion", "Food:garlic"]
    )

    # Clue 3: handball same person as onion
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda handball, onion: handball == onion,
        ["Sport:handball", "Food:onion"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # There should be exactly one solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {category: [""] * num_positions for category in categories}
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Music: rock, funk, r&b, pop, indie
2. Hobby: rock-climbing, magic-tricks, dancing, traveling, card-games
3. Sport: badminton, surfing, climbing, rowing, swimming
4. Nationality: mexican, brazilian, canadian, indian, chinese

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes r&b music is at an odd-numbered position
2. the person who plays rowing is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes r&b music
3. the person who likes funk music is adjacent to the person who enjoys magic-tricks (either immediately left or right)
4. the person who enjoys magic-tricks is somewhere between the person who likes pop music and the person who enjoys card-games (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
5. the person who enjoys rock-climbing is to the left of the person who plays surfing (not necessarily immediately)
6. the person who likes pop music is the same person as the person who enjoys magic-tricks or the canadian person is the same person as the person who likes pop music, but not both
7. the person who likes indie music is the same person as the mexican person or the person who plays swimming is the same person as the person who likes indie music or both
8. the person who likes funk music is at the same position as or to the right of the person who enjoys dancing
9. the person who enjoys rock-climbing is to the right of the mexican person (not necessarily immediately)
10. the person who likes rock music is adjacent to the person who plays badminton (either immediately left or right)
11. the brazilian person is directly between the person who likes rock music and the chinese person
12. the person who plays surfing is somewhere between the person who plays climbing and the person who likes rock music (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
13. the canadian person is the same person as the person who enjoys rock-climbing or the person who enjoys rock-climbing is the same person as the person who plays swimming, but not both
14. the canadian person is to the right of the person who enjoys traveling (not necessarily immediately)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Hobby", "Music").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Music", "Hobby", "Sport", "Nationality"]
    items = {
        "Music": ["rock", "funk", "r&b", "pop", "indie"],
        "Hobby": ["rock-climbing", "magic-tricks", "dancing", "traveling", "card-games"],
        "Sport": ["badminton", "surfing", "climbing", "rowing", "swimming"],
        "Nationality": ["mexican", "brazilian", "canadian", "indian", "chinese"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: r&b music is at an odd-numbered position (0-indexed: 0,2,4)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rnb: rnb % 2 == 0, ["Music:r&b"])

    # Clue 2: rowing is at same position or to the right of r&b music
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rowing, rnb: rowing >= rnb, ["Sport:rowing", "Music:r&b"])

    # Clue 3: funk music adjacent to magic-tricks
    problem.addConstraint(lambda funk, magic: abs(funk - magic) == 1, ["Music:funk", "Hobby:magic-tricks"])

    # Clue 4: magic-tricks is somewhere between pop music and card-games (not necessarily adjacent)
    # i.e. magic-tricks position is strictly between pop and card-games positions
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda magic, pop, card: (pop < magic < card) or (card < magic < pop),
        ["Hobby:magic-tricks", "Music:pop", "Hobby:card-games"]
    )

    # Clue 5: rock-climbing is to the left of surfing (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rock_climbing, surfing: rock_climbing < surfing, ["Hobby:rock-climbing", "Sport:surfing"])

    # Clue 6: pop music is same as magic-tricks XOR canadian is same as pop music, but not both
    def clue6(pop, magic, canadian):
        return (pop == magic) != (canadian == pop)
    problem.addConstraint(clue6, ["Music:pop", "Hobby:magic-tricks", "Nationality:canadian"])

    # Clue 7: indie music is same as mexican OR swimming is same as indie OR both
    def clue7(indie, mexican, swimming):
        return (indie == mexican) or (swimming == indie)
    problem.addConstraint(clue7, ["Music:indie", "Nationality:mexican", "Sport:swimming"])

    # Clue 8: funk music is at same position or to the right of dancing
    problem.addConstraint(lambda funk, dancing: funk >= dancing, ["Music:funk", "Hobby:dancing"])

    # Clue 9: rock-climbing is to the right of mexican (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rock_climbing, mexican: rock_climbing > mexican, ["Hobby:rock-climbing", "Nationality:mexican"])

    # Clue 10: rock music adjacent to badminton
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rock, badminton: abs(rock - badminton) == 1, ["Music:rock", "Sport:badminton"])

    # Clue 11: brazilian is directly between rock music and chinese
    # brazilian position is one more than min(rock, chinese) and one less than max(rock, chinese)
    def clue11(brazilian, rock, chinese):
        return (brazilian == rock + 1 and brazilian == chinese - 1) or (brazilian == chinese + 1 and brazilian == rock - 1)
    problem.addConstraint(clue11, ["Nationality:brazilian", "Music:rock", "Nationality:chinese"])

    # Clue 12: surfing is somewhere between climbing and rock music (not necessarily immediately)
    # surfing position is strictly between climbing and rock
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda surfing, climbing, rock: (climbing < surfing < rock) or (rock < surfing < climbing),
        ["Sport:surfing", "Sport:climbing", "Music:rock"]
    )

    # Clue 13: canadian same as rock-climbing XOR rock-climbing same as swimming, not both
    def clue13(canadian, rock_climbing, swimming):
        return (canadian == rock_climbing) != (rock_climbing == swimming)
    problem.addConstraint(clue13, ["Nationality:canadian", "Hobby:rock-climbing", "Sport:swimming"])

    # Clue 14: canadian is to the right of traveling (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda canadian, traveling: canadian > traveling, ["Nationality:canadian", "Hobby:traveling"])

    # Solve
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format result dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()
