25. the person who enjoys writing and the person who has goat as a pet are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
26. the person who has goat as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the nigerian person
27. the person who plays weightlifting is a different person than the japanese person or the person who enjoys video-games is a different person than the person who plays weightlifting or both
28. the person who uses skateboard for transportation is a different person than at least one of the person who enjoys card-games or the nigerian person
29. the person who has rabbit as a pet and the person who uses boat for transportation are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Hobby", "Nationality").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Hobby", "Transport", "Sport", "Pet", "Nationality"]
    items = {
        "Hobby": ["card-games", "writing", "cooking", "video-games", "drawing"],
        "Transport": ["boat", "trike", "scooter", "skateboard", "roller"],
        "Sport": ["skateboarding", "sailing", "weightlifting", "handball", "swimming"],
        "Pet": ["rabbit", "pony", "bird", "goat", "dog"],
        "Nationality": ["japanese", "dutch", "thai", "indonesian", "nigerian"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_category = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_category)

    # Helper functions for "somewhere between"
    def between(x, y, z):
        return (y > x and y < z) or (y < x and y > z)

    # Clue 1: The nigerian person is the same person as exactly one of the person who enjoys cooking or the person who plays swimming
    # XOR: (nigerian == cooking) != (nigerian == swimming)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda nigerian, cooking, swimming: (nigerian == cooking) != (nigerian == swimming),
        ["Nationality:nigerian", "Hobby:cooking", "Sport:swimming"]
    )

    # Clue 2: The dutch person is the same person as the person who uses boat or the person who plays weightlifting is the same person as the dutch person, but not both
    # XOR: (dutch == boat) != (weightlifting == dutch)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dutch, boat, weightlifting: (dutch == boat) != (weightlifting == dutch),
        ["Nationality:dutch", "Transport:boat", "Sport:weightlifting"]
    )

    # Clue 3: The person who enjoys drawing is the same person as the person who has dog or the indonesian person is the same person as the person who enjoys drawing, but not both
    # XOR: (drawing == dog) != (indonesian == drawing)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda drawing, dog, indonesian: (drawing == dog) != (indonesian == drawing),
        ["Hobby:drawing", "Pet:dog", "Nationality:indonesian"]
    )

    # Clue 4: The person who uses skateboard is at the same position or to the right of the nigerian person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skateboard, nigerian: skateboard >= nigerian,
        ["Transport:skateboard", "Nationality:nigerian"]
    )

    # Clue 5: The person who has pony is at the same position or to the left of the person who has dog
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pony, dog: pony <= dog,
        ["Pet:pony", "Pet:dog"]
    )

    # Clue 6: The person who enjoys writing is at the same position as or to the left of the person who enjoys writing
    # This is tautological (writing <= writing), so no constraint needed

    # Clue 7: The person who uses roller is the same person as the person who enjoys cooking or the person who enjoys cooking is the same person as the indonesian or both
    # (roller == cooking) or (cooking == indonesian)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda roller, cooking, indonesian: (roller == cooking) or (cooking == indonesian),
        ["Transport:roller", "Hobby:cooking", "Nationality:indonesian"]
    )

    # Clue 8: The person who uses trike is at the same position or to the left of the person who plays skateboarding
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda trike, skateboarding: trike <= skateboarding,
        ["Transport:trike", "Sport:skateboarding"]
    )

    # Clue 9: The person who plays handball is somewhere between the japanese person and the person who has pony (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda japanese, handball, pony: between(japanese, handball, pony),
        ["Nationality:japanese", "Sport:handball", "Pet:pony"]
    )

    # Clue 10: The person who enjoys writing and the person who has pony are at positions with the same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda writing, pony: writing % 2 == pony % 2,
        ["Hobby:writing", "Pet:pony"]
    )

    # Clue 11: The person who uses roller is at the same position or to the right of the person who uses scooter
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda roller, scooter: roller >= scooter,
        ["Transport:roller", "Transport:scooter"]
    )

    # Clue 12: The person who has rabbit is at the same position or to the right of the nigerian person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rabbit, nigerian: rabbit >= nigerian,
        ["Pet:rabbit", "Nationality:nigerian"]
    )

    # Clue 13: The person who uses boat is somewhere between the nigerian person and the person who enjoys writing (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda nigerian, boat, writing: between(nigerian, boat, writing),
        ["Nationality:nigerian", "Transport:boat", "Hobby:writing"]
    )

    # Clue 14: The person who enjoys video-games is the same person as the person who uses boat or the person who uses boat is the same person as the person who plays weightlifting, but not both
    # XOR: (video-games == boat) != (boat == weightlifting)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda videogames, boat, weightlifting: (videogames == boat) != (boat == weightlifting),
        ["Hobby:video-games", "Transport:boat", "Sport:weightlifting"]
    )

    # Clue 15: The person who uses scooter is at the same position or to the right of the indonesian person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda scooter, indonesian: scooter >= indonesian,
        ["Transport:scooter", "Nationality:indonesian"]
    )

    # Clue 16: The person who enjoys writing is a different person than at least one of the japanese person or the person who uses scooter
    # i.e. (writing != japanese) or (writing != scooter)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda writing, japanese, scooter: (writing != japanese) or (writing != scooter),
        ["Hobby:writing", "Nationality:japanese", "Transport:scooter"]
    )

    # Clue 17: The person who uses roller is at the same position or to the right of the person who enjoys writing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda roller, writing: roller >= writing,
        ["Transport:roller", "Hobby:writing"]
    )

    # Clue 18: The person who has goat is at the same position or to the right of the person who has rabbit
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda goat, rabbit: goat >= rabbit,
        ["Pet:goat", "Pet:rabbit"]
    )

    # Clue 19: The person who plays weightlifting is somewhere between the person who plays swimming and the person who plays sailing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda swimming, weightlifting, sailing: between(swimming, weightlifting, sailing),
        ["Sport:swimming", "Sport:weightlifting", "Sport:sailing"]
    )

    # Clue 20: The person who enjoys cooking and the thai person are at positions with the same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cooking, thai: cooking % 2 == thai % 2,
        ["Hobby:cooking", "Nationality:thai"]
    )

    # Clue 21: The person who uses scooter is somewhere between the indonesian person and the person who has bird as a pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda indonesian, scooter, bird: between(indonesian, scooter, bird),
        ["Nationality:indonesian", "Transport:scooter", "Pet:bird"]
    )

    # Clue 22: The person who uses trike is a different person than the person who plays swimming or the person who plays swimming is a different person than the person who has pony or both
    # i.e. (trike != swimming) or (swimming != pony)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda trike, swimming, pony: (trike != swimming) or (swimming != pony),
        ["Transport:trike", "Sport:swimming", "Pet:pony"]
    )

    # Clue 23: The person who has goat is at the same position or to the left of the person who has goat
    # This is tautological (goat <= goat), no constraint needed

    # Clue 24: The person who plays weightlifting is at the same position or to the left of the person who uses scooter
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda weightlifting, scooter: weightlifting <= scooter,
        ["Sport:weightlifting", "Transport:scooter"]
    )

    # Clue 25: The person who enjoys writing and the person who has goat are at positions with the same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda writing, goat: writing % 2 == goat % 2,
        ["Hobby:writing", "Pet:goat"]
    )

    # Clue 26: The person who has goat is at the same position or to the right of the nigerian person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda goat, nigerian: goat >= nigerian,
        ["Pet:goat", "Nationality:nigerian"]
    )

    # Clue 27: The person who plays weightlifting is a different person than the japanese person or the person who enjoys video-games is a different person than the person who plays weightlifting or both
    # i.e. (weightlifting != japanese) or (video-games != weightlifting)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda weightlifting, japanese, videogames: (weightlifting != japanese) or (videogames != weightlifting),
        ["Sport:weightlifting", "Nationality:japanese", "Hobby:video-games"]
    )

    # Clue 28: The person who uses skateboard is a different person than at least one of the person who enjoys card-games or the nigerian person
    # i.e. (skateboard != card-games) or (skateboard != nigerian)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skateboard, cardgames, nigerian: (skateboard != cardgames) or (skateboard != nigerian),
        ["Transport:skateboard", "Hobby:card-games", "Nationality:nigerian"]
    )

    # Clue 29: The person who has rabbit and the person who uses boat are at positions with the same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rabbit, boat: rabbit % 2 == boat % 2,
        ["Pet:rabbit", "Transport:boat"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Beverage: milk, coffee, cola, water, 7up
2. Sport: skateboarding, climbing, rugby, surfing, lacrosse
3. Job: lawyer, manager, accountant, architect, paramedic
4. Pet: lizard, fish, turtle, chinchilla, goldfish

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who has fish as a pet is adjacent to the person who likes cola (either immediately left or right)
2. the person who works as a accountant is the same person as the person who likes water
3. the person who plays rugby is immediately to the right of the person who works as a paramedic
4. the person who has goldfish as a pet is the same person as the person who likes 7up
5. the person who likes milk is the same person as the person who has turtle as a pet
6. the person who likes coffee is immediately to the left of the person who likes cola
7. the person who has chinchilla as a pet is the same person as the person who works as a architect
8. the person who works as a lawyer is immediately to the right of the person who plays lacrosse
9. the person who plays skateboarding is to the right of the person who works as a accountant (not necessarily immediately)
10. the person who has goldfish as a pet is immediately to the right of the person who works as a paramedic
11. the person who plays lacrosse is to the right of the person who plays climbing (not necessarily immediately)
12. the person who plays skateboarding is immediately to the left of the person who plays climbing

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Beverage", "Sport", "Job", "Pet"]
    items = {
        "Beverage": ["milk", "coffee", "cola", "water", "7up"],
        "Sport": ["skateboarding", "climbing", "rugby", "surfing", "lacrosse"],
        "Job": ["lawyer", "manager", "accountant", "architect", "paramedic"],
        "Pet": ["lizard", "fish", "turtle", "chinchilla", "goldfish"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_vars = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_vars)

    # Clue 1: fish adjacent to cola
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fish, cola: abs(fish - cola) == 1,
        ["Pet:fish", "Beverage:cola"]
    )

    # Clue 2: accountant same as water
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda accountant, water: accountant == water,
        ["Job:accountant", "Beverage:water"]
    )

    # Clue 3: rugby immediately to right of paramedic
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda rugby, paramedic: rugby == paramedic + 1,
        ["Sport:rugby", "Job:paramedic"]
    )

    # Clue 4: goldfish same as 7up
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda goldfish, sevenup: goldfish == sevenup,
        ["Pet:goldfish", "Beverage:7up"]
    )

    # Clue 5: milk same as turtle
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda milk, turtle: milk == turtle,
        ["Beverage:milk", "Pet:turtle"]
    )

    # Clue 6: coffee immediately to left of cola
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda coffee, cola: coffee == cola - 1,
        ["Beverage:coffee", "Beverage:cola"]
    )

    # Clue 7: chinchilla same as architect
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda chinchilla, architect: chinchilla == architect,
        ["Pet:chinchilla", "Job:architect"]
    )

    # Clue 8: lawyer immediately to right of lacrosse
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lawyer, lacrosse: lawyer == lacrosse + 1,
        ["Job:lawyer", "Sport:lacrosse"]
    )

    # Clue 9: skateboarding to right of accountant (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skateboarding, accountant: skateboarding > accountant,
        ["Sport:skateboarding", "Job:accountant"]
    )

    # Clue 10: goldfish immediately to right of paramedic
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda goldfish, paramedic: goldfish == paramedic + 1,
        ["Pet:goldfish", "Job:paramedic"]
    )

    # Clue 11: lacrosse to right of climbing (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lacrosse, climbing: lacrosse > climbing,
        ["Sport:lacrosse", "Sport:climbing"]
    )

    # Clue 12: skateboarding immediately to left of climbing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skateboarding, climbing: skateboarding == climbing - 1,
        ["Sport:skateboarding", "Sport:climbing"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[var]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Music", "Food", "Beverage", "Sport", "Transport"]
    items = {
        "Music": ["jazz", "electronic", "funk", "punk", "folk"],
        "Food": ["lime", "cucumber", "eggplant", "pear", "carrot"],
        "Beverage": ["7up", "hot-chocolate", "coffee", "sprite", "lemonade"],
        "Sport": ["rowing", "golf", "soccer", "snowboarding", "skateboarding"],
        "Transport": ["ship", "helicopter", "roller", "jet-ski", "motorbike"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be in different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Helper functions for "exactly one of" constraints
    def exactly_one_equal(x, y, z):
        return (x == y and x != z) or (x != y and x == z)

    def at_least_one_equal(x, y, z):
        return (x == y) or (x == z)

    def at_least_one_diff(x, y, z):
        return (x != y) or (x != z)

    def at_least_one_diff_2(x, y, z):
        # For constraints that say "different person than at least one of X or Y or both"
        # This means at least one of the two inequalities holds
        return (x != y) or (x != z)

    def between(x, y, z):
        # x is somewhere between y and z (not necessarily immediately)
        return (y < x < z) or (z < x < y)

    # Clues:

    # 1. 7up <= ship
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a <= b, ["Beverage:7up", "Transport:ship"])

    # 2. sprite >= funk
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a >= b, ["Beverage:sprite", "Music:funk"])

    # 3. coffee and cucumber different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: (a % 2) != (b % 2), ["Beverage:coffee", "Food:cucumber"])

    # 4. cucumber == exactly one of rowing or motorbike
    problem.addConstraint(lambda c, r, m: exactly_one_equal(c, r, m),
                          ["Food:cucumber", "Sport:rowing", "Transport:motorbike"])

    # 5. lime <= 7up
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a <= b, ["Food:lime", "Beverage:7up"])

    # 6. jazz >= rowing
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a >= b, ["Music:jazz", "Sport:rowing"])

    # 7. roller != at least one of golf or carrot
    problem.addConstraint(lambda r, g, c: at_least_one_diff(r, g, c),
                          ["Transport:roller", "Sport:golf", "Food:carrot"])

    # 8. hot-chocolate >= pear
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a >= b, ["Beverage:hot-chocolate", "Food:pear"])

    # 9. carrot >= carrot (always true, ignore)

    # 10. motorbike == exactly one of lime or golf
    problem.addConstraint(lambda m, l, g: exactly_one_equal(m, l, g),
                          ["Transport:motorbike", "Food:lime", "Sport:golf"])

    # 11. ship between golf and soccer
    problem.addConstraint(lambda ship, golf, soccer: between(ship, golf, soccer),
                          ["Transport:ship", "Sport:golf", "Sport:soccer"])

    # 12. snowboarding <= ship
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a <= b, ["Sport:snowboarding", "Transport:ship"])

    # 13. electronic and lemonade different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: (a % 2) != (b % 2), ["Music:electronic", "Beverage:lemonade"])

    # 14. folk <= roller
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a <= b, ["Music:folk", "Transport:roller"])

    # 15. rowing <= ship
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a <= b, ["Sport:rowing", "Transport:ship"])

    # 16. electronic != at least one of cucumber or roller
    problem.addConstraint(lambda e, c, r: at_least_one_diff(e, c, r),
                          ["Music:electronic", "Food:cucumber", "Transport:roller"])

    # 17. electronic != at least one of cucumber or golf
    problem.addConstraint(lambda e, c, g: at_least_one_diff(e, c, g),
                          ["Music:electronic", "Food:cucumber", "Sport:golf"])

    # 18. lime == exactly one of jazz or snowboarding
    problem.addConstraint(lambda l, j, s: exactly_one_equal(l, j, s),
                          ["Food:lime", "Music:jazz", "Sport:snowboarding"])

    # 19. roller <= ship
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a <= b, ["Transport:roller", "Transport:ship"])

    # 20. skateboarding <= lemonade
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a <= b, ["Sport:skateboarding", "Beverage:lemonade"])

    # 21. skateboarding and cucumber different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: (a % 2) != (b % 2), ["Sport:skateboarding", "Food:cucumber"])

    # 22. carrot between punk and pear
    problem.addConstraint(lambda carrot, punk, pear: between(carrot, punk, pear),
                          ["Food:carrot", "Music:punk", "Food:pear"])

    # 23. folk and pear different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: (a % 2) != (b % 2), ["Music:folk", "Food:pear"])

    # 24. 7up != at least one of helicopter or snowboarding
    problem.addConstraint(lambda sevenup, heli, snowboard: at_least_one_diff(sevenup, heli, snowboard),
                          ["Beverage:7up", "Transport:helicopter", "Sport:snowboarding"])

    # 25. jet-ski != lime or lime != hot-chocolate or both
    problem.addConstraint(lambda jet, lime, hot: (jet != lime) or (lime != hot),
                          ["Transport:jet-ski", "Food:lime", "Beverage:hot-chocolate"])

    # 26. lemonade between sprite and motorbike
    problem.addConstraint(lambda lemonade, sprite, motorbike: between(lemonade, sprite, motorbike),
                          ["Beverage:lemonade", "Beverage:sprite", "Transport:motorbike"])

    # 27. helicopter != golf or eggplant != helicopter or both
    problem.addConstraint(lambda heli, golf, eggplant: (heli != golf) or (eggplant != heli),
                          ["Transport:helicopter", "Sport:golf", "Food:eggplant"])

    # 28. roller and lime same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: (a % 2) == (b % 2), ["Transport:roller", "Food:lime"])

    # 29. coffee <= jet-ski
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a <= b, ["Beverage:coffee", "Transport:jet-ski"])

    # 30. snowboarding and funk same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: (a % 2) == (b % 2), ["Sport:snowboarding", "Music:funk"])

    # 31. sprite <= eggplant
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a <= b, ["Beverage:sprite", "Food:eggplant"])

    # 32. golf != eggplant or coffee != golf or both
    problem.addConstraint(lambda g, e, c: (g != e) or (c != g),
                          ["Sport:golf", "Food:eggplant", "Beverage:coffee"])

    # 33. jet-ski <= helicopter
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a <= b, ["Transport:jet-ski", "Transport:helicopter"])

    # 34. carrot between rowing and jet-ski
    problem.addConstraint(lambda carrot, rowing, jetski: between(carrot, rowing, jetski),
                          ["Food:carrot", "Sport:rowing", "Transport:jet-ski"])

    # 35. rowing and funk different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: (a % 2) != (b % 2), ["Sport:rowing", "Music:funk"])

    # 36. punk and roller different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: (a % 2) != (b % 2), ["Music:punk", "Transport:roller"])

    # 37. sprite and punk same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: (a % 2) == (b % 2), ["Beverage:sprite", "Music:punk"])

    # 38. cucumber >= motorbike
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a >= b, ["Food:cucumber", "Transport:motorbike"])

    # 39. skateboarding <= roller
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a <= b, ["Sport:skateboarding", "Transport:roller"])

    # 40. golf == at least one of funk or 7up
    problem.addConstraint(lambda g, f, s: at_least_one_equal(g, f, s),
                          ["Sport:golf", "Music:funk", "Beverage:7up"])

    # 41. sprite == at least one of pear or funk
    problem.addConstraint(lambda s, p, f: at_least_one_equal(s, p, f),
                          ["Beverage:sprite", "Food:pear", "Music:funk"])

    # 42. jet-ski == at least one of punk or lime
    problem.addConstraint(lambda j, p, l: at_least_one_equal(j, p, l),
                          ["Transport:jet-ski", "Music:punk", "Food:lime"])

    # 43. roller >= skateboarding
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a >= b, ["Transport:roller", "Sport:skateboarding"])

    # 44. coffee <= soccer
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a <= b, ["Beverage:coffee", "Sport:soccer"])

    # 45. lime == exactly one of coffee or soccer
    problem.addConstraint(lambda l, c, s: exactly_one_equal(l, c, s),
                          ["Food:lime", "Beverage:coffee", "Sport:soccer"])

    # 46. carrot <= funk
    problem.addConstraint(lambda a, b: a <= b, ["Food:carrot", "Music:funk"])

    # 47. snowboarding != at least one of hot-chocolate or punk
    problem.addConstraint(lambda s, h, p: at_least_one_diff(s, h, p),
                          ["Sport:snowboarding", "Beverage:hot-chocolate", "Music:punk"])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # Expecting a unique solution
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [None] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 3 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 2 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 3 unique items:

1. Food: artichoke, peas, peach
2. Movie: horror, western, thriller

Each category has exactly 3 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes western movies is immediately to the left of the person who likes horror movies
2. the person who likes peas is the same person as the person who likes western movies
3. the person who likes peach is immediately to the right of the person who likes artichoke

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 3

    categories = ["Food", "Movie"]
    items = {
        "Food": ["artichoke", "peas", "peach"],
        "Movie": ["horror", "western", "thriller"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain being positions 0,1,2
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_vars = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_vars)

    # Clue 1: western movie is immediately to the left of horror movie
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda western, horror: western == horror - 1,
        ["Movie:western", "Movie:horror"]
    )

    # Clue 2: peas is the same person as western movie
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda peas, western: peas == western,
        ["Food:peas", "Movie:western"]
    )

    # Clue 3: peach is immediately to the right of artichoke
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda peach, artichoke: peach == artichoke + 1,
        ["Food:peach", "Food:artichoke"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # There should be exactly one solution
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format result dictionary
    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Pet: lizard, cat, mouse, horse, guinea-pig
2. Transport: taxi, helicopter, motorbike, jet-ski, bike
3. Movie: time-travel, crime, western, satire, disaster

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who has mouse as a pet is to the left of the person who uses bike for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
2. the person who uses jet-ski for transportation is the same person as the person who likes crime movies
3. the person who likes time-travel movies is adjacent to the person who uses helicopter for transportation (either immediately left or right)
4. the person who has guinea-pig as a pet is at an odd-numbered position
5. the person who uses helicopter for transportation is to the right of the person who has guinea-pig as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
6. the person who uses bike for transportation is a different person than the person who likes western movies
7. the person who has lizard as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who uses taxi for transportation
8. the person who likes western movies and the person who uses helicopter for transportation are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
9. the person who likes crime movies is immediately to the right of the person who likes western movies
10. the person who has cat as a pet is immediately to the right of the person who uses jet-ski for transportation
11. the person who likes disaster movies is at position 1 (the leftmost position)
12. the person who likes crime movies is to the right of the person who has horse as a pet (not necessarily immediately)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Movie", "Pet").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Pet", "Transport", "Movie"]
    items = {
        "Pet": ["lizard", "cat", "mouse", "horse", "guinea-pig"],
        "Transport": ["taxi", "helicopter", "motorbike", "jet-ski", "bike"],
        "Movie": ["time-travel", "crime", "western", "satire", "disaster"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: mouse pet is to the left of bike transport (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda mouse, bike: mouse < bike,
        ["Pet:mouse", "Transport:bike"]
    )

    # Clue 2: jet-ski transport same person as crime movie
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda jet_ski, crime: jet_ski == crime,
        ["Transport:jet-ski", "Movie:crime"]
    )

    # Clue 3: time-travel movie adjacent to helicopter transport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda time_travel, helicopter: abs(time_travel - helicopter) == 1,
        ["Movie:time-travel", "Transport:helicopter"]
    )

    # Clue 4: guinea-pig pet is at an odd-numbered position (positions 1,3,5 i.e. indices 0,2,4)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda guinea_pig: guinea_pig % 2 == 0,
        ["Pet:guinea-pig"]
    )

    # Clue 5: helicopter transport is to the right of guinea-pig pet (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda helicopter, guinea_pig: helicopter > guinea_pig,
        ["Transport:helicopter", "Pet:guinea-pig"]
    )

    # Clue 6: bike transport is different person than western movie
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bike, western: bike != western,
        ["Transport:bike", "Movie:western"]
    )

    # Clue 7: lizard pet is at same position as or to the left of taxi transport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lizard, taxi: lizard <= taxi,
        ["Pet:lizard", "Transport:taxi"]
    )

    # Clue 8: western movie and helicopter transport are at positions with same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda western, helicopter: (western % 2) == (helicopter % 2),
        ["Movie:western", "Transport:helicopter"]
    )

    # Clue 9: crime movie immediately to right of western movie
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda crime, western: crime == western + 1,
        ["Movie:crime", "Movie:western"]
    )

    # Clue 10: cat pet immediately to right of jet-ski transport
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cat, jet_ski: cat == jet_ski + 1,
        ["Pet:cat", "Transport:jet-ski"]
    )

    # Clue 11: disaster movie at position 1 (index 0)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda disaster: disaster == 0,
        ["Movie:disaster"]
    )

    # Clue 12: crime movie is to the right of horse pet
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda crime, horse: crime > horse,
        ["Movie:crime", "Pet:horse"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()
    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # Normally raise error, but per instructions just pick first
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    # Format solution dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[var]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Nationality: turkish, nigerian, british, colombian, thai
2. Job: firefighter, librarian, dressmaker, freelancer, scientist
3. Music: metal, reggae, hip-hop, dubstep, techno
4. Pet: cat, snake, mouse, hamster, chinchilla
5. Transport: snowmobile, quad-bike, airplane, train, boat

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the british person is a different person than the person who uses quad-bike for transportation
2. the person who uses quad-bike for transportation is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses boat for transportation
3. the person who uses airplane for transportation is somewhere between the person who uses quad-bike for transportation and the person who uses boat for transportation (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
4. the thai person and the person who uses quad-bike for transportation are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
5. the person who uses boat for transportation and the colombian person are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
6. the person who works as a dressmaker is the same person as the colombian person or the colombian person is the same person as the person who has mouse as a pet, but not both
7. the person who likes dubstep music is a different person than the colombian person
8. the thai person and the person who likes reggae music are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
9. the person who uses train for transportation is a different person than the person who likes reggae music
10. the person who uses quad-bike for transportation and the person who has cat as a pet are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
11. the person who works as a dressmaker is a different person than the person who has hamster as a pet or the person who likes hip-hop music is a different person than the person who works as a dressmaker or both
12. the turkish person is the same person as exactly one of the person who likes techno music or the person who has mouse as a pet
13. the person who uses boat for transportation and the person who works as a firefighter are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
14. the person who has cat as a pet and the person who uses boat for transportation are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
15. the thai person is at the same position as or to the right of the colombian person
16. the person who likes hip-hop music and the british person are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
17. the person who has snake as a pet is somewhere between the person who uses quad-bike for transportation and the person who uses boat for transportation (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
18. the person who has snake as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses boat for transportation
19. the person who uses snowmobile for transportation is a different person than the person who has cat as a pet
20. the person who works as a dressmaker is somewhere between the person who likes dubstep music and the person who works as a scientist (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
21. the person who uses quad-bike for transportation is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses boat for transportation
22. the person who has mouse as a pet is somewhere between the person who works as a scientist and the nigerian person (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
23. the nigerian person is a different person than the person who uses boat for transportation
24. the person who uses boat for transportation is at the same position as or to the left of the person who uses quad-bike for transportation
25. the person who likes metal music and the person who has cat as a pet are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
26. the colombian person is a different person than the person who uses snowmobile for transportation
27. the thai person is at the same position as or to the left of the person who uses boat for transportation
28. the person who uses quad-bike for transportation is at the same position as or to the right of the person who has mouse as a pet
29. the person who works as a librarian is at the same position as or to the left of the person who has snake as a pet

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Job", "Music").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Nationality", "Job", "Music", "Pet", "Transport"]
    items = {
        "Nationality": ["turkish", "nigerian", "british", "colombian", "thai"],
        "Job": ["firefighter", "librarian", "dressmaker", "freelancer", "scientist"],
        "Music": ["metal", "reggae", "hip-hop", "dubstep", "techno"],
        "Pet": ["cat", "snake", "mouse", "hamster", "chinchilla"],
        "Transport": ["snowmobile", "quad-bike", "airplane", "train", "boat"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clues:

    # 1. british person != quad-bike user
    problem.addConstraint(lambda b, q: b != q, ["Nationality:british", "Transport:quad-bike"])

    # 2. quad-bike >= boat
    problem.addConstraint(lambda q, b: q >= b, ["Transport:quad-bike", "Transport:boat"])

    # 3. airplane is somewhere between quad-bike and boat (not necessarily adjacent)
    # means airplane position is strictly between quad-bike and boat positions
    def airplane_between(q, a, b):
        return (q < a < b) or (b < a < q)
    problem.addConstraint(airplane_between, ["Transport:quad-bike", "Transport:airplane", "Transport:boat"])

    # 4. thai and quad-bike same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda t, q: (t % 2) == (q % 2), ["Nationality:thai", "Transport:quad-bike"])

    # 5. boat and colombian different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda b, c: (b % 2) != (c % 2), ["Transport:boat", "Nationality:colombian"])

    # 6. dressmaker is same person as colombian xor colombian is same person as mouse (but not both)
    def dressmaker_colombian_mouse(d, c, m):
        return (d == c) != (c == m)
    problem.addConstraint(dressmaker_colombian_mouse, ["Job:dressmaker", "Nationality:colombian", "Pet:mouse"])

    # 7. dubstep != colombian
    problem.addConstraint(lambda d, c: d != c, ["Music:dubstep", "Nationality:colombian"])

    # 8. thai and reggae different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda t, r: (t % 2) != (r % 2), ["Nationality:thai", "Music:reggae"])

    # 9. train != reggae
    problem.addConstraint(lambda tr, r: tr != r, ["Transport:train", "Music:reggae"])

    # 10. quad-bike and cat same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda q, c: (q % 2) == (c % 2), ["Transport:quad-bike", "Pet:cat"])

    # 11. dressmaker != hamster or hip-hop != dressmaker or both
    # i.e. NOT (dressmaker == hamster AND hip-hop == dressmaker)
    def dressmaker_hiphop_hamster(d, h, hip):
        return not (d == h and hip == d)
    problem.addConstraint(dressmaker_hiphop_hamster, ["Job:dressmaker", "Pet:hamster", "Music:hip-hop"])

    # 12. turkish same person as exactly one of techno or mouse
    def turkish_techno_mouse(t, tech, m):
        return (t == tech) != (t == m)
    problem.addConstraint(turkish_techno_mouse, ["Nationality:turkish", "Music:techno", "Pet:mouse"])

    # 13. boat and firefighter different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda b, f: (b % 2) != (f % 2), ["Transport:boat", "Job:firefighter"])

    # 14. cat and boat same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda c, b: (c % 2) == (b % 2), ["Pet:cat", "Transport:boat"])

    # 15. thai >= colombian
    problem.addConstraint(lambda t, c: t >= c, ["Nationality:thai", "Nationality:colombian"])

    # 16. hip-hop and british different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda h, b: (h % 2) != (b % 2), ["Music:hip-hop", "Nationality:british"])

    # 17. snake is somewhere between quad-bike and boat (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
    def snake_between(q, s, b):
        return (q < s < b) or (b < s < q)
    problem.addConstraint(snake_between, ["Transport:quad-bike", "Pet:snake", "Transport:boat"])

    # 18. snake >= boat
    problem.addConstraint(lambda s, b: s >= b, ["Pet:snake", "Transport:boat"])

    # 19. snowmobile != cat
    problem.addConstraint(lambda s, c: s != c, ["Transport:snowmobile", "Pet:cat"])

    # 20. dressmaker is somewhere between dubstep and scientist (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
    def dressmaker_between(dub, d, sci):
        return (dub < d < sci) or (sci < d < dub)
    problem.addConstraint(dressmaker_between, ["Music:dubstep", "Job:dressmaker", "Job:scientist"])

    # 21. quad-bike >= boat (repeated clue, same as clue 2)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda q, b: q >= b, ["Transport:quad-bike", "Transport:boat"])

    # 22. mouse is somewhere between scientist and nigerian (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
    def mouse_between(sci, m, nig):
        return (sci < m < nig) or (nig < m < sci)
    problem.addConstraint(mouse_between, ["Job:scientist", "Pet:mouse", "Nationality:nigerian"])

    # 23. nigerian != boat
    problem.addConstraint(lambda n, b: n != b, ["Nationality:nigerian", "Transport:boat"])

    # 24. boat <= quad-bike (repeated clue, same as clue 2 and 21)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda b, q: b <= q, ["Transport:boat", "Transport:quad-bike"])

    # 25. metal and cat same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda m, c: (m % 2) == (c % 2), ["Music:metal", "Pet:cat"])

    # 26. colombian != snowmobile
    problem.addConstraint(lambda c, s: c != s, ["Nationality:colombian", "Transport:snowmobile"])

    # 27. thai <= boat
    problem.addConstraint(lambda t, b: t <= b, ["Nationality:thai", "Transport:boat"])

    # 28. quad-bike >= mouse
    problem.addConstraint(lambda q, m: q >= m, ["Transport:quad-bike", "Pet:mouse"])

    # 29. librarian <= snake
    problem.addConstraint(lambda l, s: l <= s, ["Job:librarian", "Pet:snake"])

    # Solve
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [None] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 2 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Nationality: japanese, chinese, pakistani, argentine
2. Hobby: collecting, hiking, magic-tricks, video-games

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the argentine person is immediately to the right of the person who enjoys collecting
2. the pakistani person is immediately to the right of the chinese person
3. the argentine person is immediately to the right of the pakistani person
4. the person who enjoys magic-tricks is immediately to the right of the person who enjoys collecting
5. the person who enjoys magic-tricks is directly between the person who enjoys hiking and the person who enjoys collecting

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Hobby", "Nationality").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Nationality", "Hobby"]
    items = {
        "Nationality": ["japanese", "chinese", "pakistani", "argentine"],
        "Hobby": ["collecting", "hiking", "magic-tricks", "video-games"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: The argentine person is immediately to the right of the person who enjoys collecting
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda argentine, collecting: argentine == collecting + 1,
        ["Nationality:argentine", "Hobby:collecting"]
    )

    # Clue 2: The pakistani person is immediately to the right of the chinese person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda pakistani, chinese: pakistani == chinese + 1,
        ["Nationality:pakistani", "Nationality:chinese"]
    )

    # Clue 3: The argentine person is immediately to the right of the pakistani person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda argentine, pakistani: argentine == pakistani + 1,
        ["Nationality:argentine", "Nationality:pakistani"]
    )

    # Clue 4: The person who enjoys magic-tricks is immediately to the right of the person who enjoys collecting
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda magic, collecting: magic == collecting + 1,
        ["Hobby:magic-tricks", "Hobby:collecting"]
    )

    # Clue 5: The person who enjoys magic-tricks is directly between the person who enjoys hiking and the person who enjoys collecting
    # That means magic-tricks is adjacent to both hiking and collecting, and between them
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda magic, hiking, collecting: (magic == hiking + 1 and magic == collecting - 1) or (magic == hiking - 1 and magic == collecting + 1),
        ["Hobby:magic-tricks", "Hobby:hiking", "Hobby:collecting"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # There should be exactly one solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {category: [""] * num_positions for category in categories}
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 4 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Job: entrepreneur, architect, firefighter, bartender, designer
2. Movie: zombie, spy, crime, sports, family
3. Food: corn, grapes, eggplant, kale, papaya
4. Hobby: collecting, photography, camping, traveling, card-games

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who works as a architect is at position 1 (the leftmost position)
2. the person who likes eggplant is the same person as the person who enjoys traveling
3. the person who works as a entrepreneur is immediately to the left of the person who likes kale
4. the person who works as a designer and the person who likes sports movies are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
5. the person who works as a firefighter is adjacent to the person who enjoys collecting (either immediately left or right)
6. the person who likes zombie movies is immediately to the left of the person who likes spy movies
7. the person who works as a designer is the same person as the person who likes eggplant
8. the person who likes family movies is to the right of the person who likes crime movies (not necessarily immediately)
9. the person who enjoys traveling is somewhere between the person who likes family movies and the person who likes corn (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
10. the person who enjoys card-games is at the same position as or to the left of the person who enjoys traveling
11. the person who likes grapes is adjacent to the person who enjoys camping (either immediately left or right)
12. the person who likes spy movies is to the left of the person who enjoys card-games (not necessarily immediately)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Hobby").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Job", "Movie", "Food", "Hobby"]
    items = {
        "Job": ["entrepreneur", "architect", "firefighter", "bartender", "designer"],
        "Movie": ["zombie", "spy", "crime", "sports", "family"],
        "Food": ["corn", "grapes", "eggplant", "kale", "papaya"],
        "Hobby": ["collecting", "photography", "camping", "traveling", "card-games"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All different in each category
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: architect is at position 1 (0-indexed = 0)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda architect: architect == 0, ["Job:architect"])

    # Clue 2: eggplant = traveling
    problem.addConstraint(lambda eggplant, traveling: eggplant == traveling,
                          ["Food:eggplant", "Hobby:traveling"])

    # Clue 3: entrepreneur immediately left of kale
    problem.addConstraint(lambda entrepreneur, kale: entrepreneur == kale - 1,
                          ["Job:entrepreneur", "Food:kale"])

    # Clue 4: designer and sports same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda designer, sports: designer % 2 == sports % 2,
                          ["Job:designer", "Movie:sports"])

    # Clue 5: firefighter adjacent to collecting
    problem.addConstraint(lambda firefighter, collecting: abs(firefighter - collecting) == 1,
                          ["Job:firefighter", "Hobby:collecting"])

    # Clue 6: zombie immediately left of spy
    problem.addConstraint(lambda zombie, spy: zombie == spy - 1,
                          ["Movie:zombie", "Movie:spy"])

    # Clue 7: designer = eggplant
    problem.addConstraint(lambda designer, eggplant: designer == eggplant,
                          ["Job:designer", "Food:eggplant"])

    # Clue 8: family is to the right of crime (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda family, crime: family > crime,
                          ["Movie:family", "Movie:crime"])

    # Clue 9: traveling is somewhere between family and corn
    # traveling > family and traveling < corn OR traveling < family and traveling > corn
    problem.addConstraint(lambda traveling, family, corn:
                          (traveling > family and traveling < corn) or (traveling < family and traveling > corn),
                          ["Hobby:traveling", "Movie:family", "Food:corn"])

    # Clue 10: card-games same position or left of traveling
    problem.addConstraint(lambda card_games, traveling: card_games <= traveling,
                          ["Hobby:card-games", "Hobby:traveling"])

    # Clue 11: grapes adjacent to camping
    problem.addConstraint(lambda grapes, camping: abs(grapes - camping) == 1,
                          ["Food:grapes", "Hobby:camping"])

    # Clue 12: spy left of card-games (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda spy, card_games: spy < card_games,
                          ["Movie:spy", "Hobby:card-games"])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Music: blues, electronic, folk, ambient
2. Transport: quad-bike, roller, snowmobile, car
3. Movie: martial-arts, documentary, scientific, horror
4. Sport: tennis, volleyball, rugby, swimming
5. Hobby: singing, traveling, cooking, woodworking

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who enjoys singing is a different person than the person who uses car for transportation
2. the person who likes horror movies is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
3. the person who likes electronic music is the same person as the person who enjoys woodworking
4. the person who enjoys traveling is to the left of the person who uses car for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
5. the person who plays tennis is immediately to the right of the person who likes documentary movies
6. the person who likes folk music is immediately to the right of the person who uses roller for transportation
7. the person who likes scientific movies is to the left of the person who enjoys traveling (not necessarily immediately)
8. the person who plays volleyball is directly between the person who uses snowmobile for transportation and the person who plays swimming
9. the person who likes ambient music is to the left of the person who enjoys singing (not necessarily immediately)
10. the person who likes blues music is the same person as the person who likes horror movies
11. the person who plays tennis is to the left of the person who plays rugby (not necessarily immediately)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Hobby", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Music", "Transport", "Movie", "Sport", "Hobby"]
    items = {
        "Music": ["blues", "electronic", "folk", "ambient"],
        "Transport": ["quad-bike", "roller", "snowmobile", "car"],
        "Movie": ["martial-arts", "documentary", "scientific", "horror"],
        "Sport": ["tennis", "volleyball", "rugby", "swimming"],
        "Hobby": ["singing", "traveling", "cooking", "woodworking"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: the person who enjoys singing is a different person than the person who uses car for transportation
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda singing, car: singing != car,
        ["Hobby:singing", "Transport:car"]
    )

    # Clue 2: the person who likes horror movies is at an end position (either leftmost or rightmost)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda horror: horror == 0 or horror == num_positions - 1,
        ["Movie:horror"]
    )

    # Clue 3: the person who likes electronic music is the same person as the person who enjoys woodworking
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda electronic, woodworking: electronic == woodworking,
        ["Music:electronic", "Hobby:woodworking"]
    )

    # Clue 4: the person who enjoys traveling is to the left of the person who uses car for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda traveling, car: traveling < car,
        ["Hobby:traveling", "Transport:car"]
    )

    # Clue 5: the person who plays tennis is immediately to the right of the person who likes documentary movies
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda tennis, documentary: tennis == documentary + 1,
        ["Sport:tennis", "Movie:documentary"]
    )

    # Clue 6: the person who likes folk music is immediately to the right of the person who uses roller for transportation
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda folk, roller: folk == roller + 1,
        ["Music:folk", "Transport:roller"]
    )

    # Clue 7: the person who likes scientific movies is to the left of the person who enjoys traveling (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda scientific, traveling: scientific < traveling,
        ["Movie:scientific", "Hobby:traveling"]
    )

    # Clue 8: the person who plays volleyball is directly between the person who uses snowmobile for transportation and the person who plays swimming
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda volleyball, snowmobile, swimming:
            (volleyball == snowmobile + 1 and volleyball == swimming -1) or
            (volleyball == swimming + 1 and volleyball == snowmobile -1),
        ["Sport:volleyball", "Transport:snowmobile", "Sport:swimming"]
    )

    # Clue 9: the person who likes ambient music is to the left of the person who enjoys singing (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda ambient, singing: ambient < singing,
        ["Music:ambient", "Hobby:singing"]
    )

    # Clue 10: the person who likes blues music is the same person as the person who likes horror movies
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda blues, horror: blues == horror,
        ["Music:blues", "Movie:horror"]
    )

    # Clue 11: the person who plays tennis is to the left of the person who plays rugby (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda tennis, rugby: tennis < rugby,
        ["Sport:tennis", "Sport:rugby"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result = {category: [""] * num_positions for category in categories}
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[var]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Music: house, rock, pop, d&b, blues
2. Food: cabbage, kale, kiwi, raspberry, artichoke
3. Pet: fish, goat, guinea-pig, snake, ferret
4. Beverage: coffee, iced-tea, almond-milk, water, 7up
5. Movie: musical, time-travel, thriller, family, scientific

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who has snake as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes raspberry
2. the person who likes kiwi is the same person as at least one of the person who likes water or the person who has goat as a pet
3. the person who likes raspberry is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes house music
4. the person who likes family movies is the same person as the person who likes cabbage or the person who likes pop music is the same person as the person who likes family movies, but not both
5. the person who likes raspberry is to the right of the person who likes artichoke (not necessarily immediately)
6. the person who has goat as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes cabbage
7. the person who likes almond-milk is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes iced-tea
8. the person who likes raspberry is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes time-travel movies
9. the person who likes scientific movies is to the right of the person who likes musical movies (not necessarily immediately)
10. the person who has guinea-pig as a pet is to the right of the person who likes scientific movies (not necessarily immediately)
11. the person who likes 7up is to the right of the person who has goat as a pet (not necessarily immediately)
12. the person who likes family movies is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes d&b music
13. the person who likes artichoke is at the same position as or to the left of the person who has fish as a pet
14. the person who has goat as a pet and the person who likes iced-tea are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
15. the person who likes kiwi is to the left of the person who likes artichoke (not necessarily immediately)
16. the person who likes almond-milk is to the right of the person who likes coffee (not necessarily immediately)
17. the person who likes kale is to the left of the person who likes blues music (not necessarily immediately)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Food").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Music", "Food", "Pet", "Beverage", "Movie"]
    items = {
        "Music": ["house", "rock", "pop", "d&b", "blues"],
        "Food": ["cabbage", "kale", "kiwi", "raspberry", "artichoke"],
        "Pet": ["fish", "goat", "guinea-pig", "snake", "ferret"],
        "Beverage": ["coffee", "iced-tea", "almond-milk", "water", "7up"],
        "Movie": ["musical", "time-travel", "thriller", "family", "scientific"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain 0..4 (positions)
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in a category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: snake pet position >= raspberry food position
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda snake, raspberry: snake >= raspberry,
        ["Pet:snake", "Food:raspberry"]
    )

    # Clue 2: kiwi same as water or kiwi same as goat (at least one)
    # Model as a constraint that returns True if kiwi == water or kiwi == goat
    def clue2(kiwi, water, goat):
        return kiwi == water or kiwi == goat
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue2,
        ["Food:kiwi", "Beverage:water", "Pet:goat"]
    )

    # Clue 3: raspberry position <= house music position
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda raspberry, house: raspberry <= house,
        ["Food:raspberry", "Music:house"]
    )

    # Clue 4: family movie same as cabbage or pop music same as family movie, but not both
    # (family == cabbage) xor (pop == family)
    def clue4(family, cabbage, pop):
        return (family == cabbage) != (pop == family)
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue4,
        ["Movie:family", "Food:cabbage", "Music:pop"]
    )

    # Clue 5: raspberry position > artichoke position
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda raspberry, artichoke: raspberry > artichoke,
        ["Food:raspberry", "Food:artichoke"]
    )

    # Clue 6: goat pet position >= cabbage food position
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda goat, cabbage: goat >= cabbage,
        ["Pet:goat", "Food:cabbage"]
    )

    # Clue 7: almond-milk position <= iced-tea position
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda almond, iced: almond <= iced,
        ["Beverage:almond-milk", "Beverage:iced-tea"]
    )

    # Clue 8: raspberry position <= time-travel movie position
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda raspberry, time_travel: raspberry <= time_travel,
        ["Food:raspberry", "Movie:time-travel"]
    )

    # Clue 9: scientific movie position > musical movie position
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda scientific, musical: scientific > musical,
        ["Movie:scientific", "Movie:musical"]
    )

    # Clue 10: guinea-pig pet position > scientific movie position
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda guinea_pig, scientific: guinea_pig > scientific,
        ["Pet:guinea-pig", "Movie:scientific"]
    )

    # Clue 11: 7up position > goat pet position
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda seven_up, goat: seven_up > goat,
        ["Beverage:7up", "Pet:goat"]
    )

    # Clue 12: family movie position <= d&b music position
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda family, dnb: family <= dnb,
        ["Movie:family", "Music:d&b"]
    )

    # Clue 13: artichoke food position <= fish pet position
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda artichoke, fish: artichoke <= fish,
        ["Food:artichoke", "Pet:fish"]
    )

    # Clue 14: goat pet and iced-tea positions have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda goat, iced: (goat % 2) != (iced % 2),
        ["Pet:goat", "Beverage:iced-tea"]
    )

    # Clue 15: kiwi food position < artichoke food position
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda kiwi, artichoke: kiwi < artichoke,
        ["Food:kiwi", "Food:artichoke"]
    )

    # Clue 16: almond-milk position > coffee position
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda almond, coffee: almond > coffee,
        ["Beverage:almond-milk", "Beverage:coffee"]
    )

    # Clue 17: kale food position < blues music position
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda kale, blues: kale < blues,
        ["Food:kale", "Music:blues"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Prepare a list of length 5
        arr = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            arr[pos] = item
        result[category] = arr

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()
