Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes zombie movies is at the same position as or to the left of the person who has hedgehog as a pet
2. the person who has goat as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes jazz music
3. the person who has hedgehog as a pet and the person who likes zombie movies are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
4. the person who has snake as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who works as a electrician
5. the person who likes thriller movies is a different person than the person who likes country music or the person who likes country music is a different person than the person who likes grapes or both
6. the person who likes superhero movies and the person who works as a freelancer are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
7. the person who has dog as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes onion
8. the person who likes lettuce is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes crime movies
9. the person who works as a freelancer and the person who likes salsa music are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
10. the person who likes thriller movies is the same person as exactly one of the person who likes electronic music or the person who has hedgehog as a pet
11. the person who has chinchilla as a pet is the same person as the person who works as a writer or the person who likes crime movies is the same person as the person who has chinchilla as a pet or both
12. the person who likes superhero movies is at the same position as or to the right of the person who has hedgehog as a pet
13. the person who likes superhero movies is somewhere between the person who likes zombie movies and the person who has snake as a pet (not necessarily immediately adjacent)

15. the person who likes techno music and the person who works as a engineer are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
16. the person who works as a freelancer and the person who has dog as a pet are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
17. the person who likes avocado and the person who works as a writer are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
18. the person who has chinchilla as a pet is a different person than at least one of the person who likes lettuce or the person who works as a freelancer
19. the person who likes lettuce is the same person as exactly one of the person who likes comedy movies or the person who has hedgehog as a pet
20. the person who likes jazz music and the person who works as a writer are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
21. the person who has hedgehog as a pet is the same person as at least one of the person who likes country music or the person who likes superhero movies
22. the person who works as a electrician is the same person as at least one of the person who likes onion or the person who has goat as a pet
23. the person who likes lettuce is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes grapes
24. the person who likes techno music is at the same position as or to the left of the person who works as a videographer
25. the person who likes jazz music is a different person than at least one of the person who likes superhero movies or the person who works as a videographer
26. the person who has goat as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes thriller movies
27. the person who likes avocado and the person who has dog as a pet are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
28. the person who likes techno music is the same person as exactly one of the person who likes lettuce or the person who has dog as a pet
29. the person who likes thriller movies is the same person as at least one of the person who works as a engineer or the person who likes lemon
30. the person who has hedgehog as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes electronic music
31. the person who works as a videographer and the person who has dog as a pet are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
32. the person who has goat as a pet and the person who likes onion are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
33. the person who likes techno music is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes lettuce

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Job").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Pet", "Job", "Music", "Movie", "Food"]
    items = {
        "Pet": ["chinchilla", "hedgehog", "goat", "snake", "dog"],
        "Job": ["freelancer", "engineer", "writer", "electrician", "videographer"],
        "Music": ["jazz", "techno", "electronic", "salsa", "country"],
        "Movie": ["thriller", "superhero", "zombie", "comedy", "crime"],
        "Food": ["lemon", "onion", "lettuce", "grapes", "avocado"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Helper functions for constraints
    def same_position_or_left(x, y):
        return x <= y

    def same_position_or_right(x, y):
        return x >= y

    def different_person_or(x, y):
        # x != y or y != z or both
        # modeled as: not (x == y == z)
        # but here we have two variables, so x != y
        return x != y

    def same_parity(x, y):
        return (x % 2) == (y % 2)

    def different_parity(x, y):
        return (x % 2) != (y % 2)

    def exactly_one_equal(a, b, c):
        # Exactly one of (a == b) or (a == c) is true
        return (a == b) != (a == c)

    def at_least_one_equal(a, b, c):
        # At least one of (a == b) or (a == c) is true
        return (a == b) or (a == c)

    def different_person_or_two(x, y, z):
        # x != y or y != z or both
        # means not all three equal
        return not (x == y == z)

    def between(x, y, z):
        # x is somewhere between y and z (not necessarily immediately)
        return (y < x < z) or (z < x < y)

    # Clues:

    # 1. zombie movies <= hedgehog pet
    problem.addConstraint(lambda zombie, hedgehog: zombie <= hedgehog,
                          ["Movie:zombie", "Pet:hedgehog"])

    # 2. goat pet <= jazz music
    problem.addConstraint(lambda goat, jazz: goat <= jazz,
                          ["Pet:goat", "Music:jazz"])

    # 3. hedgehog pet and zombie movies same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda hedgehog, zombie: (hedgehog % 2) == (zombie % 2),
                          ["Pet:hedgehog", "Movie:zombie"])

    # 4. snake pet >= electrician job
    problem.addConstraint(lambda snake, electrician: snake >= electrician,
                          ["Pet:snake", "Job:electrician"])

    # 5. thriller movie different person than country music or country music different person than grapes or both
    # means not (thriller == country == grapes)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda thriller, country, grapes: not (thriller == country == grapes),
                          ["Movie:thriller", "Music:country", "Food:grapes"])

    # 6. superhero movie and freelancer job same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda superhero, freelancer: (superhero % 2) == (freelancer % 2),
                          ["Movie:superhero", "Job:freelancer"])

    # 7. dog pet <= onion food
    problem.addConstraint(lambda dog, onion: dog <= onion,
                          ["Pet:dog", "Food:onion"])

    # 8. lettuce food >= crime movie
    problem.addConstraint(lambda lettuce, crime: lettuce >= crime,
                          ["Food:lettuce", "Movie:crime"])

    # 9. freelancer job and salsa music same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda freelancer, salsa: (freelancer % 2) == (salsa % 2),
                          ["Job:freelancer", "Music:salsa"])

    # 10. thriller movie same person as exactly one of electronic music or hedgehog pet
    problem.addConstraint(lambda thriller, electronic, hedgehog: ((thriller == electronic) != (thriller == hedgehog)),
                          ["Movie:thriller", "Music:electronic", "Pet:hedgehog"])

    # 11. chinchilla pet same person as writer job or crime movie same person as chinchilla pet or both
    # means at least one of (chinchilla==writer) or (crime==chinchilla)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda chinchilla, writer, crime: (chinchilla == writer) or (crime == chinchilla),
                          ["Pet:chinchilla", "Job:writer", "Movie:crime"])

    # 12. superhero movie >= hedgehog pet
    problem.addConstraint(lambda superhero, hedgehog: superhero >= hedgehog,
                          ["Movie:superhero", "Pet:hedgehog"])

    # 13. superhero movie is between zombie movie and snake pet
    problem.addConstraint(lambda superhero, zombie, snake: between(superhero, zombie, snake),
                          ["Movie:superhero", "Movie:zombie", "Pet:snake"])

    # 14. videographer job is between goat pet and electrician job
    problem.addConstraint(lambda videographer, goat, electrician: between(videographer, goat, electrician),
                          ["Job:videographer", "Pet:goat", "Job:electrician"])

    # 15. techno music and engineer job different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda techno, engineer: (techno % 2) != (engineer % 2),
                          ["Music:techno", "Job:engineer"])

    # 16. freelancer job and dog pet same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda freelancer, dog: (freelancer % 2) == (dog % 2),
                          ["Job:freelancer", "Pet:dog"])

    # 17. avocado food and writer job same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda avocado, writer: (avocado % 2) == (writer % 2),
                          ["Food:avocado", "Job:writer"])

    # 18. chinchilla pet different person than at least one of lettuce food or freelancer job
    # means chinchilla != lettuce or chinchilla != freelancer
    problem.addConstraint(lambda chinchilla, lettuce, freelancer: (chinchilla != lettuce) or (chinchilla != freelancer),
                          ["Pet:chinchilla", "Food:lettuce", "Job:freelancer"])

    # 19. lettuce food same person as exactly one of comedy movie or hedgehog pet
    problem.addConstraint(lambda lettuce, comedy, hedgehog: ((lettuce == comedy) != (lettuce == hedgehog)),
                          ["Food:lettuce", "Movie:comedy", "Pet:hedgehog"])

    # 20. jazz music and writer job same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda jazz, writer: (jazz % 2) == (writer % 2),
                          ["Music:jazz", "Job:writer"])

    # 21. hedgehog pet same person as at least one of country music or superhero movie
    problem.addConstraint(lambda hedgehog, country, superhero: (hedgehog == country) or (hedgehog == superhero),
                          ["Pet:hedgehog", "Music:country", "Movie:superhero"])

    # 22. electrician job same person as at least one of onion food or goat pet
    problem.addConstraint(lambda electrician, onion, goat: (electrician == onion) or (electrician == goat),
                          ["Job:electrician", "Food:onion", "Pet:goat"])

    # 23. lettuce food >= grapes food
    problem.addConstraint(lambda lettuce, grapes: lettuce >= grapes,
                          ["Food:lettuce", "Food:grapes"])

    # 24. techno music <= videographer job
    problem.addConstraint(lambda techno, videographer: techno <= videographer,
                          ["Music:techno", "Job:videographer"])

    # 25. jazz music different person than at least one of superhero movie or videographer job
    # means jazz != superhero or jazz != videographer
    problem.addConstraint(lambda jazz, superhero, videographer: (jazz != superhero) or (jazz != videographer),
                          ["Music:jazz", "Movie:superhero", "Job:videographer"])

    # 26. goat pet <= thriller movie
    problem.addConstraint(lambda goat, thriller: goat <= thriller,
                          ["Pet:goat", "Movie:thriller"])

    # 27. avocado food and dog pet different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda avocado, dog: (avocado % 2) != (dog % 2),
                          ["Food:avocado", "Pet:dog"])

    # 28. techno music same person as exactly one of lettuce food or dog pet
    problem.addConstraint(lambda techno, lettuce, dog: ((techno == lettuce) != (techno == dog)),
                          ["Music:techno", "Food:lettuce", "Pet:dog"])

    # 29. thriller movie same person as at least one of engineer job or lemon food
    problem.addConstraint(lambda thriller, engineer, lemon: (thriller == engineer) or (thriller == lemon),
                          ["Movie:thriller", "Job:engineer", "Food:lemon"])

    # 30. hedgehog pet >= electronic music
    problem.addConstraint(lambda hedgehog, electronic: hedgehog >= electronic,
                          ["Pet:hedgehog", "Music:electronic"])

    # 31. videographer job and dog pet same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda videographer, dog: (videographer % 2) == (dog % 2),
                          ["Job:videographer", "Pet:dog"])

    # 32. goat pet and onion food different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda goat, onion: (goat % 2) != (onion % 2),
                          ["Pet:goat", "Food:onion"])

    # 33. techno music >= lettuce food
    problem.addConstraint(lambda techno, lettuce: techno >= lettuce,
                          ["Music:techno", "Food:lettuce"])

    # Solve
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # There should be exactly one solution
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        arr = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            arr[pos] = item
        result[category] = arr

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 2 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Hobby: hiking, drawing, board-games, fishing
2. Transport: subway, bus, scooter, van

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who uses scooter for transportation is immediately to the left of the person who enjoys board-games
2. the person who uses subway for transportation is directly between the person who enjoys drawing and the person who enjoys hiking
3. the person who enjoys fishing is immediately to the right of the person who uses van for transportation
4. the person who uses bus for transportation is adjacent to the person who uses van for transportation (either immediately left or right)
5. the person who enjoys drawing is immediately to the right of the person who uses subway for transportation

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Hobby", "Transport").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Hobby", "Transport"]
    items = {
        "Hobby": ["hiking", "drawing", "board-games", "fishing"],
        "Transport": ["subway", "bus", "scooter", "van"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item with domain 0..3 (positions)
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_vars = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_vars)

    # Clue 1: scooter is immediately to the left of board-games
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda scooter, board_games: scooter == board_games - 1,
        ["Transport:scooter", "Hobby:board-games"]
    )

    # Clue 2: subway is directly between drawing and hiking
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda subway, drawing, hiking: (subway == drawing + 1 and subway == hiking - 1) or (subway == drawing - 1 and subway == hiking + 1),
        ["Transport:subway", "Hobby:drawing", "Hobby:hiking"]
    )

    # Clue 3: fishing is immediately to the right of van
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fishing, van: fishing == van + 1,
        ["Hobby:fishing", "Transport:van"]
    )

    # Clue 4: bus is adjacent to van
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda bus, van: abs(bus - van) == 1,
        ["Transport:bus", "Transport:van"]
    )

    # Clue 5: drawing is immediately to the right of subway
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda drawing, subway: drawing == subway + 1,
        ["Hobby:drawing", "Transport:subway"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Create a list of length num_positions with empty strings
        ordered_items = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            ordered_items[pos] = item
        result_dict[category] = ordered_items

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Movie: musical, action, mystery, scientific, comedy
2. Beverage: almond-milk, fanta, sprite, hot-chocolate, iced-tea
3. Sport: water-polo, handball, surfing, ice-hockey, climbing

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes almond-milk is adjacent to the person who likes iced-tea (either immediately left or right)
2. the person who plays ice-hockey is to the right of the person who likes hot-chocolate (not necessarily immediately)
3. the person who likes musical movies is to the left of the person who likes almond-milk (not necessarily immediately)
4. the person who likes fanta is at an even-numbered position
5. the person who plays surfing is immediately to the right of the person who likes almond-milk
6. the person who plays handball is immediately to the left of the person who likes action movies
7. the person who plays surfing is immediately to the right of the person who plays water-polo
8. the person who likes comedy movies is directly between the person who likes fanta and the person who likes mystery movies
9. the person who likes musical movies is a different person than the person who likes hot-chocolate

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Movie", "Beverage", "Sport"]
    items = {
        "Movie": ["musical", "action", "mystery", "scientific", "comedy"],
        "Beverage": ["almond-milk", "fanta", "sprite", "hot-chocolate", "iced-tea"],
        "Sport": ["water-polo", "handball", "surfing", "ice-hockey", "climbing"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: almond-milk adjacent to iced-tea
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda almond_milk, iced_tea: abs(almond_milk - iced_tea) == 1,
        ["Beverage:almond-milk", "Beverage:iced-tea"]
    )

    # Clue 2: ice-hockey to the right of hot-chocolate (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda ice_hockey, hot_chocolate: ice_hockey > hot_chocolate,
        ["Sport:ice-hockey", "Beverage:hot-chocolate"]
    )

    # Clue 3: musical movies to the left of almond-milk (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda musical, almond_milk: musical < almond_milk,
        ["Movie:musical", "Beverage:almond-milk"]
    )

    # Clue 4: fanta at an even-numbered position (positions are 0-indexed)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda fanta: fanta % 2 == 1,
        ["Beverage:fanta"]
    )

    # Clue 5: surfing immediately to the right of almond-milk
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda surfing, almond_milk: surfing == almond_milk + 1,
        ["Sport:surfing", "Beverage:almond-milk"]
    )

    # Clue 6: handball immediately to the left of action movies
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda handball, action: handball == action - 1,
        ["Sport:handball", "Movie:action"]
    )

    # Clue 7: surfing immediately to the right of water-polo
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda surfing, water_polo: surfing == water_polo + 1,
        ["Sport:surfing", "Sport:water-polo"]
    )

    # Clue 8: comedy movies directly between fanta and mystery movies
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda comedy, fanta, mystery: (comedy == fanta + 1 and comedy == mystery - 1) or (comedy == mystery + 1 and comedy == fanta - 1),
        ["Movie:comedy", "Beverage:fanta", "Movie:mystery"]
    )

    # Clue 9: musical movies different person than hot-chocolate
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda musical, hot_chocolate: musical != hot_chocolate,
        ["Movie:musical", "Beverage:hot-chocolate"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

48. the argentine person and the person who likes broccoli are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)

Your solution should be a dictionary where:

rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Beverage", "Pet", "Transport", "Food", "Nationality"]
    items = {
        "Beverage": ["tea", "mirinda", "lemonade", "juice", "soy-milk"],
        "Pet": ["rat", "ferret", "bird", "goat", "turtle"],
        "Transport": ["helicopter", "bus", "trike", "car", "roller"],
        "Food": ["apricot", "grapes", "avocado", "peach", "broccoli"],
        "Nationality": ["indonesian", "dutch", "nigerian", "australian", "argentine"]
    }

    # Add variables for each item
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(),
                              [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: the indonesian person and the person who has goat as a pet are at positions with the same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda indonesian, goat: indonesian % 2 == goat % 2,
                          ["Nationality:indonesian", "Pet:goat"])

    # Clue 2: the person who uses trike and the person who likes broccoli are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda trike, broccoli: trike % 2 != broccoli % 2,
                          ["Transport:trike", "Food:broccoli"])

    # Clue 3: the person who likes peach and the person who uses helicopter are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda peach, helicopter: peach % 2 != helicopter % 2,
                          ["Food:peach", "Transport:helicopter"])

    # Clue 4: the person who likes grapes is a different person than the person who uses helicopter or the person who likes juice is a different person than the person who likes grapes or both
    # This is equivalent to: not (grapes==helicopter and juice==grapes)
    def clue4(grapes, helicopter, juice):
        return not (grapes == helicopter and juice == grapes)
    problem.addConstraint(clue4,
                          ["Food:grapes", "Transport:helicopter", "Beverage:juice"])

    # Clue 5: the person who likes juice is a different person than the person who has bird as a pet
    problem.addConstraint(lambda juice, bird: juice != bird,
                          ["Beverage:juice", "Pet:bird"])

    # Clue 6: the person who likes juice is a different person than the person who likes avocado or the person who likes avocado is a different person than the person who has rat as a pet or both
    # Equivalent to: not (juice == avocado == rat)
    def clue6(juice, avocado, rat):
        return not (juice == avocado and avocado == rat)
    problem.addConstraint(clue6,
                          ["Beverage:juice", "Food:avocado", "Pet:rat"])

    # Clue 7: the person who has ferret as a pet is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses roller
    problem.addConstraint(lambda ferret, roller: ferret >= roller,
                          ["Pet:ferret", "Transport:roller"])

    # Clue 8: the person who has goat as a pet is a different person than the nigerian or the nigerian is a different person than the person who uses bus or both
    # Equivalent to: not (goat == nigerian == bus)
    def clue8(goat, nigerian, bus):
        return not (goat == nigerian and nigerian == bus)
    problem.addConstraint(clue8,
                          ["Pet:goat", "Nationality:nigerian", "Transport:bus"])

    # Clue 9: the person who likes peach is the same person as exactly one of the person who uses car or the person who likes mirinda
    # Exactly one means XOR: (peach==car) != (peach==mirinda)
    def clue9(peach, car, mirinda):
        return (peach == car) != (peach == mirinda)
    problem.addConstraint(clue9,
                          ["Food:peach", "Transport:car", "Beverage:mirinda"])

    # Clue 10: the person who likes grapes is a different person than the person who uses helicopter
    problem.addConstraint(lambda grapes, helicopter: grapes != helicopter,
                          ["Food:grapes", "Transport:helicopter"])

    # Clue 11: the person who has rat as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes peach
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rat, peach: rat <= peach,
                          ["Pet:rat", "Food:peach"])

    # Clue 12: the person who uses car is a different person than the person who likes tea or the person who has rat is a different person than the person who uses car or both
    # Equivalent to: not (car == tea == rat)
    def clue12(car, tea, rat):
        return not (car == tea and tea == rat)
    problem.addConstraint(clue12,
                          ["Transport:car", "Beverage:tea", "Pet:rat"])

    # Clue 13: the australian person is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes peach
    problem.addConstraint(lambda australian, peach: australian >= peach,
                          ["Nationality:australian", "Food:peach"])

    # Clue 14: the person who uses helicopter is a different person than at least one of the person who likes peach or the person who has bird as a pet
    # Equivalent to: not (helicopter == peach == bird)
    def clue14(helicopter, peach, bird):
        return not (helicopter == peach and peach == bird)
    problem.addConstraint(clue14,
                          ["Transport:helicopter", "Food:peach", "Pet:bird"])

    # Clue 15: the indonesian person and the person who likes broccoli are at positions with the same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda indonesian, broccoli: indonesian % 2 == broccoli % 2,
                          ["Nationality:indonesian", "Food:broccoli"])

    # Clue 16: the indonesian person is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes tea
    problem.addConstraint(lambda indonesian, tea: indonesian >= tea,
                          ["Nationality:indonesian", "Beverage:tea"])

    # Clue 17: the person who has turtle as a pet is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes broccoli
    problem.addConstraint(lambda turtle, broccoli: turtle <= broccoli,
                          ["Pet:turtle", "Food:broccoli"])

    # Clue 18: the person who uses trike is a different person than the person who likes peach
    problem.addConstraint(lambda trike, peach: trike != peach,
                          ["Transport:trike", "Food:peach"])

    # Clue 19: the dutch person is a different person than the person who likes peach
    problem.addConstraint(lambda dutch, peach: dutch != peach,
                          ["Nationality:dutch", "Food:peach"])

    # Clue 20: the person who has rat as a pet and the person who likes apricot are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda rat, apricot: rat % 2 != apricot % 2,
                          ["Pet:rat", "Food:apricot"])

    # Clue 21: the person who likes mirinda is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes lemonade
    problem.addConstraint(lambda mirinda, lemonade: mirinda <= lemonade,
                          ["Beverage:mirinda", "Beverage:lemonade"])

    # Clue 22: the person who likes juice is at the same position as or to the left of the person who has rat as a pet
    problem.addConstraint(lambda juice, rat: juice <= rat,
                          ["Beverage:juice", "Pet:rat"])

    # Clue 23: the australian person is the same person as at least one of the person who likes apricot or the person who likes lemonade
    # Equivalent to: (australian == apricot) or (australian == lemonade)
    def clue23(australian, apricot, lemonade):
        return australian == apricot or australian == lemonade
    problem.addConstraint(clue23,
                          ["Nationality:australian", "Food:apricot", "Beverage:lemonade"])

    # Clue 24: the person who likes tea is at the same position as or to the right of the person who has turtle as a pet
    problem.addConstraint(lambda tea, turtle: tea >= turtle,
                          ["Beverage:tea", "Pet:turtle"])

    # Clue 25: the person who likes tea and the person who likes grapes are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda tea, grapes: tea % 2 != grapes % 2,
                          ["Beverage:tea", "Food:grapes"])

    # Clue 26: the person who likes grapes is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes broccoli
    problem.addConstraint(lambda grapes, broccoli: grapes <= broccoli,
                          ["Food:grapes", "Food:broccoli"])

    # Clue 27: the person who has turtle as a pet is a different person than the dutch person
    problem.addConstraint(lambda turtle, dutch: turtle != dutch,
                          ["Pet:turtle", "Nationality:dutch"])

    # Clue 28: the dutch person is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses helicopter
    problem.addConstraint(lambda dutch, helicopter: dutch >= helicopter,
                          ["Nationality:dutch", "Transport:helicopter"])

    # Clue 29: the person who has goat as a pet and the person who likes broccoli are at positions with the same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda goat, broccoli: goat % 2 == broccoli % 2,
                          ["Pet:goat", "Food:broccoli"])

    # Clue 30: the person who likes broccoli is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes grapes
    problem.addConstraint(lambda broccoli, grapes: broccoli >= grapes,
                          ["Food:broccoli", "Food:grapes"])

    # Clue 31: the person who likes broccoli and the person who has ferret as a pet are at positions with the same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda broccoli, ferret: broccoli % 2 == ferret % 2,
                          ["Food:broccoli", "Pet:ferret"])

    # Clue 32: the australian person is the same person as the person who likes tea or the person who uses car is the same person as the australian person or both
    # Equivalent to: (australian == tea) or (car == australian)
    def clue32(australian, tea, car):
        return australian == tea or car == australian
    problem.addConstraint(clue32,
                          ["Nationality:australian", "Beverage:tea", "Transport:car"])

    # Clue 33: the person who uses roller is the same person as the person who has bird as a pet or the indonesian is the same person as the person who uses roller or both
    # Equivalent to: (roller == bird) or (indonesian == roller)
    def clue33(roller, bird, indonesian):
        return roller == bird or indonesian == roller
    problem.addConstraint(clue33,
                          ["Transport:roller", "Pet:bird", "Nationality:indonesian"])

    # Clue 34: the person who has goat as a pet and the person who uses helicopter are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda goat, helicopter: goat % 2 != helicopter % 2,
                          ["Pet:goat", "Transport:helicopter"])

    # Clue 35: the person who likes mirinda and the person who likes peach are at positions with the same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda mirinda, peach: mirinda % 2 == peach % 2,
                          ["Beverage:mirinda", "Food:peach"])

    # Clue 36: the person who likes grapes is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes mirinda
    problem.addConstraint(lambda grapes, mirinda: grapes >= mirinda,
                          ["Food:grapes", "Beverage:mirinda"])

    # Clue 37: the person who likes apricot is a different person than the person who has rat as a pet or the person who has rat as a pet is a different person than the australian or both
    # Equivalent to: not (apricot == rat == australian)
    def clue37(apricot, rat, australian):
        return not (apricot == rat and rat == australian)
    problem.addConstraint(clue37,
                          ["Food:apricot", "Pet:rat", "Nationality:australian"])

    # Clue 38: the australian and the person who likes apricot are at positions with the same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda australian, apricot: australian % 2 == apricot % 2,
                          ["Nationality:australian", "Food:apricot"])

    # Clue 39: the australian person is a different person than the person who has ferret as a pet
    problem.addConstraint(lambda australian, ferret: australian != ferret,
                          ["Nationality:australian", "Pet:ferret"])

    # Clue 40: the indonesian person is a different person than the person who uses helicopter
    problem.addConstraint(lambda indonesian, helicopter: indonesian != helicopter,
                          ["Nationality:indonesian", "Transport:helicopter"])

    # Clue 41: the person who likes soy-milk is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes apricot
    problem.addConstraint(lambda soy_milk, apricot: soy_milk >= apricot,
                          ["Beverage:soy-milk", "Food:apricot"])

    # Clue 42: the person who likes juice is somewhere between the person who likes avocado and the person who likes soy-milk (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
    # So juice position is strictly between avocado and soy-milk or equal to one of them?
    # The clue says "somewhere between" so juice is between avocado and soy-milk inclusive?
    # We'll assume juice is strictly between avocado and soy-milk (not equal)
    def clue42(juice, avocado, soy_milk):
        return (avocado < juice < soy_milk) or (soy_milk < juice < avocado)
    problem.addConstraint(clue42,
                          ["Beverage:juice", "Food:avocado", "Beverage:soy-milk"])

    # Clue 43: the person who likes grapes is a different person than the person who has rat or the person who has rat is a different person than the person who likes juice or both
    # Equivalent to: not (grapes == rat == juice)
    def clue43(grapes, rat, juice):
        return not (grapes == rat and rat == juice)
    problem.addConstraint(clue43,
                          ["Food:grapes", "Pet:rat", "Beverage:juice"])

    # Clue 44: the person who uses bus is a different person than the person who has ferret or the person who likes avocado is a different person than the person who uses bus or both
    # Equivalent to: not (bus == ferret == avocado)
    def clue44(bus, ferret, avocado):
        return not (bus == ferret and ferret == avocado)
    problem.addConstraint(clue44,
                          ["Transport:bus", "Pet:ferret", "Food:avocado"])

    # Clue 45: the person who uses trike is a different person than at least one of the person who likes broccoli or the australian
    # Equivalent to: not (trike == broccoli == australian)
    def clue45(trike, broccoli, australian):
        return not (trike == broccoli and broccoli == australian)
    problem.addConstraint(clue45,
                          ["Transport:trike", "Food:broccoli", "Nationality:australian"])

    # Clue 46: the person who uses helicopter is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes tea
    problem.addConstraint(lambda helicopter, tea: helicopter <= tea,
                          ["Transport:helicopter", "Beverage:tea"])

    # Clue 47: the person who likes apricot is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses trike
    problem.addConstraint(lambda apricot, trike: apricot >= trike,
                          ["Food:apricot", "Transport:trike"])

    # Clue 48: the argentine person and the person who likes broccoli are at positions with the same parity
    problem.addConstraint(lambda argentine, broccoli: argentine % 2 == broccoli % 2,
                          ["Nationality:argentine", "Food:broccoli"])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # In case multiple solutions found, we still print one
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        arr = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            arr[pos] = item
        result[category] = arr

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 3 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 2 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 3 unique items:

1. Food: banana, papaya, pomegranate
2. Hobby: singing, filmmaking, reading

Each category has exactly 3 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes pomegranate is at position 1 (the leftmost position)
2. the person who enjoys singing is at position 1 (the leftmost position)
3. the person who likes papaya is directly between the person who enjoys reading and the person who enjoys singing

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Food", "Hobby").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 3).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 3

    categories = ["Food", "Hobby"]
    items = {
        "Food": ["banana", "papaya", "pomegranate"],
        "Hobby": ["singing", "filmmaking", "reading"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_items = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_items)

    # Clue 1: pomegranate is at position 1 (index 0)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda pomegranate: pomegranate == 0, ["Food:pomegranate"])

    # Clue 2: singing is at position 1 (index 0)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda singing: singing == 0, ["Hobby:singing"])

    # Clue 3: papaya is directly between reading and singing
    # That means papaya's position is between reading and singing's positions
    # Since singing is at position 0, papaya must be at position 1, reading at position 2
    # But let's model it generally:
    # papaya is directly between reading and singing means:
    # papaya == reading +1 and papaya == singing -1
    # or papaya == reading -1 and papaya == singing +1
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda papaya, reading, singing: (papaya == reading + 1 and papaya == singing - 1) or (papaya == reading -1 and papaya == singing +1),
        ["Food:papaya", "Hobby:reading", "Hobby:singing"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    # There should be exactly one solution
    solution = solutions[0]

    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        items_in_order = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            items_in_order[pos] = item
        result[category] = items_in_order

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Nationality: indian, pakistani, american, thai
2. Sport: cricket, surfing, weightlifting, badminton
3. Movie: zombie, satire, horror, scientific
4. Job: entrepreneur, doctor, engineer, manager

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who plays cricket is somewhere between the american person and the person who works as a manager (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
2. the thai person is to the right of the person who likes satire movies (not necessarily immediately)
3. the person who works as a engineer is immediately to the left of the person who likes zombie movies
4. the person who works as a entrepreneur is the same person as the person who plays surfing
5. the american person is immediately to the right of the person who likes horror movies
6. the person who plays cricket is immediately to the left of the pakistani person
7. the person who likes horror movies is to the right of the person who plays cricket (not necessarily immediately)
8. the person who works as a doctor is immediately to the right of the person who plays badminton

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Job", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Nationality", "Sport", "Movie", "Job"]
    items = {
        "Nationality": ["indian", "pakistani", "american", "thai"],
        "Sport": ["cricket", "surfing", "weightlifting", "badminton"],
        "Movie": ["zombie", "satire", "horror", "scientific"],
        "Job": ["entrepreneur", "doctor", "engineer", "manager"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must occupy different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clues:

    # 1. the person who plays cricket is somewhere between the american person and the person who works as a manager (not necessarily immediately)
    # cricket is between american and manager: cricket > min(american, manager) and cricket < max(american, manager)
    def cricket_between_american_manager(cricket, american, manager):
        return (american < cricket < manager) or (manager < cricket < american)
    problem.addConstraint(cricket_between_american_manager,
                          ["Sport:cricket", "Nationality:american", "Job:manager"])

    # 2. the thai person is to the right of the person who likes satire movies (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda thai, satire: thai > satire,
                          ["Nationality:thai", "Movie:satire"])

    # 3. the person who works as a engineer is immediately to the left of the person who likes zombie movies
    problem.addConstraint(lambda engineer, zombie: engineer == zombie - 1,
                          ["Job:engineer", "Movie:zombie"])

    # 4. the person who works as a entrepreneur is the same person as the person who plays surfing
    problem.addConstraint(lambda entrepreneur, surfing: entrepreneur == surfing,
                          ["Job:entrepreneur", "Sport:surfing"])

    # 5. the american person is immediately to the right of the person who likes horror movies
    problem.addConstraint(lambda american, horror: american == horror + 1,
                          ["Nationality:american", "Movie:horror"])

    # 6. the person who plays cricket is immediately to the left of the pakistani person
    problem.addConstraint(lambda cricket, pakistani: cricket == pakistani - 1,
                          ["Sport:cricket", "Nationality:pakistani"])

    # 7. the person who likes horror movies is to the right of the person who plays cricket (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(lambda horror, cricket: horror > cricket,
                          ["Movie:horror", "Sport:cricket"])

    # 8. the person who works as a doctor is immediately to the right of the person who plays badminton
    problem.addConstraint(lambda doctor, badminton: doctor == badminton + 1,
                          ["Job:doctor", "Sport:badminton"])

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # Just take the first solution if multiple
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    # Format the solution as requested
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        result[category] = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            result[category][pos] = item

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 5 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Beverage: almond-milk, coffee, cola, sprite
2. Sport: skateboarding, sailing, rugby, basketball
3. Pet: hedgehog, chinchilla, rat, mouse
4. Music: reggae, jazz, blues, rock
5. Hobby: photography, baking, singing, filmmaking

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes coffee is at the same position as or to the left of the person who enjoys filmmaking
2. the person who likes cola is somewhere between the person who likes coffee and the person who likes rock music (not necessarily immediately adjacent)
3. the person who likes jazz music is at the same position as or to the right of the person who enjoys singing
4. the person who has mouse as a pet is the same person as at least one of the person who likes rock music or the person who plays basketball
5. the person who likes almond-milk is immediately to the left of the person who plays basketball
6. the person who likes sprite and the person who plays rugby are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
7. 0 is at position 4
8. the person who likes reggae music is adjacent to the person who likes rock music (either immediately left or right)
9. the person who likes blues music is immediately to the right of the person who has chinchilla as a pet
10. the person who enjoys baking is immediately to the right of the person who plays skateboarding
11. the person who plays basketball is the same person as the person who has mouse as a pet or the person who enjoys filmmaking is the same person as the person who plays basketball, but not both
12. the person who likes cola and the person who has mouse as a pet are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
13. the person who plays sailing is immediately to the right of the person who has rat as a pet
14. the person who plays skateboarding is to the left of the person who plays rugby (not necessarily immediately)

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Beverage", "Hobby").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Beverage", "Sport", "Pet", "Music", "Hobby"]
    items = {
        "Beverage": ["almond-milk", "coffee", "cola", "sprite"],
        "Sport": ["skateboarding", "sailing", "rugby", "basketball"],
        "Pet": ["hedgehog", "chinchilla", "rat", "mouse"],
        "Music": ["reggae", "jazz", "blues", "rock"],
        "Hobby": ["photography", "baking", "singing", "filmmaking"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            problem.addVariable(f"{category}:{item}", range(num_positions))

    # All items in same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(),
                              [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]])

    # Clue 1: coffee <= filmmaking
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda coffee, filmmaking: coffee <= filmmaking,
        ["Beverage:coffee", "Hobby:filmmaking"]
    )

    # Clue 2: cola is between coffee and rock (not necessarily adjacent)
    # So coffee < cola < rock or rock < cola < coffee
    def cola_between(coffee, cola, rock):
        return (coffee < cola < rock) or (rock < cola < coffee)
    problem.addConstraint(
        cola_between,
        ["Beverage:coffee", "Beverage:cola", "Music:rock"]
    )

    # Clue 3: jazz >= singing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda jazz, singing: jazz >= singing,
        ["Music:jazz", "Hobby:singing"]
    )

    # Clue 4: mouse is same person as rock or basketball
    # mouse == rock or mouse == basketball
    def mouse_rock_basketball(mouse, rock, basketball):
        return mouse == rock or mouse == basketball
    problem.addConstraint(
        mouse_rock_basketball,
        ["Pet:mouse", "Music:rock", "Sport:basketball"]
    )

    # Clue 5: almond-milk immediately left of basketball
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda almond_milk, basketball: almond_milk == basketball - 1,
        ["Beverage:almond-milk", "Sport:basketball"]
    )

    # Clue 6: sprite and rugby positions have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda sprite, rugby: (sprite % 2) != (rugby % 2),
        ["Beverage:sprite", "Sport:rugby"]
    )

    # Clue 7: 0 is at position 4
    # This clue is ambiguous as '0' is not defined in categories or items.
    # We will interpret it as position 4 (index 3) is assigned to some attribute.
    # Since no further info, we skip this clue.

    # Clue 8: reggae adjacent to rock (immediately left or right)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda reggae, rock: abs(reggae - rock) == 1,
        ["Music:reggae", "Music:rock"]
    )

    # Clue 9: blues immediately right of chinchilla
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda blues, chinchilla: blues == chinchilla + 1,
        ["Music:blues", "Pet:chinchilla"]
    )

    # Clue 10: baking immediately right of skateboarding
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda baking, skateboarding: baking == skateboarding + 1,
        ["Hobby:baking", "Sport:skateboarding"]
    )

    # Clue 11: basketball == mouse XOR filmmaking == basketball
    # Exactly one of these is true
    def xor_constraint(basketball, mouse, filmmaking):
        cond1 = basketball == mouse
        cond2 = filmmaking == basketball
        return cond1 != cond2
    problem.addConstraint(
        xor_constraint,
        ["Sport:basketball", "Pet:mouse", "Hobby:filmmaking"]
    )

    # Clue 12: cola and mouse same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda cola, mouse: (cola % 2) == (mouse % 2),
        ["Beverage:cola", "Pet:mouse"]
    )

    # Clue 13: sailing immediately right of rat
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda sailing, rat: sailing == rat + 1,
        ["Sport:sailing", "Pet:rat"]
    )

    # Clue 14: skateboarding to the left of rugby (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda skateboarding, rugby: skateboarding < rugby,
        ["Sport:skateboarding", "Sport:rugby"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        # Choose the first solution if multiple exist
        solution = solutions[0]
    else:
        solution = solutions[0]

    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        # Prepare list of 4 empty strings
        ordered_items = [""] * num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            ordered_items[pos] = item
        result[category] = ordered_items

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 4 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 4 unique items:

1. Hobby: cooking, dancing, magic-tricks, chess
2. Movie: horror, mystery, crime, comedy
3. Nationality: german, argentine, chinese, american

Each category has exactly 4 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who likes horror movies is directly between the person who enjoys cooking and the person who enjoys magic-tricks
2. the person who likes comedy movies is immediately to the right of the person who likes mystery movies
3. the person who likes horror movies is immediately to the left of the person who likes crime movies
4. the person who likes crime movies is adjacent to the person who enjoys dancing (either immediately left or right)
5. the chinese person is the same person as the person who enjoys cooking
6. the argentine person is directly between the person who likes horror movies and the german person

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Hobby", "Movie").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 4).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 4

    categories = ["Hobby", "Movie", "Nationality"]
    items = {
        "Hobby": ["cooking", "dancing", "magic-tricks", "chess"],
        "Movie": ["horror", "mystery", "crime", "comedy"],
        "Nationality": ["german", "argentine", "chinese", "american"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(var, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: horror is directly between cooking and magic-tricks
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda horror, cooking, magic: (horror == cooking + 1 and horror == magic - 1) or (horror == magic + 1 and horror == cooking - 1),
        ["Movie:horror", "Hobby:cooking", "Hobby:magic-tricks"]
    )

    # Clue 2: comedy is immediately to the right of mystery
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda comedy, mystery: comedy == mystery + 1,
        ["Movie:comedy", "Movie:mystery"]
    )

    # Clue 3: horror is immediately to the left of crime
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda horror, crime: horror == crime - 1,
        ["Movie:horror", "Movie:crime"]
    )

    # Clue 4: crime is adjacent to dancing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda crime, dancing: abs(crime - dancing) == 1,
        ["Movie:crime", "Hobby:dancing"]
    )

    # Clue 5: chinese is the same person as cooking
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda chinese, cooking: chinese == cooking,
        ["Nationality:chinese", "Hobby:cooking"]
    )

    # Clue 6: argentine is directly between horror and german
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda argentine, horror, german: (argentine == horror + 1 and argentine == german - 1) or (argentine == german + 1 and argentine == horror - 1),
        ["Nationality:argentine", "Movie:horror", "Nationality:german"]
    )

    # Solve
    solutions = problem.getSolutions()
    if not solutions:
        return None
    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    # Format output dictionary
    result = {}
    for category in categories:
        arr = [None]*num_positions
        for item in items[category]:
            pos = solution[f"{category}:{item}"]
            arr[pos] = item
        result[category] = arr

    print(result)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

question:
You are given an Einstein logic puzzle. In this puzzle, there are 5 people living in the same community. Each person has exactly one attribute from each of 3 different categories (like nationality, pet, drink, etc.). No two people share the same attribute from any category. Your task is to determine which attributes belong to which person based on the given clues. The clues describe relationships between people and their attributes. For example 'the person with the red house is immediately to the left of the person who drinks coffee'. By logically combining all clues, you should be able to determine the complete solution.

Setup:

The puzzle involves the following categories, each with 5 unique items:

1. Job: coach, scientist, dancer, videographer, lawyer
2. Music: jazz, blues, ambient, salsa, trance
3. Sport: sailing, parkour, cycling, golf, skiing

Each category has exactly 5 items, and no item repeats within a category.

Clues:

1. the person who works as a coach and the person who likes jazz music are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
2. the person who likes salsa music is at position 1 (the leftmost position)
3. the person who plays golf is to the right of the person who likes ambient music (not necessarily immediately)
4. the person who works as a coach is to the right of the person who works as a dancer (not necessarily immediately)
5. the person who plays golf and the person who likes trance music are at positions with the same parity (both at odd or both at even positions)
6. the person who works as a coach is a different person than the person who likes trance music
7. the person who works as a lawyer is at the same position as or to the left of the person who plays parkour
8. the person who works as a videographer is the same person as the person who plays skiing
9. the person who works as a lawyer and the person who plays golf are at positions with different parity (one at odd, one at even position)
10. the person who works as a dancer is to the left of the person who plays cycling (not necessarily immediately)
11. the person who works as a coach is directly between the person who works as a lawyer and the person who likes salsa music

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:
- Each key is a category name (e.g., "Job", "Music").
- Each value is a list of items, ordered by position from left to right (position 1 to position 5).
- Each item in a category must appear exactly once.
rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Job", "Music", "Sport"]
    items = {
        "Job": ["coach", "scientist", "dancer", "videographer", "lawyer"],
        "Music": ["jazz", "blues", "ambient", "salsa", "trance"],
        "Sport": ["sailing", "parkour", "cycling", "golf", "skiing"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must be at different positions
    for category in categories:
        vars_in_cat = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), vars_in_cat)

    # Clue 1: coach and jazz have same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda coach, jazz: coach % 2 == jazz % 2,
        ["Job:coach", "Music:jazz"]
    )

    # Clue 2: salsa is at position 1 (0-indexed 0)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda salsa: salsa == 0,
        ["Music:salsa"]
    )

    # Clue 3: golf is to the right of ambient (golf > ambient)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda golf, ambient: golf > ambient,
        ["Sport:golf", "Music:ambient"]
    )

    # Clue 4: coach is to the right of dancer (coach > dancer)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda coach, dancer: coach > dancer,
        ["Job:coach", "Job:dancer"]
    )

    # Clue 5: golf and trance have same parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda golf, trance: golf % 2 == trance % 2,
        ["Sport:golf", "Music:trance"]
    )

    # Clue 6: coach and trance are different persons (positions)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda coach, trance: coach != trance,
        ["Job:coach", "Music:trance"]
    )

    # Clue 7: lawyer is at same or left of parkour (lawyer <= parkour)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lawyer, parkour: lawyer <= parkour,
        ["Job:lawyer", "Sport:parkour"]
    )

    # Clue 8: videographer is same as skiing
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda videographer, skiing: videographer == skiing,
        ["Job:videographer", "Sport:skiing"]
    )

    # Clue 9: lawyer and golf have different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda lawyer, golf: (lawyer % 2) != (golf % 2),
        ["Job:lawyer", "Sport:golf"]
    )

    # Clue 10: dancer is to the left of cycling (dancer < cycling)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda dancer, cycling: dancer < cycling,
        ["Job:dancer", "Sport:cycling"]
    )

    # Clue 11: coach is directly between lawyer and salsa
    # That means coach is at position x, lawyer and salsa at positions x-1 and x+1 in some order
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda coach, lawyer, salsa: (coach == lawyer + 1 and coach == salsa - 1) or (coach == salsa + 1 and coach == lawyer - 1),
        ["Job:coach", "Job:lawyer", "Music:salsa"]
    )

    solutions = problem.getSolutions()

    if not solutions:
        return None

    if len(solutions) > 1:
        raise ValueError("Multiple solutions found")

    solution = solutions[0]

    result_dict = {}
    for category in categories:
        result_dict[category] = [""] * num_positions

    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            var = f"{category}:{item}"
            pos = solution[var]
            result_dict[category][pos] = item

    print(result_dict)

solve_einstein_puzzle()

Expected Output Format:

Your solution should be a dictionary where:

rationale:
from constraint import Problem, AllDifferentConstraint

def solve_einstein_puzzle():
    problem = Problem()
    num_positions = 5

    categories = ["Nationality", "Food", "Music", "Transport", "Sport"]
    items = {
        "Nationality": ["mexican", "indonesian", "brazilian", "spanish", "colombian"],
        "Food": ["radish", "pomegranate", "pear", "garlic", "artichoke"],
        "Music": ["jazz", "hip-hop", "classical", "pop", "dubstep"],
        "Transport": ["car", "airplane", "motorbike", "scooter", "taxi"],
        "Sport": ["badminton", "water-polo", "cricket", "climbing", "ice-hockey"]
    }

    # Add variables
    for category in categories:
        for item in items[category]:
            variable_name = f"{category}:{item}"
            problem.addVariable(variable_name, range(num_positions))

    # All items in the same category must have different positions
    for category in categories:
        category_items = [f"{category}:{item}" for item in items[category]]
        problem.addConstraint(AllDifferentConstraint(), category_items)

    # Clue 1: the colombian person is at the same position as or to the left of the indonesian person
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda colombian, indonesian: colombian <= indonesian,
        ["Nationality:colombian", "Nationality:indonesian"]
    )

    # Clue 2: the mexican person is at the same position as or to the right of the person who likes garlic
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda mexican, garlic: mexican >= garlic,
        ["Nationality:mexican", "Food:garlic"]
    )

    # Clue 3: the person who uses scooter for transportation and the spanish person are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda scooter, spanish: scooter % 2 != spanish % 2,
        ["Transport:scooter", "Nationality:spanish"]
    )

    # Clue 4: the person who plays ice-hockey is at the same position as or to the right of the person who plays water-polo
    problem.addConstraint(

    def clue5(taxi, indonesian, pear):

    problem.addConstraint(

    problem.addConstraint(

    # Clue 9: the person who likes pomegranate and the person who uses taxi for transportation are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(

    problem.addConstraint(

    def clue11(pop, water_polo, taxi):

    problem.addConstraint(
        clue11,
        ["Music:pop", "Sport:water-polo", "Transport:taxi"]
    )

    # Clue 12: the person who likes hip-hop music is to the left of the person who uses scooter for transportation (not necessarily immediately)
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda hip_hop, scooter: hip_hop < scooter,
        ["Music:hip-hop", "Transport:scooter"]
    )

    # Clue 13: the person who uses taxi for transportation is a different person than the person who likes hip-hop music
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda taxi, hip_hop: taxi != hip_hop,
        ["Transport:taxi", "Music:hip-hop"]
    )

    # Clue 14: the person who likes garlic is the same person as at least one of the person who uses motorbike for transportation or the brazilian person
    def clue14(garlic, motorbike, brazilian):

    )

    # Clue 15: the person who likes pomegranate is the same person as the indonesian person or the person who uses car for transportation is the same person as the person who likes pomegranate, but not both
    def clue15(pomegranate, indonesian, car):

        same_car_pomegranate = car == pomegranate
        return same_pomegranate_indonesian != same_car_pomegranate
    problem.addConstraint(
        clue15,
        ["Food:pomegranate", "Nationality:indonesian", "Transport:car"]
    )

    # Clue 16: the person who uses airplane for transportation is at the same position as or to the right of the person who uses scooter for transportation
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda airplane, scooter: airplane >= scooter,
        ["Transport:airplane", "Transport:scooter"]
    )

    # Clue 17: the person who plays badminton and the person who uses car for transportation are at positions with different parity
    problem.addConstraint(
        lambda badminton, car: badminton % 2 != car % 2,
        ["Sport:badminton", "Transport:car"]
    )

    # Clue 18: the person who likes pop music is at the same position as or to the left of the person who likes dubstep music
    problem.addConstraint(

    problem.addConstraint(
